Manipulating Life.name: Manipulating Life
Manipulating Life.text:
Chapter 5:
Apothecary Abominations

Manipulating Life

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.110imgipulatingl inline]

“That creature just stabbed me with a needle full of green! The only terrible green thing I put in my body is salad. Classic apothecaries and their weird experiments and torsos chained to walls, there's no way those working conditions are viable. They are just trying to scare some would-be adventurer. I, the great Pluto Jackson, do not fear torsos. I have the greatest torso of all! My torso is carved from the relentless pursuit of perfection and red meat.”

—Pluto Jackson

T hrough Through occult science and eldritch magic, apothecaries manipulate life and death itself. Most use their skills to cure ailments, mend injuries, and save lives. Superstition and rumors abound regarding their practice and abilities, these healers and doctors are often well-regarded within their communities. Experience and curiosity inspire apothecaries to experiment, seeking out new knowledge and advanced techniques.

Well-intentioned exploration turns to dark practice when an apothecary discovers that the same magic that repairs the body can also reanimate dead flesh, transmogrify muscle and bone, animate inorganic matter, manipulate the mind, and even create new life. It begins in small ways: the apothecary offers an experimental concoction made from dangerous materials to a desperate patient, or transplants body parts harvested from the dead to save a grievously wounded friend. Perhaps next they attempt to reanimate a beloved pet, create a laboratory assistant from mud and chemicals, or use a new technique to gently dissuade local authorities from investigating their laboratories. Most stop there, content to close the book on their occult discoveries and return to more humble and reliable methods. However, unforeseen circumstances or boundless ambition drive a rare few to take these studies even further; to push the boundaries of science and magic with no regard for ethics, morals, or safety.

Tragically, though the vast majority of apothecaries harness science to aid others, heal the sick, and change the world for the better, a rare few among them become villains who unleash nightmares from their laboratores. These monsters perpetuate a vicious cycle when their masters send them out into the world to collect body parts and unwitting victims for use in further experimentation. Even after their creators are brought to justice, the horrors they created remain hiding in the dark corners of villages, in underground lairs beneath cities, or in secret and forgotten laboratories.

The twisted and unusual abominations crafted by the minds of apothecaries who have thrown away morals in exchange for scientific advancement are becoming an unfortunate byproduct of their avenues of study. These monster maker's vile experiments have unleashed a new generation of wicked creations upon the world. Tales spread around campfires and amongst children that tell of the things that go bump in the night: stitched-together corpses, their limbs replaced with medical instruments; grave-robbing body-snatchers stealing away in the dead of night; strange monstrosities lurking in the shadows seeking fresh victims; and patients who got more than they bargained for in a desperate plea for help.

What is an Apothecary?

The apothecary is a new class for Fifth Edition introduced in Sebastian Crowe's Guide to Drakkenheim. These Intelligence-based spellcasters and medical experts use their knowledge to both heal and harm, augmenting their conventional skills with alchemy and occult magic. They mimic magical effects using the right combination of natural ingredients, chemical reagents, and occult practices. Many monsters in this chapter are inspired by the six subclasses available to apothecaries: Alienist, Chemist, Exorcist, Mutagenist, Pathogenist, and Reanimator.

Some apothecaries might first attempt treatment with traditional means like medicinal herbs and surgical techniques. When these methods are not enough, they use arcane magic and eldritch forces to restore their patients. Apothecary magic revolves around the body: healing it with tinctures, modifying it via transmogrification or psychoactive compounds, or harming it with poisons and diseases.

Though much rarer than sorcerers and wizards, apothecary techniques are spreading through the continent from master to apprentice, as well as in a few institutions for higher learning. While their magic isn't forbidden, the Amethyst Academy does not take kindly to magical instruction outside their schools. Thus, knowledge about apothecary magic has spread largely in secret. These desperate circumstances have often inspired less ethical apothecaries to carry out unsavory magic and methods to continue their research, gain power, and protect themselves and their techniques.

Occult Creation

During their training, many apothecaries develop skills used to create strange creatures, be that through modifying the dead, stitching together flesh into something new, or harnessing the essence of a creature and transforming it into something else. Apothecaries have, at times, strayed from their paths of scientific study for the betterment of mortals, and gotten carried away with the possibilities of if they could accomplish a new feat, disregarding if they should. Often these practices have been used in creating brainless lab assistants, minions to help and perform menial surgical tasks or bodyguards who need no rest to protect and safeguard the important works of the scientists. All manner of bizarre creations bending science and the arcane have been noted as apothecary inventions. The most ambitious and insane apothecaries may even use themselves as a canvas for their experiments.

Alienist

The mind is a malleable thing to an Alienist. To the untrained and ignorant, the methods of an alienist may appear little more than cunning charm and subtle words. However, they know potent occult techniques for mental manipulation including hypnosis, suggestion, telepathy, and telekinesis. When their practice moves on to test subjects, they use mental projection, indoctrination, and even brain surgery to brainwash their victims, altering mental capability, memory, and thought patterns.

An Alienist will use their vast and expanding intellect to create monsters from the severed and broken minds of their patients. @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimApo05.JournalEntryPage.514disembodiedps]{Disembodied Psyches}, @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimApo05.JournalEntryPage.512cerebrograft0]{Cerebrografts}, and @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimApo05.JournalEntryPage.518bloodleeches0#mind-leech]{Mind Leeches} are notable Alienist creations. They have also been known to implant victims with aberrations to take control of the host's body, removing the brains of patients and using them in further experimentation—and other more unfathomable things.

Chemist

Chemists often start with mixing mundane acids and compounds in a laboratory. They practice harnessing heat, cold, and electricity in new and unique ways. As they move on to larger projects, Chemists begin experimenting with more destructive forces, attempting to perfect what combination of the least ingredients results in the biggest elemental reactions. They also create sentient alchemical mixtures, creating life from the very core and raw alchemical elements. Eventually a Chemist learns the skills to raze buildings to the ground with little more than a flask of chemicals used in the right way.

Chemists often create various forms of oozes or elementals as lab assistants or defenses. @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.NwQpeeaMxAC3fRft]{Black Puddings}, @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.3fzQVYQhXxCXRa2o]{Gelatinous Cubes}, Mephits, and all manner of elementals are common creations. The @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimApo05.JournalEntryPage.527tanker0000000]{Tanker} acts as a common lab assistant to the Chemist, but no creation is as deadly as the @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimApo05.JournalEntryPage.513chemystral000]{Chemystral}, the ultimate creation of chemical sentience, adaptable and durable; they are the pride of any Chemist.

Exorcist

Exorcists have long been an outlier in the branches of scientific study. However, in a world full of portals to other planes, creatures from the Hells and the Shadowlands, and even the fairy Otherworlds constantly slipping through, the scientific study into these planes is a discipline many will undertake. They do not share the devotion of a paladin or cleric, but instead research the origins of divine power, and how to harness it to manipulate extraplanar beings. Many Exorcists begin their path banishing simple spirits or communicating with ghosts. Eventually they master the ability to vanquish possession and banish much more powerful foes. Exorcists who are driven to more sinister paths can reverse engineer this knowledge to summon entities from other planes, and even allow these beings into themselves, using their bodies as a vessel.

Exorcists could be accompanied by @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.qoFEjfrANBdrCP6m]{Ghosts} or demons of any sort, but their true vile powers come to light in the form of possessions. An Exorcist on a path for power may let a demonic being into their body to try and harness and control the power of that creature, these @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimApo05.JournalEntryPage.525soulboundhost]{Soulbound Hosts} often struggle, and often fail to maintain control over such power.

Mutagenist

A Mutagenist is practiced controlling mutations and altering of the flesh of creatures. They are less crude in their implementations than a Reanimator, and often their experiments will lack the stitched-together nature of other apothecaries, instead containing growths, misplaced appendages and orifices and other grotesque mutations. Mutagenists often begin their practice on small rodents and other creatures, testing their transmogrification to see if they can bend these creatures to be stronger and faster, or mutate them to grow new beneficial properties. It's when a Mutagenist turns to human experimentation that things tend to take a dark turn. For every successful experiment, there are a handful of failures.

The @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimApo05.JournalEntryPage.524skinwing00000]{Skinwing}is the byproduct of a Mutagenist tampering with smaller creatures, while creations such as @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimApo05.JournalEntryPage.512cerebrograft0]{Cerebrograft} are a much more advanced creation. Sometimes their failures do remain beneficial to the doctor in the form of @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimApo05.JournalEntryPage.528uncontainedgr]{Uncontained Growths}. Ultimately the end goal of any Mutagenist is to create the Apex Formula and use it on themselves, transforming into what they deem to be the perfect version of humanity. However, there are always side effects.

Pathogenist

The Pathogenist studies viruses, diseases, poisons, and pathogens. They usually begin their careers with innocent intentions, such as attempting to perfect combating deadly pathogens and viruses by creating cures or medicines. However, some turn more toward harnessing the powers of poison and disease for harmful purposes. When they begin experimenting on test subjects, using them as breeding grounds for their new mutant strains begins their path toward creating horrible abominations.

Pathogenists who use human subjects as testing grounds for their diseases often create @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimApo05.JournalEntryPage.520plaguecarrier]{Plague Carriers} as a means of delivering these diseases, while @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimApo05.JournalEntryPage.515injector00000]{Injectors} act as loyal lab assistants, ready to deliver the Pathogenist's deadly toxins to their often unwilling patients.

Reanimator

Reanimators are often first practiced in the art of reattaching severed limbs, or moving body parts from one creature to another. As their desire for perfection in their creations grows, their path to deadly experimentation begins. Their minds blossom with wild ideas to attempt physical manipulations that no being should endure.

Reanimators will often be accompanied by @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimApo05.JournalEntryPage.521reautomata000]{Reautomata} as their first foray into human testing, but they create all manner of @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimApo05.JournalEntryPage.526stitcher00000]{Stitchers}, @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimApo05.JournalEntryPage.523ripper0000000]{Rippers}, and @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimApo05.JournalEntryPage.515injector00000]{Injectors} as lab assistants to help them with the production of new creations.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.111imgipulatingl inline]

Apothecaries and Delerium

When delerium first arrived in Drakkenheim on that fateful day, it left behind devastation and death in its wake, but it also left opportunity for those willing to seek it, and determined enough to harness its power.

While the vast resources and institutional organization of the Amethyst Academy were fully leveraged to research and obtain delerium, the mages were not the only ones interested in learning about and exploiting the strange crystals. Apothecaries of all stripes sought samples of their own as whispers of the magical potency and corrupting influence of delerium spread. Most purchase delerium from traders, prospectors, and smugglers, but others go as far as hiring adventures or mounting their own expeditions to the ruins to collect the stones.

There can be no doubt that the boundless magical power and contaminating influence of delerium has sharply increased the scope and horror of apothecary experimentations. Practitioners of all sorts have begun to use delerium to further extend their scientific research, as it offered magical potency to places that were without it before. Apothecaries have long wished to harness the abilities of mages, and in many ways were able to mimic those examples through blending the right chemicals, or the use of carefully practiced procedures. However, when delerium was added into the mix, it amplified the capabilities of apothecaries to new heights, allowing them to push the nature of scientific study into realms hitherto unimagined.

Commonfolk can often no longer tell the difference between a mageborn spellcaster and an apothecary twisting science to their will. Both the Academy and Silver Order have frowned upon the back-alley practices of many apothecaries. These traditionalists fear that as science grows ever closer to the realm of magic, the provisions of the Edicts of Lumen begin to blur. Delerium is showing up in places it should not, and its presence is always cause for concern. Experimenting with delerium brings inevitable danger, and the pathway to things beyond mortal comprehension. Still, apothecaries aim to harness this power to modify and enhance their capabilities—with understanding comes power. The more an apothecary understands delerium, the less there is to fear from it, and the more power they believe they can have over it.

Roleplaying Traits.name: Roleplaying Traits
Roleplaying Traits.text:
Roleplaying Traits

T hough Though many apothecaries began working alone keeping their creations closely guarded secrets, over time their knowledge of these horrors has spread through whispers and desperate collaborations. Increasingly, ambitious young apothecaries beginning their careers with noble-minded altruism are tempted by the power and promise of these occult secrets. However, one does not so easily meddle with the secrets of life and death itself without compromising one's moral compass. Who knows what dire and desperate situations may cause good-hearted young doctors to find themselves tempted to take up a less ethical choice?

Twisted Motives

What once-noble reason caused the apothecary to create such horrible monsters?

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.tables.RollTable.rSEli7wDFyBMgFrK rollable]

Intelligent Masters

The apothecaries themselves are smart and cunning scientists and they do not often put themselves in situations where they do not have the upper hand. What does the apothecary think of its adversaries and how do they engage with others?

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.tables.RollTable.d1634L4nG2IRVTnl rollable]

Voiceless Horrors

Few of an apothecary's minions are intended for conversations or deep thought. They are more often creatures designed with a singular focus. They obey the demands of their masters without faltering.

These creatures are the things that go bump in the night. They are the monsters of classic science fiction literature, black and white monster films, and horrors found in dark corners. Roleplaying the minions should bring to life the classic concepts of horror and fear. What odd quirk does the Apothecary Abomination possess?

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.tables.RollTable.smRypTjjNW97UPId rollable]

Imprinted Instincts

What traits or mannerisms from the former victim has the monster inherited?

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.tables.RollTable.yGlb214R9eh8OCPc rollable]

Combat Tactics.name: Combat Tactics
Combat Tactics.text:
Combat Tactics

A pothecary Apothecary Abominations are ruthless in battle and obey their apothecary creators without fail. They are deadly and precise creatures who are skilled as both medical lab assistants and defenders. With their surgical tools or unbound strength, they pose a deadly threat to any who dare meddle in the affairs of the mad apothecaries who created them.

Mindless Minions

Most abominations are specifically designed to feel no pain, and lack a mind of their own. They will often fight until they die, relentlessly attacking until they cannot anymore. Oftentimes, these minions operate on the commands of their apothecary masters, performing the orders they have been given to the best of their abilities.

Eyes and Ears

Apothecaries can often use their experiments as a means of gathering intel. Whether through psychic links, telepathic connections, or other more inventive means, it is common that when an apothecary's minion spots a threat, the apothecary will be alerted to that threat immediately. The minions frequently act as a security system for an apothecary's lair.

Sample Encounters

Apothecaries often collect an eclectic mix of creations and experiments, so it is common for several different monsters in this chapter to be found together. Here's a few thematic encounters with Apothecary Abominations:

Sample Collector (Level 3+)

An @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimApo05.JournalEntryPage.516innocentharve]{Innocent Harvester} with a sack full of various @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimApo05.JournalEntryPage.518bloodleeches0]{Leeches} is collecting body parts from a recent battle.

Violently Volatile (Level 7+)

A @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimApo05.JournalEntryPage.527tanker0000000]{Tanker} and two @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimApo05.JournalEntryPage.521reautomata000#scrap-reautomata]{Scrap Reautomata} prepare chemicals in a lab.

Failed Experiments (Level 9+)

A discarded gaggle of @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimApo05.JournalEntryPage.524skinwing00000]{Skinwings} and an @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimApo05.JournalEntryPage.528uncontainedgr]{Uncontained Growth} are lurking in the wilds near an apothecary's hideout, attacking travelers.

Spooky Science (Level 10+)

An @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimApo05.JournalEntryPage.506apothecaries0#exorcist]{Exorcist}, two @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.qoFEjfrANBdrCP6m]{Ghosts}, and 3–4 @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.PuPo4H4Dcxigf0fY]{Specters} working on summoning a demon, using the Exorcist as a host, in an old, abandoned church. If they are not stopped, the Exorcist will become a @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimApo05.JournalEntryPage.525soulboundhost]{Soulbound Host}.

Out of Sight, Out of Mind (Level 12+)

A @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimApo05.JournalEntryPage.511bodysnatcher0]{Body Snatcher} collects victims from a nearby town under the watchful eye of a @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimApo05.JournalEntryPage.512cerebrograft0]{Cerebrograft} and a @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimApo05.JournalEntryPage.514disembodiedps]{Disembodied Psyche}.

Surgical Team (Level 15+)

A @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimApo05.JournalEntryPage.523ripper0000000]{Ripper}, an @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimApo05.JournalEntryPage.515injector00000]{Injector}, and a @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimApo05.JournalEntryPage.526stitcher00000]{Stitcher} are working together in an operating theater, preparing the next subject for experimentation by their master.

The Perfect Specimen (Level 15+)

An @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimApo05.JournalEntryPage.511apex000000000]{Apex}, and his team of @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimApo05.JournalEntryPage.529wretchedpatie]{Wretched Patients}, unleash an @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimApo05.JournalEntryPage.528uncontainedgr]{Uncontained Growth} within their lab.

Adventure Hooks.name: Adventure Hooks
Adventure Hooks.text:
Adventure Hooks

T he The abominations made by apothecaries pose a threat to unsuspecting villages. The secret scientific research they brew up in hidden labs cause all manner of problems for the regular folk residing nearby. Apothecaries in need of fresh subjects for experimentation are the center of unease in any community when people start going missing in the middle of the night. These missing people are often accompanied by reports of strange creatures on the outskirts of town.

Infiltrating the Guild

The Amethyst Academy is concerned with the scientific research happening in secret at the Mobius Facility, located in the Drakeclaw mountains. The Academy needs a team of adventurers to find the hidden entrance to this facility, infiltrate it, and find out if any illegal magic is practiced there. Unfortunately, the facility is overrun with demons, most dangerous of all a @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimApo05.JournalEntryPage.525soulboundhost]{Soulbound Host} being overseen by an @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimApo05.JournalEntryPage.506apothecaries0#exorcist]{Exorcist} Apothecary.

Can I Copy Your Homework?

As an aspiring apothecary yourself, with curiosity about the multiple studies of science happening across the continent, you wish to travel to Altbruke University, Lento College, the Liberio Institute, and the Southern Reach Research Centre to learn what you can from a master apothecary at each institution.

Elyrian Bonesaw Massacre

There is a @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimApo05.JournalEntryPage.523ripper0000000]{Ripper} on the loose in one of the smaller towns of Elyria. A local apothecary had created a lab assistant to help him with his medical practices and research, but the creature became violent and vengeful. Now the Ripper is on a rampage through the countryside and needs to be stopped.

The Blob

A @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimApo05.JournalEntryPage.513chemystral000]{Chemystral} has escaped its lab and devoured the apothecary who created it. Now it wanders the countryside, consuming everything is passes and growing larger. The key to stopping it must be in the apothecary's notes in his lab.

The Lost Ones

People have been going missing in the dead of night, and reports of those very people being seen wandering the woods nearby are causing quite the stir. A nearby @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimApo05.JournalEntryPage.507dreverettfree]{Reanimator} Apothecary has been kidnapping victims using a @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimApo05.JournalEntryPage.511bodysnatcher0]{Body Snatcher} and turning them into @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimApo05.JournalEntryPage.521reautomata000]{Reautomata} and @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimApo05.JournalEntryPage.529wretchedpatie]{Wretched Patients}. The Reanimator is hidden in a wilderness tower and must be stopped.

Locations and Lairs.name: Locations and Lairs
Locations and Lairs.text:
Locations and Lairs

A pothecary Apothecary lairs are often labs and workshops, hidden from the public eye. These places hold the mysteries of science and occult lore. Finding an apothecary's lair is often a difficult task, as they go to great lengths to conceal their work; the monsters that inhabit the dank workshops and occult labs are the stuff of nightmares.

Repurposed Facilities

Whether working alone or in small groups, apothecaries typically repurpose an existing structure to serve as their lair. They may choose a disused old manor house, abandoned fortress, or a remote sanitarium. Often their lairs are unknown to most, in long forgotten facilities, in remote locations, or in secret chambers below a town.

Institutional Facade

Apothecaries who make their lairs in towns and cities may provide legitimate medical services and healing to the community while concealing their experiments from public view. Their lair may outwardly operate as a school, hospice, or clinic open to those seeking the apothecary's talents, while housing their real work in hidden chambers below ground. Less scrupulous apothecaries may use this as a scheme to transform unwitting patients into test subjects.

Science-Fiction Furnishings

An apothecary lab is often filled with bizarre alchemical ingredients, various types of lab equipment, and strange chambers filled with occult secrets. Strange contraptions: tesla coils, cadavers, half-finished experiments, and all manner of science-fiction staples can be found in their labs. No matter the type of apothecary inhabiting the lair, it is a bizarre place that fringes on the borders of what is science and magic.

Nothing as it Seems

There is no way of knowing when you are walking into a horrible trap when exploring an apothecary's lair. Cadavers may get up and walk around, the vat of bubbling liquid may be a sentient ooze, and the multitudes of experiments and equipment may cause elemental traps and hazards. With the numerous forms of science that apothecaries experiment with, there is no telling what mind-bending contraptions they may have at their disposal.

Minions and Monsters

Many of the monsters in this chapter operate as minions to powerful apothecaries. Depending on the type of apothecary you are using, there are monsters it may use more often than others. Regardless, an apothecary uses its experiments and mastery of arcane science to protect themselves and their valuable research.

Puzzles and Protections

Apothecaries do not easily allow access their labs and research. They often have powerful locks, puzzles, and various ways to outsmart and confuse those trying to infiltrate to their secret lairs.

Laboratory Features

This lair is based on the secret apothecary laboratory found beneath Altbruke University, but could be adapted to the lair of any apothecary. The descriptions of the rooms are left ambiguous in nature, as different apothecaries may decorate their rooms in different ways.

  • An @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimApo05.JournalEntryPage.506apothecaries0#alienist]{Alienist} may have more texts on psychology, simple puzzles and games, abstract ink blots with sinister interpretations, a Newton's cradle on the desk, or a classic brain in a jar.
  • A @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimApo05.JournalEntryPage.506apothecaries0#chemist]{Chemist} will likely have vials and vats of chemicals, alchemical equipment, tongs, furnaces, barrels of water, safety equipment, and lots of test samples. They may keep a small ooze in a contained space.
  • An @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimApo05.JournalEntryPage.506apothecaries0#exorcist]{Exorcist} will have summoning circles in place of operating labs, books on undead, demons, specters, and hauntings. Macabre décor decorates the laboratory, such as skulls and bones, along with religious items relating to the Sacred Flame or Old Gods. They may even have a ghost or spirit contained in a warded vessel.
  • A @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimApo05.JournalEntryPage.506apothecaries0#mutagenist]{Mutagenist} will often have books of biology, diagrams of the human form, test samples of their formulae, alchemical equipment, and perhaps even a failed test subject kept as a minion or pet.
  • A @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimApo05.JournalEntryPage.506apothecaries0#pathogenist]{Pathogenist} may have more vials and toxins lining their shelves, books about viral infections, pathogens, healing, and occult lore. They could have microscopes, petri dishes, and all manner of scientific gear for studying and creating pathogens.
  • A @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimApo05.JournalEntryPage.507dreverettfree]{Reanimator} will likely have the most grotesque gear in their lab: bone saws, knives and scalpels, and preserved body parts in jars. Nondescript meat hanging from hooks or severed limbs in piles are not unheard of.

1. Doctor's Office

This private office is where the apothecary retreats for some light reading of their own.

A small wooden desk covered in writing supplies, specimens, and scientific knick-knacks sits in the far corner. A comfortable looking chair, and a few bookshelves filled with occult lore and scientific texts forms a comfortable reading nook. A rather plain rug sits upon the floor and artwork on the walls depicting various scientific or medical procedures relating to the apothecary's field of work

2. Laboratory

This large chamber can be set up for a variety of alchemical and scientific experiments, involving both organic and inorganic materials. It may even be appropriate for creating magic items.

Shelves of samples and equipment line the walls with long tables in the middle of the room, each equipped with alchemical gear, or strange instruments for performing scientific experiments and research.

3. Library

This library contains rare and exotic works on medicine, occult magic, science, nature, and may contain forbidden lore or secrets mortals were not meant to know.

4. Operating Theatre

This grim chamber is a horrifying laboratory dedicated to mad science. At the center of the room is a pedestal in the middle of a large magic circle. Four sconces bearing delerium crystals surround the raised pedestal. A massive dissection slab flanked by two great machines crackling with arcane energy resonate with the slab, which sits atop the pedestal. There are sets of dissection tables all about the room, with various corpses and bodies in different states of dismemberment placed upon them. Along one of the walls are several jars containing preserved brains and body parts.

5. Materials Storage

This organized chamber contains chemicals and reagents used for the apothecary's work.

6. Subject Containment

A prison by any other terms, these rooms are used to hold test subjects for the apothecary's work—or their failed experiments.

7. Morgue

A room for storing the dead, often for use in grim experiments.

8. Patient Ward

This room is filled with beds for the apothecary's more willing patients to convalesce and rest.

9. Waiting Room

Some apothecaries run functional businesses where patients will come to seek their aid. The waiting room is a place for those waiting to see the doctor to pass time.

Notable Apothecary Lairs in the World of Drakkenheim

Altbruke University

One of the continent's finest institutions for higher learning, Altbruke University offers programs in the humanities, natural philosophy, mathematics, physics, and medicine. However, the curriculum at Altbruke University concerns mundane topics only. Under the Edicts of Lumen, none save the Amethyst Academy may operate a school for instruction in the arcane.

Nevertheless, the school is home to the Guild of Conscientious Practice and Scientific Discovery, an organization of philosophers, scientists, and doctors, who share knowledge, collaborate on research, and clandestinely operate an occult study of apothecary magic. The guild took advantage of the political turmoil in the years following the Westemär Civil War to work largely unnoticed by school authorities, amongst the nobility, and, most importantly, the Amethyst Academy. Working in hiding for almost a decade, the guild instructed promising students in occult magic and repurposed the subterranean chambers below the Lena Leuven Laboratory of Medicine and Natural Philosophy into an extensive secret school and lab.

The intense secrecy surrounding their hidden labs enabled several guild members to conduct truly dark and horrifying experiments, contrary to the group's mission statement. The psychic manipulator Dr. Sina Rienks, aided in concealing the mutagenic experiments of Dr. Johanna Veers, while Anton Jonge conspired to create deathly pathogens. It may have continued had not the reanimated experiments of one Dr. Everett Freed begun wreaking havoc on the student body.

Mobius Facility

Rumors throughout Westemär speak of a facility deep in the twisting peaks of the Drakeclaw Mountains. Known as the Mobius Facility, its location is kept secret by the apothecaries who wish to hide their research from the rest of the world. It is said that the Mobius Facility's internal structure is built around optical illusions, making it a mind-bending place to navigate. Inside the deep lab's seemingly endless rooms are scientific atrocities that push the boundaries of fathomable knowledge.

Lento College

Lento College in Caspia is known mostly for its arts programs. The school produces many of the continent's well-known bards, but it also provides standard studies, including a few small labs and science facilities. Although not as well known as Altbruke, a small group of Caspian apothecaries formed their own research facilities after graduating from Lento College.

Liberio

The arts and sciences flourish in the Free City of Liberio, sponsored by wealthy aristocracy and merchants who flock to the city. Many apothecaries see themselves as artists, and they thrive in Liberio. The cosmopolitan city has no shortage of ailments, and skilled doctors readily establish themselves by treating sick sailors, healing injured commonfolk, or doting on a vain noble. Liberio is a mercantile crossroads; apothecaries here have no trouble procuring rare ingredients and materials, especially those of a less-than-legal nature thanks to the smuggling and piracy flowing from the city across the Middle Sea.

Liberio's political independence also means apothecaries can work more openly here than anywhere else in the continent, despite the direct presence of the Amethyst Academy and their Enigma Ziggurat. Interestingly, occultists in the city find working under the Academy's nose beneficial. First, the mages' presence means that willing adventurers and rare curiosities pass through the city regularly, especially delerium. Second, Academy mages seem to tolerate apothecaries in Liberio, unwilling to disturb the peace where their great stronghold sits. Indeed, it's not unknown for apothecaries and Academy guildmages to gather, trade, and occasionally collaborate here.

Although many apothecaries operate their own clinics, the city is home to one of the few purpose-built hospitals in the Continent: the Sanatoria Obscura, led by two prolific apothecaries, Isidora Venefica and Lucius Noctis. The hospital none-the-less is the subject of many rumors about what happens in the extensive morgue and research labs housed beneath the public-facing medical wings.

Southern Reach

The coastal side of the Southern Reach is far enough away from the rules and regulations of Elyria, that although those in Lumen consider the Southern Reach part of their nation of Elyria, they hold little control or sway over what goes on beyond the Witherbleach Desert. Those in the Southern Reach have, for a long time, considered themselves their own separate nation. One that is free from the rule of many of the other nations, and very seldom looked at even for maintaining the Edicts of Lumen. The Black Lambda Facility, one of the largest facilities of science and research resides in the base of the Pale Teeth Mountains. Dozens of apothecaries practice and study here, performing occult rituals, dangerous science, and brutal experiments.

Apothecaries.name: Apothecaries
Apothecaries.text:
Apothecaries

B ehind Behind every horrible abomination, every inch of grafted flesh, every failed experiment, and every wretched patient who went seeking help and ended up on the unfortunate end of a scalpel is an apothecary. These maddened and misguided practitioners have been bent towards evil ends, and have used their vast knowledge of science, the occult, and the human body to twist and bend the laws of human nature and physiology to their will.

Alienist

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.113imgthecaries0 inline]

I don't know if I want these guys poking around in my head! That's where I keep my thoughts!

Statblock: @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.sv1DylLXj9vDZxkg]{Alienist}

Hovering inches from the ground, lab coat billowing in an unknown breeze that seems to swirl around the figure, the Alienist mutters under their breath, eyes glowing white as they pull on the threads of your mind. You feel the imminent threat of your psyche shattering to this apothecary's will with little more than a flick of their wrist.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef01.JournalEntryPage.98bioothecaries0 inline]

His mouth isn't moving but I can hear everything he's saying, I guess it's time to silence the voices.

Chemist

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.114imgthecaries0 inline]

Word of advice, if the doctor you go to looks like this guy, maybe find a new doctor.

Statblock: @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.dFXzfQ4YUdkFK8bE]{Chemist}

The figure is garbed in large safety goggles, an acid-burned thick lab apron, white chemical-stained lab coat, and rubber gloves. The skin on their face is the only visible flesh on them, scarred by bubbling chemical burns.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef01.JournalEntryPage.99bioothecaries0 inline]

The only chemists I admire are the ones who make Caspian cinnamon rolls. This is not one of them.

Exorcist

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.115imgthecaries0 inline]

Listen, I don't care if you call yourself a scientist or a doctor, if you put a demon in you, I'm going to kill you.

Statblock: @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.2gJlashMBY1RZDKd]{Exorcist}

The figure wears a wide-brim hat that casts shadows on their face. A long, black trench coat covers their form. The dour figure carries a simple doctor's bag in one hand and a holy symbol of the Sacred Flame in the other. Ethereal energies flit and flick around the doctor as they mumble incoherent ancient words, summoning spirits, or perhaps something worse.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef01.JournalEntryPage.100biothecaries0 inline]

I admire their divine focus but it's the controlling you with ghosts thing where they lose me.

Mutagenist

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.116imgthecaries0 inline]

I have often thought it would be pretty great to have an extra arm. I could swing even more swords!

Statblock: @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.efjLS35RF7XR3vZp]{Mutagenist}

With thick glasses, a white lab coat, and some rather mundane garb, the Mutagenist is an unassuming figure. The most notable thing about them is the strange potion they carry in their hand: an elixir that bubbles with purple and orange hues, swirls of shimmering blues and greens flow within it. In some fleeting moments, you swear you see the liquid take forms of grotesque faces within the bottle.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef01.JournalEntryPage.101biothecaries0 inline]

She doesn't look so tough, now surrender before you...uh oh

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.117imgthecaries0 inline]

Statblock: @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.SpIGRVKyebsZPEV2]{Pathogenist}

This figure is draped in a heavy coat, with a bag full of tinctures, poisons, alchemical ingredients, and dried herbs. A gas mask and a drawn hood conceal their face. The Pathogenist draws a syringe filled with a glowing green formula as an acrid smell wafts from around them. They double check their pathogen, ensuring it is ready for their victims.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef01.JournalEntryPage.102biothecaries0 inline]

Pro tip, go for the eyes before it goes for your blood.

Dr. Everett Freed, Reanimator.name: Dr. Everett Freed, Reanimator
Dr. Everett Freed, Reanimator.text:
Dr. Everett Freed, Reanimator

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.118imgverettfree inline]

Statblock: @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.q1JXPCTGrXyClMIc]{Dr. Everett Freed, Reanimator}

Dr. Everett Freed regards you with a stern frown. He is long-faced, bald-headed, and wears thick, circular glasses that magnify his focused gaze. Beneath his bleached-white surgical apron, he is dressed in a tailored dark jacket. The coat is deceptively normal: thick and heavy, it conceals numerous pockets stuffed with vials and unusual instruments. His hands, sheathed in slightly stained rubber gloves, tightly grip a black leather doctor's bag at his side. A faint scent of formaldehyde and burnt metal clings to him.

“I think we can all agree you're better off without vocal chords.”

— Everett Freed, Reanimator

Think Tank.name: Think Tank
Think Tank.text:
Think Tank

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.119imgnktank0000 inline]

Statblock: @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.tGMG5oks7iSWw3J3]{Think Tank}

A severed head bobs gently aloft. The top of its scalp has been sawed off, exposing its pulsing brain, which is encased in a dome filled with bubbling, glowing liquid. A dozen thin mechanical arms emerge from its eye sockets. Around each delicate limb is coiled an elongated strand of the optic nerve, and upon the tip of each are curiously blinking human eyes of different sizes and colors. A haphazard bundle of tubes, hoses, and cables flows from its open neck along the still-attached spine, which connects via several sinewy strands to an array of fluid-filled glass tanks containing a throbbing heart, pounding lungs, and other nearly unrecognizable internal organs. Attached to the spine are spindly mechanical arms each ending in human hands.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef01.JournalEntryPage.104bionktank0000 inline]

Apothecary Familiars.name: Apothecary Familiars
Apothecary Familiars.text:
Apothecary Familiars

N o No matter their research or practice, apothecaries of all stripes have need for assistants. However, they often struggle to find competent, discrete, and trustworthy help. Talented orderlies, scribes, and nurses might cost an arm and a leg. Some apothecaries take that a little too literally when they resolve to make their own help.

A familiar makes an ideal beginner project for an ambitious young apothecary seeking to create their first minions. Apothecaries often create their familiars from the remains of a friend, family member, or colleague: such as the hands of a rival surgeon or the skull of a former mentor. The apothecary may treat these familiars similarly to how they treated the person in life.

Helpful Hand

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.120imgthecaryfam inline]

Statblock: @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.UyrB8vJBelCBDznY]{Helpful Hand}

Skittering out from the shadows is a grotesque parody of a hand, desiccated and skeletal, its bony fingers clicking against the floor. The creature moves with an unsettling agility, crawling up walls and across ceilings with ease. As you watch, its sharp, talon-like digits flex and twitch, ready to jab or latch onto its next victim.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef01.JournalEntryPage.106biothecaryfam inline]

Speaking Skull

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.121imgthecaryfam inline]

Statblock: @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.5h4Ynod9XsV5qEpJ]{Speaking Skull}

Resting on the apothecary's desk, amidst vials, surgical implements, and scattered anatomical notes tomes is a skull, ordinary at first glance. It lies motionless — but then it begins to stir, hovering an inch above the wooden surface. Its eye sockets, dark and hollow, seem to fix on you, its bony grin frozen in a sinister smirk. The skull begins to speak, its voice a chilling murmur. “You're not one of the doctor's patients…” it hisses. “You should not be here…”

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef01.JournalEntryPage.107biothecaryfam inline]

Player Character Familiars

Subject to GM approval, an apothecary with the Laboratory Assistant esoteric theory can create a Helpful Hand or Speaking Skull to serve them using the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.JGT5bNqu9REL7Fuz]{Find Familiar} spell. A familiar created in this manner always acts in combat immediately after its creator's turn. It can use its special attacks in its stat block only if the apothecary uses a Bonus Action on their turn to command the familiar to take one of those actions.

Abominations.name: Abominations
Abominations.text:
Abominations

W hen When an apothecary's research goes too far, when their thirst for power grows greater than their morals, when an apothecary begins testing the boundaries of science, this is where a misguided apothecary finds themselves creating the monsters that become whispered horror stories around campfires. This is where the Apothecary Abominations are made.

Apex.name: Apex
Apex.text:
Apex

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.122imgx000000000 inline]

Statblock: @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.f1NxmhjUQd0zpit4]{Apex}

A perfect physical form of humanity stands before you, its flawlessly formed and muscle-bound flesh is tinted in a golden hue while its veins bulge and glow with octarine light. Their eyes emit cascades of light and their voice is a booming chorus. As swirls of fire, ice, and electricity crackle around them, they pulse with unbound energy.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef01.JournalEntryPage.108biox000000000 inline]

Body Snatcher.text:

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.123imgysnatcher0 inline]

Statblock: @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.np4tx9RNqRGwKxXK]{Body Snatcher}

This patchwork monster of stitched-together corpses oozes black ichor from its seams. The figure is a hulking form, about 7 feet tall with broad shoulders and a hunched back. Its head seems small compared to its body, with pale white eyes highlighting sunken dark sockets. A lipless mouth forces the creature into a constant menacing grimace. Draped in a thick black trench coat and wide brimmed hat while smelling of sulfur and brimstone, the unsettling humming and mumbling of the creature echoes in the ears of those it is about to grab. The most unsettling feature is the creature's four arms, which end in massive, oversized hands, each with eight long, spindly fingers. The creature shifts from shadow to shadow effortlessly, in a haunting ghost-like fashion unusual for its size.

Cerebrograft.text:

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.124imgebrograft0 inline]

Given the strange features of this massive, muscled, eight-foot-tall figure, it is difficult to say if it was once human or a troll. Its bruised skin stretches and rips over barely contained muscles. It is pin-headed, with an emotionless face, glassy-eyes, and a slack-jawed maw.

Most disturbingly, its ribcage is splayed open, revealing guts and viscera along with a smaller, vestigial creature with wrinkled flesh and a mewling mouth. It holds its sticklike arms and curled fingers close, and its neck can barley hold its massive head. Thin translucent skin covers its huge brain, the blood vessels within softly glowing. Raising its tiny hands to its temples, its eyes bulge and its face contorts into a twisted expression.

Chemystral.text:

This lithe, 8-foot-tall creature has an array of tanks and hoses connected to four mechanical limbs that end in massive syringes, filled with all manner of toxins, contagions, and afflictions. Beady white eyes glare at you from its bald head. No mouth is visible, instead, it wears hose-connected mask and several magnifying lenses that can slotted over its eyes for surgical precision.

These small mannequins are cobbled together from wood, clay, and scrap metal. Visible tubes pump blood through their lithe forms. Garbed in scavenged clothing and wigs, many resemble human children, while some appear like deformed stuffed animals or dolls. Some especially macabre specimens are built with flesh, including painted masks as faces. Each has a single hand replaced with an array of scissors and scalpels, while the other holds an extractor or syringe. Several are equipped with small satchels or bloodied bags that they drag behind them. Some carry ragged stuffed animals filled with pockets. All bags are filled with dismembered body parts, bits of bone, flesh, organs, eyes, and other parts they bring back to their masters.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef01.JournalEntryPage.114bioocentharve inline]

The patchwork form of the hydra appears to be fused together with metal scrap, and spare parts from large monstrosities. Its flesh is pale and discolored, with multicolored scales that have lost their luster over time. In many places patches of scales are missing entirely. The creature's multiple heads are all surgically attached, with milky white eyes placed in old and rotting sockets. Foul chemicals pump through the creature's body causing glowing veins to show throw the places where its scales are the most thinned. Sickly green salvia drips from the many and varied mouths of its lizard heads.

Charging towards you with unbound fury is a lithe human clad in a hulking suit of full plate wielding a pair of oversized scimitars. As they draw closer with a snarl, it becomes clear you face no mere warrior, but a monstrous abomination of metal and flesh. The emaciated figure is not wearing the armor: the plates have been riveted and bolted into their bones. Globs of weeping, infected scar tissue pulsate where the body fights against the metal fused into muscle and sinew. It does not hold its weapons: its forelimbs have been entirely replaced with scything talon-blades. Their metal helmets are smooth and featureless save for a single ocular delerium lens, and expose the creature's sickly mouth and sharpened teeth, its breath giving off a rank chemical odor.

Extraplanar Powers.name: Extraplanar Powers
Extraplanar Powers.text:
Appendix A:
Ancient Entities

Extraplanar Powers

D escribed Described herein are a few of the mightiest extraplanar beings known in the World of Drakkenheim. Although they are not gods, their vast powers and incredible knowledge often allows them to masquerade as such to naive or unwitting mortals. Indeed, these entities can seal eldritch pacts with those who seek their favor and patronage; some of their warlocks even revere and worship these patrons. Other spellcasters may seek forbidden lore from them via magic like the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.dSTu1MaPhBqPITwM]{Contact Other Plane} spell. Perhaps some of these entities may have come to mortals in ancient days and made some of the first warlock pacts which brought magic to the Mortal World.

Promising and ambitious mortals, such as courageous adventurers, often attract the interest and ire of these ancient beings. Their plans and machinations stretch on for countless mortal lifetimes, and so these ancient entities often appear to adventurers as patient patrons, offering information, aid, magical powers, and insights. However, they extract their own costs, for these entities seldom share human values, instead following their own amoral principles and alien perspectives. Often, they demand a service performed at a perpendicular purpose to the heroes' own objectives — their reasons or purposes may not become apparent until years, decades, or centuries have passed.

Inscrutable Origins

These ancient entities are intrinsically connected to their planes of origin. The metaphysical tethers mean that such beings normally cannot travel physically into the Mortal World without extraordinary amounts of magical energy. However, their planar connection also makes them nearly impossible to permanently destroy. Since they are part of the essence of their planes of origin, they will re-form if their physical forms are slain, although it could take centuries before they regain their full forms. Nevertheless, even in this disembodied state, it is still possible to interact with their consciousness via magic or their intermediaries. Instead, mortals who wish to end these otherworldly threats investigate ways to bind or imprison them indefinitely, as their complete destruction is impossible.

If these beings possess any true knowledge regarding the fundamental nature of the cosmos or the existence of the gods, it is not clear. They only speak to mortals of such topics in a cryptic manner, and often in metaphorical or figurative language which deliberately obfuscates their meaning.

Using the Ancient Entities in Your Campaign

Although presented here with their game statistics as Epic Bosses, these Ancient Entities should not be cast in the role of the ultimate villain in a Drakkenheim campaign! These beings care little for mortal affairs, and who triumphs in the contest between the embattled factions of the Continent matters very little to them. They do, however, have a profound interest in delerium, but only because its chaotic influence creates fertile ground for their own schemes.

While player characters may speculate as such — and you should certainly feed into this suspicion — none of these ancient entities are responsible for sending the meteor that annihilated Drakkenheim. They did not create delerium; the crystals are a much more fundamental property of the way magic works in the Drakkenheim cosmos. However, some are entertained by what that notion prompts in mortals. Others, such as the Thing with the Writhing Tail and the Whispered Promise, seek to use delerium to advance their agendas and power. Other beings ultimately desire the destruction or domination of the Mortal World—such as He Who Laughs Last and the Rat God—but those plans are centuries from fruition and will come at a time when no heroes live to oppose them. Even if the player characters manage to slay one of these beings, such an event is ultimately an insignificant setback to their longstanding plans.

Instead, these beings are best involved in the campaign as patrons, manipulators, and puppetmasters, orchestrating schemes far beyond the comprehension of the player characters. Not only do they make excellent patrons for warlocks of all stripes and great targets for the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.dSTu1MaPhBqPITwM]{Contact Other Plane} spell, roleplaying interactions with the Ancient Entities are also delightful opportunities to test the principles and desires of the player characters. These Ancient Entities can offer the player characters shortcuts to knowledge and power if the characters are willing to make bargains or pacts with terrifying eldritch creatures. These entities could offer characters the chance to “correct” a past mistake, or a direct path to achieve a key objective related to their personal quests — but the possible cost and consequences should give the heroes pause.

All you need to do is place a statue, shrine, mysterious portal, or magic circle along the adventurers' path to facilitate a telepathic interaction between the entity and the player characters. Play to the characters' desires, fears, ambitions, and regrets. Cryptically offer them everything they want and more, but without answers or explanations. Take delight in playing the entities with a sense of alien distance, nonchalant superiority, and arrogant assurance. After all, the heroes are but insignificant pawns in a grand game for them — and all the characters' struggles and victories aren't even a key play in the overall strategy for these enigmatic beings.

I have killed a lot of weird monsters in my day, but these things eat my toughest foes for breakfast. Still, I'd love to mount one of their heads in the halls of Jackson's Keep some day.

Its fur seems to absorb light, creating a silhouette that shifts and wavers, as if its true form is utterly incomprehensible to your mind. Amethyst Academy.name: Amethyst Academy
Amethyst Academy.text:
Appendix B:
Faction Agents

Allies or Enemies?

Amethyst Academy

T he The wizards of the Amethyst Academy perform all sorts of arcane tasks throughout the nations. They study ancient ruins, maintain their magical strongholds, accompany nobles on errands, or participate as members of their council. These mages are well known throughout the continent and are identifiable by their purple-robes and academy rings.

Academy Combat Tactics

Broadly speaking, Amethyst Academy mages eschew combat, valuing their own lives too highly to take such risks. They view themselves as researchers, craftspeople, and scholars, not war mages—few bother learning damaging spells beyond simple cantrips, instead focusing on practical magic for their academic and industrial pursuits. Nevertheless, they know that magic is still a dangerous vocation, and ready themselves to flee perilous situations with @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.1N8dDMMgZ1h1YJ3B]{Invisibility} spells or teleportation magic.

When violent confrontation seem inevitable, Amethyst Academy agents often hire mercenaries or adventurers, or dispatch summoned creatures in their stead. Nevertheless, there are bold explorers who take to field research and prepare themselves for dangerous expeditions—particularly, those who personnally study the ruins of Drakkenheim. They often utilize constructs such as Shield Guardians or summoned elementals bound to service with @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.42O2aNBW7vK90gTL]{Planar Binding}. Mages usually begin combat with defensive or control spells as befits the situation, such as taking to the air with @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.yfbK8gZqESlaoY5t]{Fly} or subduing foes with @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.yqUDoxk4x0NWG5Bz]{Slow}. Only once they are certain the situation is under control will they use their signature Prismatic Blasts or area-of-effect spells like @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.ztgcdrWPshKRpFd0]{Fireball} and @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.IyikgTEOTv701jgQ]{Lightning Bolt}. These mages almost always flee once they've become Bloodied, viewing a temporary setback or mission failure as a preferable outcome over their deaths.
