Followers of the Falling Fire.name: Followers of the Falling Fire
Followers of the Falling Fire.text:
Followers of the Falling Fire

T he The Followers of the Falling Fire are a religious sect who believe the meteor signaled a celestial prophecy. These fanatics consider delerium a holy sacrament. Called to pilgrimage by the prescient testament of their leader, Lucretia Mathias, zealous masses of devout commonfolk now journey to the Crater's Edge to take their place in a divine plan.

Falling Fire Combat Tactics

Falling Fire pilgrims give up their possessions and wealth and often carry very little on them. For the most part, common Falling Fire devotees are not equipped to fight. Most members try to avoid combat. Preferring a peaceful approach, they are more reactionary in their tactics and hope most situations do not come to bloodshed. However, Drakkenheim is a dangerous city, and monsters and bandits have attempted to thwart the efforts of the devout worshippers often. Pilgrims have been known to take up clubs, daggers, and any mundane weapons they can find to defend themselves, and often groups of traveling pilgrims are accompanied by armored zealots and spellcasting divine leaders who are ready to protect their flock.

There comes a time in every man's life where he wants more. Delerium in your chest is the wrong way.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.219imgllowersoft inline]

Pilgrim

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.220imgllowersoft inline]

Statblock: @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.lswU4nTHwGbM5Goc]{Pilgrim}

Dressed in plain gray robes tied off with a frayed rope, and wearing little else but a pair of old sandals, these pilgrims carry little on them and have given up their possessions for a simple life dedicated to the Falling Fire.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef01.JournalEntryPage.200biollowersoft inline]

Zealot

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.221imgllowersoft inline]

Statblock: @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.gIM3MSrHJ7aYvIa5]{Zealot}

Dressed in gray robes with a tabard bearing the symbol of the Falling Fire, these protectors carry large greatswords of simple design. Fiery faith burns in their eyes.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef01.JournalEntryPage.201biollowersoft inline]

Missionary

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.222imgllowersoft inline]

Statblock: @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.JBaQ8OAzlvKL4FMK]{Missionary}

The faith's missionaries are draped in white robes with leather belts and a sash hanging from their side adorned with the symbol of the Falling Fire. These devout missionaries lead pilgrims on their holy path to Drakkenheim, clutching the sacred writing of Lucretia Mathias in their hands.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef01.JournalEntryPage.202biollowersoft inline]

They believe their faith brings them closer to the flame. I have other ways to bring them closer.

Congregation

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.223imgllowersoft inline]

Statblock: @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.DwnRlIvhxW79kCvH]{Congregation}

A crowd of pilgrims brandish clubs, torches, and pitchforks. They begin to muster up courage, spouting out passages from the writings of the Falling Fire, calling out the blasphemous to be brought low by the fires to cleanse them of their sins.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef01.JournalEntryPage.203biollowersoft inline]

Three's a crowd and coincidentally the number of prongs you get stabbed with. People get too excited in groups.

Sanctified Monk

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.224imgllowersoft inline]

Statblock: @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.RTQANHAefQDoYWpe]{Sanctified Monk}

Dressed in simple white tunics and loose trousers, these monks have sworn themselves to the Faith of the Falling Fire and have taken the Sacrament, pulling divine energy from within themselves and using it to channel their martial arts and combat capabilities.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef01.JournalEntryPage.204biollowersoft inline]

I don't like getting hit in the face and these guys end up being hugely disappointing. My face is my moneymaker.

Sanctified Knight

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.225imgllowersoft inline]

Statblock: @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.TmZ4pPtSMY053bJE]{Sanctified Knight}

Clad in plate armor and carrying a longsword, the Sanctified Knight's delerium shard embedded in their chest glows through their armor as they protect the pilgrims from any threats.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef01.JournalEntryPage.205biollowersoft inline]

Self-righteous are those who follow the flame. Also they can't do as many push-ups as me.

Sanctified Soul

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.226imgllowersoft inline]

Statblock: @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.INITnC8LUGwaHP2J]{Sanctified Soul}

Wearing no symbols of their faith, and dressed simply, the glow of their delerium shard embedded in their chest glows through their robes signifying their dedication to the Falling Fire. Carrying a book in one hand and speaking passages of the Falling Fire, Sanctified Souls gather flocks of pilgrims before them.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef01.JournalEntryPage.206biollowersoft inline]

Nathaniel Flint

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.227imgllowersoft inline]

Statblock: @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.AfSa15EOIFRNAsUK]{Nathaniel Flint, Pilgrimage Leader}

A simple looking man in his early thirties stands before you, one hand outstretched towards you in a gesture of friendly aid. He has curly brown hair, a warm calm upon his face, and wears dark gray robes and simple boots. Beneath his robes, the gentle octarine glow can be seen from his chest.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef01.JournalEntryPage.207biollowersoft inline]

The happiest man with a raw gem of containation jammed in his chest that I have ever met.

Lucretia Mathias

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.228imgllowersoft inline]

Statblock: @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.DLaS7LBA7ONSUJMx]{Lucretia Mathias}

Lucretia Mathias is a willowy and wizened woman with piercing eyes and pursed lips. She is in her early nineties and keeps her graying black hair in a coiled bun beneath a linen shawl. Lucretia wears simple gray robes, and clutches a heavy leather-bound tome. A glowing golden crystal dangles from a silver chain around her neck. Her garb lightly conceals the delerium shard embedded in her heart.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef01.JournalEntryPage.208biollowersoft inline]

Queen's Men.name: Queen's Men
Queen's Men.text:
Queen's Men

“Who I am is not as important as what I am. I am quicker than thought, quieter than contemplation, and more slippery than a fading memory. I deal in secrets and lies as lesser thieves deal in larceny. I can fulfill your wildest dreams, or be your worst nightmare.”

—The Queen of Thieves

T he The ruins of Drakkenheim attract all manner of scavengers, looters, deserters, and fugitives. The anarchic and dangerous ruins are an ideal hiding place for those on the wrong side of the law, and there is no shortage of plunder and work for those who don't mind getting their hands dirty. The many disparate bands of brigands and outlaws have been brought together into a loose alliance under the thumb of the manipulative and enigmatic Queen of Thieves. Under her rule, the Queen's Men smuggle delerium to disreputable clients in distant lands, exhort and rob adventurers, shakedown pilgrims, and act as a constant thorn in the side of the other factions.

Queen's Men Combat Tactics

Amongst the Queen's Men, different groups may be organized as infiltrators, thieves, saboteurs, and assassins, who work unseen until the moment they strike. In contrast, highway robbers and enforces operate openly, trying to shakedown and intimidate their marks to give up any valuables without a fight. Regardless, members of the Queen's Men are seldom willing to stick around when a fight starts going against them, valuing their own lives first and foremost.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.229imgeensmen000 inline]

Royal Assassin

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.230imgeensmen000 inline]

Statblock: @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.HO8iwz5iRcl0ycgX]{Royal Assassin}

Dressed in black and red, with a large hood and mask concealing their face and a flourished cape trailing behind them, this assassin brandishes a series of poison-tipped throwing daggers. They are posed ready to strike.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef01.JournalEntryPage.210bioeensmen000 inline]

Eldritch Trickster

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.231imgeensmen000 inline]

Statblock: @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.E23ZlQAuGLfSpAot]{Eldritch Trickster}

Draped in black robes and carrying an obsidian wand, the Eldritch Trickster has a hood pulled up tight around its head as arcane power focuses into its hand, forming a blade of raw energy.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef01.JournalEntryPage.211bioeensmen000 inline]

Blackjack Mel

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.232imgeensmen000 inline]

Statblock: @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.2ueuNXJIHpeDm8c1]{Blackjack Mel}

A short and scrawny man in his late thirties stands before you with a funny-looking but clean-shaven mug and greasy slicked-back hair. He wears a black padded jacket and buckled slacks that appear distinguished at first glance but are actually quite shabby and worn.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef01.JournalEntryPage.212bioeensmen000 inline]

All bets are off when you're dealing with this thug. He's got info on anything for a price or a threat.

Queen of Thieves

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.233imgeensmen000 inline]

Statblock: @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.k6q6YbmVI2v1L053]{Queen of Thieves}

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef01.JournalEntryPage.213bioeensmen000 inline]

Knights of the Silver Order.name: Knights of the Silver Order
Knights of the Silver Order.text:
Knights of the Silver Order

The Silver Order is an elite church-sanctioned regiment of paladins and ordained knights oath-sworn to combat supernatural evils, otherworldly incursions, and dark magic. As faithful devotees of the Sacred Flame, they believe delerium is a dangerous and contaminating blight. Led by the valiant Knight-Captain Theodore Marshal, the knights have been dispatched to eradicate Drakkenheim's corruption at its source.

T he The Silver Order are a well-known military organization hailing from the nation of Elyria in the southwest of the continent. Loyal to the Church of the Sacred Flame, they operate as a church-sanctioned military whose stated purpose is to protect the world from evil magical intrusions, to keep otherworldly threats at bay, and to protect the people against dark magic and abuses of power from mageborn. Many believe the Silver Order are a strict organization who upholds the letter of the law within the Edicts of Lumen, a legal document that dictates the balance of power between the church, the mages, and the royalty.

Combat Tactics

What the Silver Order lacks in subtlety they make up for with sheer force. They are a military organization, and their soldiers are well trained and work together as a team. When they tackle problems, they do so in a uniform fashion, knowing when to rely on one another, complete tasks and make pushes in unison. The Silver Order has simple call signs, hand signals, commands, and strategies that they can rely on in the field.

Silver Order knights and paladins should work as a cohesive unit who know their strengths and how to protect their weaknesses.

Any Silver Order regiment is accompanied by at least one paladin or Flamekeeper, and usually at least one of each. Larger organized military missions will see griffon riders as well as entire units of paladins and several Flamekeepers or Pyre Priests. This means that no Silver Order unit is without moderate healing, protective buffs, and often forms of divination and holy battle magic. When push comes to shove, the order's divine spellcasters tend to have a few @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.ztgcdrWPshKRpFd0]{Fireballs} and @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.5e1xTohkzqFqbYH4]{Flamestrikes} amongst their options.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.234imgightsofthe inline]

Silver Order Squire

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.235imgightsofthe inline]

Statblock: @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.TmSzCBo3qK5GuCxG]{Silver Order Squire}

Dressed in leathers, and carrying a short sword, shield, and shortbow, the young squire hefts a small backpack of gear for maintaining and patching armor and weapons, griffon care, ammunition, and other essentials that may be needed on the field. They are eager to serve, and to prove themselves in battle.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef01.JournalEntryPage.215bioightsofthe inline]

Silver Order Recruit

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.236imgightsofthe inline]

Statblock: @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.eqfaVjk2GtMOIVRl]{Silver Order Recruit}

These simple foot soldiers make up the bulk of the ground troops for the Silver Order. Fitted with decent armor and shields, a longsword, and the emblems of the Silver Order, they are the first lines of defense against otherworldly monsters and magical threats.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef01.JournalEntryPage.216bioightsofthe inline]

Silver Order Paladin

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.237imgightsofthe inline]

Statblock: @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.HVDVBvOWzFEBjUwy]{Silver Order Paladin}

Garbed in heavy armor with blue capes lined in silver trim, embroidered with the symbol of the Silver Order, the paladin holds a large kite shield, and a glowing radiant mace.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef01.JournalEntryPage.217bioightsofthe inline]

They spent years studying and memorizing scripture, but do any scriptures teach you how to cut a troll in half? I think not!

Silver Order Cavalier

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.238imgightsofthe inline]

Statblock: @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.fRbNu51V32Hiu1ED]{Silver Order Cavalier}

Garbed in heavy armor with blue capes lined in silver trim, embroidered with the symbol of the Silver Order, the paladin's helmet has a large blue plume. A quiver of javelins rests upon their back.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef01.JournalEntryPage.218bioightsofthe inline]

I enjoy seeing a magnificant lion-bird, the great hunters of the sky. Do they eat seeds? Probably rats.

Flamekeeper

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.239imgightsofthe inline]

Statblock: @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.vk26hMW1ry7SDHrj]{Flamekeeper}

Dressed in white and gold robes adorned with the holy symbols of the Sacred Flame, the Flamekeeper recites prayers and holds a burning candle. Warding off evil and healing its allies, it stands as a protective beacon to the Knights of the Silver Order.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef01.JournalEntryPage.219bioightsofthe inline]

I'll show you who should be keeping the flame! It's me, with my awesome sword.

High Flamekeeper Ophelia Reed

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.240imgightsofthe inline]

Statblock: @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.LdKQe0I0M41E35vX]{High Flamekeeper Ophelia Reed}

A stout woman in her late forties with rich brown skin stands invitingly before you. Her warm smile is framed by rounded features and braided hair. She wears the flowing gold and white robes of a Flamekeeper of the Sacred Flame. She carries a silvered staff and a censer with a Continual Flame spell cast upon it.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef01.JournalEntryPage.220bioightsofthe inline]

Knight-Captain Theodore Marshal

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.241imgightsofthe inline]

Statblock: @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.AYTv1RTdQRXU67jr]{Knight-Captain Theodore Marshal}

Theodore Marshal is athletic and tall with boldly sculpted features, bronzed skin, and unkempt sandy brown hair. Unshaven stubble has grown into a beard over the criss-cross of scars on his face. A leather eye patch covers his right eye. He wears gleaming silver plate armor etched with golden trim, and carries a shimmering sword a broad shield engraved with the symbol of the Sacred Flame.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef01.JournalEntryPage.221bioightsofthe inline]

Hooded Lanterns.name: Hooded Lanterns
Hooded Lanterns.text:
Hooded Lanterns

T he The Hooded Lanterns are an irregular military force drawn from remnants of the old Drakkenheim City Watch and veterans of the Westemär Civil War, led by the grim Lord Commander Elias Drexel. They wish to drive out the monsters and outlaws who infest their nation's capital, find an heir to the throne, and restore the realm of Westemär.

The Hooded Lanterns are divided into three regiments which occupy the city and the areas surrounding it. New recruits joining the Lanterns are often first put into the Support Regiment. They make up the chefs, apothecaries, scribes, and maintenance workers at every Hooded Lantern fortification. Many of those positions are held by folk who will never move beyond the Support Regiment, and their job is valuable to the foundations of the Hooded Lanterns.

The Watch Regiment defend the walls and gates of any Lantern-controlled location. Oftentimes, if the Vanguards manage to gain a new foothold in the city, a group of Hooded Lanterns Watch are sent to hold the new position and ensure it remains in the Hooded Lanterns' hands. They also often operate as scouts in the field. Not specifically aiming for tactical engagement or large-scale battles, but they are the eyes and ears of the Lanterns throughout the city and occasionally clean up wandering monsters from the streets near their bases.

The Vanguard Regiment are the front line of the Hooded Lanterns. They are skilled combatants, who know their way around the ruins of the city and can find vantage points, plan ambushes, secure positions, and dispose of monster dens and other enemies. Vanguards are often soldiers who have proven themselves as reliable and talented Watch or Support Regiment and aim to prove themselves further in the city.

Combat Tactics

The Hooded Lanterns rarely go into a fight without a plan. They set up ambushes, tailoring an encounter to put them at an advantage. They know their territory and can navigate the ruins of the city with relative ease compared to most adventurers who journey into Drakkenheim. They travel in well-equipped groups, and often carry tools to alert other nearby scouting parties if they need help.

The Hooded Lanterns are skilled archers. They often occupy rooftops and ruined towers. If they expect combat to occur, they position soldiers with bows in any nearby vantage points with a clear view of their allies down on the streets. They place scouts in ruined buildings to keep eyes on the streets and run for aid if a combat breaks out. The Lanterns lay traps and ambushes before their enemies have entered the area. Hooded Lanterns are often incredibly prepared and use the ruins as camouflage for their attack.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.242imgodedlanter inline]

Hooded Lantern Scout

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.243imgodedlanter inline]

Statblock: @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.HNqjLxavQzH8PrV9]{Hooded Lantern Scout}

This lightly-armored urban scout is armed with a grapple gun, flare gun, shortsword, and longbow. They wear tight and simple garb to help them with mobility, with patches of boiled leather to protect critical areas. A simple green cloak and hood signify their allegiance to the Lanterns.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef01.JournalEntryPage.223bioodedlanter inline]

Very reliable are the scouts of the Hooded Lanterns however with great eyes come weak abdomens.

Hooded Lantern Trapper

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.244imgodedlanter inline]

Statblock: @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.e4KBNMeI6TFAIht4]{Hooded Lantern Trapper}

This Hooded Lantern field agent wears a green tunic emblazoned with the symbol of the Hooded Lanterns, and a belt heavy with hanging tools, satchels of powders, and vials of liquids. Their large backpack is loaded with rope, animal traps, containers, small wooden kegs and boxes, and all sorts of gear for building and setting traps in the field. The Trapper wears thick leather boots and gloves, heavy worker goggles, and a dirt smeared face with wild hair.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef01.JournalEntryPage.224bioodedlanter inline]

The Hooded Lanterns traps can be as deadly to monsters as I am, but I require less preparation.

Hooded Lantern Apothecary

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.245imgodedlanter inline]

Statblock: @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.5arr5iK2yaIlbV2V]{Hooded Lantern Apothecary}

Hooded Lantern Apothecaries are the Lanterns' field medics. Called Apothecaries, they are distinct from other Hooded Lanterns, often wearing a white tunic with a simple green Hooded Lanterns insignia. They have a leather hood and typically carry a large doctor bag and a bandelier of vials for various ailments or poisons. They carry several medical instruments on their belt.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef01.JournalEntryPage.225bioodedlanter inline]

Having an apothecary around can help if you've had a bad day. Of course, a good sword can prevent a bad day from ever happening.

Hooded Lantern Veteran

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.246imgodedlanter inline]

Statblock: @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.DEChFynLz6uIY99I]{Hooded Lantern Veteran}

These Hooded Lanterns are garbed in dark and rustic armor whose colors match and blend with the city ruins of Drakkenheim. They wear cloaks of deep green and carry well-made precision longbows. They wear masks that cover their nose and mouths to limit the sound of their breathing, and are equipped with grapple guns to scale walls quickly.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef01.JournalEntryPage.226bioodedlanter inline]

I've never had a bad day in Drakkenheim, except the first day, and maybe one more.

Lieutenant Petra & Captain Ansom Lang

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.247imgodedlanter inline]

Statblocks: @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.UqNnWp8RxC7yk5xa]{Lieutenant Petra Lang}, @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.nRq8fq6ANfGxlWsh]{Captain Ansom Lang}

Petra Lang is a fit and nimble teenager with long black hair, a narrow, pointed chin, and bold features. She wears the Lanterns' hooded green cloak and light studded leather armor with a lieutenant's insignia on her shoulder pauldron.

Ansom Lang is an athletic teenager with long black hair and a short neat beard, angular jaw, and rugged features. He is garbed in a hooded green cloak and studded leather armor of the Hooded Lanterns that prominently displays a captain's insignia on his shoulder.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef01.JournalEntryPage.227bioodedlanter inline]

Nothing like family to keep you honest. That and a sword that makes you tell the truth.

Lord Commander Elias Drexel

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.248imgodedlanter inline]

Statblock: @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.Y8YrNgJuWiyliOwk]{Lord Commander Elias Drexel}

Elias Drexel is a man in his early fifties. He is stocky and imposing with a furrowed brow and a grim frown on his wide and angular face. His harsh features are framed with a thick moustache, side chops, and mane of long braided brown hair. He is garbed in chainmail armor with heavy leather gloves and boots, worn under a fur-lined dark green cloak and iron pauldrons. He wears a pinned brooch depicting the Seal of Drakkenheim, the symbol of his office as Lord Commander. A quiver, a longbow, and two longswords are strung on his back.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef01.JournalEntryPage.228bioodedlanter inline]

Appendix C: Contamination, Delerium & ne.name: Appendix C: Contamination, Delerium & new Conditions

Contamination.name: Contamination
Contamination.text:
@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.252appendixccove inline]

Appendix C:
Contamination, Delerium, & New Conditions

Contamination

C haracters Characters in the world of Drakkenheim may be exposed to eldritch pollutants or arcane radiation emitted by delerium. These hazards cause a new condition called Contamination, which causes otherworldly Mutations that have both detrimental and beneficial effects.

Contamination [Condition]

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef00.JournalEntryPage.wgt7Kv5VTCzIwOR1 inline] @Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef02.JournalEntryPage.80gainmutations0 inline] @Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef02.JournalEntryPage.90longrestcontam inline] @Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef02.JournalEntryPage.100removingconta inline] @Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef02.JournalEntryPage.110dyingwithcont inline] @Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef02.JournalEntryPage.120monstroustran inline] @Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef02.JournalEntryPage.130reverttransfo inline]

New Spell

Purge Contamination

Level 3 Abjuration (Bard, Cleric, Druid, Paladin, Ranger, Sorcerer, Warlock, Wizard)

Casting Time: 1 hour

Range: Touch

Components: V, S, M (100 gp of alchemical fluids or holy water, which the spell consumes)

Duration: Instantaneous

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.features.Item.zgfmQrRMpvBoPAnB inline]

What's Changed?

Veterans of the Drakkenheim setting may notice these Contamination rules are slightly different from the original ones presented in Dungeons of Drakkenheim. Now that we've been using the Contamination rules for a few years, we felt there was an opportunity for refinement. Here's a summary of what's different from the rules originally printed:

  • Contamination Level 4 now causes the Weakened condition; this is mechanically similar to the original Symptom but uses the new Conditions in this book.
  • Contamination Level 5 now causes the Dazed condition instead of the Incapacitated condition. Player characters should find this gives them a solid opportunity to survive at this high contamination level, and villainous adversaries can now recklessly force a monstrous transformation upon themselves by casting a contaminated spell!
  • The Mutations table has been expanded to a d100 table with 50 different possibilities. As before, most mutations remain beneficial or cosmetic, but there are a few drawbacks sprinkled among them.
  • The Arcane Anomalies table has similarly been expanded to a d100 table with 50 different options. If you've been following the development of this project, you may be wondering where the Greater Arcane Anomalies went: many have been rolled into the new table.
  • The monsters introduced in this book offer a great selection of choices for Monstrous Transformations!

Delerium.text:
Delerium

D elerium Delerium is a magical mineral left behind by the meteor that landed in Drakkenheim. It appears in geode clusters of translucent, sharp-edged crystals which reflect octarine light. The eldritch stones softly hum in dissonant tones, and glow brightly at night or when exposed to magic. Deposits are found throughout Drakkenheim, often fused into stone streets and buildings like crystalline moss.

A typical delerium fragment is about the size of a finger. Crystals may be fist-sized or slightly larger, and geodes may be as big as a pumpkin. Massive clusters might grow taller than a human.

Crafting and Harvesting.name: Crafting and Harvesting
Crafting and Harvesting.text:
Appendix D:
Crafting & Harvesting

T his This appendix presents rules player characters may use to create magic items using components harvested from defeated monsters. Here you'll find:


  • Rules for Harvesting Components from slain foes. The monster descriptions earlier in this book detail the specific monster parts player characters can harvest from each creature.
  • Rules and recipes for creating new magic items found in the world of Drakkenheim using parts from monsters in this book!
  • Descriptions for various Workshops where characters can build their items.

These rules are intended to replace the typical magic item crafting found in the Fifth Edition Core Rules. You should choose which system works best for your campaign rather than combining these rules with other magic item crafting systems.

Crafting Overview.name: Crafting Overview
Crafting Overview.text:
Crafting Overview

In brief, here's how characters craft items using these rules:

  1. Learn the Recipe. The player characters must first find the Recipe for the magic item they want to create, which identifies its properties and the Components needed. The Recipe also details the types of monsters from which the Components must be harvested. Permanent items, such as weapons and armor, require between four and ten Components, while consumables, like potions and scrolls, only need two or three.
  2. Harvest the Components. After the player characters defeat a monster, they can spend ten minutes to Harvest and preserve Components from the corpse. This process must be completed quickly after a monster dies, otherwise the Component's innate magic fades. The Game Master describes what Components are available, and then each player character may choose to harvest one Component (regardless of how many foes were defeated). This abstractly represents how Components can be damaged in battle, ruined by harvesting, or of insufficient quality for crafting.
  3. Locate a Workshop. Once the required Components are collected, the characters must bring them to a suitable Workshop to build the item. Workshops have a rarity that corresponds to the magic items which may be produced there. Uncommon or Rare Workshops may be found in great cities, whereas Very Rare and Legendary Workshops are only found in fantastic locations with powerful magical phenomena present, such as magma forges deep in the heart of the earth and arcane laboratories constructed along extraplanar rifts.
  4. Construct the Item. The characters spend one day working at the Workshop to combine the Components, and their new magic item is complete!

Component and Workshop Rarity

Components and Workshops have a rarity, which correspond to the rarity of the magic item made with them. For example, an Uncommon magic item typically calls for Uncommon Components and must be created at an Uncommon workshop. This rarity also provides a rough gauge for what level characters should be able to craft the item.

The rarity of harvested Components are based on the monster's Challenge Rating. Unless otherwise specified, a component's rarity is defined by the Component Rarity table.

Component Rarity

Component Rarity

Monster Challenge Rating

Common

1/4 to ½

Uncommon

1 to 4

Rare

5 to 10

Very Rare

11 to 16

Legendary

17+

The rarity of the Components and workshop used in crafting always determine the highest rarity item they can produce. You can use higher rarity Components and Workshops to produce lower rarity items. For example, if a recipe calls for an Uncommon part, such as monster blood, a character may substitute Rare monster blood to fill the requirements of the Recipe.

How Often Do Characters Craft an Item?

Assuming that the player characters face about 4 to 8 combat encounters per character level against non-humanoid foes over the course of an entire campaign, each player character can craft the following quantities of permanent magic items:

  • 3–4 Uncommon
  • 2–3 Rare
  • 1–2 Very Rare
  • 1 Legendary

These numbers are approximate but are provided to offer a baseline set of expectations which you can adjust accordingly based on how many magic items you wish your player characters to possess. Characters may craft many more Common magic items, as well as many consumable magic items (potions and scrolls) of all rarities.

We recommend adjusting the amount of treasure found in your campaign when you use these rules. Characters should find about half as many magic items as they normally would, since they'll be crafting their own instead.

This is Not an Economic System!

Our objective for these rules was to offer player characters a way to create magic items for their use during adventures. Crafting flows from the adventure's narrative, with every magic item having an evocative tale with its creation. While this system can handle characters occasionally selling items, its not suited for those looking to run a business “farming” monsters for Components, building items, and selling them for profit. Similarly, these rules should not be extrapolated into a setting's functional economy. This system is about functional gameplay that tells a rewarding story, not creating a realistic simulation.

We recommend discussing these rules during Session Zero before using them at your table. We felt that the fun of this system would be spoiled with restrictions to prevent economic abuse. We didn't want an overly analytical approach to get in the way of fun. Frankly, no rules-based safeguards are as effective as setting the expectations at the start of a campaign for how these rules may be used.

For those looking for narrative justification, the Edicts of Lumen limit magic item creation and sale to the Amethyst Academy, and the mages strictly control this trade. Nevertheless, NPCs may discuss using Components, the need for appropriate facilities, and share recipes with the player characters. Indeed, the Amethyst Academy does pay adventurers to collect Components for them. However, proficient adventurers, capable craftspeople, and suitable monsters, especially higher-level ones, are relatively scarce. The player characters are amongst the few who are in a position to craft magic items using the rules presented here.

Step 1 - Learning Recipes.name: Step 1 - Learning Recipes
Step 1 - Learning Recipes.text:
Step 1: Learning Recipes

Every magic item has a Recipe which lists the monster parts required to craft the item and the type of workshop used to construct it.

Most items require between three and ten parts to create. For example, a +1 Weapon must be created at an Uncommon Workshop and requires the following Uncommon Components:

  • [Animus] Any Animus.
  • [Bones] Any Bones.
  • [Natural Weapon] Any Natural Weapon.
  • [Hide] Any Hide.

Recipes vary from item to item, but most call for monster parts from at least two or three different creatures or sources.

Characters can learn Recipes in three main ways: Finding Schematics, Purchasing Schematics, or through Research.

Finding Schematics

Most often, characters learn how to craft a particular magic item by finding a Schematic. These documents reveal the rarity, type, and full properties for a crafted magic item, as well as all Components needed to create it. A Schematic may be found as treasure placed by the Game Master or given as a reward for completing a quest.

A Schematic takes the form of written or illustrated plans, such as a diagram on parchment, an instruction manual, or inscriptions upon ancient ruins. A master craftsperson might be able to teach the player characters how to make an Uncommon or Rare magic item, whereas Schematics for Very Rare and Legendary items may be knowledge gleaned from the whispers of an otherworldly entity, ancient archmage, or powerful dragon.

Learning Components from a Schematic is an ideal method to kick off a “scavenger hunt” side-quest for the player characters. Plans in hand, they know what they need to get, but it's up to them to locate the monsters and Components needed. Schematics encourage the characters to keep a careful eye out for rare or interesting creatures, and perhaps search a little more thoroughly through the deep dungeons and dark streets of Drakkenheim for a rare prize.

Purchasing Schematics

Occasionally, player characters may have the opportunity to purchase a Schematic. The Schematic Pricing table below details suggested prices based on the rarity of the finished item:

Typical Price

I like the recipes with pictures and arrows so I can get right down to business.

Research

During their adventures, player characters may gather all manner of curious Components, but they may not know exactly what magic items can be created from these collected materials. In such cases, the player characters may study the found parts to discover possible Recipes on their own. This method allows the player characters to discover a magic item Recipe piecemeal, and creates the feeling the characters are inventing or discovering something new.

During a Long Rest, a character can examine a number of Components equal to their Intelligence modifier (minimum one Component). Once they finish a Long Rest, the character learns the Recipe for one magic item the studied Component can be used to create. Since some monster Components can be used to create a variety of different items, an individual Component can be studied multiple times.

Instant Discovery

If the player characters have collected all the monster parts needed to craft an item, but haven't yet learned the Recipe, they discover the full Recipe once they research any one of the required parts. Seeing all the parts together is enough for a flash of inspiration!

Step 2 - Harvesting Components.name: Step 2 - Harvesting Components
Step 2 - Harvesting Components.text:
Step 2: Harvesting Components

Characters may harvest and preserve Components from the corpse of a slain creature using monster harvesting tools.

Harvesting monster components or extracting its animus must begin within ten minutes of its death. After this time, the magical energy within fades and the animus passes to the ether, and any remaining Components are no longer usable for creating magic items.

No ability checks are required to successfully harvest monsters or extract an animus. As long as a character has the time and tools, they always successfully collect one monster Component from a creature's corpse. The toolkit provides everything a character needs to extract and preserve parts from any creature.

  • Monster Harvesting Tools (50 GP). The toolkit provides everything characters need to extract animus and preserve any creature parts. This kit contains skinning knives, a cleaver, syringes, a hammer, scissors, scalpels, a bone saw, hooks, as well as a vials, watertight containers, binding reagents, and wrappings.

Monster Components

When the characters decide to harvest a monster's corpse, the Game Master determines which Components can be harvested from a monster, if any. In this book, each monster entry lists the Components available from that creature.

Component Rarity

The rarity of all parts are determined by the CR of the monster as presented by the table earlier in this chapter.

Most item recipes call for Components with the same rarity as the item itself. However, some recipes may call for a component from a specific named monster, such as a Frost Giant, an Ancient Red Dragon, or a Banshee. In such cases, if no part of the presented rarity is available for a monster of that type, the DM should allow a component of a lower rarity to be used. For example, the ghost site bow is a Very Rare item that requires the bones of a Dryad and the hair of a Banshee. In this case, these components require you to find any Dryad or Banshee and do not require the parts to be Very Rare.

Component Categories

Each Component belongs to one of the following categories:

  • Animus. This special Component is described below.
  • Bones. This includes the skull, spine, or the stem of a plant monster.
  • Dust. Detritus left behind by magical creatures or undead.
  • Fluid. Usually monster blood, and also ectoplasm, sap, or mucus.
  • Hair. Any fur or feathers.
  • Hide. Includes the monster's skin, scales, carapace, bark, or plates.
  • Natural Weapons. Almost any natural weapon from the monster's game statistics, such as teeth, claws, horns, tentacles, etc.
  • Organs. A broad category including both internal body parts and sensory organs, such as the heart, brain, glands, eyes, or guts.

Magical Animus

In the world of Drakkenheim, magic items are created by imbuing a physical object with a metaphysical animus. This vital energy must be properly extracted from a magical creature. A creature's animus is formed from the latent magical energy held within its body, but it is distinct from a creature's soul. Aberrations, Celestials, Constructs, Dragons, Elementals, Fey, Fiends, Giants, Monstrosities, Plants, Oozes, and Undead all possess a magical animus. Beasts and Humanoids typically do not possess an animus.

When a creature is slain, its animus lingers momentarily before fading into the ether. However, a creature's animus can be collected and contained within a vessel of some kind, which is then used to make a magical item. It is impossible to extract the animus of a creature without killing it.

Creating magic items requires the animus of one or more suitably powerful creatures. However, some magic items may call for a specific type of animus, such as the animus of a fey creature or dragon. In rare cases, a magic item may require the animus of a much more specific monster.

Animus Vessels. An animus must be collected and stored in a specially prepared magical vessel. Traditionally, these vessels were minor magic items in their own right: often rune-etched gemstones infused with magic and created in a laborious process. However, the world of Drakkenheim was transformed by the arrival of delerium: the eldritch crystals function as suitable vessels in their raw state. A delerium crystal filled with magical animus glows with a brilliant octarine light, similar to how the crystals resonate with energy when exposed to magic.

Creating Animus Vessels. An animus vessel can be created in 1 hour by combining any three other components of the same rarity. The resulting vessel can then be used as a vessel for an animus of the corresponding rarity. For example, an animus made from three Rare components can hold a Rare animus.

Animus Vessel Crystal Sizes

Animus Rarity

Harvest and Extraction Time

Once started, collecting Components or animus takes ten minutes of work. During this time, the character must remain within 5 feet of the corpse. If the process is interrupted, harvesting must resume within ten minutes, or the Components are lost. A player character may only harvest Components from one creature at a time, regardless of its size. Several characters can work together to harvest multiple parts from the same corpse. No matter how many characters harvest a single corpse, they must all spend ten minutes harvesting.

Collector's Choice

Each character may harvest one component from a creature's corpse per encounter.

Characters can work together to harvest several different parts from one monster, or they may split up and harvest parts from several creatures at once. A monster's body usually provides only one of each available part, so two characters harvest

ing parts from the same corpse must choose to collect different parts, unless the Game Master determines that the creature's unique physiology allows the collection of multiples of the same part. For example, a Game Master might allow both horns from a Minotaur to be harvested, but it would take the work of two characters to collect both. Other parts may be more abstract in quantity: it's enough to know that the characters collected a bag of dragon fangs or a vial of troll blood without worrying about a specific measurement.

When the player characters decide to butcher a carcass for Components, the Game Master lists all the possible Components available from the body. Each character may then choose one Component to collect. All other Components are lost and unusable, either because they were damaged in battle, ruined in the harvesting process, or deemed of unsuitable quality for magic item crafting.

Example Harvesting

For example, suppose the player characters defeat a Gorgon. They decide to harvest parts from its corpse. The Game Master describes that the Gorgon has the following Rare Components: eyes (organ), a skull (bones), monster blood (fluid), plates (hide), horns (natural weapon), glands (organs), and its animus. There are three player characters, and all work together to harvest parts from the Gorgon. Sebastian decides to collect the Gorgon's Animus, Pluto decides to take the Gorgon's plates, and Veo decides to take the Gorgon's monster blood. All the other parts are lost.

In another case, suppose four player characters defeat a small horde of ten Ratling Warriors. The party would only be able to collect parts from four of them. The parts from the other monsters are lost.

Keeping Records

When recording what monster parts the player characters have collected, it's important to identify the Component's name category, as well as the name, creature type, and rarity of the creature. For example, a character might record the following Components:

  • Minotaur, horns (natural weapon). Uncommon Monstrosity.
  • Vampire, undead dust (dust). Rare Undead.
  • Troll, skin (hide). Uncommon Giant.
  • Adult Red Dragon, monster blood (fluid). Legendary Dragon.

Recording how many bones characters collect from a slain red dragon, or how many vials of blood characters drain from the corpse of a dead troll, isn't necessary. Regardless of a creature's actual size or dimensions, a character harvests enough material from its corpse to fulfill the ingredients required for a single magic item. Simply recording “Red Dragon monster blood” or “Troll hide” is sufficient. If characters collect the blood or hide from multiple dragons or trolls, simply record “3x Red Dragon blood” or “3x Troll's hide.”

Component Weight. In general, most Components weigh no more than 1 pound each. When tracking the weight of individual Components, consider the final weight of the constructed item it will be used to create. Most weapons, wondrous items, and consumables weigh between 1 and 5 pounds, so most Components should fall within this range. The Game Master may determine that certain Components intended for use in medium or heavy armor (or other bulky items) weigh substantially more. For example, dragon scales or gorgon plates collected for use in scale or plate armor could weigh as much as 50 pounds.

Buying and Selling Components

Talented arcanists, artificers, and forgesmiths alike frequently eschew the adventuring life, preferring to commission adventurers to procure rare Components for magic item crafting on their behalf.

Buying and selling Components is an optional downtime activity characters can engage in between their adventures.

Most often, those purchasing Components are looking for a specific Component or two, and seek the services of dedicated monster hunters to retrieve their materials. Even the industrious Amethyst Academy rarely makes an unsolicited purchase, and the mages are seldom willing to purchase anything presented to them.

Typically, finding a seller or buyer for a monster Component takes a number of days equal to the Challenge Rating of the monster.

Why Only One Item?

These rules intentionally abstract monster harvesting. Instead of rolling to determine whether or not they harvest parts, or how many parts are harvested, it is simply one part per character per harvest. This prevents the player characters from finding more monster parts than expected (and thus being able to craft more magic items than intended). Similarly, this restriction minimizes the amount of required bookkeeping. Even taking one monster part per character will result in the characters holding on to a lot of crafting materials, and we wanted to avoid clogging up their inventories with hundreds of items they won't ever use.

Gently slide your knife along the spine,or as close to what could be considered a spine, the primary spine.

Step 3 - Find a Workshop.name: Step 3 - Find a Workshop
Step 3 - Find a Workshop.text:
Step 3: Find a Workshop

Crafting magical items also requires a suitably equipped Workshop to create the item, such as a blacksmith's forge, arcane laboratory, or artisan's studio. While a typical blacksmith's forge is fine for making steel, it is ill-suited to working with dragonbone, demonic animus, troll's blood, and elemental earth!

In addition to providing all the tools and equipment necessary, a Workshop also supplies all mundane materials needed for crafting magic items. A forge has an ample supply of coal, iron, and steel, for example, whereas an arcane laboratory or artisan studio has paper, inks, chemicals, and other materials characters would logically need to supplement the monster Components.

Workshop Rarity

Like monster parts, each Workshop has a rarity from Common to Legendary. The Workshop's rarity corresponds to the maximum rarity of the magic items which may be created working there. Creating a Rare magic item requires a Rare Workshop, but a Legendary Workshop could be used to fashion an Uncommon magic item, for example.

Common Workshops

These Workshops are made for fashioning everyday mundane equipment, and usually lack the specialized and magical tools needed for making magic items. However, they're usually sufficient for making Common magic items, or consumables such as potions and scrolls.

Uncommon Workshops

Characters can find Uncommon Workshops in towns and larger settlements. Examples include the finest blacksmith's forge in the region, or a typical wizard's tower.

Crowe and Sons Smithy

In Emberwood Village, just outside the city of Drakkenheim sits the Crowe and Sons Smithy. Tobias Crowe is a humble family man who has worked the forge his whole life. His forge is well stocked with all the mundane gear someone would need to craft basic items, and Tobias himself has worked magical gear in the forge as long as he has the right supplies. He is always willing to let adventurers who show they know what they are doing handle the forge, and often aids them in the crafting of unique magic items.

The forge sits under a wooden overhang connected to an old shop. The wall is lined with tools and fitted with a table and shelves containing iron, wood, sacks of coal, brass, copper, leather straps and much more. The old stone forge has a large bellow that you can operate by foot and a rustic and worn anvil next to a metal bucket of cool water.

Rare Workshops

Rare Workshops are usually only found in large cities. These impressive facilities are equipped with state-of-the art tools and machinery, and able to import the finest raw materials from around the world.

Smithy on the Scar

The Smithy on the Scar was an old blacksmith shop taken over by a group of Ironhelm dwarves. They have refitted the forge to work delerium, meteoric iron, and gunpowder. They have all the tools needed for crafting fine magic items, gunpowder weapons, and some of the best dwarven inventions in the area. With a constant supply of delerium arriving, a group looking to use the forge need only do a seemingly simple task: help the Ironhelm dwarves and guard their forge through the night while they mine the delerium in the scar. Do this, and they will happily allow you to access their gear and make any weapons you need.

Apothecary Laboratory

Beneath Altbruke University is a labyrinthian series of corridors, tunnels, and workshops. Amongst them is a great Laboratory complete with a forge, alchemical gear, and a well-stocked storage of every rare element the school could get their hands on. It is better equipped for the crafting of unique potions, poisons, and tonics, but can also be used to craft unique magical items of exquisite design. The abundance of iron, leather, and steel the school has at its disposal means that if one can gain access to this forge, they will be well equipped to do any crafting needed. However, getting the apothecaries of Altbruke University to grant permission is another story.

Very Rare Workshops

Very Rare Workshops are built with access to a notable power source used to channel the great heat or mighty arcane forces needed to work with rare and valuable materials. Examples could include an adamantine forge located along a magma flow, or an arcane university channeling the energy of a Thin Place.

Inscrutable Tower Laboratories

In the lower chambers of the Inscrutable Tower lies the great Arcane Forge. The Tower is a conduit of sorts that draws in raw arcane energies and focuses them within the tower's nexus. Although the nexus powers many arcane devices throughout the tower, and used as a prime focus for magical practices throughout, the Arcane Forge also draws from this well of power when being used to craft exceptionally rare and powerful magical artifacts. Many of the Academy's most renowned artificers worked in the Arcane Forge. Even in the destruction of Drakkenheim, the forge remains well stocked with the gear needed to draw immense arcane power for forging items. The only issue is that the nexus is not fully operational and the tower needs to be brought back online to use the forge again.

Dwarven Volcano Forge

High in the Drakeclaw Mountains is the great Dragon's Maw, a sleeping volcano that was once home to the Firebrand dwarves, who built their great city in the heart of the caldera of the volcano, and harnessed the magma flows into a powerful dwarven forge. Fire elementals once worked the forge and crafted some of the finest dwarven weapons in history. The forge still sits amongst the ruins of this great dwarven empire and is completely operational. However, the ancient red dragon Volmongoth claimed the caldera centuries ago as their lair, and access to the forge has been near impossible since then. One would either need to treat with Volmongoth for access or defeat them in battle. Neither seems likely.

Legendary Workshops

A Legendary Workshop is a one-of-a-kind place built in special locations due to the magical phenomena present. Indeed, these storied places are seldom found in the Mortal World at all and may require travel to other dimensions or worlds.

Space Between Worlds Star Forge

Deep within the Space Between Worlds, on a floating pile of rubble within the Void Sea, sits the Star Forge. There is no record of who built the Star Forge, or what its intention was. Perhaps just a strange random happenstance amongst the chaotic possibilities, or maybe a chunk of rock drawn in from some distant dimension, the Star Forge can harness the very fabric of arcane magic from the roiling cosmos of the Space Between Worlds and channel that into the gear made within it. For those seeking to harness unimaginable power into their creations, journeying into the Space Between Worlds and seeking out this forge is one of the few known paths to creating such potent items. Getting there is nearly impossible, and is only half the problem, for firing up the forge draws the attention of all number of eldritch beings, who feed on the raw arcana that flow into the forge. One must survive the onslaught long enough to finish their gear, and then escape with it.

Workshop Quests

Locating a suitable Workshop can be a quest all on its own. However, a Game Master may wish to add an additional complication or problem:

  • The Workshop's power source has been damaged or stolen, and the characters must retrieve a replacement and conduct necessary repairs.
  • The Workshop has run out of raw materials or fuel. For example, a dwarven forge relied on a nearby iron mine which has been overrun by monsters, or bandits raided the supply caravans supplying alchemical materials for an apothecaries' lab. The characters must recover the Components or deal with the issue before the Workshop can be used.
  • The Workshop is owned or run by a powerful individual or faction who will not allow the characters to use it until they complete a mission to prove their worthiness or demonstrate their capabilities.

Step 4 - Craft an Item.name: Step 4 - Craft an Item
Step 4 - Craft an Item.text:
Step 4: Craft the Item

Once the characters have collected their items, learned the Recipe, and brought all Components to a suitable Workshop, it's time to make the item!

Creating the item only requires a few hours of diligent work. Set the pace appropriate for the campaign and the part of the narrative: it's fine for the characters to spend an hour making the item, or a day. An extended period of downtime isn't necessary: this system makes the characters take an active role collecting the Components, Schematics, and crafting Workshop rather than downtime and gold.

Interlopers!

At your option, characters crafting a Legendary magic item may have to do battle against invaders seeking to stop them in the process! This can make for a fun and climatic end to an adventure arc.

Doing so is a simple skill challenge: completing the magic item requires the characters spend a number of actions to finish the item.

Each round, magical invaders, such as elementals, outsiders, demons, or spirits, appear to try to stop the characters completing the item. They won't relent until the item is finished.
