SRD Recipes

Recipes for a selection of magic items are detailed below.

Armor, +1, +2, or +3

  • +1 armor: Any Rare Animus; any Rare Bones, any Rare Skull [Bones], and any Rare Hide, and any Rare Hair. Each item must come from a different monster.
  • +2 armor: Any Very Rare Animus; any Very Rare Bones, any Very Rare Natural Weapon, any Very Rare Hide, and any Very Rare Hair. Each item must come from a different monster.
  • +3 armor: Any Legendary Animus; any Legendary Bones, any Legendary Natural Weapon, any Legendary Hide, and any Legendary Hair. Each item must come from a different monster.

Potion of Healing

  • Healing: Any Common Animus, any Common Fluid, and any Common Organ.
  • Greater Healing: Any Uncommon Animus, any Uncommon Fluid, and any Uncommon Organ.
  • Superior Healing: Any Rare Animus, any Rare Fluid, and any Rare Organ.
  • Supreme Healing: Any Very Rare Animus, any Very Rare Fluid, and any Very Rare Organ.

Potion of Resistance

Any Uncommon Animus, any Uncommon Elemental Fluid, any Uncommon Dust, any Uncommon Organ.

Shield, +1, +2, or +3

  • +1 shield: Any Uncommon Animus; any Uncommon Bones, any Uncommon Natural Weapon, and any Uncommon Hide. Each item must come from a different monster.
  • +2 shield: Any Rare Animus; any Rare Bones, any Rare Natural Weapon, and any Rare Hide. Each item must come from a different monster.
  • +3 shield: Any Very Rare Animus; any Very Rare Bones, any Very Rare Natural Weapon, and any Very Rare Hide. Each item must come from a different monster.

Spell Scroll

  • Cantrip or 1st level spell: Any Common Animus, any Common Fluid, any Common Hide.
  • 2nd or 3rd level spell: Any Uncommon Animus, any Uncommon Fluid, any Uncommon Hide.
  • 4th or 5th level spell: Any Rare Animus, any Rare Fluid, any Rare Hide.
  • 6th, 7th, or 8th level spell: Any Very Rare Animus, any Very Rare Fluid, any Very Rare Hide.
  • 9th level spell: Any Legendary Animus, any Legendary Fluid, any Legendary Hide.

Weapon, +1, +2, or +3

  • +1 weapon: Any Uncommon Animus; any Uncommon Bones, any Uncommon Natural Weapon, and any Uncommon Hide. Each item must come from a different monster.
  • +2 weapon: Any Rare Animus; any Rare Bones, any Rare Natural Weapon, and any Rare Hide. Each item must come from a different monster.
  • +3 weapon: Any Very Rare Animus; any Very Rare Bones, any Very Rare Natural Weapon, and any Very Rare Hide. Each item must come from a different monster.

Night Born Undeath.name: Night Born Undeath
Night Born Undeath.text:
Chapter 6:
Court of the Night

Night Born Undeath

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.146imghtbornunde inline]

"They appear in a lords court, a tribunal, a ceremony. Just ready to suck the life out of some prominent member of society or influence some noble. What a bunch of shadowy cowards. I do my best work in the daylight, and with an audience. These leeches go after the rich and powerful but I'd like to see them face a true Caspian."

—Pluto Jackson

H idden Hidden within the political squabbles of the continental nobility is an ancient conspiracy swathed in darkness and bound by blood. A few highborn houses have been ruled by vampires for centuries, their family leaders gifted with undead immortality yet cursed with sanguine cravings. Secretly preying upon their mortal subjects whilst concealing their undead nature from their noble peers, these vampire lords have in turn transformed their heirs, lieutenants, courtesans, and staff into obedient spawn to secure their lineage and loyalty.

Yet their dark ambitions do not end there, for the vampire aristocrats desire complete control and total domination over the people of the continent. Together, thirteen vampire-ruled noble houses established a sinister cabal and shadow government collectively known as the Court of the Night, a shadowy alliance that aims to influence and manipulate political affairs and eventually seize power. The Court of the Night works in the shadows, pulling noble puppet strings across the continent. Originally founded in the kingdom of Westemär, the Court of the Night's influence has spread, infiltrating the noble ranks of neighboring lands such as Caspia and Elyria.

The elusive vampires have managed to keep their plot undiscovered for hundreds of years. During this time, however, a few amongst the court and even entire vampire households have been exposed — sometimes by intrepid monster hunters, other times by the devout paladins of the Silver Order, or occasionally by the mages of the Amethyst Academy, or astute mortal nobles. While many exposed vampires have been eradicated, others have managed to escape and reestablish themselves elsewhere under new identities.

The few mortals who have come dangerously close to unraveling the full extent of the vampire conspiracy have faced grim fates. Some have disappeared without a trace, swallowed by the shadows that cloak the Court of the Night's operations. These unfortunate souls stumbled too deep into the vampires' secrets, provoking a lethal response to ensure their silence. Others, however, suffer a fate arguably worse than death: they are captured and transformed into thralls by the vampires. Stripped of their will and enslaved, these thralls serve their vampire masters, their former lives obliterated by vampiric compulsion and dark magic. This sinister practice ensures not only the continuation of the vampire's secrecy but also a sadistic reinforcement of their dominance over humans.

However, within the secretive bounds of the Court of the Night, an atmosphere of constant suspicion and ambition breeds endless betrayal and intrigue. The vampire households, each led by ancient and cunning undead lords, vie fiercely for influence and control. Alliances are as fleeting as they are strategic, formed to stabilize power or to execute swift betrayals when advantageous. The stakes of this internal power struggle are exceedingly high, as supremacy within the Court can grant unparalleled control over both the vampire and human realms. These internal conflicts often manifest in covert sabotages, assassinations, and intricate plots that further complicate the dynamics within the Court, making the hierarchy within this shadow government both volatile and deadly.

Vampiric Origins

Legends claim the vampiric curse first fell upon mortals who, hungry to extend their own lives, fed upon other's life essence through sanguine rites. Though they attained their coveted power and immortality, these first vampires were forever banished to the shadows for their dark predations. Ancient stories amongst those who keep the Old Faith attribute the curse to the fickle goddesses Morrigan, who laid the punishment upon heretical druids blasphemously seeking immortality in her name. Amongst the Faith of the Sacred Flame, vampirism represents a twisted and fallen soul utterly consumed by darkness and bloody impulses, one so completely shunned by the light they are destroyed by its very presence.

Though vampirism is unquestionably a curse, it is one that brings great power through unnatural abilities. As such, ambitious mortals have themselves often sought out the curse willingly. Unscrupulous warlocks have made dark pacts with demonic entities and become vampires in the process. Indeed, the tyrannical Sorcerer-Kings were masters of blood magic, wielding dark power to imbue their bloodlines with draconic and fiendish lineages. Many amongst them sought to establish an eternal empire through some form of immortality. Academy scholars speculate that several Sorcerer-Kings attained undeath through vampirism or lichdom, though their dreams of everlasting rule ended in betrayal by their own rivals.

As the Faith of the Sacred Flame rose in Elyria, these vampires and surviving blood mages fled its spreading light for other lands where they could more safely hide in the shadows. Meanwhile, in the deep forests of the lands which would one day become Westemär, descendants of the druids cursed by Morrigan still practiced their sanguine rites in secret, until a bloodthirsty ruler emerged who sought their cursed power for himself.

The legendary Vladimir von Drakken was a peerless swordman and ruthless warlord born in the late sixth century, who forged the nation of Westemär through bloody conquest over three decades of brutal invasion. Vladimir von Drakken carved a gore-streaked path through his neighbors and built a kingdom born out of genocidal massacres and brutal subjugation. He established himself as the Lord of Castle Drakken, naming Drakkenheim for his household. History tells that Vladimir von Drakken ruled as a despot and had imperial ambitions upon his neighbors in Elyria and Caspia. However, he was cut down by his rebellious daughter, Carmen, who succeeded her father's throne. While sensational stories about Vladimir von Drakken's bloodthirsty nature are scrawled into the margins of history, no records remain that tell the full story: Vladimir von Drakken was in fact a powerful ascendant vampire.

Two decades into his conquests, Vladimir von Drakken became paranoid that he would be betrayed and usurped by one of his lieutenants, or worse, by one of his own family members. Fearing his own death most of all, he sought out forbidden magic to grant him power and immortality. He found it in the form of vampirism. Deep within the Brachenwald, he was transformed in an unholy ritual known as the Sanguine Rite.

When he returned to Castle Drakken, Vladimir von Drakken turned his vassals into vampire spawn so that none could ever stand against him, holding them as thralls in his Court of the Night Over the next ten years, he continued his cruel and merciless campaign to dominate the lands of Westemär and beyond. Although he was struck down by his daughter, many members of his Court of the Night survived to carry on his legacy.

Calling of the Court

Originally comprised by the surviving vampiric vassals and lieutenants of Vladimir von Drakken, the court has grown over the centuries, both in power and influence, silently manipulating events and entities from behind the scenes as its members dispersed themselves across the continent.

Once every thirteen years, a malevolent meeting of the Court of the Night is held. During the founding decades of the Court, the families gathered in the Brachenwald of Westemär, at the ancient grove where the Druids of Morrigan transformed Vladimir von Drakken into a vampire. However, a more organized and central location space was needed as the vampiric court grew and the families spread throughout the continent and beyond.

Now, the secret meeting is held in the heart of the Free City of Liberio at Rossovino Manor. The cosmopolitan port and independent city-state is located on the Middle Sea, and represents a melting pot between the major nations of the continent. Given its inherent bustle of travel and trade, Liberio is no stranger to fantastic sights and sounds. Visitors from faraway places, mages, and all sorts of strange folk and adventurous types gather in the democratic city. Vampires can easily conceal their presence here and find no shortage of activities or appetizers during the warm nights in Liberio.

Each vampire family dispatches a delegation to attend once every thirteen years to discuss the next steps for the court. Though they often send grand contingents of vampires, spawn, and thralls, each family chooses two representatives to speak on their behalf. The vampires meet for nights, punctuated with dark revelry, macabre masquerades, and grisly feats which stretch into the long hours of the night. During these events, the vampires openly discuss their plots, their triumphs, their struggles, and how their goals may further the Court of the Night's longevity and prosperity. They review their plots and deception for their continued infiltration of the Mortal World.

Amongst the vampires, the Calling of the Court is a neutral ground, where all families must put aside infighting, backstabbing, past betrayals, and schemes against each other under penalty of true death. Yet, the vampires are conniving and clever — the Calling of the Court is the time to strengthen their shared goals and gain the support they need. If a rival or two can be eliminated before or after the gathering itself… so much the better.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.147imghtbornunde inline]

Vampiric Ideologies

Although to mortal eyes the Court of the Night appears to be a united faction, in truth, the vampiric nobility is deeply divided internally. Amongst their number have emerged three competing ideologies.

Resurrectionists

Steadfast in their oaths of eternal fealty to Vladimir von Drakken, the Resurrectionists plot nothing more than the return of the legendary vampire. Keepers of lore and ancient artifacts, the Resurrectionists are the most reclusive. They dream of the return of the mighty vampire lord, when he will bathe the world in blood and establish a true empire of the night, where mortals are lorded over like livestock to feed the ambition and power of the vampiric nobility.

Inheritors

The Inheritors arose in response to the slow and ponderous pace of the Resurrectionists plans. Impatient to await a long-dead lord of the night to return and command them, the Inheritors seek to claim the legacy of Vladimir von Drakken for themselves. Instead of returning the dread lord to power, each Inheritor instead dreams of usurping the might of the Vampire King for themselves. The Inheritors are a fractious and scheming organization. Each member ultimately wishes to rise in power over their peers, and so their grand plans are often fraught with subterfuge and sabotage.

Libertines

Growing in power and influence amongst the Court of the Night are a contingent of vampire lords who reject both the old ways of the Resurrectionists, and the scheming politics of the Inheritors. Instead, the Libertines seek to live out their undeath with lavish decadence and unholy debauchery, unfettered by the morals and responsibilities of mortal life. They crave wealth and power only because it fuels and supports their existence of excess. Avarice, lust, and pride prompts the Libertines to defend themselves and their holdings, often using the mortals they live so easily among to do their bidding.

Vampire Strains

There exist three main strains of vampiric affliction and two sub-strains. Each cause different physical manifestations and behavioral impulses, while granting diverse vampiric abilities. All three strains are present in the Court of the Night; typically, all the members of a household possess the same strain, though the strains occasionally mingle amongst one another and many courts and houses contain vampires from different strains.

Regardless of their strain, all vampires possess the same classic vampire weakness: vulnerability to sunlight.

Vampyre

The regal vampire standing before you scoffs and smiles devilishly as its fangs protrude. Its eyes take on a crimson hue as it gracefully lifts into the air, hovering slowly towards you, its cape billowing behind it. The well-dressed noble who stood before you is gone, now revealing its true form: that of a hungry vampire.

The Vampyre consider themselves the purest descendants of Vladimir von Drakken, believing they were crafted in his perfect image. They appear almost humanoid until they choose to reveal themselves and are the most well equipped for infiltrating human settlements. With their charm and wit, they blend in by standing out, becoming important members of the communities they intend to take over. Like a parasite, they infiltrate, spread, and devour until they have claimed the entire settlement, leaving behind a husk now filled with an undead army bent to the will of the vampiric family.

Many of the Vampyrs are positioned as powerful nobles in some of the greatest cities on the continent, and through them the Court of the Night has eyes and ears in every major decision, plot, or scheme made throughout the continent. Unbeknownst to the vast majority, the Vampyre are everywhere, leading the Court of the Night in their efforts for complete domination.

This is the most common and well-known strain of vampirism, the Vampyre are often represented by the game statistics for @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.DDO9lDCDtNHkfShP]{Vampires} found in the Core Rules. These vampires appear as regular humans with sullen and pallid flesh, sharpened features, crimson-hued eyes, and sharp fangs that they use to feed on blood. They possess greatly enhanced physical endurance, strength, speed, and intellect thanks to their vampiric curse. Their subtle and easily concealed features allow most Vampyres to blend in with mortal society. Many Vampyres consider themselves the most pure and refined of their kind, and many claim to be blood-borne descendants from Vladimir von Drakken, meaning they were transformed by the legendary vampire personally or turned by another vampire who can trace their own vampiric lineage back to Vladimir von Drakken.

The Vampyre are at the forefront of the Court of the Night's infiltration of civilization. They lurk in the shadows of established communities, pulling the strings in major cities throughout the continent. Using their cunning illusion and wit, the Vampyre have masterfully built a network of noble vampires leading the court in their goals of bringing about a revolution of blood.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.148imghtbornunde inline]

Nosferatu

The creature before you is humanoid in shape, appearing almost elven; they are slender and tall, with pointed ears. However, their complexion is sickly pale, and their sunken back crimson eyes give their gaunt face an almost skeletal appearance. Their fingers are gnarled elongated and end in dirty clawed nails. As the creature opens its mouths, its teeth are all fine points, razor sharp.

Amongst the Druids of the Old God Morrigan, several heretical sects emerged in ancient days, their origins shrouded in blood magic and sanguine rituals. These blood-drinking druids used magic to prolong their life indefinitely. They developed the vampiric curse that they shared amongst their small circles in the deep wilderness of the Brachenwald.

The Nosferatu are the descendants of these first druidic vampire cults. Over the centuries of blood drinking and sunlight aversion, they have developed extremely gaunt features, sunken eyes, and often skeletal appearances, pointed ears, and their teeth are all sharpened fangs.

Unlike their vampiric cousins, they cannot be killed by piercing the heart. They cannot enter a home without permission, cross a stream of running water, and are cursed to never see daylight again. More than most vampires, however, daylight destroys them almost instantly, so the Nosferatu tend to stick to shadows and dark places more than most.

Nosferatu Traits

Any vampire from the Nosferatu strain has the following traits.

Add missing features

Vrykolakas

The beast before you is half man and half bat. Its bald head has two bat-like ears and beady red eyes above a snout and a fanged mouth. It walks in a hunched gaunt, sometimes pulling itself forward on its burly forearms with long taloned claws, while its legs are shorter with wide-set clawed feet.

These monstrous vampires have taken on the bat-like qualities of vampirism to a place where they are no longer recognizable as humanoid. They still speak, walk, and carry themselves as well as other vampires, but their demeanor tends to be more ravenous and enraged. Rather than drinking blood, the Vrykolakas vampires gain their energy by consuming living flesh. They are more prone to outwardly attack their prey, and feast upon them while they scream.

The Vrykolakas vampires hunt in packs, and rather than hide themselves with illusions, they live in secluded castles and remote isolated caves. They sweep into small farming communities and villages in the dead of long winter nights and devour every living creature they find. There are some reports of entire communities going missing overnight, with nothing left but blood splatters in the snow.

The Vrykolakas vampires will change their appearance to appear as more humanoid when engaging in affairs with non vampires, but prefer their more animalistic appearance when they are on the hunt.

These vampires developed from a twisted form of undeath. The vampiric curse creates an eternal hunger for mortal blood, and a vampire who does not feed regularly develops more monstrous qualities over time. The Vrykolakas developed over years of starvation amongst sects of vampires, and as they became more twisted forms, the vampire spawn they would produce carried that hunger, and developed a taste for raw flesh, and could not come back from their monstrous nature.

Vrykolakas Traits

Any vampire from the Vrykolakas strain has the following traits.

Add missing features

Spawn

These lesser vampires use the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.zpaZb7I8alY32vWV]{Vampire Spawn} game statistics from the Core Rules. Vampire spawn are intermediate, they are under the control of the vampire who created them, but not yet granted full independence from their master. However, many develop unique abilities to fulfill their roles. The Crimson Knight, Dark Confessor, Grim Custodian, Night Blade, and Sanguine Witch all represent vampire spawn with specialized capabilities used to achieve their master's goals.

A vampire spawn becomes a full-strain vampire when they can partake in the blood of a full-blooded vampire. Often this is a gift granted by their own creator, and these stray spawn are often led to believe that only the blood of their creator can grant them their full vampiric powers. However, this is not the case: consuming the blood of any vampire will accomplish complete the transformation. A vampire spawn whose master is destroyed regains their autonomy but does not become a full-strain vampire.

Ascendant Vampire

Legend claims that a fourth strain of vampirism exists: the Ascendant Vampire. This mighty form is supposedly granted vast power encompassing all three lesser strains. Furthermore, it is claimed that such a vampire could walk unharmed in the light of the sun, and that their every word is a command to any other vampire. Members of the Court of the Night know this is no mere legend; Vladimir von Drakken was the first, and thus far, only vampire to gain this power. None since have been able to attain this form, though many have sought it over the centuries.

These monsters have a face only my blade could love.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.149imghtbornunde inline]

Vampire Families

The Court of the Night was founded by thirteen vampiric noble houses. Although some of these families have been uncovered, and in some cases eradicated, the dead houses' legacy lives on through vassals and thralls. The remaining families all hold positions of importance within the current political landscape of the continent, and unbeknownst to the wider world, are subtly manipulating the ebb and flow of power within the continent. In addition, several lesser families have sprung up over the centuries as a vassals in service or cadet branches of a higher household.

House Kleinkessel

Head Vampire: Constance Kleinkessel

Location: Kesselholm, Westemär

Ideology: Inheritor

Strain: Vampyre

House Kleinkessel is a cadet branch of House von Kessel, who were in turn themselves distant descendants of House von Drakken. The household formed shortly after Helena I von Kessel took the throne to separate the royal household from their extended family in matters of succession. Nevertheless, the Kleinkessels have perhaps one of the stronger claims to the throne of Westemär since they can trace their ancestry back to Helena I. In fact, when the main House von Kessel line ended during the Civil War, they took up the royal family's ancestral castle in Kesselholm.

Constance Kleinkessel is in fact the sister of Helena I. Originally known as Camilla von Kessel, she has passed through a series of identities to hide her vampiric nature. Every few decades, she marries a hapless nobleman, slowly draining his life force so that he appears to expire from old age. Shortly thereafter, her so-called daughter inherits the estate and the cycle continues. During the Civil War, Constance Kleinkessel used her vampiric abilities to manipulate and scheme alongside Cecilia von Kessel and Lord Commander Elias Drexel to plot the murder of Mannfred von Kessel. She had planned to follow through and murder her co-conspirators, but the subsequent death of Cecilia von Kessel was an unexpected development. Constance had been planning to target Cecilia's future children with her replacement scheme to seize the throne of Westemär.

Constance also witnessed the impact of delerium firsthand when a fleeing family of vampires came to her for help after the meteor fell. Impressed by its potency and effects on vampiric blood, but disheartened by the negative impact it had, she began studying the strange rocks, buying delerium in large quantities and experimenting on her lesser thralls, attempting to make a new breed of vampire. Her creation, she hopes, would be strong enough to rise above all the others.

Since undead creatures are not immune to the effects of delerium contamination, Constance Kleinkessel befriended and made close alliances with her Apothecary, the malfeasant wizard and mad chemist Deidrick Mors. Since then, they have been creating an army of delerium-infused vampires in secret in the chambers under Kesselholm Keep.

House Crossbruke

Head Vampire: Viktor Crossbruke

Location: Drakkenheim, Westemär

Ideology: Resurrectionist

Strain: Nosferatu

Baron Viktor Crossbruke was a steadfast captain who served Vladimir von Drakken in life, and was among the first of Vladimir von Drakken's vampire spawn, and among the first the Ascendant Vampire granted the boon of full-strain vampirism. Victor Crossbruke survived Carmen von Drakken's rebellion against her father, and was instrumental in securing Vlad's remains in the aftermath. He has been dedicated to the cause of restoring his old master ever since.

Viktor founded the village of Crossbruke four miles southwest of Drakkenheim. After Vladamir was struck down, he quietly secluded himself into a life managing the sleepy village. When the city of Drakkenheim was destroyed, much of the surrounding area was left a corrupted landscape. The farmland all withered and died, the weather turned into a constant overcast gray, and daily rainfall on dead crops meant there was little left for those within several miles of the cursed city.

The village of Crossbruke was assumed to be abandoned. The ghost town, however, was not. Viktor seized the opportunity to transform Crossbruke's villagers into vampires and other undead in the aftermath of the fall of Drakkenheim. He maintained the illusion by traveling to Drakkenheim and meeting with Elias Drexel of the Hooded Lanterns. Viktor desired to remain in the town of his namesake, and offered it to the Hooded Lanterns as a meeting point and supply chain. Crossbruke served as a military camp where Hooded Lanterns could stop for the night before bringing wagons of food, water, armaments, and other supplies to Drakkenheim. Viktor was also a prominent benefactor in the multiple Hooded Lantern expeditions into the city, and remains their primary noble contributor.

The Hooded Lanterns have a saying amongst their ranks: Crossbruke Quitters. The first task of a new recruit is always to be stationed in Crossbruke to see that the trade route remains open, and to do counts of goods passing through. It's common that amongst every batch of new recruits, a handful of them do not last the first week. They disappear without a word in the middle of the night, assumed to have abandoned their post in the dreary town, unable to cut it for what it means to be a Lantern. What the Lanterns do not know is that the recruits never leave. They are taken in the night by the vampires hiding in the shadows and turned into thralls or undead servants for Viktor's secret undead army.

House Jovovich

Head Vampire: Carina Jovovich

Location: Duelcross, Caspia

Ideology: Inheritor

Strain: Vampyre

As vassals of House Joplin, the Jovovich name has been held in high regard in Caspia for some time. Never as notable as the six great houses, the Jovovichs were a small noble house who bided their time to rise to power. The former marquis, Revati Jordan, held the position in Duelcross for seventy years. In that time, Revati had six children, which were assumed to carry on her legacy. In her fading years, Carina Jovovich befriended Revati and the two became very close. In the time they spent together, Revati began to fall ill. The children grew suspicious of Carina, who encouraged them to keep their distance, and she would tend to their mother's needs as she passed. In the final days, the children report Revati spoke as if possessed. They said she stopped sounding and acting like herself. When she passed, she left everything to Carina. Her wealth, her house, and her servants all went to Carina — the children were left with nothing.

The Jovovich children promptly began an investigation into Carina, believing she somehow fooled their mother into leaving her the family's wealth. Strangely, all six children passed away from illness within the next year and the Jovovich family became one of the most powerful lesser houses in all of Caspia. In truth, the children are alive as thralls, chained up in Carina's dungeons below her castle, where they are used as a supply of blood for her and her other thralls. She controlled and manipulated Revati and fed on her until she died, combining the two families' wealth ensured the Jovoviches a position of power in Caspia. Along with her ties to the Joplin household, Carina Jovovich may very well be one of the most influential people in the nation.

House Devero

Head Vampire: Gorman Devero

Location: Geldstadt, Westemär

Ideology: Libertine

Strain: Vrykolakas

The Devero family acquired great wealth during the Glimmer Mountain gold rush and established themselves in Geldstadt as a prominent noble house. Their riverside manor is known as the wealthiest and most opulent house in an already wealthy city. Known for collecting rare artifacts, and old tomes, the house is somewhat a museum of ancient literature and historical antiques. The walls are lined with world renowned paintings. Four times a year, Gorman opens his house to the public, allowing paid tours where he boasts about the history of the items in his collection.

The Devero family also were early investors in Altbruke University, and one of the main study halls is named after them. Many Devero, and their cadet branch the Veers, have studied at Altbruke, becoming some of the most renowned apothecaries in the continent. Few would guess the deep connections the court has in the study of alchemy, and the few renowned vampiric apothecaries that operate in secret.

Through the centuries of his family's longevity, Gorman has managed to acquire nearly half the land in Geldstadt, and now the main strip of shops, studios, taverns, and inns all pay high rent to the Devero family for the privilege of being on the main road in the wealthiest city in Westemär. Because the Devero's own so much of the land, they do not need to be invited in to prey on their tenants. Rumors amass among the shop owners and late night talks at the Inns of bats in the city, and people seeing figures standing over their beds in the middle of the night.

Usually I love a free meal, but these are family dinners I'd rather not be part of.

House Wolfenbach

Head Vampire: Winchester Wolfenbach

Location: Drannsmund, Westemär

Ideology: Inheritor

Strain: Nosferatu

Vassals of House von Baden, House Wolfenbach have held their position in the city of Drannsmund for some time. Known as elite sea captains, their vessel the Crimson Fang sails the Crystal Coast, fending off raiders from Skye.

Unknown to the people of Drannsmund, the ship raises a different flag, one of blood-soaked teeth instead of Drannsmund's crest. House Wolfenbach defeated a fleet of raiders from Skye some years ago and reanimated them, using them as their proxy crews. These undead warriors now crew a fleet of ships who stay out at sea, away from the eyes of the city. They are known to send their ships down as far as the Elyrian coast to plunder seaside villages, and none realize the connection the house has to Drannsmund.

They also have established a cadet branch in Skye and have raided many small villages within the island, claiming the forgotten villages as towns of undead. Winchester Wolfenbach hopes to raise an undead fleet that could sail the oceans and conquer the world. Winchester believes himself the true inheritor of the power of Vladimir von Drakken—where Vladimir failed, Winchester will not.

House Graveworth

Head Vampire: Corbin Graveworth

Location: Dregden's Ferry, The Eastern Vale

Ideology: Libertine

Strain: Vrykolakas

House Graveworth is an ancient bloodline that does not partake in the typical schemes of the Court of the Night. They are more monstrous in appearance due to the Vrykolakas strain, and do very little to hide their traits. Rather than infiltrating a community and sneaking in the shadows, the Graveworth family have an old castle deep in the woods north of Dregden's Ferry. There they rule over the wilds, hunting loggers, miners, hunters, and travelers heading along the Dawnbreaker trail. They only use illusions to disguise themselves as regular humanoids when they need to enter a town to meet with other vampires, such as attending the Court of the Night, and only ever when in public. They drop their guises whenever they can, feeling like hiding themselves is a mark of shame amongst the vampires, and that their form is perfect as it is.

The monsters of the Iron Woods are now a folktale passed around the Eastern Vale, and many steer clear of the woods after sunset. But there are always those who venture too deep or get lost in the thick pines and muddy grounds. Those who dwell too late are often never heard from again.

House Rossovino

Head Vampire: Dmitri and Darya Rossovino

Location: Liberio

Ideology: Resurrectionist

Strain: Vampyre

The only known halfling family of vampires, House Rossovino descends from Milos Rossovino, the steward who loyally served Vladimir von Drakken. After Vladimir's fall, the Rossovino family made its way to Liberio, establishing themselves as wealthy moneylenders, bankers, and benefactors of arts and culture. They quickly became well known nobles in Liberio, accumulating incredible wealth and building a manor house rivaling most kings on the continent. Yet these efforts are not for vanity or personal power, as the Rossovinos command considerable power amongst the Court of the Night and have led the efforts to resurrect Vladimir von Drakken. To further collaboration between the vampire houses, the Rossovinos constructed a massive secret auditorium below their manor where the Court of the Night gathers once every thirteen years.

Those who borrow money from them and fail to pay it back in time mysteriously go missing in the night, often ending up as thralls working in the secret depths of the Rossovino manor. They use their manor home as a lush museum for ancient art and old artifacts, and no one questions a rich halfling family of bankers collecting old tomes and art, but really, they are searching for relics that can aid in their plots and bring about vampiric domination.

House Crane

Head Vampire: Isobel Crane

Location: Lumen, Elyria

Ideology: Libertine

Strain: Nosferatu

House Crane is the only surviving vampiric family in Elyria, and notably stand apart from their rivals in the Court of the Night: the family is deeply committed to tenets of the Sacred Flame in spite of their cursed nature. Forming their own shadowy cult, the family's strange faith preaches that darkness and light exist together in careful balance, and that through blood, both shadow and flame coalesce into transcendence. They revere undead creatures as holy guardians whose role is to safeguard life from otherworldly and demonic forces which aim to utterly destroy it. Their cult attracts mortal followers who partake in so-called sacred rituals in secret chapels where they willingly offer a blood-tithe to a vampire-priest, teaching that this is a sacred offering which shows respect for the great curse and responsibility borne by undead who protect the living. Their agents operate throughout Elyria as the secret Society of the Bat, aiming to convince other undead creatures to take up their purportedly noble cause. Although House Crane's goals are noble-minded, their peers on the Courts of the Night tolerate their strange religion since it still situates undead as the masters over mortals.

Too many family names to remember, I have a hard enough time remembering the 6 Caspian Houses.

Locations and Lairs.name: Locations and Lairs
Locations and Lairs.text:
Locations and Lairs

V ampires Vampires are often creatures of refined taste, elegance, and opulence, but require secretive places to indulge their dark desires and violent passions. It is not unheard for lower vampires to dwell in abandoned homes or secluded caves. But more often vampires attempt to spend their years acquiring great wealth and working their way to the higher positions of societies. Noble houses, manors, and castles are all common places for a vampire to make their home. Many of the locations of the Court of the Night are a complete mystery. It stands to reason that nearly any lonely castle, secluded town, misty fishing village, or abandoned home could be a space for nighttime rituals, dark offerings, and secret meetings amongst vampiric nobility.

Service of the Dead

A vampire's first order of business is to clean house once they have acquired a suitable castle or manor house. This usually involves draining the blood of the staff, guards, and any other people who frequent the castle. Instead turning them into thralls, knights, or assassins. A vampire castle is usually occupied by multiple forms of undead. Sometimes skeletons or zombies can perform menial tasks. More intelligent and human-looking thralls provide the vampires eyes and ears in the surrounding towns, and allow them to keep the guise of normalcy throughout the castle.

Illusions Hide Decay

Often vampires will use powerful illusion magic to hide the blood, refuse, and general disarray of their homes. They may even disguise themselves or their staff with illusion magic to ensure they appear as normal as possible. Vampires are all about trickery, charm, and deceit, and will use any magic at their disposal to ensure their secret remains hidden from the public. Those who happen to see through the disguises are often moments from joining the ranks of the vampire's thralls themselves.

Treasures and Trinkets

A vampire's castle is often filled with opulent and ornate decorative treasure. Fine rugs, unique paintings, rare books and tomes, vases, statues, and jewelry. With their long lifespans they tend to acquire wealth and are avid collectors of items that few mortals would be able to obtain in a single lifetime.

Known Lairs

Vampires of all sorts can be found throughout Westemär, with several families stretching into Caspia and Elyria. The most prominent name associated with the Court of the Night is House von Drakken. Although it is rumored that it has seeped into other noble names as well.

Rossovino Manor

When the Court of the Night is called to meet, they gather at Rossovino Manor in the Free City of Liberio. Located in the hilltops outside the city proper, when Rossovino Manor was constructed nearly 250 years ago, it was among the largest estates in the region. Now, the manor sits inconspicuously among many grand villas in the countryside near Liberio, able to keep its secrets without drawing any unwanted attention. The sight of several black carriages drawing up to it once every thirteen years is thought no stranger than any of the galas, balls, or parties thrown by their wealthy neighbors. Indeed, the Rossovinos are a well-regarded house who play host to many gatherings. The meeting of the Court of the Night is a wonderful opportunity to invite some of their mortal peers to join the exclusive society.

Deep below the sprawling estate lies a secret dungeon accessed via the great library. Playing the right notes on a baroque piano (a specific chord known well to children of the night: G F# B E) causes the back wall of a massive fireplace to open into a stone staircase that spirals down. There, a vaulted chamber houses a great auditorium which can fit a hundred guests. Round tables with lavish chairs fill the chamber, decorative skull-adorned chandeliers hang from the high ceiling, and ancient flags bearing the thirteen family crests line the gray stone walls. A hundred candles and torches alight with everlasting magical flames flicker and illuminate the room, and a large stage and podium sit at the far end with crimson curtains set behind it. The feasts are supplied by a wine-cellar stocked with blood wine and a pantry filled with preserved hearts, with the many bottles labeled like vintages of the year it was bottled and the surname of the mortal who provided it. Appropriately, the high rafters house several bats that flitter about and add to the macabre atmosphere. It is here in this dark chamber that the Court of the Night holds its midnight seances.

Brachenwald Grove

This ancient grove is the place where the dark druids of Morrigan performed the Sanguine Rite on Vladimir von Drakken. In the depths of the forest is a place where the thick trees create a canopy over an old grove. No sunlight penetrates through the old branches. There, nestled between moss-caked cliffs, is a circle of standing stones. They rise up out of the earth covered in ancient symbols and dried blood. Thorny, blood-red vines wrap around them and twist like veins through the grove. In the central clearing is an old stone tablet set out like a stage, covered in splashes of blood. A series of caves along the cliff faces are makeshift hovels for druids to sleep and rest.

Kesselholm

The city of Kesselholm has recently fallen victim to a curse. The castle staff don't seem to be present during the day. No one sees the nobility anymore, many townsfolk are complaining of strange nightmares, and odd shapes in the dark. The Kleinkessels rule over Kesselholm as a cadet branch of House von Kessel, which itself has ties to the von Drakkens. So naturally there are rumors abound on the possible cause of all these mysteries.

Crossbruke Castle

The lonely castle sits atop a hill in the ghost town of Crossbruke. A dark husk of its former glory, the dark and dreary keep lays decaying in the decrepit, rain-soaked village. The town itself is mostly deserted, save for a Hooded Lanterns encampment on the edge where a series of reinforced houses and an old barn form a makeshift military outpost. A line of wagons carrying goods and cargo to Drakkenheim are hitched while scouts survey and count the contents to ensure delivery to their comrades in Drakkenheim.

Aside from the small bonfire the Lanterns keep, the only other light in the town comes from the uppermost windows of the old castle, where the dim candlelight signifies Lord Crossbruke's presence. The town is prone to eerie noises, bats, and strange movements in the dark streets and hidden corners. Everyone who stays in Crossbruke describes a general feel of unease, and the itching sensation of being watched.

Combat Tactics.name: Combat Tactics
Combat Tactics.text:
Combat Tactics

V ampires Vampires of the Court of the Night are patient predators, who strike when the situation lies in their favor. As the name implies, they are better suited to battles at night, or in the dark. They will seldom be foolish enough to fight outside during the day. Vampires are smart and have lived for centuries by not taking unneeded risks in battle. If they are discovered, and being hunted, they will draw the hunters to their castle, where their armies, minions, and dark corridors aid them. The vampire's thralls and soldiers create a slaughterhouse for those who believe they can face a vampire. If vampires fight in open military combat, they do so under moonlight.

The Court of the Night seldom operates alone. The entire operation of the court is to infiltrate a community and turn as many key members of that community to their will as possible. This includes transforming priests, mages, nobles, and any others they can into vampires. These vampire lords create Crimson Knights from castle guards, Sanguine Witches of court mages, Night Blades from assassins, Grim Custodians of loyal house servants, and a Dark Confessor from local clergy. Vampiric nobles use these allies to incite a cult following to their cause, selecting any who wish to “ascend” into the ranks of being a vampire thrall. So, to face down a single Vampire Lord or Vampire Master, one must expect that they are facing an entire entourage of vampiric figures, complete with their own networks of thralls, cultists, and minions.

Vampire Weaknesses

Roleplaying Traits.name: Roleplaying Traits
Roleplaying Traits.text:
Roleplaying Traits

V ampires Vampires are cunning and deceptive and when they choose to infiltrate a city or town — they do so with cunning plots and the benefit of time. Vampires do not age or die like other mortals; vampires construct plots that capture power for centuries. Once a vampire has selected a place to rule, they begin feeding on the townsfolk. Most begin only feeding as needed, leaving victims alive with nothing more than bad nightmares and strange bite marks. The vampire may turn some into thralls and soldiers for their army, allowing them to keep more eyes and ears around the area. Eventually the vampire's insidious plot comes together and they become leaders in the area, often from castles bearing noble names.

The Court of the Night does not stop at nobility. In many cases, as vampires seek to gain dominance over a settlement, their first task is to dismantle and control all pillars of a community. This means they create vampiric loyal servants of the castle stewards, the guard captains, even the Flamekeepers of the church, and court mages. If they can turn each known pillar of the community into a vampire, then there is nowhere for the townsfolk to turn that is not part of the expanding network of the Court of the Night.

Charming Hosts

Members of the Court of the Night conceal their undead nature from their mortal peers through several means. Many establish themselves in remote fiefs, claiming backwater domains and distant castles where their isolation allows them to simply go unnoticed. They seldom treat with others, but carefully comply with their feudal obligations to their liege lords. Over time, they slowly manipulate and turn their household staff, family members, and vassals into their own thralls, leaving none in any position of power to expose or stand against them. Others instead prefer to use misdirection and trickery to integrate with mortal society in a more conventional manner as befits their noble station.

Many vampires of the court hold lavish parties, open their castles to the public, and attempt to maintain a helpful and kind position in the community they inhabit. The more the people of their community look up to them, the easier time they have infiltrating it. They are charming and seductive, charismatic and powerful. Vampires carry themselves with a grandiose persona and have centuries of anecdotes, wit, and tales to weave into conversation.

Masters of Deception and Illusion

The Court of the Night maintains their position through powerful illusions, often kept in check by the court's Grim Custodians. They disguise their vampiric traits and hide the parts of their castles and manors that would give away their vampiric tendencies. The vampires weave such intricate lies and illusions that even a full on investigation of their homes, or a face-to-face study of one of the undead lords themselves, may reveal nothing out of the ordinary to those not sure where to look, or what to look for.

Due to their undead immortality, vampires do not appear to age, cannot sire heirs, nor will their reign end upon expected natural deaths. This prompts many to rely on a clever scheme whereby they play the role of both ruler and heir apparent: pretending at some times to be one or the other. Then, at an appointed time, the heir appears to announce the “death” of their “parent” and take up the title as ruler. Thus, many

Anyone that does that much business at night should be a suspect. When do they even get their beauty sleep?

vampires have lived under several different names over the centuries, taking up a new identity every few decades as their own children or grandchildren to maintain the ruse of noble succession. Alternatively, some vampires opt to rule from the shadows, often appointing a favored thrall as a decoy or puppet for any meetings with mortal nobles.

Purveyors of Fine and Rare Items

With centuries of wealth and warfare under their belts, the Court of the Night often find themselves in noble positions. They enjoy these lifestyles of privilege and wealth, and take every opportunity to show off their collections of fine arts, tapestries, rugs, vases, weapons and armor, and anything else they have managed to procure in their long lifetimes.

Adventure Hooks.name: Adventure Hooks
Adventure Hooks.text:
Adventure Hooks

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.151imgenturehook inline]

Consider these ideas when building adventures involving the Court of the Night.

Finding the Sanguine Rite

The ultimate goal of the Resurrectionists faction within the Court of the Night is to perform the Sanguine Rite again and resurrect Vladimir von Drakken. This adventure hook lays the groundwork for an entire high-level campaign, and makes for a great potential follow up to a Dungeons of Drakkenheim campaign.

None know for certain who taught the heretical druids of Morrigan the Sanguine Rite. Perhaps it was the Old God Morrigan herself, as her faithful often hold power over life and death, and trade knowledge and magic for blood and souls. Yet, the Druids of the Sanguine Rite are remembered as outcasts and blasphemers amongst many of Morrigan's worshippers even today, and so it's possible the knowledge they possessed came from another, darker source, an evil power that finds joy and mirth in death and the macabre: the demonic entity known as He Who Laughs Last.

Whatever the source, the Court of the Night has thus far failed to obtain knowledge of the Sanguine Rite. It's possible that the ritual may be taught again to a powerful individual who wins the favor of Morrigan or He Who Laughs Last, or instead the secrets of the ritual were indeed recorded. However, if written details of the Sanguine Rite do exist, they would be far flung and closely guarded — agents of the Court of the Night have sought them for centuries. A fragment may be held in the library of the Inscrutable Tower in Drakkenheim; another may have been sealed away by the Faith of the Sacred Flame; one key piece of text has been sequestered away to the Far Continent; and the final scraps of knowledge have been banished to another world entirely, drifting lost in the Shadowlands or the Space Between Worlds.

Perhaps the cunning Court of the Night could seek out a competent band of adventurers to help them find these pieces, posing as double agents of a trusted faction, and falsely claiming the rite is used to prevent Vladimir von Drakken's return? It would be deliciously ironic indeed if among those adventurers were suitable sacrifices, or an unwitting descendant of Vladimir von Drakken…

Along the way, a faction of Inheritor vampires seek to infiltrate the mission, usurping the knowledge to use for themselves. If the player characters fall for the ruse, they may just end up being the ones responsible for unleashing Vladimir von Drakken again!

Night Terrors

A local community living under the shadow of an old castle is complaining of several townsfolk having horrible nightmares, reporting demons standing over them in their sleep. The local guard and the priest seem to wave these stories away.

Army of Darkness

A neighboring town from where the party is based has been discovered to be entirely composed of vampires and their cultist minions. Knowing they have been found out, the locals are concerned that the army of vampires will march upon their home at the next full moon.

The Longest Night

A thrall has arrived in town and is being held at the local sheriff's office. He has come with a warning. That on the longest night of the year, in 3 days, his masters will be arriving to feast on the town.

Vampires in Drakkenheim

Rumors exist that a small family of vampires are operating out of the city of Drakkenheim, or possibly from a small nearby town. They are very keen to find a means of placing themselves on the throne and bring the corrupted city into a new age of blood and terror. Luckily the dangers of the city offer its own problems for anyone after the throne to overcome, even vampires seem unable to claim the city without help.

The Lost Ones.name: The Lost Ones
The Lost Ones.text:
Chapter 2:
Delerium Dregs

The Lost Ones

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.72imgdeleriumdre inline]

“One minute you're getting a foot rub from your royal masseuse Peter and suddenly, because you asked him to grab something sharp to carve off the dead skin, he's transformed into a blobby monster. These poor souls used to be so important to my daily routine. My sword fetcher, my helmet fetcher, my servant fetcher, heck, even my flower arranger all turned into wretched twisted creatures. Good help is hard to find but when they become an amorphous killing machine bent on consuming your flesh it's time to find some new hires.”

—Pluto Jackson

W hen When a human is exposed to enough eldritch contamination to cause a monstrous transformation, the ensuing cascade of mutations most commonly results in a horrific mockery of their former selves. Countless inhabitants of Drakkenheim have suffered this horrible fate, transformed after the meteor fell. Others are fallen soldiers, lost adventurers, or faction agents who never escaped the ruins. Survivors and explorers often refer to these creatures as “wretches,” “unfortunates,” “the lost ones,” but they are most commonly known as Delerium Dregs.

These monsters are hideously transfigured in both body and mind. They are trapped in a terrifying landscape filled with delusions and torment, left with only fragmented memories, unable to comprehend what has happened to them. Delerium Dregs have been driven mad by their transformations.

Occasionally, a Delerium Dreg may still be recognizable to their friends and loved ones, but are so stricken with madness that little remains of their former personalities. Others have changed so much they bear no resemblance to their former selves, though most retain some humanoid features and body proportions. No matter how they ended up in this horrific form, they are doomed to wander the ruins, disorientation occasionally wavering into anguish, distress, or violent outbursts.Multitudinous Mutations

No two Delerium Dregs are exactly alike, as all are transformed in chaotic and unpredictable ways. Their bodies sprout all manner of twisted limbs, spines, and bones. Their organs, muscles, and flesh are resculpted, their faces twisted painfully into terrifying visages. Nevertheless, there are several recognizable and relatively common variations which all express a differing degree of danger to those exploring Drakkenheim.

Those who have studied eldritch contamination and mutations have theorized that certain factors may influence

the types of mutations a contaminated individual may manifest. Perhaps the subject's physical or biological traits are the determining factor, especially in those who may already possess magical talents or who have been touched by arcane forces in some way. It may also be that the environment and conditions under which an individual gains Contamination affect the forms they develop, as Bloated Dregs appear more commonly near flooded regions, and Lambent Dregs are more common near the crater. It is also entirely possible it is all simply chaotic magic, and any patterns are mere coincidence.

Indeed, a Delerium Dreg continues to mutate with continued exposure to eldritch contamination. Over time, the typical Delerium Dreg described here may change into one of the other forms. However, these continued mutations may eventually cause their form to destabilize, transforming them into a Protean Abomination or Pyknic Maunder.

Warped Minds

While their new form may hold some uncanny resemblance to their original appearance, most often, a Delerium Dreg's mutations are so drastic and their behavior so radically altered that little trace is left of their former identity. Most Dregs wander Drakkenheim unfettered from reality and are easily provoked to violence.

Experienced soldiers amongst the Hooded Lanterns have observed how Dregs passively follow one another. As they aimlessly roam the ruined streets, more stragglers and lone dregs join a group, which eventually gathers into a large crowd. While occasionally infighting or hostility breaks out within the throng, left unchecked in the city, Delerium Dregs slowly start to form massive mobs that clog the city streets.

Hooded Lantern scouts have adamantly patrolled the western parts of the city near their barracks, slaying any small group of Dregs on sight. If they can keep their numbers down, it is less likely that uncontrollable swarms of them will gather. Dreg cleanup is one of the most harrowing duties for the Lanterns. More often than not, the Dregs in western Drakkenheim are fallen Lanterns, friends, or even family.

Adventurers incorrectly believe Delerium Dregs are cannibalistic, driven to feed on flesh. All evidence suggests Delerium Dregs are physically sustained by the magic of the Haze. They do not need to eat or drink, and do not sleep. They do, however, need to breathe. Consequently, they do not consume the bodies of their victims; rather, they attack out of madness-induced aggression. As such, a Delerium Dreg won't be lured into a trap by meat and usually can't be bargained with using food.

Haze Hulks

Occasionaly, these transformations include tremendous growth. Although studies of this are scarce, it seems that a common change is an instant increase in both muscle mass and ferocity. These violent monstrosities are known as Haze Hulks, huge cousins to the twisted Delerium Dregs.

The delerium affects the flesh of the creature, immediately toughening a creature and increasing its inherent strength, while diminishing parts of the brain that process emotions such as anger or frustration, and completely neutralizing the concepts of fear and greatly diminishing pain. The effects of this are a massive hulking beast that shrugs off attacks, is violently territorial, and shows no fear in the face of danger.

Advanced Mutations

Some creatures grow beyond the confines of standard mutations, where a rare few no longer fit into the obvious categories of Delerium Dregs or Haze Hulks. These creatures possess traits that separate them from the mutated hordes of the ruins, often because of their ability to maintain control of their sentience and sense of self in a way most others cannot.

The danger occurs when these creatures believe they are still human despite terrible transformations. These advanced mutants are often twisted by misguided goals, such as gaining control over their mutations. Others are just unfortunates who cling to the shreds of self remaining in their slowly fragmenting minds. These may be the most dangerous of all. They still possess a cunning intellect while slipping into a madness they cannot fathom.

Although rare, encountering these forms of advanced mutations is always dangerous—they have been known to control Dregs, or unite the mutated monsters to fight on their behalf. Two of these advanced mutants are described in this chapter: the malfeasant wizard known as the @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimDel02.JournalEntryPage.226paleman000000]{Pale Man}, and the former Queen of Drakkenheim, @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimDel02.JournalEntryPage.225lenorevonkess]{Lenore von Kessel}.

Roleplaying Traits.name: Roleplaying Traits
Roleplaying Traits.text:
Roleplaying Traits

These traits can be used in tandem with those described in the Horrors of Drakkenheim chapter. In particular, consider items from the Aberrant Physiology table to add additional variation to individual Delerium Dregs.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.tables.RollTable.EmfNp2E9er1of1Kq rollable]

Shattered Psyches

Rookie adventurers often liken Delerium Dregs to the mindless undead such as zombies. While the comparison is apt in some respects, Delerium Dregs are not brainless creatures or reanimated thralls. Rather, these mutated humans retain a broken consciousness drifting in and out of a lucid state. These horrible shreds of sentience can be difficult to witness, as the once human creatures mumble phrases of their last moments. Some cry for help, others beg for safety, while others call to loved ones and old companions. There are a few reports of Delerium Dregs have apparently coherent conversations for a few minutes before returning to their incoherent mumbles and ravenous cries.

Over the years, many have attempted to communicate with Delerium Dregs in search of their former humanity. Occasionally, Delerium Dregs respond to such appeals, but the effect is short-lived. The madness gripping their minds is all-consuming and isn't readily treated with words or even powerful magic. More than once have well-intentioned individuals sought out a transformed friend or loved one and tried to coax them back into a cogent state, grasping at whatever shreds of humanity remain. Unfortunately, these attempts ultimately fail; at best gleaning a fleeting moment of recognition before the terrifying realization of their wretched state becomes apparent. Often, such efforts only succeed in triggering frenzied outbursts, but there is no doubt that a handful of Dregs are kept captive in the hopes that one day their condition may somehow be healed or reversed.

Lasting Memories

Dregs may not be coherent, or even human anymore, but a small sliver of their former selves remains. Many have strange quirks that reveal their former selves, often displayed while tearing their victims apart.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.tables.RollTable.EmfNp2E9er1of1Kq rollable]

Locations and Lairs.name: Locations and Lairs
Locations and Lairs.text:
Locations and Lairs

The Streets of Drakkenheim

Dregs do not build lairs or burrows like many of the other creatures that occupy Drakkenheim. They do not have a specific preference to the types of environments they inhabit. Once a creature succumbs to Contamination and is lost, they stay within the Haze and tend to gravitate to areas of contaminated magic, such as delerium clusters and Thin Places. However, they can be found almost anywhere throughout the city. These Dregs wander in groups throughout Drakkenheim, attacking anything not touched by Contamination.

Dark Corners and Old Ruins

Many Dregs tend to stick to shadowy areas, such as old ruins or abandoned buildings. They wander through the dimly lit streets often enough, but any venture into an old building is likely to find a conglomerate of various Dregs.

Gathering at the Source

Dregs will gather around clusters of delerium. It is unclear why they are instinctually pulled to delerium. Perhaps because Dregs were initially created by the Contamination produced by delerium, they constantly seek more as a means of fulfilling some sort of advanced transformation. Regardless of why, large groups of Dregs have been known to gather around clusters and remain in the area.

Combat Tactics.name: Combat Tactics
Combat Tactics.text:
Combat Tactics

Predatory Instincts

Few Delerium Dregs possess the clarity of mind to execute any strategy or tactic beyond pure direct aggression. However, a few are patient predators who are more cunning in their approaches. Some of the smarter, or larger, Dregs will stalk their prey and know to stick to the shadows, hiding behind rubble. In very rare instances, Dregs may plan an ambush.

Herding Creatures

It is rare for a Dreg to be found alone, unless it has recently transformed. Dregs who find one another tend to band together and form wandering groups. Often the largest or smartest of the Dregs will lead the group, while others follow aimlessly. In the instances where Dregs surprise and ambush an adventuring group, it is often a smaller group of smarter Dregs.

The rank and file soldiers in the now twisted city huddle together to attack those who haven't changed yet. Don't become one, use your sword.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.48imgdeleriummet inline]

Adventure Hooks.name: Adventure Hooks
Adventure Hooks.text:
Adventure Hooks

The Hog Town Butcher

A butcher on the outskirts of Drakkenheim is feeding his livestock with delerium infused meat and selling cuts of the contaminated beasts at the market. His farm is now a twisted menagerie of mutated horrors; his family are unrecognizable masses of mutated flesh.

Hulk Smash

A small group of Haze Hulks have been on a rampage and need to be brought down. They are picking off Followers of the Falling Fire who try to venture into the city. If they are not stopped, they will cause major problems for the Followers.

Night's Watch

Hooded Lantern scouts have barricaded the barracks and are trying to last the night. A horde of Dregs is approaching and will smash against their fortifications through the night. Any aid could turn the tides of battle for the Lanterns.

Folktales of the Pale Man

Those who go seeking the Pale Man in Drakkenheim only do so with good reason. Stories have spread of a strange man who snatches up those dying of contamination in the city, never to be seen again. Children sing little rhymes about him as a chilling legend of Drakkenheim's very own version of the boogeyman.


The noble man, in his noble home.

Withered, old, and all alone.

His stare can chill you to the bone.

A Pale Man, on a pale throne.


For who goes wandering here or there,

they best watch out, they best beware.

It's better then, to stay at home.

The Pale Man, on his pale throne.


If you fall ill he comes for you

And takes you to his mansion to

Make you into something new

The Pale Man is watching you


Variations on the rhyme crop up from time to time. Though made by parents in Emberwood Village to keep their children from daring to wander near the ruins, the simple rhyme has struck fear into the hearts of adventurers and scouts alike.

The Pale Man has a compound within the Kleinberg Estates, a wealthy arrangement of large manor houses in the northern parts of Old Town, deep in the Haze, in the shadow of Castle Drakken. There, he houses all manner of Dregs. They serve and follow him, believing him to be their savior, and caring little for the constant experiments he performs on them. The Dregs the Pale Man houses do not attack visitors on site, however. The Pale Man welcomes those brave enough to seek him out, and will even offer aid to those who are sick. But he is always looking for the moment to turn a situation into an opportunity to acquire new test subjects for his brutal transformations and horrible experiments with eldritch contamination.

Their facial features are unnaturally warped into a permanent expression of confused agony, and an octarine glow fills their sunken eyes. Small aberrant mutations appear across their bodies: crystalline bony protrusions and small tendrils bursting forth through their skin, a yellow eyeball blinking open upon their neck, and a disturbingly elongated tongue. As they catch sight of you, they moan painfully and lunge forward.

Its head, however, is strangely small given the size of its body, though it wears a furious expression upon its broad, flat face. Plodding toward you on thumping, gigantic feet, it curls its massive hands into a cannonball-like fist. Letting out a fierce roar, it reveals its jagged rows of teeth and elongated tongue.

She wears an astonishing but tarnished golden necklace set with eleven emeralds. Her long, thin limbs and chalky skin are cracked and rigid like stone, and her hair is a writhing mass of thick, wet, tendrils, each ending in a toothy maw.

A hunched and frail looking man stands before you, draped in a shadowy black cloak that covers most of his body, save for two hands wearing thick leather gloves, and a glimpse of a withered, pale face. His lidless eyes are open wide and yellow, with glints of octarine upon them. His lipless mouth reveals prominent yellowing teeth, and a sickly green tongue resembling a large fat worm darts in and out of his mouth as he speaks. His appearance is disturbing, like the thin skin holding him together is hanging off his sickly form. Looking closely, you start to realize several beetles, roaches, maggots, and other fat and fleshy insectoid creatures skittering along his cloak, out from his sleeves, across his neck, and trailing behind him as he moves. His raspy voice is stilted, and has a distinct sound of clicking, writhing things upon it.
