Chapter 8: Dwellers of the Space Between.name: Chapter 8: Dwellers of the Space Between Worlds

The Realms Beyond.name: The Realms Beyond
The Realms Beyond.text:
Chapter 8:
Dwellers of the Space Between Worlds

The Realms Beyond

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.180imgrealmsbeyo inline]

"I knew something was wrong when I started smelling color. An old tea set grew to the size of a mountain, exploded into just letters like words from a page and dripped off into the ground before me. I don't know how to leave this place, I can't remember how I got here. I'm constantly looking at my feet to make sure they're still there. I'm probably gonna have to kill a creature with a bunch of limbs. I can hear distant screams that turn into birds that become the songs of my youth. I'm gonna just start swinging my sword at things and hope they weren't friendly."

—Pluto Jackson

E ven Even the most learned sages and mightiest archmages of the Amethyst Academy understand little about the realms beyond the Mortal World. Through centuries of research, a few have gleaned scraps of knowledge, as scholars attempt to catalog the planes and discover the means to reach them. It is known that beyond the Mortal World are countless planes, side realms, and parallel dimensions: the verdant Faerie Otherworlds, the grim Shadowlands, the fuming Elemental Planes, and more. Though few mortals ever visit these other worlds, their influence permeates the material plane through magic and creatures that slip though the metaphysical veil that separates one reality from the next. However, sewn within the seams of the planar fabric is a realm unto itself, one more incomprehensible and bizarre than any other: the roiling non-place known as the Space Between Worlds.

The Space Between Worlds is a tumultuous expanse of raw magical potential, a surreal landscape where crystalline obelisks rise at bewildering angles beneath a sun shaped like a square circle setting into an endless horizon. This horizon never touches the psychedelic, octarine sky. Logic and reason fade from meaning and the paradoxical reigns — here chaos and order are one and the same.

Often thought of as the borderland between planes, or a void that collects the detritus of failed realities, broken timelines, annihilated universes, and collapsing dimensions, the Space Between Worlds is believed to be the source of all arcane magic, and metaphysically connected to every other plane. In this endless tundra of incomprehensible chaos, creatures beyond mortal understanding glide through the void or linger within pockets of semi-coherent reality. Void pirates navigate the cosmic seas, while elder beings traverse shattered dimensions. Sentient planets engage in celestial wars across a nebulous cosmic landscape, and inscrutable entities study and abduct mortals for obscure purposes. Within this tumultuous realm, various self-proclaimed gods manipulate mortal lives, viewing them as trivial playthings. To these beings, mortals represent mere ephemeral and erratic blips in the vast, ever-shifting expanse of the universe.

These few scraps of information are the totality known to mortal scholars in the World of Drakkenheim about the Space Between Worlds. The remaining information on the Space Between Worlds is for the heroes to discover themselves during play.

Conventional understandings of space, time, and causality do not necessarily apply in the Space Between Worlds. Indeed, the foundational laws of logic itself do not hold here. The entire Space Between Worlds is a contradiction unbound; the excluded middle made manifest; a place where whatever is, is not, and is also something else, and that which is not, is. The realm is spatially multi-dimensional, extending into the fourth, fifth, sixth, and potentially infinite spatial dimensions. Similarly, time flows freely forwards, backwards, stands still, accelerates, and slows down. Finite mortal creatures confined to three spatial dimensions and a linear timeline cannot experience the full spatial and temporal breadth of the Space Between Worlds in its utterly infinite potential. Within the Space Between Worlds, everything extends endlessly everywhere all at once, while being simultaneously compressed into a singularity.

The Amethyst Academy mages Adama Borgess and Killgar Copperpot as well as apothecary Mathias van Buskirk were leading minds in the study and understanding of the Space Between Worlds. The deeper these brilliant minds delved into the knowledge of the Space Between Worlds, the more they began to lapse from reality. Copperpot died after his breakthrough into understanding the entities of the realm. Borgess published multiple books on the topic, each more esoteric and confused than the last. In his final years, he became reclusive and isolated, speaking at length about dimensions and reality in an increasingly confounded manner. Van Buskirk is a modern practitioner and is still alive today. His study is focused on Thin Places, and the entities that emerge through them, dealing with the protection of our realm from such creatures.

Beyond these brilliant minds, other entities exist that have a firm grasp of the Space Between Worlds, but these entities are just as rare to encounter as the realm itself. What secrets these

incredible beings of vast intellect may know they care little to share with mortals. Three such entities have a deep understanding of the nature of the Space Between Worlds. The first is The Thing With The Writhing Tail. Second is He Who Laughs Last, the demon lord from the Hells speculated to have existed since the origin of time, and destined to be the last creature to exist at the end of all things. Last is Amaranthyst, The Ultraviolet, archmage of the Amethyst Academy Directorate, a being who transcends time and space. There might be other incomprehensible entities that traverse the Space Between Worlds and know it as no others could, but those entities are beyond a mortal's perception and understanding.

Order Out of Chaos

In the rare instances of communication between beings of the Space Between Worlds and mortals, very little has been gained. The gnome wizard Killgar Copperpot used a planar contact spell to communicate with a being from the Space Between Worlds. Upon making contact, his fellow mages witnessed a one-sided discussion that went as follows.

“I, Killgar Copperpot, reach out to you now to seek understanding.”
“I do not understand.”
“I do not understand.”
“Oh…”
“I understand.”

Which promptly ended with the mage standing up and walking to the edge of the sea ten miles away. For twelve days he spoke not a word and silently wept. None of his fellow mages could get him to communicate. After sunset on the twelfth day, during a full moon, the mage stood from his place in the sand. Witnesses transcribed what he said:

“The gibbering and entombed wretches, by the twinkled pointed stings of dusks settling, hark, cast ye into the sea so I shall be swept into foam upon the waves and be Killgar Copperpot no more.”

The mage's eyes then melted into mush, and a strange octarine glow came from within the empty sockets. He then walked into the sea and was never seen again. Some who observed the act say that as the waves crashed over him, he slowly dissolved as if he was made of sand.

Many philosophers, mages, and priests have thus speculated that the void found within this chaotic realm is little more than incomprehensible nothingness, one that mortal minds were not meant to bear witness to, but simply is a space between the pockets of functioning realities that we are intended to exist within.

However, the mad mage Adama Borgess suggested that rather than existing between worlds as befits its name, the Space Between Worlds actually contains all of reality and existence itself. Under their utterly baffling model, the entire multiverse — all planes of existence, timelines, and worlds — are merely thought of as “islands of order within a sea of chaos.” Borgess theorized that the fate of such islands is inevitably to be broken down and consumed, returning to primal chaos. To Borgess, order is merely a temporary state cast against the natural chaotic state of the multiverse, a chance snapping together of cogent components forming randomly within the ether.

Fundamentally Contaminated

The raw magic within the Space Between Worlds is intense and manifests as unrestrained eldritch contamination, transforming matter and energy into everything beyond imagination. The chaotic magical landscape produces constantly fluctuating arcane energy that forms a swirling nebula of contaminated energy.

Not dissimilar to the Haze found over Drakkenheim, the Space Between Worlds is a contaminated place; delerium crystals can be found in the Space Between Worlds in massive quantities. A form of concentrated raw arcane power turned into a solid form, delerium is an inevitable constant in a realm of churning arcane power. Growths of it dot every landscape and structure found in the realm, and in other regions it dominates the terrain, shaped like colossal mountains, crystalline forests, octarine obelisks, and strange edifices. Entire planetoids of delerium drift through the void. Delerium may have very well originated from the Space Between Worlds, shifting into the various realms and realities through Thin Places, or arcane gates.

The creatures that inhabit the realm are born from this contamination, and their alien physiologies and incomprehensible arrangements echo the horrible mutations occurring in Drakkenheim. Adama Borgess's theory suggests that delerium is the inevitable return to chaos that all realities will eventually suffer. The process of returning order to its natural state of chaos is caused by the swirling arcane void and delerium is simply a catalyst for this destruction caused by the inherent nature of magic itself. The realms floating within the Space Between Worlds are at all times deathly contaminated, and it is perhaps the epicenter of the chaotic whims of contamination.

Cats of the Moons

One of the strangest noted occurrences within the Space Between Worlds is the relative frequency in which cats occur. Multiple accounts from those who have traversed the Space Between Worlds and lived to tell about it mention cats, or similarly feline creatures, guiding them back to their mortal realms. No mortal being alive has been able to surmise how, or why, of all the possible creatures, within realms of unfathomable arrangements of possibilities, we have found multiple occasions of cats, or creatures closely resembling cats.

Speculation suggests perhaps all cats are from the Space Between Worlds, and have in fact infested our reality, observing humans for reasons we could never know. Others think the opposite may be true, that cats slipped from our reality into the Space Between Worlds, and somehow found a home there, multiplying and occupying the pockets of space within the chaotic realm.

Whatever the reason, cats have seemingly guided mortals through the twisted chaotic realms on multiple occasions, though their true nature is a mystery. It is unclear what dealings those who never made it home had with the cats, and whether they were nefariously involved in any way.

The problem with cats and their "owners" is discerning at any given time who is in charge. I would consider myself a dog person.

Roleplaying Traits.name: Roleplaying Traits
Roleplaying Traits.text:
Roleplaying Traits

C reatures Creatures from the Space Between Worlds are often beyond comprehension. Many possess forms and consciousness so bizarre that mortals do not recognize them as creatures at all. They view mortals similarly, nothing more than inert matter and whose souls are little more than passing thoughts. Still, these otherworldly creatures interact with mortals in more cogent and physical ways. The plane's inscrutable inhabitants include sphinxes, gemstone dragons, and countless aberrations. Those humanoids who have been lost to this realm are forever changed by the arcane anomalies of the Space Between Worlds.

Paradoxical Physiology

The native creatures of the Space Between Worlds often have physical features that defy the laws of physics:

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.tables.RollTable.5QUviFpQYqWfXHhI rollable]

Inscrutable Minds

Dwellers of the Space Between Worlds behave and think in ways incomprehensible to mortals. Consider using the following mannerisms and traits to capture their bewildering nature:

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.tables.RollTable.aQG7qX0mLrC3wMUl rollable]

Locations and Lairs.name: Locations and Lairs
Locations and Lairs.text:
Locations and Lairs

Mortal spellcasters are seldom able to physically travel between differing planes of existence; for in the entire world only a handful of tuning forks for the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.J6Jpw5XzB5aTeqnz]{Plane Shift} spell are known to exist, and only a few living people are able to cast unfathomable spells such as gate. Instead, most interplanar travel occurs via happenstance. Rifts in reality appear seemingly at random throughout the Mortal World and on occasion creatures have been known to slip through.

Travel to the Space Between Worlds

Physical travel to the Space Between Worlds is a deadly prospect for all but the most seasoned and powerful mortals. Rather, it is more common that the influence of the Space Between Worlds appears in the Mortal World in the form of Thin Places.

Thin Places

These are spots where the borders between worlds are especially weak. Emerging under extraordinarily rare magical circumstances, Thin Places form a connection between the Mortal World and another plane of existence. Thin Places often mark sites where creatures from the worlds beyond step into the Mortal World. Powerful planar magic can be harnessed here; Thin Places are characterized by a subtle influence of their corresponding plane.

Thin Places can wax and wane over time. An object such as a doorway, arch, stone circle, bridge, wardrobe, or looking glass can act as a fulcrum for a Thin Place, and even spontaneously form a planar portal. Animal burrows, lakes, and trees can act in the same manner, becoming places where mortals and extraplanar creatures slip between worlds. When Thin Places wane, they can leave planar travelers trapped in another dimension, unable to return home. Academy scholars claim this is how gnomes, goblins, and many anthropomorphic peoples came to the Mortal World, as well as monsters such as lycanthropes, trolls, and worse.

Most commonly, Thin Places connect to the Faerie Otherworlds or the Shadowlands, but the presence of delerium can trigger much more wild rifts that open to never-before-seen realms. Since the emergence of delerium, the Thin Places connected to the Space Between Worlds have appeared, mostly in and around Drakkenheim. These places are especially dangerous, as the monsters and wild magic that leak into the Mortal World from the Space Between Worlds are far more deadly and hostile than those of other realms. Worse, the eldritch contamination from the Space Between Worlds tends to slowly cause these conditions to worsen over time.

Plane Shift

There are only three known tuning forks that allow one to venture into the Space Between Worlds via Plane Shift. One is a tesseract, another a mobius strip, and the last is a melting pocket watch. The locations of these mythical items are known only to a select few. The Directorate of the Amethyst Academy knows of one. Another is said to be held by the great dragon Opularis the Wise, though none have ever been able to confirm this with the dragon. The third is a mystery. Some believe it was lost in Drakkenheim; others say the Divine Matriarch holds it in a secret vault; still others believe some great demonic entity houses it within the hells.

Temporal Disjunction

There is no meaningful concept of time in the Space Between Worlds beyond the perception of mortal creatures. Traveling through this place is a journey of eons which can unfold in mere minutes within the Mortal World. Many who find themselves lost in the Space Between Worlds have returned to the Mortal World having found the world completely changed. Although they believed themselves gone for months, they came home to a century of time passing. Other rare stories speak of an apothecary claiming they were lost in the Space Between Worlds for at least forty years, returning unaged only 42 minutes after they entered. With the absence of time within the realm, it has been observed that those who enter go through physical and mental changes that are disproportionate to the time spent in the realm. Where one creature might age, another may not. These inconsistencies continue to prove difficult to map or speculate upon due to their inherent lack of reason or consistency.

Visions of Madness

The sights of the Space Between Worlds are so bizarre and incomprehensible that few mortal minds can withstand beholding them. The landscapes leave those who witness them with severe headaches, dizziness, and in some cases have caused lasting bouts of madness, lethargy, and death. The Space Between Worlds is so utterly devoid of reason or logic that no mortal mind that dares imagine such a place could ever conceivably fathom the true reality of it. Those who have spied its landscapes and been coherent enough to document their findings have struggled to do so by any words or phrases of any language. The few recorded documentations are also wildly inconsistent amongst one another, further proving that there is no perceivable way to draw conclusions about the Space Between Worlds besides its utter chaotic incomprehensibility.

Impossible Vistas

The terrain of the Space Between Worlds varies greatly. Within it are some common groupings of matter that have been observed and mapped amongst the otherwise impossible to comprehend landscapes:

Desert of the Unreal

Trackless dunes of hourglass sands engulf the ruins of forgotten civilizations. Ancient bone-white monuments and half decayed structures jut out of the dunes along with strange jewel toned rocks that reach towards a purple sky. The rocks reshape at incoherent angles depending on how they are observed, and the howl of unnatural winds billow through the sands under an eternal blazing sun.

Hyperdimensional Caverns

A network of caves and dungeons extend past the third dimension, comprising chambers with four, five, six, or more spatial dimensions, all overlapping one another. With no consistent path to take or to map, the caverns seemingly reform and reimagine themselves at any given moment. Journeying down a straight corridor may very well lead you in a circle, and descending into a pit may lead you to the top of a mountain.

Void Sea

A great roiling mass of eldritch storms, the Void Sea is not quite outer space, not quite ocean, and not quite landless sky. Floating rocks drift through the sea in various shapes and forms, some as small as a pebble, others large enough to house entire structures or cities. Void Pirates roam the sea surviving off the drifting debris seeping in from the Thin Places of other realms. The Void Sea is a terrifying space where gravity is broken in illogical ways. Stepping off the edge of a cliff might cause you to fall in any direction, or float through the air gently, or even have gravity shift so you are still walking on solid ground in a new direction. Navigating this eternal sea is an art few can comprehend besides those born in the Space Between Worlds, or those forever altered by it.

Monolith Plains

The Monolith Plains are made up of vast fields of orange grass upon rolling hills that shift and move like waves upon an ocean caught in slow motion. Stretches of land are spotted with great monoliths of black obsidian stone formed in perfect geometric shapes. Scattered perfect cubes of rock orbit the largest of the great stones, giving off a slight ringing hum. The sky is a deep crimson, filled with churning green clouds that flash with purple lightning in an ever present storm. Occasional torrential downpours of contaminated rain cause flooding and form rivers and lakes along the landscape.

Temples of Ulthar

A series of vast islands within the Void Sea house ancient temples of white stone with bizarre architecture unlike that of any mortal creature's making. Great statues of cat-like creatures stand upon ancient pedestals or within carved vistas throughout the geometrically baffling hallways. The temples are both ancient and pristine, standing out of time, and oddly fathomable amongst the otherwise chaotic landscapes.

The Screaming Heads

Dead gnarled trees, some resembling bony human hands or petrified tentacles burst forth from a blackened marshland of wet ground. Trickling waterfalls flow upwards into a darkened sky. Amongst the dribbling black waterways, thousands of circular stone tablets jut out of the ground. Many are perfect circles and each one contains two smaller circles punched through the stone and one large circle towards the bottom, giving the strange stone monuments the appearance of screaming faces. The stone surfaces are perfectly smooth, as if it was polished and finely crafted.

Towers of Gears

Amongst the Void Sea are a collection of epic towers that stretch for eternity in length. These towers are composed entirely of metal mechanical workings: gears, belts, levers, buttons, wires, segmented tubes, bolts, and dials constantly turning like clockwork, grinding and clicking. The towers are alive with metal creatures of geometric shapes and shifting metal workings who continually rearrange and restructure the machine workings of the towers. The towers are pulled apart and its nodes and conduits powered up by great floating mechanical beings with wires and tubes flowing off of them like a squid. The purpose of these towers is completely unknown, and seemingly inconsequential. Nevertheless, the creatures are determined to continue their work.

Combat Tactics.name: Combat Tactics
Combat Tactics.text:
Combat Tactics

T he The creatures of the Space Between Worlds do not engage in combat with the mentality, motives, or tactics of any mortal being. Some are motivated to simply consume and persist while others are driven by entirely alien goals. Their incomprehensible nature means that engaging in combat with these strange entities will often prove as chaotic and confusing as the landscapes they inhabit.

The beings of the Space Between Worlds often have utter disregard for the wellbeing of mortals. They see mortals as little more than another assortment of chaotic matter in their way to either be moved, destroyed, or studied. These aliens attack unfamiliar creatures simply to remove them from their presence and return them to the nothingness of the void. Others find the occurrence of mortals curious and take to abducting them and performing bizarre experiments in service to some otherworldly science for reasons that the helpless subjects could never understand.

When their physical forms are injured, creatures from the Space Between Worlds will often bend reality around them or alter space and time as a reaction to violence. It is unclear if this is a defensive measure, or simply the byproduct of physically harming a creature that exists within a multi-dimensional space that is beyond human comprehension. These alien creatures have been known to phase in and out of existence, split into multiple timelines, completely change shape and form, or slip through space and time to another location when attacked.

These alien creatures do not leave behind parts or organs that mortals might understand. Many of their remains are inconsistent with any grasp one might have on biology. On occasion, bones, organs, limbs, and fluid can be gathered all the same, but more often than not, the purpose of these remains and how they relate to the creature's physiology remain a complete mystery.

Aberrant Traits

Adventure Hooks.name: Adventure Hooks
Adventure Hooks.text:
Adventure Hooks

Pirates of the Void Sea

Captured by @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimDwe08.JournalEntryPage.819voidpirates00]{Void Pirates}, you hear whispers from the crew of a great treasure hidden in temples beyond the Void Sea. If you escape and get their map, maybe you can find this ancient relic.

Dwellers Domain

A @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimDwe08.JournalEntryPage.809fardwellers00#far-dweller-mastermind]{Far Dweller Mastermind} and its @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimDwe08.JournalEntryPage.809fardwellers00#far-dweller-abductor]{Far Dweller Abductors} and @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimDwe08.JournalEntryPage.809fardwellers00]{Far Dwellers} have kidnapped someone close to you, intent on experimenting on them.

Star Warden

While lost within maze-like caverns, something follows you. It seems to navigate the labyrinth better than you. It may be a threat, but it may also be your only chance to find an escape.

Lost in Space

You find yourselves stuck in the Space Between Worlds trying to navigate your way home. A @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimDwe08.JournalEntryPage.821sentientplane]{Sentient Planetoid} has agreed to give you directions—sadly, they take you through multiple dimensional rifts that involve traversing several strange vistas of unfathomable creatures to get back to your plane of existence.

Blade Between Worlds

Within the islands of the Void Sea is an astral forge said to use stars to temper incredible weapons. There you can find plans for a sword that cuts through the very fabric of time and space.

Triumph of Order

The Space Between Worlds is the source of delerium. Seeking to prevent a disaster like that which befell Drakkenheim, the player characters embark on an epic quest to seal away the Space Between Worlds. This interdimensional odyssey takes them to the edge of reality, where they must defeat and bind elder beings such as @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimApp0A.JournalEntryPage.907thealgorithm0]{The Algorithm} and @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimApp0A.JournalEntryPage.904thingwiththew]{Thing with the Writhing Tail} to a locus of @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimDwe08.JournalEntryPage.821sentientplane]{Sentient Planetoids}, constructing a powerful planar matrix to separate the Space Between Worlds from the Mortal World. Opposing the players are @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimDwe08.JournalEntryPage.809fardwellers00]{Far Dwellers} and @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimDwe08.JournalEntryPage.808deleriumdrago]{Delerium Dragons}, who wish to return the Material World to a state of primal chaos. Whether factions such as the Followers of the Falling Fire, the Amethyst Academy, and the Silver Order aid or oppose the characters may depend on their actions and knowledge of the consequences for their success. The repercussion this adventure would be cosmic in scale, fundamentally altering the fabric of the multiverse.

The cost for their success would be high indeed: the Space Between Worlds is the source of all magic, and magic cannot exist without delerium. Separating the Space Between Worlds from the Material Plane irrevocably banishes magic from the world and severs all forms of planar or interdimensional travel between the Material Plane and other planes. Mageborn and priest alike lose their spellcasting powers, and the pacts between warlocks and patrons are forever snuffed out. Any whispers from old gods, eldritch powers, celestial beings, and demons are silenced. Every thin place is destroyed, and magical creatures, such as trolls, giants, fey, and dragons slowly go extinct as the magic intrinsic to their nature fades from reality. The world of Drakkenheim would be safe from Delerium, but it would become a mundane place, utterly devoid of all magic.

This horrific thing has no shape or body resembling anything from the Mortal World. It roughly resembles a tree stump with four root-like legs each ending in a misshapen hoof. It has a wet, mottled, bark-like hide, and sprouting from the side of it like branches are knobbly arms ending in sharp claws. The top of its body is a gaping, tooth-filled mouth. It is shoveling chunks of horse-flesh into itself, and giggling as it swallows the ripped flesh. Whatever passes for arms, on the inside of the palm are yellow eyes.

Delerium Dragons.name: Delerium Dragons
Delerium Dragons.text:
Delerium Dragons

This unearthly dragon is a crystalline horror, its body formed from angular gem-like scales pulsing with octarine light. Its form is raw delerium. Each scale is a gleaming crystal refracting light into eerie hues of purple, yellow, and green, with an unnatural sharpness that feels both fragile and impossibly durable.

The dragon's wings are translucent and webbed with glowing crystal veins that shimmer, casting kaleidoscopic patterns as it moves. Each beat causes the air to hum, vibrating with a chaotic energy that overwhelms and distorts the senses. Each step the dragon takes leaves delicate motes of crystal growing into jagged formations, tainting the landscape. Its eyes are like multifaceted gems, swirling with chaotic magic pooling within their depths. The beast's crystalline horns and talons are razor-sharp, gleaming like polished jewels, yet crackling with eldritch energy.

Getting lost in the Border Ethereal Plane

When encountering a Fractal Lepidoptera, characters can get stranded in the Border Ethereal Plane. This has the potential to derail a campaign. Here are a few suggestions on how to run this scenario instead:

  • When the lepidoptera dies, the fabric of reality temporarily weakens and everyone can safely return to the Prime Material Plane.
  • Immediately after the lepidoptera dies, the party needs to succeed in a skill challenge to traverse the veil between the planes. Each character can contribute to the skill challenge by suggesting actions that they take to help find the veil, withstand the pull of the Ethereal Plane, and open a gate. The group succeeds if they make 4 successful DC 15 skill checks before 3 failures.
  • The characters must harvest the animus of the lepidoptera and craft a fractal key.

Horrific Legacy.name: Horrific Legacy
Horrific Legacy.text:
Chapter 1:
Horrors of Drakkenheim

Horrific Legacy

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.1imghorrificlega inline]

“That purple rock is very valuable. I used to carry it around in my pocket but it turns merchants into monsters and the ones I love into weird mutant spiders. That is what we faced as soon as we crossed the threshold into Drakkenheim, an endless hodge podge of inside out carcasses, spines in the wrong places, and a plethora of appendages. No matter for a Caspian with a quick sword. Although it reminded me of the endless battles with Hydras. You attack one long limb and suddenly two more in its place! This is why we hate math! The delerium spreads quickly and even the most gentle creatures turn into nightmarish abominations! I watched a soldier of Caspia get eaten by his own rations. I've seen veteran soldiers open their lunch boxes awaiting a fight! You must stick to the roads because you cannot trust the alleys. Sneaky bugs and behemoths wait to pounce with suckers and stickers looking for an opening. Be ready adventurer! For you are in the thick of it. The place where a rare sword freshly awaits a new set of hands to carry it further into the belly of the broken city known as Drakkenheim. If you didn't kick the horse may your god have mercy on your soul.”

—Pluto Jackson

T Though hough it was a metropolis of over a hundred thousand people, only a few hundred escaped Drakkenheim in the days following the disaster. Trembling as they spoke, these survivors recounted how they narrowly avoided the fire and ash that consumed the city, only to watch in horror as their loved ones, neighbors, and fellow citizens were twisted into grotesque parodies of themselves by the chaotic energies that followed the falling stars. All agreed that the only lucky ones that day were those who were swiftly incinerated in the initial meteoric impact. Ever since, those who perish within Drakkenheim or succumb to the contaminated Haze transform into hideous monsters.

Those who dismissed these claims as the distressed inventions of a few traumatized refugees were decisively proven wrong in the years following the disaster. Seeking to restore order as quickly as possible, the nobility of Westemär desperately mustered an expeditionary force to search Drakkenheim for royal survivors, recover the lost crown, and retake Castle Drakken. Lord Commander Elias Drexel was placed in command of the mission, hand-picking a contingent of fifty elite House von Kessel soldiers to be the first team dispatched into the ruins. Captain Pieter Lang was appointed to lead the squadron.

Although they were well-equipped veterans, this conventional military force was wholly unprepared for the conditions in the ruins. Arriving on the outskirts of the city, the troops found Drakkenheim cloaked in a thick opalescent fog, which came to be known as the Haze. When the mists did not abate, the soldiers cautiously proceeded into the ruins from the south, making their way along Champion's Way. The details are unclear about what exactly occurred next, since only a few scrawled notes from Captain Lang's logbook were ever found from that first mission.

Lang records that a few among their number began to fall ill shortly after entering the ruins and encountering a “gigantic and misshapen rodent” of some kind. Nevertheless, the unit pushed onward and ran afoul of “a throng of reanimated dead shuffling the streets.” Lang notes that many were wounded in the battle against the undead after the creatures “violently exploded with some kind of strangely-colored magic” when slain. At that, the regiment decided to stop and rest to help their comrades recover. While making camp, a few of the soldiers presented Lang with “brightly glowing gemstones, which glimmered like nothing from this world” that they'd found amongst the rubble. Lang explains how he confiscated the stones, keeping them on his person “for safety, lest the troops get ideas about looting.”

However, the soldiers were unable to sleep, haunted by whispers and nightmares of something in the swirling darkness. More began to fall sick, and that's when the changes began. One of the wounded soldiers started convulsing violently as their arms transformed into flailing tentacles, and their stomach opened into a gaping, toothy maw. Unsure what to do, a panicked Lang had “no other choice but to slay the poor wretch.” At that point, Lang's writing becomes less clear, as he explains the affliction spreading amongst his soldiers taking hold in himself. That was the final entry in his log. The scribbled notebook was found by adventurers some years later amidst the remains of a terrible shapeless mass of monstrous flesh and limbs. None from Lang's unit ever returned from the ruins.

Since that time, many expeditions and adventuring parties have met a similar fate to Lang's unit, and rarely are records or remains ever found. However, a few were far more fortunate and returned from their missions. Through these few successes, the world was able to learn about the horrors of Drakkenheim, and the vast power—and danger—of delerium.

Eldritch Contamination

It is now well-known that the delerium crystals scattered throughout the ruins emit arcane radiation known as eldritch contamination (the game rules for which are described in @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimApp0C]{Appendix C: Contamination}). These energies also manifest the misty Haze that covers the city. Sustained exposure to this raw magic causes all matter to warp erratically. While living animal tissue is readily susceptible to contamination, over time even plant and vegetable matter, dead flesh, solid rock, metal, and even the elements themselves are affected by delerium. Overexposure to eldritch contamination induces a chain reaction of rapid mutation which changes humans, animals, and even inanimate objects into terrifying monsters in a painful and gory process. As the body betrays itself, the mind slowly unravels. A monstrous transformation drives even the most strong-willed individuals irrevocably mad, though a few retain a distorted facade of their intelligence and personality. Each creature described in this chapter has suffered this terrible fate.

The mutations caused by eldritch contamination are endless in possibility, and do not conform to any need for biological function or natural law. There is no telling what strange appendages, odd shapes, and unnatural abilities a contaminated creature could possess. While some mutations make for a fearsome abomination, many mutated creatures become a pathetic lump of flesh barely able to support their own misshapen bodies. However, within the churning chaos of change, occasionally patterns emerge. Even two creatures which share the same mutations and game statistics may have wildly different appearances and behavior.

Hideous Beasts

Humans are not the only creatures that have been transformed into monsters. The beasts that once inhabited Drakkenheim have also become abominations: the livestock and pets living alongside the citizenry, the vermin crawling in the streets and sewers, the skittering insects inhabiting every home, and the wild animals eking out a life amidst the pockets of nature found within the urban sprawl. Worse, even plant life has gained otherworldly sentience, animated by the eldritch forces taking root in the soil. Although monsters have always been known to exist, these horrific nightmares are unlike anything seen in any other place on this world.

Sometimes Drakkenheim's mutations are so bizarre and mind warping that they create an entirely new species. Although many mutated creatures appear related to the various animals and people who once inhabited the city, some have mutations so bizarre and mind warping that they create an entirely alien species. At times these changes manifest as masses of indistinguishable flesh, bloated tentacled limbs, or in rare cases they develop into a creature more uniform and recognizable in its makeup, but never before seen in the world.

Walls that Talk

It is a common misconception that eldritch contamination only affects living, organic creatures. The Haze infuses the atmosphere: conjuring bizarre and violent weather, polluting the earth and waterways, and even warping and changing the objects and structures within the city. Scouts claim the mists and fog have reshuffled the streets and thoroughfares of Drakkenheim into a shifting maze, but the reality is far more unsettling. Reports and rumors tell of walls of flesh, plants and trees turned to delicate glass, doorways opening portals to other realms, grasping tendrils emerging from seemingly inanimate objects, eyes and faces appearing amongst the stonework, and teeth, tongues, and hungry maws opening between the floorboards. Even time seems to flow erratically within the ruins, and on occasion adventurers thought lost in the ruins for months emerge suddenly, thinking they were only in the city for a day.

Given these strange effects, the monsters roaming the ruins, the hazards of rubble and wreckage, and the corrupt environmental conditions in Drakkenheim, nowhere in the city is safe. Anything, even the very walls of the buildings, are potential threats waiting for an opportune moment to strike.

Haze Dependent

Most contaminated monsters are dependent on the magic of the Haze to sustain themselves, as their unstable physiologies often defy the laws of nature. Brought outside the Haze, these monsters begin to rapidly wither and deteriorate, and seldom live much longer than a week. Once this was discovered, it was widely believed that the threats posed by the horrors of Drakkenheim were largely contained to the ruins. Nevertheless, the devastating effects on the countryside from spreading contamination and the danger of wandering monsters nearby was enough to see most towns and villages near Drakkenheim abandoned within a few years of the disaster.

Today, the only settlement within two weeks' travel of Drakkenheim is Emberwood Village. Fortunately, the large concentration of adventurous sorts and faction agents gathering in the town is more than enough to fend off most curious creatures who come to Emberwood, though no one questions what may have happened when a person disappears anymore.

However, contact or exposure to delerium can be enough to nourish these creatures for longer forays from the ruins. Worse, a significant concentration of delerium in any one place can cause a local manifestation of the Haze, which can maintain a great number of monsters. Bold and particularly lucid monsters seeking new hunting grounds may bring delerium with them on their own excursions outside the ruins, driven by an innate compulsion to spread their contaminated state.

Corrupted Urban Ecology

Drakkenheim has transformed over the last fifteen years into a nightmarish wasteland where urban decay meets the wild. The city's ruins are now more akin to a vast, untamed wilderness, teeming with violent and predatory creatures that have adapted to this new, harsh environment. These monsters have carved out their own ecological niches within the crumbled streets, decrepit sewers, and broken spires, turning the city into a landscape that is both alien and hostile.

These creatures have become the true inhabitants of Drakkenheim, mastering every aspect of their environment to their advantage. They use the dense Haze for cover, the labyrinthine ruins for navigation, and the scattered debris for shelter. The tunnels, alleys, and hollowed-out buildings serve as their nests, homes, and battlegrounds. To these monsters, Drakkenheim is familiar territory, their hunting ground where they thrive.

For any outsider venturing into the city, Drakkenheim offers no safe passage. Iconic landmarks such as towering spires, grand gates, city squares, and once-vibrant gardens have become twisted and unfamiliar. The city's layout is constantly shifting with fallen buildings blocking paths, broken and cratered streets, and contamination altering the environment unpredictably. This makes the city a labyrinth, constantly changing and challenging even to those who once knew it well.

First Contact

A report from Vanguard Captain Rose Walker, first expedition into Drakkenheim.

We were crossing the river on the eastern outskirts, making our way up King's Road. As we approached the Drann, Faraday spotted strange eggs along the shore, colored unlike anything we had seen before. Similar, I think, to the fog hanging over the ruined city. Collins said they reminded him of tadpole eggs he saw as a child. We heard a low gurgling noise from the river and drew our bows. Collins was hit with one of the strange eggs. We saw a figure lurking in the water and unleashed our arrows at it, but it vanished beneath the surface. The egg that hit Collins had stuck to his neck. He was on the ground, writhing in discomfort. Faraday examined the egg, which had seemingly fused to Collin's flesh, appearing like a strange pulsing growth.

We were hesitant to attempt to remove it, and that hesitancy may be what cost Collins his life. I can't say for sure what happened next. We continued to travel towards King's Gate, keeping an eye on Collins, who claimed he felt alright; we would drop him off at a nearby Lantern waypoint to seek medical attention. Faraday observed a small creature within the egg, possibly a tadpole, disappear into Collins's neck as the egg merged even further. Collins lost consciousness only a minute or two later, and moments after that, began convulsing. His skin turned strange hues of yellow and green, his eyes grew pale, and he began to bleed from sores that appeared across his body. As we attempted to staunch the bleeding and tend to his ailments, Collins was lost to the disease that had quickly overtaken him. As we came to terms with losing one of our own to such bizarre circumstances, horrible events began to occur.

It's difficult to describe what happened to Collins's body. His skin began to writhe, and crack. His ribcage ripped open as a large frog emerged, its face split down the middle with a strange maw. It let out a horrible croak and leapt past us. We unleashed multiple arrows at the creature until it fell. Approaching the creature's body, we saw that it had already begun producing its own eggs, likely to use on the rest of us. However, the most unsettling thing was that its eyes were strangely familiar. They reminded me of Collins's.

Roleplaying Traits.name: Roleplaying Traits
Roleplaying Traits.text:
Roleplaying Traits

T he The eclectic monsters presented in this chapter are diverse in their motivations, appearance, and behavior, but all share the same origins as creatures contaminated by the Haze. As such, the roleplaying traits below are common amongst them.

Beyond Reason

The monsters inhabiting Drakkenheim are irrevocably gripped by otherworldly madness. Most become predatory and instinctively violent as a result, but a few are lucid and capable of speech. However, even these creatures possess an unstable consciousness: they may be perfectly capable of carrying on a conversation for a short while, only to break out into rage, despair, or other extreme emotions without warning. Appeals to logic and reason often confuse and frustrate them, and they possess a twisted sense of empathy and alien logic. Few of Drakkenheim's horrors understand the origin of their malevolent predilections, and instead construct elaborate fantasies or incoherent narratives to explain their predicaments and behaviors.

Struggle for Survival

These monsters are often just as hostile to one another as they are to explorers who venture into the ruins. Although some have formed groups, many live a solitary existence wandering the city streets. Some are aimless, while others desperately search for something, be it food, their own memories, or some other delusion. A particularly empty or desolate area of the city may indicate that a powerful beast lurks nearby, as weaker abominations know to give the dangerous predator a wide berth.

Motivated by Madness

The monsters inhabiting the ruins have strange and incoherent motives.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.tables.RollTable.b2CEvkZNXbakUEPf rollable]

Aberrant Physiology

The monsters presented in this chapter are typical of their kind, but even creatures with the same game statistics may have extreme variation in physical appearance. Consider using the following additional descriptions to distinguish creatures:

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.tables.RollTable.791immqvxt0K1UOl rollable]

Otherworldly Effects

The monsters are otherworldly and at times incomprehensible or horrifically bizarre. Rarely do the monsters of Drakkenheim speak or utter coherent words. Those that do are most likely humans who have mutated in the ruins. What bizarre and otherworldly elements occur when the monster is nearby?

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.tables.RollTable.lxRGghnSSJfCbITx rollable]

Universal Mechanical Features

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.features.Item.EKAJ5aeoV5hfHFKl inline]

These features do not apply to creatures originating outside the Haze or who are recruited or conjured by the characters, such as familiars and summoned monsters.

If you are using these monsters in a setting that doesn't use Contamination or the Haze, you may disregard these mechanical features.

Locations and Lairs.name: Locations and Lairs
Locations and Lairs.text:
Locations and Lairs

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.2imglocationslai inline]

M Monsters onsters find plentiful places to make their lairs throughout the ravaged streets, desolate plazas, crumbling structures, and flooded sewers of Drakkenheim. Here are a few ideas to keep in mind when designing encounter locations and lairs for the monsters in this chapter.

Ruined City

Amongst the city streets and back alleys are hundreds of buildings brought low by the rain of falling stars. Some buildings are more intact than others, but the devastation of the city is everywhere and the scars of the aftermath of that horrible day remain. Thick dust, octarine Haze, rubble-blocking paths, fallen towers and caved-in roads all have turned the great city into an endless labyrinth of twisting and turning passages.

Monsters in the Dark

There is always something hiding in the city's dark corners. An explorer may think they are in the clear and away from danger only to be ambushed unexpectedly by a hungry abomination. Nothing can be trusted, and if the city is quiet, that's even more reason to be on your guard — the worst terrors are the ones you never hear or see.

Hazards Abound

The city is always a dangerous place, even in the rare instance a mutated horror is not lurking just out of sight. Ruined buildings collapse, streets cave in, and the Haze can make navigation difficult. At any moment a terrible hazard can cause problems for adventurers trying to make their way through the city. Few buildings in the city stand unscathed. Most are in a partial state of collapse and heavily damaged. Shattered windows, splintered boards, and jagged rocks make up a large portion of the structures found throughout the city. Any encounter could be more lethal due to these constant hazards.

Threats Above and Below

The dangers of Drakkenheim's streets make many adventurers consider if safe routes may be found underground through the sewers, or by taking the high road along the rooftops of the city buildings. However, there are monsters and dangers on both routes. The choice to take the streets, sewers, or rooftops is more about the threats explorers are best equipped to handle, rather than a means to avoid monsters entirely.

Drakkenheim had a sophisticated sewer system running beneath the city. There are two types of tunnels in the system: drainage and sewage tunnels, which carry refuse and wastewater away from the city, as well as aqueducts and underground canals, which supply fresh water to the wells, cisterns, and fountains located throughout Drakkenheim. Of course, the damage and disarray to both systems means it's sometimes difficult to tell the difference. In these confined tunnels are all manner of horrible creatures. @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.142lobfrog000000]{Lob Frogs}, @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimPre04.JournalEntryPage.403deepdregs0000]{Deep Dregs}, @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.113bloatedhive00]{Bloated Hives}, @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.121drakkensewgtr]{Drakkenheim Sewer Gators}, and @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.146sewerthing000]{Sewer Things} all lurk in the fetid waters under the city.

Those agile and athletic enough to leap and run across the rooftops may evade threats in the streets below, but expose themselves to the wide range of airborne creatures who rule the skies above Drakkenheim, such as @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.149skretch000000]{Skretches}, @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.147shardmaulmant]{Shardmaul Manticores}, and @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.128eldritchcata0]{Eldritch Cataclysms}.

Notable Locations.name: Notable Locations
Notable Locations.text:
Notable Locations

Castle Drakken

Built atop a high crag overlooking the city is this imposing military fortress and royal palace. It once stood as a glimmering beacon over Drakkenheim, and a testament to the majesty and royalty of the city. Now, the castle looms over the ruins, a dark and foreboding presence whose shadow casts an ever-present feeling of gloom and despair.

The castle is made up of two front gates along a winding path up the cliffside that leads to the upper and lower bailey. The lower bailey houses the castle stables and barracks. The upper bailey holds the castle chapel, gardens, and courtyard. The castle proper is composed of a long central building, with five great towers attached to it.

The castle is now overrun with demons, devils, vengeful spirits, and all manner of mutated monstrosities. Some of the most horrible monsters in Drakkenheim such as the @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.130gravekeeper00]{Gravekeeper}, and the @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.106amalgamationn]{Amalgamation} reside in the castle, but the halls are filled with @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.151warpwitch0000]{Warp Witches}, @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.131hazehusk00000]{Haze Husks}, @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimDel02]{Dregs}, and a menagerie of other horrors, making it one of the most dangerous locations in the city.

Drann River

The wide Drann River flows southwest, and divides Drakkenheim into the North Ward and the South Ward. Averaging about four hundred feet wide as it travels through the city, the water is deep, slow-moving, and thoroughly contaminated.

The Drann River travels hundreds of miles before it empties into Ash Bay at the port city of Drannsmund. The Drann can accommodate lumber barges and small row boats, but seaworthy sailing vessels cannot travel this far upriver. While there are small quays and docks along the Drann, it does not support large ports.

The polluted waters of the Drann carry a steady amount of delerium downstream, and the river is now home to a wide variety of contaminated monsters, including @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.142lobfrog000000]{Lob Frogs}, @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.121drakkensewgtr]{Drakkenheim Sewer Gators}, @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.123elementalcont]{Animated Delerium Sludges}, and the @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimPre04.JournalEntryPage.403deepdregs0000]{Deep Dregs}.

Four large bridges cross the Drann River from the north to south ward of Drakkenheim. All of which can be found in the Inner City, while the Outer City houses two ferries, one to the south, and one to the northeast.

Champion's Bridge

This decorated stone causeway is the largest in Drakkenheim at nearly five hundred feet long and fifty feet wide. It extends from Champion's Way in the south over towards the great Market Square in the Middle Ward. Five arched spans supported by stone piers hold the bridge thirty feet above the Drann. The bridge has an elegant stone guardrail, and overhanging balconies spaced along its outer edges each hold statues depicting mighty heroes from Drakkenheim's past. Today, the haunted bridge is home to countless monsters who occupy both the waters below, and the bridge itself. @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.142lobfrog000000]{Lob Frogs}, @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.113bloatedhive00]{Bloated Hives}, and even the @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.121drakkensewgtr]{Drakkenheim Sewer Gator} have been spotted in the areas under the bridge and some of these creatures wander up to its surface when hungry, looking for anything to eat.

Temple Bridge

This narrow bridge is made up of white cobblestone with seven stone arches supporting it twenty to twenty-five feet above the Drann River. The bridge is only twelve feet wide and has a slight arched curve to it as it extends across the river. A wrought iron fence flanks either side of the bridge, and every ten feet a tall, ornate pillar holds a torch. These torches have long been snuffed out, and the once pristine and bright bridge is now caked in dirt and blood. @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimPre04.JournalEntryPage.402garmyr0000000]{Garmyr} occupy the bridge now and hold a small encampment on the north side of it.

Saint Selina's Bridge

This bridge was under construction when the meteor struck, and sections made of thick wooden scaffolds are still set between the partially complete stone arches. The ruined bridge is extremely hazardous, with many of its support beams missing or damaged. A section of the bridge has crumbled and one of the arches is jutting out of the water below. Anyone daring the bridge must keep their wits about them, as any section of it could collapse at a moment's notice. Several @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.149skretch000000]{Skretches} who perch upon the city walls occasionally fly over and circle the bridge, waiting for an accident to grant them an easy meal, while @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.109beetleknightt]{Beetle Knights} skitter below the bridge, and a great @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.107anomolluskkkk]{Anomollusk} occupies the stony debris below.

Albrecht's Crossing

The northernmost bridge is the oldest in Drakkenheim and was constructed originally as the main entrance to the city from the south, when the city was only the Old Town surrounding Castle Drakken. The bridge was constructed during the reign of the last House von Drakken monarch, Albrecht, and is made of finely crafted brass and iron into one of the most beautiful functional art pieces in the city. The bridge is lined with metal sculptures of dancing dragons that flow and coil around the railings, the long walkway etched with depictions of heroic deeds of long dead warriors. Now caked in debris and moss, the metal has lost its shine, but the bridge still stands sturdy against time. A @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimTro07]{Troll} encampment sits on the north side of the bridge while the south is close to the Crater, and well known for being a hot spot of @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.rules.JournalEntry.NizgRXLNUqtdlC1s.JournalEntryPage.D2BdqS1GeD5rcZ6q]{Undead} and @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimDel02]{Dregs}.

Stick's Ferry

Old Sticks was a simple ferryman who ran a small rowboat crossing from The Sprawl to The Spokes in the southern stretch of the Outer City. He used to be a talkative sort, always wanting to hear the stories of the people he took across the Drann while sharing his own tales. Old Sticks was known amongst the locals as a jovial and kindhearted man, who simply loved being out on the water and enjoyed the steady, meditative nature of rowing. An elderly man in his late sixties, he would always claim that rowing kept his heart young, and joked that when he did eventually go, wherever he ended up he would likely just keep rowing if he could. Old Sticks didn't survive the initial blast of the meteor. He is now a @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.131hazehusk00000]{Haze Husk} that seems to lack any of the normal hostile traits of the undead in the city. True to his word, he is content to just keep rowing people back and forth for an eternity.

Abandoned Ferry

The northeast stretch of the Drann in the Outer City has become a difficult place to cross. The ferry that once operated here is left abandoned. This old raft has been pulled up on shore with an old frayed rope that lazily stretches across the river. Now a self-service ferry of sorts, explorers can use the rope to cross the Drann. The river here is home to multiple @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.142lobfrog000000]{Lob Frogs} that hide under the two docks of the old ferry path and lay their eggs in large clusters there. A crude sign has been placed on the south banks by some unknown adventurer that simply reads “Don't.”

Outer City

Stretching outward from the city walls in all directions, the Outer City itself comprises three main districts: Kingside, The Sprawl, and The Spokes.

Kingside

The area north of the Drann River to the east of the city walls is known as Kingside. Appropriately, the district is built along King's Way on the way to King's Gate. This once lush and beautiful landscape had the largest manors and houses outside the walls. It was also home to some well-known vineyards, inns, and the most luxurious stables, orchards, and cider houses in the city. Since the fall of Drakkenheim, strange magics have rested in the area. Twisted creatures haunt the old vineyards and inns, an eerie and constant chorus of wails and moans echo through the wide streets, and packs of @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimTro07]{Trolls} hunt the area looking for fresh meat.

The Sprawl

The large region west of the city walls is known as The Sprawl. Three main roads, Shepherd's Way, Temple Road, and College Street, all cross The Sprawl towards their respective gates. This stretch of small, packed together houses, street markets, taverns, and shops was always bustling with people prior to the collapse of the city. It was the most densely populated area in Drakkenheim. This unfortunately means that now it is also one of the most densely populated areas for the horrible, mutated monsters that roam the old streets and ruined buildings, filled with @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimDel02]{Dregs}, @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRat03]{Ratlings} and @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.114bojack0000000]{Bojacks}.

The Spokes

The Spokes are the entire area outside the walls south of the Drann River. Champion's Way, leading to Champion's Gate, is the main road through The Spokes, and the only one that is paved. This large assortment of industrial buildings, warehouses, shops, mills, and taverns was where most of Drakkenheim's industry happened. Brewers, smiths, forges, lumber mills, tanners, granaries, and textile mills make up a large portion of the area closest to the walls, while many of the most established farms spanning out further south from The Spokes, connecting down to Emberwood Village five miles away. Now most of the buildings lie in ruin, shattered and broken by the initial blast of the falling star that landed right on the edge of where The Spokes meet the South Ward. The Spokes is the most ruined area in Drakkenheim—rubble blocks streets, buildings barely stand, and the place holds the Haze, dust, and debris thick in the air. The Spokes is a common place to find some of the more horribly mutated monsters such as @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.120digipede00000]{Digipedes}, @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.138kronen0000000]{Kronen}, @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.118darkgrowth000]{Dark Growths}, and @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.122effulgent0000]{Effulgent Cnidarians}.

Inner City

Protected within the walls, the densely packed Inner City features winding cobblestone streets and towering spires of stone. Decorated plazas and broad squares mark major landmarks, monuments, and important buildings. Major landmarks in the Inner City include the ornate Saint Virturvio's Cathedral, the Inscrutable Tower of the Amethyst Academy, the lush and verdant Queen's Park Garden, the once-bustling Market Square, the Cosmological Clocktower, and Slaughterstone Square.

South Ward

Once the most densely populated area of the Inner city, South Ward had rows of small shops, temples, and taverns along its main roads, with packed houses grouped together in small bustling communities. Now, it is nothing but smoldering, indistinguishable ruins. A wood beam, or a stone arch jutting from the ground amidst ash and rubble, is mostly what you will find as you draw closer to the great Crater Basin. From decrepit wooden skeletons of homes, to piles of shattered stone, heaped bodies, and half buried foundations, the landscape becomes increasingly sparse closer to the Crater. Finding a standing structure in the South Ward is rare, and often filled with monsters such as @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.138kronen0000000]{Kronen}, @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimDel02]{Dregs}, or @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.139lastmemory000]{Last Memories}. This ward is also a common place for @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.141loathsomegagf]{Gag Flies} and @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.133hazewingmoth0#hazewing-moths]{Hazewing Moths}.

Old Town

Old Town stretches through the northeast of the Inner City and was the first area of Drakkenheim to be built. It is made up of well-spaced properties, each with a large manor house. Main roads are lined with stables, high end shops, and well-regarded establishments. Much of this area of the city remains intact, especially the old Kleinberg Estate resting against the cliffs that lead up to Castle Drakken. Although known as the wealthiest part of the city, in its ruin this area is now a prime haunt for malfeasant wizards to operate. Old Town is home to @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.110belfray123456]{Belfrays}, @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.120digipede00000]{Digipedes}, @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.122effulgent0000]{Effulgent Cnidarians}, and has been known to be a hunting ground for @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.140livingcity000]{Living Cities}.

Middle Ward

The Middle Ward was a common place for inns, taverns, shops, and a few of the more prominent blacksmiths and woodcarvers. Sprawling through the west end of the city, it is the largest district in the Inner City. The Great Market Square rests on the inner border of the Middle Ward and was the most popular place for shopping in the city. The Middle Ward also housed many of the prestigious playhouses and brothels of the city. Now ruled over by the @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimPre04.JournalEntryPage.405hazewindharpi]{Harpies}, and an abundance of undead like @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.131hazehusk00000]{Haze Husks}, @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.132hazewight0000]{Haze Wights}, @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.108arcanewraithh]{Arcane Wraiths}, and @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.151warpwitch0000]{Warp Witches}.

Temple Ward

The Temple Ward makes up the southwest portion of the Inner City around Temple Gate and Temple Road. The main attraction of the Temple Ward is Saint Virturvio's Cathedral, which towers high above the residential surroundings. Now packed with roving bands of @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimPre04.JournalEntryPage.402garmyr0000000]{Garmyr}, this once bright and vibrant part of the city is littered with carnage and death. Besides the roving packs of war dogs, one can expect to find @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.138kronen0000000]{Kronen}, @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.109beetleknightt]{Beetle Knights}, and @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.120digipede00000]{Digipedes} roaming through the buildings or hiding in the darkened corners of abandoned homes.

Queen's Park Garden

This elegant park was built to commemorate the ruling monarchs of Westemär and their royal consorts. The garden was a social hub during the spring and summer, featuring bountiful fountains, secluded grottos, grand monuments, and lush gardens.Today, the entire area is covered by the Deep Haze (see appendix C). Queen's Park Garden has been transformed into a terrifying maze. Before the meteor struck, from its trellised paths, you could nearly see from one side of the park to the other, and most landmarks could be seen from the central fountain. Today, adventurers exploring the park speak of getting lost in the thickets; the once carefully curated orchards are now dangerously tangled forests.

Queen's Park Locations

  1. Lenore's Grotto. An elegant, tiered garden with two rectangular pools marks the entrance to a wondrous grotto built for the Queen Consort to Ulrich IV.
  2. Lunar Meadows of Arwen. This once lush green clearing was a prime spot for stargazing, or picnics dotted with small floral patches and a babbling creek.
  3. Fountain of Beauty. The heart of Queen's Park Garden is a majestic, multi-tiered marble fountain which honors all the royal women of Westemär.
  4. Botanical Gardens of Mother Danu. These vast gardens housed the largest assortment of flowers in all of Westemär, including unique species brought in from the Far Continent.
  5. Queen Eleanor's Lavender Fields. A winding cobblestone path navigated through these beautiful purple flowers with small benches and statues dotting the walkway.
  6. Old Willow Falls. Near the north end of the gardens is a natural three-tiered waterfall that flows into the winding river that snakes through the gardens, next to it is the oldest tree in Drakkenheim, a massive weeping willow.
  7. Weeping Angels of Gunhilda. Not far from the willow is a clearing holding multiple statues of weeping angels gifted from Caspia to Queen Gunhilda years ago. Mists from the waterfall hang low around the moss-caked statues giving the clearing a fantastical ancient atmosphere.
  8. Dream-pools of Phantasia. Several small bridges and walkways weave between ornate pools and fountains, the sound of flowing water filling the space. In the center, a statue of Phantasia watches over the pools, smiling.
  9. Statue of Nuada Vitrix. This glorious statue depicts the Old God Nuada as a winged valkyrie striking down the enemies of Drakkenheim.
  10. Hildegarde's Arch. This impressive victory arch on four columns commemorates Queen Hildegarde von Drakken I's signing of the Edicts of Lumen.
  11. Helena's Column. Dedicated to House von Kessel's first monarch, Helena I, who used the Crown of Westemär's power to cure a plague ravaging the nation. Her deeds are etched upon the column, and a bust of her likeness rests on top.
  12. Carmen's Dragons. This topiary garden depicts the famous draconic mounts of Carmen von Drakken, the first Queen of Westemär. Oddly, despite the garden's overgrown state, these masterpieces remain well-trimmed and pristine.
  13. Theresa's Grove. A small clearing featuring several standing rocks and simple benches, all overtaken by creeping vines.
  14. Lily Ponds of Queen Beatrice. The lily ponds once housed many different frogs and fish, as well as an old tower that one could climb to see most of Drakkenheim and overlook the gardens.
  15. Groundskeeper's House. The gnomish head groundskeeper, Wilber Greenroot Pebblepond, and his many gnome gardeners kept their tools here, conducted garden business, and also rested here on night shifts.
  16. Corridor of Queens. The main cobblestone road leading from the south entrance of the gardens up to the central fountain is flanked by large ten-foot-tall statues of every queen that ruled Drakkenheim.

Crater Basin

The meteor that annihilated Drakkenheim landed in the South Ward, shattering part of the wall dividing the Inner and Outer City. Little remains of the original buildings save wreckage and the gaping crater. Swirling mists fill the Crater while an eldritch storm rages overhead. It is perhaps the most dangerous and contaminated region in Drakkenheim. No expedition into its depths has ever returned to tell the tale — except for Lucretia Mathias, leader of the Followers of the Falling Fire. Today, the Chapel of Saint Gresha by the Crater's Edge is a destination for the faction's pilgrims seeking to partake in their most sacred rituals.

Exceptionally dangerous creatures dwell here, including @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.107anomolluskkkk]{Anomollusks}, @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.117craterwurm000]{Crater Wurms}, @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.123elementalcont]{Contaminated Elementals}, @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.128eldritchcata0]{Eldritch Cataclysms}, and @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.108arcanewraithh]{Arcane Wraiths}.

Pulsing at the Crater's center is the throbbing Delerium Heart, a massive formation of the magical crystals which was the core of the meteor itself. If it were ever destroyed, the resulting disasters would unleash the terrifying @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.152theworldend00]{World Ender}.

Adventure Hooks.name: Adventure Hooks
Adventure Hooks.text:
Adventure Hooks

Mimic Mayhem

The player characters are searching for a relic or heirloom lost in an old family estate. Unfortunately, the entire manor house has transformed into a @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.140livingcity000]{Living City}!

The Old Library

An old library has been infested with contaminated undead horrors, but some of the books might be of value to one of the many factions. An old mage now resides in the library as an @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.108arcanewraithh]{Arcane Wraith}, and the staff are all @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.131hazehusk00000]{Haze Husks}, @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.151warpwitch0000]{Warp Witches}, and @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.132hazewight0000]{Haze Wights}.

The Ruined Tower

An old, dilapidated tower could make an excellent vantage point if it could be cleared out. Be wary of the @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.149skretch000000]{Skretches} and @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.110belfray123456]{Belfrays} occupying it though.

Crossing the Drann

The Drann river has no means of crossing it on the north-east side of the city save for a raft and a rope to pull you across. Apparently, several @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.142lobfrog000000]{Lob Frogs} and sightings of a massive gator have made traversing that way even harder, so naturally, someone needs to check it out.

Hunt for the Chimera

Horror stories are spreading of the @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.115cacophonous00]{Cacophonous Chimera} killing large groups of faction agents heading into the city. The creature has been spotted all over the city, but none have been able to fell the dreadful beast.

Amalgamation.name: Amalgamation
Amalgamation.text:
Amalgamation

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.3imgamalgamation inline]

Statblock: @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.2Msb23l9F9GpB7hy]{Amalgamation}

Before the throne is a gibbering amalgamation of fleshy tumors, rotting bones, and rancid layers of bloated fat suspended between the ceiling and floor by stalky strands of gnarled tissue. A palpable aura of contamination emanates from the beast. The mass is covered in bursting sores and shuddering mucus nodule that weep bile and delerium sludge. The creature mutters in alien tongues from six yawning mouths, piping and sputtering in discordant musical tones, and lazily shifting eyes of massive size open and close throughout its bulk. Thick trunk-like tentacles reach out from its hideous stinking form to squirm and writhe around the chamber. Several appendages are wrapped around pulsing human organs: lungs, liver, kidney, a heart, a brain, and dangling amongst them is the jeweled Crown of Westemär.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef01.JournalEntryPage.vC0XgHhgAb9NS4G4 inline]

There is no royal etiquette when dealing with a swelling growth wearing a crown. Use fire.

Anomollusk.name: Anomollusk
Anomollusk.text:
Anomollusk

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.4imganomolluskkk inline]

Statblock: @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.T1wJYE6nV9LHTcZb]{Anomollusk}

A colossal snail as wide as a city street with a shell the size of a small house glides slowly into view. Its shell has a kaleidoscopic fractal shimmer, projecting hues of unknown colors that swirl in incomprehensible patterns. As it moves, its shell seems to refract light in ways that seem nonsensical or wrong. You must strain your eyes to look at it wriggle towards you. Its bulbous head ends in two long antennae each holding a small octarine eye. Slimy mucus drips off its flesh, leaving sizzling trails and corroding anything it touches.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef01.JournalEntryPage.VoohwIlEMGvUm7dq inline]

Arcane Wraith.name: Arcane Wraith
Arcane Wraith.text:
Arcane Wraith

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.5imgarcanewraith inline]

Statblock: @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.NSxLGrWD2k1N2VnO]{Arcane Wraith}

Tattered purple robes hang off the ethereal skeleton drifting silently through the air. Its rune-inscribed skull menacingly chants arcane words as points of octarine light flare from the dark holes of its eyes.
