Deep Dregs.name: Deep Dregs
Deep Dregs.text:
Deep Dregs

C uriously, Curiously, creatures transformed by exposure to the contaminated waterways of Drakkenheim often develop piscine features and aquatic adaptations. Although they have similar origins to Delerium Dregs, many of these so-called Deep Dregs have become thralls to an eldritch entity dwelling deeper in the sewers of Drakkenheim known as the Duchess. This nightmarish horror lurks deep below Drakkenheim's forsaken waterways, slowly amassing contaminated minions while fostering dark dreams to usurp control of the surface.

The Deep Dregs patrol the sewers and waterways of Drakkenheim while making forays onto the surface to gather supplies or take captives. Despite the ambitions of the Duchess, Deep Dregs are peculiarly social, and frequently do not attack explorers and faction agents when they encounter them. Rather, Deep Dregs can be indifferent or even helpful in some cases. However, beneath the surface lurks a monstrous plot, as the Duchess commands her Deep Dregs to seek out fresh subjects.

The Duchess's body secretes contaminating mucus. When this slime is combined with delerium and used to contaminate a humanoid creature, that individual transforms into a Deep Dreg should they succumb to a monstrous transformation. Mortals with significant martial or magical talents may instead become deep knights or deep sirens. These transformed mortals dimly remember their former lives, but are stricken with madness and are forever cursed to serve the Duchess. They look back on their land-bound lives with scorn, and unquestionably follow the Duchess's will.

Roleplaying Traits

Refer the following traits when roleplaying the Deep Dregs and the Duchess's thralls if the player characters attempt to converse with them:

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.tables.RollTable.geo5wdL30en1vYax rollable]

Combat Tactics

Deep Dregs prefer to fight in areas where they can take advantage of their aquatic capabilities, such as contaminated sewer canals, rivers, and pools. While a few of their number might begin to parley, others lurk in the water, waiting for an opportune moment to strike. Especially when facing uncontaminated humanoids, Deep Dregs prefer to attack from the water since they know their foes are hesitant to risk contamination.

Often, Deep Dregs attempt to subdue their foes instead of killing them so they can bring live captives back to the Duchess, where she will transform the captives into fresh thralls. Deep Dregs also use the watery environment to their advantage, and may sometimes drag a Restrained target into contaminated water either as an attempt to mutate or drown the creature.

Locations and Lairs

Sewers of Drakkenheim

Throughout the sewers of Drakkenheim are many old tunnels, clogged waterways, and wide sewer passages that the Deep Dregs have transformed into small villages or encampments. Often small groups of the Dregs occupy these locations, collecting food and resources to bring back to the @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimPre04.JournalEntryPage.403deepdregs0000#the-duchess]{Duchess} or luring lost adventurers or faction agents to join them. These camps, although not immediately hostile, often house a handful of guards and knights who protect the Dregs that dwell there.

The Old Town Cistern

In the heart of Drakkenheim sits the Old Town Cistern, right below Slaughterstone Square. This old well is now filled with the bloated corpses of the @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimPre04.JournalEntryPage.404guardianconst#executioner]{Executioner} kills, and the Deep Dregs pick through the bodies looking for good meat and valuable trinkets to bring back to their @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimPre04.JournalEntryPage.403deepdregs0000#the-duchess]{Duchess}. The entrance to the Duchess's lair is in the Cistern and leads to a great cavern hidden underground where the Duchess and her minions plot their inevitable takeover of the city.

Adventure Hooks

Guests of Honor

A friendly @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimPre04.JournalEntryPage.403deepdregs0000#deep-dreg-warrior]{Deep Dreg Warrior} has offered to guide the player characters through the sewers, in exchange all that they ask is that you come and meet their leader, a @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimPre04.JournalEntryPage.403deepdregs0000#deep-siren]{Deep Siren} named Cookie who is about to hold a special ceremony. The ceremony of course is to indoctrinate newcomers with the contaminated mucus of the @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimPre04.JournalEntryPage.403deepdregs0000#the-duchess]{Duchess}. If they refuse, they will be given the serum by force.

The Duchess's Departure

The @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimPre04.JournalEntryPage.403deepdregs0000#the-duchess]{Duchess} has abandoned Drakkenheim, either by being discovered and forced to flee, or because the situation in the city became unfavorable to her ambitions. Fleeing the city down the Drann River, she escaped to Ash Bay, where the delerium of the city flows and rests along the bottom of the ocean, creating a massive reef of contaminated sea life. Here the Duchess plots her revenge on mortals, and slowly her minions have begun to creep into the homesteads and small villages along the Crystal Coast.

Deep Dregs

T ransformed Transformed into monsters by the contaminated waters of the Drann River, these piscine abominations now follow the deep call of the malevolent Duchess.

Deep Dreg Warrior

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.96imgepdregs0000 inline]

Statblock: @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.dA9zcvxOSBENxH22]{Deep Dreg Warrior}

Emerging from the contaminated waters is a humanoid figure with disturbing piscine mutations. Their body is covered in glittering scales of sea green, midnight purple, and deep blue. Their monstrous face has two large, bulbous eyes and a gaping, fishlike mouth filled with oddly-shaped teeth—a mixture of humanoid, shark, and other aquatic animals. Spindly, fleshy whiskers surround their fish lips. They have webbed feet and hands, and thin fins jut from their arms, legs, and face. They wear little more than ragged clothing and scraps of leather armor, and carry a brace of javelins, a spear, and a fishing net.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef01.JournalEntryPage.86bioepdregs0000 inline]

If you have to fight it don't do it in water because it likes that and you won't.

The Duchess

This horrific monstrosity is larger than a whale. It has a long, serpentine body bristling with sleek fins, undulating barbed tentacles, and rubbery, purple-black flesh. It writhes through the waves with unearthly grace despite its bulk, and seeping from its flaps and vents are secretions of a thick, oozing oil which shimmers with prismatic hues. It has adorned its brow with fishing nets, coral, sea debris, and delerium crystals, resembling a coronet and jewelry. As you look upon its form, you feel a slight headache, a buzzing in your ear, and a pressing in your chest; as if the psychic presence of this otherworldly creature has conjured the crushing pressure of the abyssal depths. It has a gigantic, fanged maw which it holds agape. Seaweed, fish entrails, and slime dribble from between its sharp teeth, and its bulbous eyes glow with octarine light.

Guardian Constructs.name: Guardian Constructs
Guardian Constructs.text:
Guardian Constructs

T he The ancient and imperial city walls of Drakkenheim are decorated with baroque architectural features, including impressive columns and sculptures, iron-studded spiked trim, and carved corbels supporting the battlements. Most impressive are the grotesque gargoyles of stone, marble, and cast bronze which resemble winged fiends or ferocious dragons. However, these are no mere ornamentations. Centuries ago, the reigning monarch of Drakkenheim, Hildegarde von Drakken I, secretly used the power of the Crown of Westemär to bring these statues to life to serve as protectors for the city. These magical constructs were bound to the will of the monarch, but also answered to the commands of any who bore one of the six Seals of Westemär. Although rumors swelled about the living statues of Drakkenheim, the common folk never truly knew the full extent of the stone guardians watching over them.

During Ulrich von Kessel IV's last moments as the meteor overwhelmed the city, a final command was given to the constructs: “Protect Drakkenheim and its people!” However, the magical energies of the Haze have contaminated even these guardians, and the ambiguity of the king's last order has been corrupted in their construct minds. They enact a twisted interpretation which sets them upon any who dare trespass into the city, and view the mutated inhabitants of Drakkenheim as the very citizens they are charged to protect.

This has made adventuring into the city even more dangerous, and getting into the Inner City has proven difficult as scaling the walls or attempting to fly over them immediately draws the attention of the defenders. Approaching the castle has proven nearly impossible, and as for Slaughterstone Square, the small handful of survivors who have seen it simply encourage any traveling into the city to avoid it at all costs.

Roleplaying Traits

In the former glory of Drakkenheim the constructs of the city were bound to the crown and the holders of the seals of Drakkenheim. There are those who believe that obtaining all six seals would allow some control over the situation. Others think the contamination and Haze has caused an irreversible problem that can no longer be contained or controlled.

Distinguishing Decorations

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.tables.RollTable.msqZqUXdaEjsjT2M rollable]

Combat Tactics

Guardian constructs feel no pain, and know no fear. They are simply designed to protect the walls of the city, or the castle proper. They are relentless in their pursuit within the domains they occupy, but rarely chase a creature beyond their designated locations. The gargoyles and tower dragons stick to the city walls. Still, those who find themselves within the territories of these constructs are pursued by unflinching horror determined to protect its territory at all costs.

Locations and Lairs

City Walls, Gates, and Towers

During the construction of Drakkenheim, the outer walls of the city were built with large gargoyles facing both inside and outside the city. The towers along the walls were each constructed with a beautiful ornate dragon perched atop it. Across Drakkenheim's walls, there are approximately 500 beautifully constructed statues. They now guard the towers and walls from anyone who attempts to climb or fly over them, and hunts any intruders with vicious determination.

Castle Drakken

When Castle Drakken was constructed, it followed suite with the design of the city walls and housed gargoyles perched along every tower and roof, as well as several alcoves and niches throughout the building. Each tower was placed with a bronze dragon coiled along its roof. The central tower houses a massive statue of a dragon much more ornate and well decorated than the rest. The statue, named Minazorond, was built by the eccentric Liberio artist Nicoletti, and animated by a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.3okM6Gn63zzEULkz]{Wish} spell. It now acts as the sworn protector of the castle.

Slaughterstone Square

A great construct built by the Glitterpeak dwarves, recovered from the ruins and brought to Drakkenheim, was deemed “The Executioner” and designed to carry out the death sentence in Drakkenheim. The massive construct was a spectacle that many who traveled to the city would stop to witness. Now it haunts the square, consumed by a need to execute any living creature that enters its domain. Its original programming is confused—it deems anyone who sets foot in Slaughterstone Square a criminal worthy of the harshest sentence.

Adventure Hooks

Scale the Walls

Climbing the walls of Drakkenheim might still be one of the better ways into the city, and if a patch of the walls can be cleared of its constructs, perhaps there is a way to make a permanent entry point for those hoping to enter the city.

Reset

Perhaps there is a way to reset the programming of the constructs of Drakkenheim. If all the seals can be uncovered and brought to the throne room, control over the constructs could be a turning point in saving the city.

Guardian Constructs

Once animated by royal decree, these corrupt guardians now regard everyone and everything as a hostile trespassers and invaders assaulting the rule of Drakkenheim.

Wall Gargoyle

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.100imgrdianconst inline]

Statblock: @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.0ZP2Si5z0cTG7pha]{Wall Gargoyle}

These winged creatures resemble fiendish bats, often with grotesque exaggerated grinning or snarling faces. They are made completely of stone and remain motionless, but you swear that one is looking at you — and it was looking the other way just a moment ago, wasn't it?

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef01.JournalEntryPage.93bioardianconst inline]

Tower Dragon

Statblock: @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.3itQ9lsZB4cdOLeH]{Tower Dragon}

The bronze dragon coils around the top of the tower, its head outstretched toward the outskirts of the city, surveying the streets. Its body is meticulously crafted and beautifully detailed, as you think you notice it move its head ever so slightly toward you.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef01.JournalEntryPage.92bioardianconst inline]

Executioner

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.102imgrdianconst inline]

The massive construct looms menacingly within the center of Slaughterstone Square. Pacing back and forth, it drags its guillotine blade behind it, with the grinding of steel on stone echoing off the old buildings. Its form is a mass of steel plates and gears resembling a huge suit of armor. From within its frame, the glow of octarine light illuminates it with an eerie glow of corruption. The poor souls of its victims cling to it, reaching out in terror as if clawing to escape their last moments when the Executioner took their heads.

How do you dead what is dead?I see no end to this riddle.

Its cold eyes detect the slightest movement within the castle grounds. It stands, its wings unfurling, and cracks of octarine energy pulsing throughout its wicked form. As lightning forks behind it, illuminating its draconic form in all its majesty, it readies itself for the hunt.

Hazewind Harpies.name: Hazewind Harpies
Hazewind Harpies.text:
Hazewind Harpies

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.104imgewindharpi inline]

T he The harpies who occupy the towers throughout Drakkenheim can be heard singing their discordant hymns throughout the streets, luring lost adventurers to their doom. The harpies are some mutated combination of humanoid and avian, though it is believed many of them were once birds who occupied the towers in the city, now twisted by the Haze and corruption.

You can find these creatures nesting in the tallest structures throughout the city and prowling the skies, making aerial travel within the city exceptionally dangerous. The harpies have managed to make uneasy alliances with other flying monsters throughout the city and are known to befriend manticores, who they often use as brute protectors of their territories, as well as keeping the awful skretches nearby as additional problems for any who would threaten them.

Their songs echo through the streets of the city and have a haunting effect on those who draw close. From a distance, travelers may feel a building tension or a sense of unease when the chorus of disarming melodies hits them. Those closer to the harpies may be drawn in by the tunes, or even find themselves entranced by them. Some who have heard the songs have felt a strange sense of dream-like wonder, only to snap out of it by being plucked off the ground by the harpies. Most who hear the melodies do not live to share their stories.

The clock tower has become the roost of their leader, the Crimson Countess. While the harpies hunt the streets of the city and attack anything that attempts to fly in or out, they all answer the call of the Crimson Countess, who loves plucking adventurers from the streets, and protects her tower with ferocity and cunning. She enjoys the tower for its open concept—perfect for flinging foolish adventurers who dare challenge her domain.

Roleplaying Traits

The hazewind harpies are loyal to their chain of command, and all serve the matriarchs and crones of their communities. They are proud warriors who are well trained combatants and skilled hunters.

Combat Tactics

Hazewind harpies stick to the skies and high towers, relying on ranged attacks to down their foes. Stronger harpies swoop in and pluck their enemies off the street, lifting them into the air before dropping them to their death. When possible, harpies find perches, rafters, balconies, or other higher vantage points to take cover, attacking from these optimal positions.

Harpies attack as a unit and almost always travel in a flock. If a harpy is alone, it usually means it is lost or it has allies nearby.

Locations and Lairs

The Cosmological Clock Tower

The Crimson Countess makes her lair in the great clock tower in Market Square. Her and her greatest champions occupy the tower, claiming the central streets of Drakkenheim as their territory. Any who have opposed the Crimson Countess must climb the tower's dangerous stairs while fending off harpies. The Crimson Countess herself has knocked many would-be heroes to their death from the highest balconies of the clock tower. It is an incredibly defendable position for flying creatures, and one not easily taken.

Old Town Towers

Many ancient towers now lie in ruin within Old Town. These were once command posts for the original city guard and older temples in the city. Most of these locations have been occupied by harpy nests, and the streets are now a hunting ground for the avian huntresses

Adventure Hooks

Disturbing the Nest:

A group of harpies led by a deadly crone has occupied a small watchtower in the sprawl and the surrounding area has become a death trap for navigating or traversing. Someone needs to put those harpies down and make travel through the sprawl at least mildly safer.

Break a Few Eggs

An apothecary in Drakkenheim is paying good money for anyone willing to obtain a harpy egg for them for an experiment. It needs to be undamaged and unhatched in order to work. So whoever gets it needs to also make it out of the city without taking more than half their Hit Points in damage, otherwise the egg will be ruined.

Out to Lunch

The harpies have plucked a group of Queen's Men or Hooded Lanterns from the city streets and taken them back to their roost. We need someone to go get them out, but the roost is likely swarming with harpies, so stealth will be key.

Hazewind Harpies

T he The witch-covens of the Hazewind Harpies rule the skies over the Inner City of Drakkenheim. They unleash terrifying screams and haunting songs which echo down the city streets.

Hazewind Harpy Crone

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.105imgewindharpi inline]

Statblock: @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.O5AwbPTwLaz5vQPt]{Hazewind Harpy Crone}

The crone perches atop a stoop, its elegant wings unfurl, revealing a massive, 12-foot wingspan that vividly shimmers green, blue, violet, and gold. Unlike most harpies, it lacks arms. Its taloned feet clutch its perch, while matted, white hair falls upon wrinkled, sagging flesh. Sitting atop a long neck, its face seems distorted, bearing a hooked nose and pointed chin—its grin too wide, its teeth too sharp, and its eyes too large and white. Adorned with feathered necklaces, earrings, and a crown of golden ivy, it sings a chorus of unsettling notes, seemingly glowing with radiant light.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef01.JournalEntryPage.94biozewindharpi inline]

The harpy has great wings which end in claw-like hands in place of arms, their avian legs end in talons, and they have a feathered plume and tail feathers. They grasp their weapons in their taloned feet as they bear themselves aloft, adroitly aiming an elegant longbow.

Verminous Multitudes.name: Verminous Multitudes
Verminous Multitudes.text:
Chapter 3:
Ratlings

Verminous Multitudes

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.73imgrminousmult inline]

"Dirty plague-bearing vermin that feed on even the leftovers of the scavengers. Surprisingly resilient! Quite the little tunnelers too. I think it's a numbers game with them, making rabbits look monogamous. It must be the delerium that drives them mad. I have seen them grow, talk and even build. As pets they are quite loyal but they quickly outgrow the care you can provide and you end up throwing them in a sewer with the rest of their lot. They swarm and bite with razor sharp teeth. The little ones can squeeze through the plates of your armor and find the tender spots. Nasty little rodents with big appetites. I've watched lesser men become simply an appetizer. Not me, Pluto Jackson is like a banquet! All you can eat and I never close! These delerium rats are something to behold as they rival the intellect of even our sharpest Caspian minds. They study the wizard books and write as they chatter their teeth but it is all for nothing as their furry little bodies fall upon the swords of my Caspian brothers in arms for they are simple pests that must be exterminated. That being said, no harm will come from tucking your pants in your boots."

—Pluto Jackson

D rakkenheim Drakkenheim was notorious for its rat infestation. The back alleys and basements of the Sprawl teemed with rats, and countless more prowled the sewers. As a result, many households kept cats, and the city even commissioned a Rat Trapper's Guild to help control the rat population to little avail. When the city fell to ruin, the problem grew much, much worse. Delerium mutated the rats into ratlings, hideous monsters imbued with a malevolent cunning, and driven by a mad compulsion to consume and multiply.

Ratlings grow to the size of a gnome or halfling, with big eyes and ears, and large, pointed noses. They are slender creatures, covered with matted, coarse fur, and with thick hairless tails longer than their bodies. Today, thousands of ratlings dwell in Drakkenheim, lurking in underground burrows and subterranean tunnels. An individual ratling is far from the most fearsome threat in Drakkenheim, but these verminous multitudes present a creeping, gnawing danger that could one day grow beyond any other.

Mutated Vermin

Ratlings begin their lives as ordinary rats. Born in the contaminated sewers and subterranean tunnels of Drakkenheim, their pups feed on carrion tainted with eldritch contamination. The continual ingestion of delerium accelerates their development and mutation, allowing a ratling pup to reach maturity in just a few weeks. A ratling can live for five to seven years, although many die from infighting or accidents within their first year or two.

Granted a warped intellect by delerium, ratlings suffer from a constant internal struggle between their cowardly survival instincts and violent and impulsive urges. Ratlings dream of eating everything, and will eat anything, but especially love eating people. They have acquired an appetite for humans that are easy to capture, kill, and devour such as children and the elderly, and especially babies. While they can subsist on carrion, ratlings prefer fresh meat, and will take captives back to their lairs.

Despite their innate madness and violent predilections, ratlings are industrious and will fashion makeshift gear from scavenged equipment, favoring long knives, rusty spears, slings, and crossbows. They rarely wear armor, although they have been known to strap scrap metal pauldrons or an occasional breastplate onto their matted fur. Ratlings sometimes carry makeshift shields that once were shutters, tabletops, or parts of a door to defend themselves. Crafty and resourceful, a rare few ratlings have even learned to master the contaminated magic that created them, becoming powerful spellcasters.

Cunning Cowards

Ratlings display inherent naivety towards basic human concepts, especially kindness, empathy, and bravery. Many adventurers have made a grave mistake thinking ratlings are simple-minded fools. While ratlings care little for the lives of others, they value their own hide above all and will do just about anything to survive. Most are cowards who will flee at the first sign of a losing battle, willing to throw their best friend in the way of a hungry gator, a swarm of harpies, or a battle-ready group of adventurers if it ensures their own escape. When cornered or trapped, ratlings often break down in tears to beg for their lives, and offer delerium, information, or help infiltrating or sneaking through the city in exchange for their life. Those who have survived the longest usually become cunning warriors and clan leaders, and tend to develop skills in manipulation, lying, and bargaining.

Occasionally, adventurers exploring Drakkenheim make deals with ratlings they capture to act as guides into more treacherous parts of the city. Almost every time, the ratling eventually attempts a horrible betrayal. Ratlings are always waiting for the moment they can turn the situation in their favor, and lead their enemies into an ambush, or deliver them to the lair of a much more horrible monster.

Teeming Mass

Ratlings form colonies consisting of several closely related families. They work together to dig maze-like burrows that incorporate multiple entrances and tight looping passages. The biggest ratling usually leads the pack, though in some cases the smartest and most cunning can find themselves as leaders as well. Individual ratlings easily recognize others from their colony by scent, a trait which often foils adventurers trying to use disguises or trickery to infiltrate ratling burrows.

However, ratling colonies are quite hostile to each other, fighting over food and territory. Indeed, ratlings spend more time fighting each other than any other creatures or factions in the ruins, which is probably why they haven't taken over Drakkenheim yet. Successful colonies grow in number rapidly, as ratlings mature in a matter of weeks when ample food and delerium are available. The largest and most powerful ratling colonies bully others into submission and rule over them. Fortunately, intense competition with other ratling colonies over a limited food supply, predation from other monsters, and constant clashes with explorers and the Hooded Lanterns keeps their population in check. Lacking these constraints, their numbers would quickly swell beyond all hope of containment.

The Shiny

Ratlings call delerium “the shiny” and value the crystals highly. It acts as both a food source and a means to induce quick and aggressive mutations. Ratlings scratch out their burrows around delerium deposits and bring a steady flow of delerium into their burrows. It's the ratlings' obsession with delerium that generally causes them to forgo their inherent cowardice in exchange for wild aggression. Researchers or even a group of adventurers harvesting or carrying delerium are a prime pick for an ambush. Ratlings will kill just about anything to get their hands on more delerium and continue expanding their colonies.

The Rat God

Many ratlings worship a fiendish entity they call the Rat God. Ratlings construct crude effigies to the Rat God, who whispers to the most cunning and intelligent ratlings, granting them magic through eldritch pacts. This nightmarish and malevolent demon encourages the ratlings to multiply, collect delerium, and consume everything. Ratlings believe that the Rat God grows in power and size as they themselves feed and breed, and that one day the ravenous entity will emerge in the Mortal World to eat everything in an apocalyptic feast known as the Great Gnaw. The ratlincgs seem indifferent or oblivious to the implication they too will be devoured by their hungry god.

The Rat God is one of many powerful fiends inhabiting the cosmos that claims to be divine. Scholars of religion and the arcane postulate this being is likely not a true god and is more likely a rising demon lord. This technicality is utterly irrelevant to the Rat God's ratling worshippers. Although the Rat God cannot grant divine spells to its followers, they can create eldritch pacts, imbue ratlings with sorcerous powers, and inspire faith in a rare few truly devoted priests.

Beyond these details, Ratlings understand surprisingly little about the Rat God, and make up stories and fables about the ravenous god's exploits (see the @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRat03.JournalEntryPage.302roleplayingtr#beliefs-about-the-rat-god]{"Beliefs About the Rat God"} table). Even warlocks and oracles devoted to the strange being speak more lies than truths about its depiction, deeds, and desires. The full game statistics for the Rat God are described in @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimApp0A]{Appendix A: Ancient Entities}.

Roleplaying Traits.name: Roleplaying Traits
Roleplaying Traits.text:
Roleplaying Traits

The ratlings' goals seem simplistic to most: first there is the Great Feeding and then the Great Breeding until ratling numbers swell into an insurmountable army. Thousands upon thousands of vermin will pour from the sewers, ruins, burrows, and tunnels and into the streets and houses and, with the aid of the great Rat God, they will devour the world.

Murderous Monsters

As creatures born of otherworldly contamination, the ratlings are, above all else, gleeful and remorseless killers. They care little for their own wellbeing and the feelings and needs of others. The only thing a ratling cares about is their own goals, and how they can most easily obtain them. Although they will listen to reason, they only agree to cooperate with non-ratlings if they see an opportunity for themselves. Otherwise, they would rather simply murder every humanoid they see.

Manipulative and Cunning

Ratlings may not be the smartest creatures, but they know that other creatures are also driven by their goals and needs. When cornered and with little options left, they plead to the needs of their captors and promise anything, if it means their own survival. Oftentimes they are lying, but they will see their promises through until they can devise a better plan to backstab and murder their foes. Some ratlings have gone as far as being hired as guides and scouts to help adventurers enter Drakkenheim. They lead those parties safely through the maze of ruined streets, only to spring a ratling ambush, or bring them to the den of a more horrible monster and turn on them the moment the numbers are favorable.

Murderous Tendencies

Most ratlings are driven towards violence, though their motivation for doing so can vary from one to the next.

Beliefs About the Rat God

Ratlings make up fantastic stories about the Rat God's wrath and cunning. In truth, they know little about the Rat God except it likes the shiny, and they perform cannibalistic rituals in its name. Ratlings love eating, so they love these rituals.

Many ratlings are driven by irrational fears, causing them to act in unusual ways.

Ratling Names

When it comes to names, Ratlings tend to be very simple and disorganized in their naming conventions. Ratlings will sometimes name other ratlings at a young age, other times they completely forget to name the young and a ratling will name themselves once they can speak. Ratlings have been known to change their names from time to time based on the deeds they have accomplished, or their most notable achievement.

Ratling names are usually inspired by the sounds they make, the things they do, or a notable deformity or oddity they have. For example, the Rat Prince simply gained that name by declaring himself as such after leading a horde of ratlings into the Rat's Nest Tavern and eating the Dregs swarming the streets in that part of the city. In the process, he found some jagged metal that resembled a crown, conquered the Rat's Nest Tavern, and declared himself the Rat Prince. Often, a ratling will be given a nickname after it does something, and the name just sticks.

Locations and Lairs.name: Locations and Lairs
Locations and Lairs.text:
Locations and Lairs

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.74imgcationsandl inline]

Ratlings form vast labyrinths of intricate tunnels beneath Drakkenheim. Beginning from empty cellars, maintenance tunnels, and sewer canals, ratlings then dig their own passages and chambers. A ratling burrow is a looping maze filled with overlapping routes, dead-ends, traps, and dozens, if not hundreds, of hungry defenders.

Unbeknownst to surface-dwellers, ratlings occasionally dig tunnels extending out from the city limits, allowing them to slip away from the ruins to plunder the few remaining farmsteads nearby, and even threaten Emberwood Village. Perhaps one day, other cities in Westemär, or throughout the world, will hear a gnawing beneath their feet.

Burrows and Dens

A ratling lair is often composed of networks of winding tunnels, small hollowed out rooms, and multiple passages between them. Oftentimes these dens and burrows can be labyrinthian and cramped to outsiders, but to the ratlings they offer multiple positions to attack from, or to flee.

Strength in Numbers

Ratlings know that their strength is in numbers, and often design their burrows for quick access for fighting or fleeing. When they can, they will group together to fight as a large force. Attempting to use the winding and multiple passages to surround and overwhelm enemies.

Traps and Tunnels

Ratlings are notorious trap builders. Traversing their lairs is often more of a threat than actually facing the ratlings. Ratlings protect their lairs by building spiked pit traps, rolling barrels, and dug out holes in the walls and ceilings to fire from if they are infiltrated, as well as devising multiple other ways to thwart their enemies. They use poisons and fire to try and trap enemies inside areas of their burrows and burn or gas them to death. They lead intruders into trapped rooms or narrow corridors before dropping wooden gates down and lighting the hallway ablaze. Ratlings generally don't care about the damage their own traps do to their lairs, since they are happy to dig themselves out once the battle is over.

Sample Traps.

Some common ratling traps are listed below.

Spiked Pit. A creature who enters the space of a spiked pit must succeed on a [[/save dex 10 format=long]] or fall in the pit, taking [[/damage 2d6 type=piercing & 2d6 type=bludgeoning average]] damage. Climbing out of the pit requires an action and a successful [[/check ath dc=12 format=long]] check.

Collapsing Tunnel. All creatures in the area of the collapsing tunnel must succeed on a [[/save dex dc=12 format=long]] or take [[/damage 3d6 type=bludgeoning average]] damage and become &Reference[prone]. In addition, creatures that fail their saving throw by 5 or more become partially buried, gaining the &Reference[restrained] condition until they escape. A creature can use their action to make a [[/check ath dc=10 format=long]] check to escape the rubble. A creature that succeeds on its saving throw may choose which side of the collapse it wishes to be on.

Spike-bomb. All creatures in a 15-foot-radius Sphere from the trap that are not behind &Reference[totalcover] must make a successful [[/save dex dc=15 format=long]] or take [[/damage 4d4 type=piercing average]].

Poison Spray. All creatures within a 15-foot Cone from the trap must succeed on a [[/save con dc=15 format=long]] or become &Reference[poisoned] (save ends).

Cage Trap. All creatures within 5 feet of the cage trap must succeed on a [[/save dex dc=12 format=long]] or become &Reference[Immobilized]. A creature can break out of the cage by spending an action and making a successful [[/check ath dc=18 format=long]].

Roller-crusher. Any creature in the path of the roller-crusher must succeed on a [[/save dex dc=14 format=long]] or take [[/damage 3d8 type=bludgeoning average]] and be knocked &Reference[prone].

Pot of Acid. Any creature within 10 feet of the pot of acid must succeed on a [[/save con dc=14 format=long]] or take [[/damage 3d4 type=acid average]] and become &Reference[burning] ([[/damage 3d4 type=acid]]).

Flame Bottles. The ratling using the flame bottle must make a ranged attack against a target within 30 feet. On a hit, the target takes [[/damage 2d8 type=fire average]] and is &reference[burning] ([[/damage 2d8 fire]]). Hit or miss, the bottle shatters. The target and each creature within 5 feet of it must succeed on a [[/save dex dc=15 format=long]] or take [[/damage 2d6 type=fire average]].

Ratling Burrow

Groups of related ratlings live together in burrows. They often dig out the burrows to form networks of interweaving tunnels, trap filled hallways, and several small rooms that they use for storage, sleeping, or gathering. Below are several common rooms you would find in a ratling burrow.

Altar to the Rat God

A Rat God's altar often includes a crude effigy of varying depictions. Where one depicts a massive, bloated rat, another shows a demon-like figure with wings and horns, and others might present an almost angelic form. Regardless, these effigies are crudely made, involving horrifyingly graphic depictions of the Rat God devouring humans, or other murderous acts.

Ratlings leave offerings in the form of well-gnawed bones, bits of old food, delerium chunks, unusual looking rocks, and other trash few would find valuable. On rare occasions there may be [[/r 1d4]] copper, or a common gemstone worth 1 silver.

Ratling Hovels

These small chambers are where the ratlings sleep. Hovels are burrowed out as a network of small adjoining rooms, each lined with garbage, rags, hay, grass, and mud. Anything a ratling can find to make the hovel more comfortable for them to sleep in.

Food Storage

Ratlings enjoy fresh meat, so they occasionally take prisoners back to their burrows to consume later. To the ratlings, this storage space holds an assortment of fresh and old meat that needs to be regularly rotated out. To non-ratlings, it is a prison cage where they wait among the dead and half-dead to be eaten. They can clearly see their fate before them. Hung up on hooks are dead creatures, loose limbs, and half-eaten people struggling to survive.

Delerium Storage

Ratlings will keep shards and crystals of delerium, or even build their burrows around underground delerium veins; these become valuable parts of any ratling home and a place for the ratlings to gather in worship, or for planning. Sometimes delerium crystals will lightly illuminate the ratling burrows like tiny octarine lanterns.

Known Lairs

The City of Drakkenheim

Ratlings first mutated in the contaminated ruins of Drakkenheim — here the impact of their unchecked growth has had the most impact. They clog the sewers and streets of the city and every venture into the ruins is bound to put adventurers up against a swarm of ratlings. As their numbers swell, the prospect of the growing ratling horde grows more and more daunting.

The Sewers of Drannsmund

The city of Drannsmund has had several reports of large rats seen lurking near sewer entrances, and stories of monsters snatching children. People who stay out too late sometimes go missing when taking the back roads or quiet streets. Faction agents fear that the ratlings of Drakkenheim have made their way along the roads and into the sewer systems of other major cities as well.

Combat Tactics.name: Combat Tactics
Combat Tactics.text:
Combat Tactics

Every Advantage

Ratlings will use everything they can to gain the upper hand in battle, and never fight fairly if they can avoid it. If the environment can be used against their foes, or if they can lure their foes into a trap, they will. They will light things on fire, throw debris, cover the ground in oil, toss poison vials, and roll flaming barrels down ramps. Ratlings will surely take any opportunity to turn the tide in their favor.

Cowardly

Ratlings will not fight if they are outnumbered, or if a few of them go down in combat. Instead, as soon as the battle seems to turn against them, they fall back and regroup with more ratlings, trying to overwhelm and outnumber their foes with replenished numbers. If they do not stand to win the battle, the ratlings either plead for their lives and surrender, waiting for the right moment to backstab their foe, or flee. If the battle is lost, they will scurry off into the darkness and return to their burrow at a later time to rebuild.

Adventure Hooks.name: Adventure Hooks
Adventure Hooks.text:
Adventure Hooks

Vermintropolis

The Ratlings have occupied an entire city block within the city of Drakkenheim. All the houses, towers, and sewers below are one giant ratling nest.

Missing Persons

Children in the city of Drannsmund keep going missing when they are out past sunset. Rumors are spreading of strange people whispering from the sewers.

Maw Vermin

There is a rat in the old clock tower that has grown so fat with delerium contamination and mutations that it has now become a horrible Maw Vermin. Other ratlings are flocking to it. It needs to be destroyed.

Rescue Mission

Several Hooded Lantern scouts went missing near the sewers. They believe a ratling burrow has been made nearby, and those scouts might still be alive and in captivity.

A grotesque form lies before you. At first it seems to be just a mound of rotten meat, but its form becomes apparent when it turns toward you. A rat-like snout and eyes protrude from its rolling mass of pinkish flesh and patchy fur. It reaches for you with three long, gangly arms. Its midsection then opens with a yawning moan where a large purple tongue flops from between jagged teeth, slurping gobs of vile saliva as it drags itself towards its next meal.

Amalgamation.name: Amalgamation
Amalgamation.text:
D welling Dwelling within the throne room of Castle Drakken is the Amalgamation, the result of a cascading catastrophe of contamination and mutation.

When the meteor struck, several magical occurrences happened almost instantaneously throughout the city. The Fracturing of the Inscrutable Tower triggered haywire arcane anomalies through the city, while the impact of the meteor sent a shockwave of magical devastation that shattered glass, blew through stone and wood, and reduced most living creatures to ash. Others caught in the blast were instantly transformed into monsters, and buildings and streets were shifted into sentient growths and misshapen horrors.

Castle Drakken was an epicenter of magical wards, protective spells, divination, and all manner of inherently magical trinkets and artifacts. The throne room where King Ulrich sat housed several of the most powerful magical relics in Westemär. The Crown of Westemär being the most prominent, although King Ulrich himself held a magical scepter, wore four magical rings, and a possessed a protective amulet. Furthermore, the large circular stained glass window behind the throne was imbued with magic that allowed it to change colors and depict different images throughout the seasons.

Naturally, when the rippling wave of arcane destruction blasted through the throne room, it fractured the abundant magical energies within the room, immediately opening a rift to the Space Between Worlds (see chapter 9) and amalgamating all the king's men into a massive mound of rippling fatty flesh. King Ulrich tried to escape but the magical mayhem fused him to his throne. As the King melted, he was absorbed by the expanding flesh, his face coming to rest as a disfigured grimace placed in the center of the horrible Amalgamation.

The creature continued to grow as the years passed, and those who went searching for the lost king would soon become one with the Amalgamation as well. Tendrils of strange flesh now spread like a web of sinew and skin across the throne room while pulsing contamination ripples out of the grotesque mass. A massive maw spans the length of the creature with various human bones posing as jagged and sharp teeth. Its tongue is a writhing mass of intestines and gore. No longer can any semblance of those lost to the Amalgamation be found. The king's face still prominently sits above the creature's massive maw, a mocking display of the fragility of the empires of a world not ready to face horrors beyond their comprehension.

The Amalgamation has a multidimensional form that straddles the Material Plane and the Space Between Worlds. Its mere presence acts as an anchor for the dimensional rift that pulls more and more contamination into Drakkenheim.

Study the Foe

Characters who have one or more mutations, or who are afflicted with any form of madness gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they Study the Amalgamation, learning the following based on the result:

(20+) Multidimensional. You recognize its Immunities, and its Rejuvenation, Malignancy, and Immutable Form traits.

(25+) Insatiable Hunger. You know of the creature's Bite attack, as well as its Mind-Breaking Whispers ability.

(30+) Beyond Comprehension. You are aware of its strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.

Combat Tactics

The Amalgamation is a formidable foe capable of grappling multiple targets and eating them or throwing them around the battlefield. It constantly summons @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.CuSUJc5NnYVVaU0K]{Pyknic Maunders} as additional support while it uses Mind-Breaking Whispers to shatter the minds of its greatest threats.

The Amalgamation does not fear any mortal creature, believing itself indestructible to mortal means. It does not flee or cower.

Harvestable Components (Legendary)

Animus: Aberration.

Fluid: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor, Goopy Ooze, Acidic Bile.

Organs: Eyes, Heart, Flesh, Guts.

Natural Weapons: Tentacles, Teeth.

Hair: Hair.

Hide: Skin.

Dust: Aberrant Dust.

Trophy: The Crown of Westemär

Cacophonous Chimera.name: Cacophonous Chimera
Cacophonous Chimera.text:
T he The Cacophonous Chimera emerged from a catastrophic convergence of several creatures — a Garmyr, Deep Dreg, Manticore, Ratling, and a Harpy — amidst a fierce battle. Caught in a terrible arcane anomaly, these creatures were unwillingly combined into this single, horrific form. Each head retains the memories and instincts of its original form, driving the chimera in a constant battle for dominance and survival. This relentless conflict within itself fuels its madness and aggression towards anything it encounters in the ruins.

The Cacophonous Chimera lives in a constant state of internal discord as its three heads, each with its own predatory instincts, vie for control over its body. The constant bickering and screaming among the heads produce a sound that reverberates painfully within the skulls of all who hear it, inducing terror, confusion, and madness. Depending on which head momentarily gains dominance, the tone and effect of their combined shrieking varies, leaving their prey disoriented and defenseless.

This terror hunts throughout the Outer City, making lairs within the crumbling ruins of the Spokes Merchants Exchange. The main tower was one of the tallest buildings outside Drakkenheims walls and functioned as a hub for traders and local craftspeople to conduct business without needing to travel to the bustling market square of the Inner City. The structure has become a ramshackle ruin, the crooked spire compromised by the constant shrieking of the chimera. Still, this strategic perch not only provides an ideal vantage point for the monstrosity. The structural damage also dissuades other monsters and adventurers from intruding on the chimeras personal domain.

Roleplaying Traits

The following traits can be used to inspire roleplaying the Cacophonous Chimera:

  • Personality Trait: “Just ONCE can we chat with someone a little before we eat them? RARGH! STOP TALKING! RIP AND TEAR! NO! NO! NO! Our stomach is FOUR TIMES bigger than it used to be! Im STARVING!”
  • Bond: “Were fused together. Although each of us wants to be separated, in truth were afraid of what would happen if we were ever torn apart.”
  • Ideal: “I make such wonderful music! Each howl, shriek, and chitter resonates to form a deadly orchestra. I cant stand silence!”
  • Flaw: “Were constantly arguing. Our internal strife often distracts us from opportunities or leads us into traps, as we cant agree even on the simplest decisions.”

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Nature or Survival gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they Study a Cacophonous Chimera, learning the following based on their result:

(15+) Freakish Fusion. Youre aware of the chimeras Epic Resistance Epic Action.

(20+) Fighting for Control. You recognize the chimeras Cacophony Epic Action, noting that if the creature could be silenced, it would be far less formidable.

(25+) Powerful but Distracted. You understand its strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.

Combat Tactics

Desperate to eat and consume, the Cacophonous Chimera viciously attacks prey on sight despite the desires of its harpy head to engage in a little conversation first. The Cacophonous Chimera is not a very subtle hunter. Its prey can hear it coming by the sound of its droning cacophony from at least a city block away, which may give them opportunity to prepare, hide, or flee.

The range of its Cacophony can affect creatures before they can see the chimera itself. By the time the chimera arrives, its prey may be shaken and immobilized by the sound. Depending on how ravenous and furious it is, the chimera closes with its prey and tears them apart using its Claws, Bite, and Tail.

Against a target that shows resilience to its cacophony or who retaliates with formidable attacks of their own, the chimera keeps a middle distance, trying to keep out of melee range while leaving its foes in its Cacophonous Chorus aura. However, its ravenous Garmyr head and Ratling head can often get in the way of the better judgment here, prompting the chimera to engage in melee even when it would not be advantageous. Furthermore, the three creatures are generally too busy arguing or overconfident to think twice about the actual danger and stakes they might be facing, and so may need to be grievously wounded before fleeing is an option.

Harvestable Components (Very Rare)

Animus: Monstrosity.

Fluid: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor.

Organs: Eyes, Heart, Brain, Guts, Flesh.

Bones: Skull, Spine, Ribs.

Natural Weapons: Teeth, Claws.

Hair: Fur, Hair, Feathers.

Hide: Skin, Webbed Membrane.

Exorcist.name: Exorcist
Exorcist.text:
An Exorcist comes prepared to deal with evil entities, sinister spirits, and fearsome fiends. Equipped with their holy symbol, a book of prayers, and a bag of ritualistic baubles, Exorcists stand ready to face the most unnatural and otherworldly entities of the realms. Some Exorcists, however, are so familiar with the ways of the undead, they can summon spirits into hosts. In some rare cases, Exorcists allow demons to inhabit the living.

Exorcists Minions. Exorcists deal with all manner of entities. They can call forth Specters, Ghosts, Demons, Wraiths, and other extraplanar entities. The most horrifying creation of the Exorcist is the @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimApo05.JournalEntryPage.525soulboundhost]{Soulbound Host}, which occurs when an Exorcist allows themself to be a vessel for demonic, extraplanar, or fairy entities, attempting to harness the power of such beings. Most are driven mad during the process.

Roleplaying Traits

  • Personality Trait. I speak to the dead often, sometimes when I am not even sure if they are there.
  • Bond. The understanding of life and death grants us power over the planes that few have dared to grasp.
  • Ideal. It is in control of demons and ghosts that we will transcend to our true potential.
  • Flaw. I am sure I have the strength within me to host a demon or spirit without succumbing to its will.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Medicine or Religion gain Advantage on Wisdom (Insight) or Intelligence (Investigation) checks to Study an Exorcist, learning the following based on the result:

(5+) Demons and Undead. You recognize the Exorcist's Immunities as well as their Expel Evil action.

(10+) Master of Possession. You are aware of the Exorcist's Grasping Ghost action.

(15+) Weak of Character and Body. You learn the Exorcist's Strength and Charisma ability scores and saving throws.

Combat Tactics

The Exorcist relies on its divine weapons and direct combat skills. They often reside in locations that have natural hazards where they can use their Grasping Ghosts to force enemies into danger. Hazards could include burning braziers, spiked pits, or a pool of blessed acid. If any foe has a summoned creature, the Exorcist dispatches it using Expel Evil, and destroy any undead foes with Last Rites.

If the Exorcist is in a losing situation, they attempt to use Spiritual Healing on themself before fleeing.

Mutagenist.name: Mutagenist
Mutagenist.text:
A Mutagenist has researched a serum that they inject to transform into a monstrous form. They use themselves as the conduit for this power and hurl themselves towards their enemies as a hulking abomination. They spend their lives researching and discovering new ways to improve and modify the serum in hopes of becoming the perfect Apex form.

Mutagenist Minions. The Mutagenist is constantly experimenting on other creatures before turning their concoctions onto themselves. First their tests involve small rodents, birds, or other unassuming livestock. @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.HOLROD29YKlLXM7u]{Skinwings} are one such example of a Mutagenist's early experimentation. When they move on to humanoid subjects, they create abominations like the @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.xIV1fle7lIJfQqtF]{Cerebrograft}, while their failed experiments end up as @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.Pd2TGABJfa3SLKPY]{Uncontained Growths}.

Every Mutagenist strives to accomplish the ultimate goal of the Apex Formula, the elixir that will transmogrify them into the perfect specimen of humanity, at least in their altered and maddened view.

Roleplaying Traits

  • Personality Trait. I bury myself in books and research, and seldom talk to others.
  • Bond. My work is important, with my research I could cure so many of humanity's inherent weaknesses, and make us stronger as a species.
  • Ideal. Perfection is achievable if one just puts the time and effort into obtaining it.
  • Flaw. I know my view of the perfect human is flawless, I will not hear otherwise.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Medicine gain Advantage on Wisdom (Insight) or Intelligence (Investigation) checks to Study a Mutagenist, learning the following based on the result:

(10+) Physiological Experts. You recognize the Mutagenist's saving throws, as well as the Grotesque Gargantuan's Resistances and Immunities.

(15+) Forced Mutation. You learn of its Mutant Strain and Transmogrifying Elixir action.

(20+) Hulking Form. You know of the Transmogrified Form's Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma ability scores and saving throws.

Combat Tactics

The Mutagenist relies on their spellcasting and Forced Mutation, attempting to cause debilitating effects on its foes while altering their forms.

If the Mutagenist is in a losing situation, it drinks its Transmogrifying Elixir to become its Transmogrified Form. In this form, it hurls rocks at its targets, knocking them Prone. The hulking Mutagenist then bounds up to them and slams them with its Meaty Fists.

Pathogenist.name: Pathogenist
Pathogenist.text:
The study of diseases opens doorways to many dangerous scientific discoveries. As experts in both ridding the body of illness and the mutations of infectious disease, a Pathogenist brings their study to the battlefield by using monsters and enemies as test subjects for their infections. Long years spent carefully monitoring the causes and effects of such plagues has led to a mastery of disease mutation. A Pathogenist's creations can spread in a terrifying manner, riddling their foes with debilitating symptoms, crippling their bodies and rattling their minds.

Pathogenist Minions. An @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.Nd4oyqyMeYuUAwLC]{Injector} makes a great lab assistant for the Pathogenist, helping it administer disease and pathogens to its victims. @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.zAN1wRt81LfiLRBi]{Wretched Patients} are often disease-ridden, bandaged individuals who are convinced that, if they aid the doctor, they will be cured. @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.NL61CL1wkTF2lovv]{Plague Carriers} are a common unfortunate product of a Pathogenist's experiments, used to deliver disease to its enemies in grotesque fashion.

Roleplaying Traits

  • Personality Trait. I love my pathogens and viruses, and speak to my babies as if they were my children.
  • Bond. Understanding the fine balance between what it takes to harm or heal is vital to the ongoing progression of modern medicine.
  • Ideal. Disease is often feared and misunderstood, but with understanding, comes control. You do not need to fear that which you control.
  • Flaw. I am bound to my work and cannot fathom the idea that I am misguided in my research.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Medicine or Survival gain Advantage on Wisdom (Insight) or Intelligence (Investigation) checks to Study a Pathogenist, learning the following based on the result:

(10+) Poison Master. You learn of the Pathogenist's Resistances and Immunities as well as its Heightened Tolerance trait.

(15+) Disease Experimenter. You are aware of its Pestilent Infection and Outbreak actions.

(20+) Lacks Character. You know the Pathogenist's Strength and Charisma ability modifiers and saving throws.

Combat Tactics

The Pathogenist uses poison and disease to disable their foes. When combat begins, they attempt to inflict Plague of Wind upon a target, and proceed to use Outbreak to spread that disease. The Pathogenist uses Poison Needle to subdue problematic targets. The Pathogenist will attempt to flee if they have fewer than 40 Hit Points and are outnumbered.

Dr. Everett Freed, Reanimator.name: Dr. Everett Freed, Reanimator
Dr. Everett Freed, Reanimator.text:
P erhaps Perhaps no apothecary is a more prolific creator of monsters than the Reanimator, and amongst them,Dr. Everett Freed is perhaps the most infamous.

A gifted professor of anatomy and medicine at Altbruke University, Dr. Everett Freed served as a field medic and surgeon during the Westemär Civil War, where the brutality and chaos of war allowed him to clandestinely begin his experiments with the fallen or grievously wounded soldiers thrust into his care. The sights of the war caused him to see the frailty of the human form — the cries of pain and agony of the wounded collected in the fields disgusted him with their feeble, broken bodies. Deep within himself welled the desire to create a perfect soldier, a warrior who would not bend or break in battle.

During the war, one of Dr. Freed's duties included triaging casualties to determine who could be saved or recover. Unbeknownst to his commanders, Dr. Freed used his position to manipulate the diagnosis, choosing ideal specimens for his experiments, individuals who would then be listed amongst the slain and missing.

Reanimator Minions. It's possible Dr. Freed was the first to create many creatures. He is most well known as the first to create @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.UyOmSjpHeyIyUb9n]{Reautomata}. In the process of making his magnum opus, Freed built creatures such as the @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.np4tx9RNqRGwKxXK]{Body Snatcher}, @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.xIV1fle7lIJfQqtF]{Cerebrograft}, the @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.kPUsVqqm2hWpJhvG]{Ripper}, and the @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.qRPFrEzzXqY185Ai]{Stitcher}. Freed's experiments did not stop there, and in many ways his practice ascended the body alone thanks to his collaborations with the Alienist Dr. Sina Rienks, eventually transforming himself into a @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.tGMG5oks7iSWw3J3]{Think Tank}.

Mind Over Body. One of Freed's infamous gambits was to remove his brain from his own body, placing it into a body double. Eventually, Freed became a Think Tank, able to remotely control brainless bodies from his hidden sanctum.

Roleplaying Traits

  • Personality Trait. I am always calm and composed, especially when explaining the ‘necessary' cruelty of my experiments.
  • Ideal. Progress demands sacrifice; the advancement of knowledge justifies all actions, no matter how gruesome.
  • Bond. I still possess the first successful reanimation I ever created: the preserved head of a beloved family member. It's both my proudest achievement and my darkest secret.
  • Flaw. I am obsessed with the perfection and infallibility of my creations, often dismissing any evidence of their defects, uncontrollable behavior, and horrific appearances. I never accept any failure as my fault.

The mastermind behind some of the worst things to ever find in a basement. Watch out because even your fallen allies can be enemies.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Medicine or Survival gain Advantage on Wisdom (Insight) or Intelligence (Investigation) checks to Study the Reanimator, learning the following based on the result:

(10+) Protected by the Reanimated. You know of his Resistances, Immunities, and Bodyguard Reaction.

(15+) Deadly Toxins. You are aware of his Touch of Death.

(20+) Electrical Reinvigoration. You learn of his Reanimate action.

Combat Tactics

Prior to combat, Freed casts @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.7e3QXF10hLNDEdr6]{False Life} and @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.VtCXMdyM6mAdIJZb]{Death Ward} on himself, and perhaps any allies joining him in battle. He does not engage in combat without creations by his side. If Freed is caught alone, he doesn't fight; he flees. However, when supported by his loyal creations, he can be overconfident and brash, secure that his bodyguards will keep him safe from harm. Freed always remains within 10 feet of one or more creations so he can use his Bodyguard Reaction reliably.

On his turn, Freed uses Electric Jolt and Necrotic Blast to hammer his foes, while directing a favored creation with Creator's Command. Should one of his minions be brought down, he uses Reanimate and immediately sends it back into the action with Creator's Command.

Freed uses Touch of Death against a particularly loathsome foe, one who harries him with dangerous abilities, or who he especially wishes to slay. All the while, he threatens his enemies by telling them his plans for their body parts once he's killed them.

Think Tank.name: Think Tank
Think Tank.text:
D ue Due to their dabbling in magical arts, many a maddened and maniacal apothecary has sought the secrets of elongating their life beyond anything deemed normal. Sometimes these studies do not begin with a malicious intent for greed or personal goals. Sometimes they are not targeted toward the apothecary at all, but a sick and dying loved one, the apothecary on the verge of finding the cure to save them; or a friend or colleague who is on their deathbed, whose research and assistance is the factor standing between a scientific breakthrough and absolute failure. It is in the desperate moments that apothecaries have pushed the boundaries of science and tested the limits on mortal physiology.

The Think Tank stands as a grotesque and hideous form of final desperation to an apothecary who has failed at all alternative options. Whether it be to keep a loved one alive, or an attempt to prolong the apothecary's own life, the Think Tank is a horrid and utterly dreadful procedure to endure, with no hope afterwards of being brought back to any resemblance of their former selves.

Roleplaying Traits

  • Personality Trait. Too many thoughts, all the time, my mind is free, uncontained!
  • Bond. I did what I had to! My mind was too valuable to let go to waste, I had to preserve it, to improve it!
  • Ideal. I avoided death to continue to pursue the vast unknown of my scientific study. My research will change the world, I just need more time!
  • Flaw. I cannot fathom the monster I have become, and to witness myself is a horror I cannot endure.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Medicine gain Advantage on Wisdom (Insight) or Intelligence (Investigation) checks to Study the Think Tank, learning the following based on the result:

(15+) Tear the Mind. You recognize the Think Tank's Nightmare Aura.

(20+) Gravity Control. You know of the Think Tank's Unbind Gravity Epic Action.

(25+) Protected Regenerator. You learn of its Shield Generator and Life Support System traits and identifies its location.

Combat Tactics

Due to the nature of its Life Support System, the Think Tank is seldom encountered outside its lair, which is always a well-defended and secret location. The mastermind surrounds itself with powerful abominations, and protects its sanctum with traps, defensible locations, and escape routes. A Think Tank's lair may include elements that are outright hostile to living organisms, such as radiation, contamination, or deadly neurotoxin. As such, player characters encountering the Think Tank in combat must have already outmaneuvered it somehow to gain access to its innermost lair.

The Think Tank makes for a climatic encounter against a villainous foe. Before the player characters even get close to the Think Tank, it will have tested their abilities many times against its minions, using its telepathic eavesdropping to learn everything it can about them. The Think Tank knows when they are coming, how they are approaching, as well as their abilities, spells, equipment, and their expected tactics.

The Think Tank uses Unbind Gravity and Mind Cage to control the battlefield, while using Pluck the Puppet Strings to turn any remaining targets against its other foes. Its Telekinetic Grip can help it further control enemy positions while using Contaminated Blast to slowly contaminate them to death, picking on whoever has the most Contamination going into the encounter.

Harvestable Components (Legendary)

Animus: Monstrosity.

Fluid: Contaminated Ichor, Chemical Solution.

Organs: Brain.

Bones: Skull, Spine.

Natural Weapons: Tentacles.

Hide: Plates.

Helpful Hand.name: Helpful Hand
Helpful Hand.text: Every apothecary could use an extra set of hands. Overstretched apothecaries use Helping Hands in a variety of ways: fetching tools and ingredients, taking notes, sending messages, holding open ribcages, and assigning them to suturing or administering concoctions to a patient.

Speaking Skull.name: Speaking Skull
Speaking Skull.text: The work of an apothecary can be lonely, and the mind craves another good head to bounce ideas off. The Speaking Skull is an ideal companion, one who can carry on conversation with their creator, read out text from instruction manuals and tomes while the apothecary works, and offer advice and observations. The familiars also make useful and discrete sentinels, positioned carefully to watch over the apothecary's private notes, treasures, or experiments.

Apex.name: Apex
Apex.text:
Perfect Transmogrification. Amongst Mutagenists, the quest for genetic perfection can become an all-consuming obsession. Those who seek to achieve this so-called superior state refer to it as the “Apex” and describe the transformation as creating the ultimate humanoid specimen.

Through years of study and trials, Mutagenists have perfected their Transmogrifying Elixir to harness the ultimate power of mortal potential. This formula allows them to amplify their natural capabilities to the peak physical form while maintaining their unbound intellect. There is no telling how many long years a Mutagenist has spent in their lab, and how many unwilling test subjects had to suffer the fates of their imperfect formulae before they arrived at the ultimate conclusion of their research. This is the pinnacle of their scientific study, the perfected Transmogrifying Elixir: the Apex Formula.

Permanent Transformation. The process renders the Mutagenist permanently altered. Energy courses through their veins, their strength and agility extended to the very limits of human capabilities. Their form is able to shift and adapt to incoming threats, and they are able to perceive events around them with great precision. Their mind, although it remains intellectually intact by the process, is inherently and irrevocably shattered. No Mutagenist who takes the Apex Formula could ever perceive or admit to the fracturing of their mind. Regardless of their vast intelligence, a sickening madness takes hold of their psyche; one that plunges the apothecary-turned-Apex creature into a hostile, madness-filled rage. They still hold onto the threads of their vast scientific mind, using that as a justification for their actions, unaware of the deranged mental state they now reside within.

The Folly of Perfection. Even Mutagenists who achieve the Apex state have a gnawing question in the back of their minds: is it truly enough? Could they become even more? Their seemingly perfect form is not without subtle flaws, broken psyche, and weaknesses. Many Mutagenists can never truly be satisfied with their results, and even the Apex Formula can never fulfill the unattainable desire for absolute perfection. It is this obsession that has led many Mutagenists to lunacy in the face of their achievements. For even an Apex may spend eternity bound to their workshop, kidnapping unwilling subjects to continue to test and experiment, seeking a perfection that will never truly be achieved.

Roleplaying Traits

  • Personality Trait. I am humanity perfected! All beings are beneath me, for I am the apex of physical existence. All should cower in my glory!
  • Bond. Science has granted us this gift! This research is the most valuable scientific discovery in the world and must be protected!
  • Ideal. Do not try and stop me, for I am offering perfection to all of humanity. Can't you see? The Apex Form will cure the world of all sickness, all flaws, all weakness!
  • Flaw. There cannot be a weakness in my design. If there is, I will solve it — I just need more time!

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Medicine, Survival, or Arcana gain Advantage on Wisdom (Insight) or Intelligence (Investigation) checks to Study the Apex. , learning the following based on the result:

(15+) Adapts to Threats. You recognize the Apex's Rapid Adaptation Reaction and Regeneration trait.

(20+) Harness the Elements. You are aware of its Bonus Action attacks.

(25+) Perfect Form but Fragile Mind. You know the Apex's weakness to Necrotic and Psychic damage.

Combat Tactics

The Apex will often be accompanied by several abominations of its own creation. Lab assistants, failed experiments, and Wretched Patients are often by its side.

An Apex begins combat by unleashing one of its Bonus Action attacks. It quickly analyzes the battlefield, looking for the most optimal use of its energy. It observes the arrangement of its enemies and decides if it is best to use its lightning, fire, or cold attack based on what will deliver the most damage to the most targets.

It then uses its speed to move close to a target to smash it with its Slam attacks. The Apex prefers to target Frozen enemies with its Slams.

The Apex is unwilling to see its own flaws, but it is not stupid. If reduced below 60 Hit Points, it unleashes a final attack and attempts to distance itself from its enemies, hoping to escape and recuperate.

Harvestable Components (Very Rare)

Animus: Monstrosity.

Organs: Eyes, Heart, Brain, Guts.

Bones: Skull, Spine. Hide: Skin.

Dust: Elemental Dust.

Body Snatcher.name: Body Snatcher
Body Snatcher.text:
S titched Stitched together from the remains of numerous corpses and animated through forbidden alchemical processes, the Body Snatcher roams the darkness. Created by a deranged doctor to abduct subjects for gruesome experiments, it lingers in shadows, waiting for unwary travelers to seize and vanish into the night.

Empowered by the night, the Body Snatcher uses shadow to drain the vitality and energy of those it grabs, weakening them as they attempt to resist and escape. Shadows wrap around it, helping it hold its victims in place while it absconds with them into the darkest corners of the night.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Medicine gain Advantage on Wisdom (Insight) or Intelligence (Investigation) checks to Study a Body Snatcher, learning the following based on the result:

(10+) Emotionless Undead. You know the Body Snatcher's condition Immunities.

(15+) Shadowy Energy. You are aware of its Clinging Shadows trait.

(20+) In the Dark of Night. You recognize the Body Snatcher's Sunlight Weakness trait.

Combat Tactics

The Body Snatcher sticks to dimly lit areas or places of complete darkness. It teleports up to a creature and attempts to grapple it, teleporting away as soon as it has one or two targets in its hands. Often the Body Snatcher will emerge from tunnels or secret entrances to its lair. They do not travel far from the labs they were created in and often have easy points of escape to disappear once they have a victim in hand.

Harvestable Components (Rare)

Animus: Undead.

Fluid: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor.

Organs: Eyes, Heart, Brain, Guts.

Bones: Skull, Spine.

Hair: Stitches, Hair.

Hide: Skin.

Dust: Undead Dust.

Chitter.name: Chitter
Chitter.text:
T he The Queens Park Gardens are one of the most heavily contaminated areas in the city. Its massive gardens and trails were once a place of lush beauty, thick with trees, floral arrangements, topiary masterpieces, tranquil groves, and an abundance of wildlife. Drakkenheims contamination warped all things, monstrously changing the creatures within. Now even the squirrels, which occupied the gardens in large numbers, are feral and mutated. Those wandering forested areas should be wary of chittering sounds echoing through the trees. These monsters attack in numbers, their clacking teeth maddening those nearby. The once friendly squirrels that locals would stop to feed now feed whether you want them to or not.

Chitters are also encountered along the heavily wooded northern outskirts of Drakkenheim and much of the farmlands surrounding the city. These places are not free from contamination; Chitters have been seen roaming like packs of feral dogs through the fields or lurking near woods. Chitters now occasionally roam the streets in the center of the city, climbing towers and buildings before leaping down onto their prey. No longer confined to the gardens, the city is their hunting ground and its ruins make wonderful homes for packs of Chitters.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Animal Handling gain Advantage on Intelligence (Nature) checks to Study a Chitter, learning the following based on their result:

(5+) Wall Crawling. You are aware of its climb speed, its Running Leap trait, and its Slow Fall feature.

(10+) Madding Noise. You know of its Chitter attack action.

(15+) Simple Minded. You recognize its mental ability scores and saving throws.

Combat Tactics

Chitters often attack in a small group. Usually two to three that form a family will stick together. The mutated squirrels have been known to be quite territorial and hostile, even to other Chitter families who try to infringe on their territory.

Chitters are excellent climbers, capable of falling a great distance without fear of hurting themselves. It is not uncommon for Chitters to be found in tall buildings, or up on the top floor of ruined houses, or hard-to-reach rooftops or attics. Chitters charge their enemies and leap at them, attempting to disable them with their chittering, and relying on their Claws and Bite. Chitters protect their homes with determined ferocity, but if reduced to less than a third of their Hit Points, they leap and clamber away.

Harvestable Components (Uncommon)

Animus: Monstrosity.

Fluid: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor.

Organs: Eyes, Heart, Brain, Guts.

Bones: Skull, Ribs, Spine.

Natural Weapons: Teeth, Claws.

Hair: Fur.

Hide: Skin.

Cerebrograft.name: Cerebrograft
Cerebrograft.text:
T he The Cerebrograft is a horrific attempt to combine two creatures into a singular form, a nightmarish combination of brains and brawn. Through surgical implantation and flesh-melding, an apothecary creates a forced symbiosis, fusing their nervous systems and unlocking potent psionic abilities.

Improved Lackeys. A Cerebrograft is often the “reward” granted to a pair of loyal lab assistants, a means of “removing deficiencies” by combining their bodies and minds, frequently named a portmanteau of its constituent beings.

Dominant Personality. Although intended to be a symbiosis of two minds, typically, the implanted creature subsumes the psyche of its host, fully controling the new form. However, sometimes, the two beings form a constituent mind combining elements of the originals, or even a bicameral mind where the original two debate internally over what action to take.

Delicate Work. Thanks to their psionic abilities, Cerebrografts are well suited to controlling other test subjects. Apothecaries find their precise telekinetic powers especially useful in surgical procedures and laboratory experiments.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Medicine gain Advantage on Wisdom (Insight) or Intelligence (Investigation) checks to Study a Cerebrograft, learning the following based on the result:

(10+) Occult Fleshmending. You uncover the Cerebrograft's Dual Minds trait.

(15+) Powerful Psionics. You recognize its Telekinetic Grip and Psychic Crush.

(20+) Powerful, Clumsy, and Slow. You learn the Cerebrograft's ability scores and saving throws.

Combat Tactics

Despite its physical and psionic might, Cerebrografts prefers fighting alongside allies of its apothecary master. When confronted with multiple foes, it tries to overwhelm their minds using Psychic Crush to escape and find reinforcements.

A Cerebrograft uses its Telekinetic Grip to hold its enemies, unruly test subjects, and wild experiments at bay. It typically focuses on one target, allowing allies to pummel the Restrained foe.
