If it can, it uses the environment to its advantage, moving foes to restrain them such as into mancles, cages, or surgery tables.

Harvestable Components (Rare)

Animus: Aberration.

Fluid: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor.

Bones: Skull, Spine.

Hair: Stitches. Hide: Skin.

Dust: Aberrant Dust.

Chemystral.name: Chemystral
Chemystral.text:
O ne One of a Chemist's ultimate creations, the Chemystral is a perfectly balanced sentient compound capable of altering its physiology to adapt to surrounding threats. The horrific ooze has the ability to stick to any surface and even propel itself into the air and fly. It is impervious to nearly all forms of elemental attack. Much like a chameleon changing its color to blend into its surroundings, the Chemystral changes itself at a cellular level to adapt to environmental changes and elemental threats, gaining properties to better combat predators. Even with its inherent resilience, the Chemystral is unable to adapt to the cold, or deal with intense sound.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Medicine gain Advantage on Wisdom (Insight) or Intelligence (Investigation) checks to Study a Chemystral, learning the following based on the result:

(15+) Living Chemical Reaction. You know the Chemystral's Resistances and Immunities.

(20+) Elemental Adaption. You uncover the Chemystral's Elemental Reaction trait.

(25+) Weakness to Cold. You recognize the Chemystral's Cold Vulnerability trait.

Combat Tactics

The Chemystral attempts to Engulf as many victims as it can. It cares little about taking elemental damage and only thinks to retreat if it is consistently taking Cold damage.

Harvestable Components (Very Rare)

Animus: Ooze.

Fluid: Contaminated Ichor, Goopy Ooze, Elemental Fluid.

Disembodied Psyche.name: Disembodied Psyche
Disembodied Psyche.text:
O ne One of the most harrowing procedures an Alienist can perform on their victims results in the Disembodied Psyche. An Alienist looking to permanently control the mind of their victim may opt to remove the brain altogether, killing the patient and resurrecting the mind as its own sentient entity. Somewhere within this process the brain loses its sense of self and any connection it had to the former body it held, becoming an organism made up entirely of electrical synapses and controlled thoughts. The Disembodied Psyche is then subject to several arduous experiments to heighten its fortitude and mental capabilities, giving the creature forms of telepathy and telekinesis.

The now-undead form of this controlled consciousness can be unleashed upon the foes of the alienist and even take over the bodies of other victims, putting them in a controlled and obedient state for the alienist to perform even more mental experiments on, or use as a puppet against their enemies.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Medicine or Arcana gain Advantage on Wisdom (Insight) or Intelligence (Investigation) checks to Study a Disembodied Psyche, learning the following based on the result:

(10+) Unnatural Immaterial Form. You are aware of the creature's damage and condition Immunities.

(15+) Telepathic Energy. You recognize the creature's Hypnotize and Mental Possession actions.

(20+) Incorporeal Mind You know the creature's AC, Hit Points, and Strength ability score.

Combat Tactics

The Disembodied Psyche begins any combat by getting into a position where it can hit as many creatures as possible with its Hypnotize before attempting to mentally possess a target. If it is in a dangerous situation, such as being surrounded or cornered, it uses Teleport to move to a more advantageous position.

Harvestable Components (Rare)

Animus: Undead.

Fluid: Contaminated Ichor, Ectoplasm.

Organs: Brain.

Dust: Undead Dust.

Injector.name: Injector
Injector.text:
T he The first creations many apothecaries attempt to construct are lab assistants, and the Injector is one of these primary creations. Equipped with massive syringes and a tank with multiple canisters of toxins and tinctures, the Injector can mix and combine these chemicals to produce a multitude of medicines or toxins. Individual apothecaries outfit their Injectors with different chemicals for their experimentation. Although primarily a medical assistant, the Injector also doubles as a sentry or guard for the apothecary's occult research and hidden labs.

Different Injectors for Different Practices. Injectors are a common creation for Reanimators, often constructed from stitched-together body parts and medical instruments welded into the flesh, but both Chemists and Pathogenists also create Injectors. Reanimators use Injectors as assistants to administer paralysis, mind dampening, and even adrenaline into their creations, hoping to keep subjects alive during intense procedures. Pathogenists use Injectors to deliver deadly viruses, poisons, and diseases. Chemists have been known to use Injectors for mixing alchemical formulae in case problems arise and cause unforeseen accidents—it's better you blow up an assistant than yourself.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Medicine or Survival gain Advantage on Wisdom (Insight) or Intelligence (Investigation) checks to Study an Injector, learning the following based on the result:

(10+) Impervious to Pain. You understand the creature's damage and condition Immunities.

(15+) Be careful, it's volatile! You know of its Unstable Tank Reaction.

(20+) Hardy Creature. You are aware of the Injector's AC, Hit Points, and weakest ability score and saving throw.

Combat Tactics

If the Injector has allies nearby, it uses Booster Dose to bolster them before combat. Otherwise, it ruthlessly attacks with its Syringe Arms. It feels no pain and does not waver or retreat.

Harvestable Components (Very Rare)

Animus: Construct.

Fluid: Contaminated Ichor, Chemical Solution.

Organs: Eyes, Heart, Brain, Guts.

Bones: Skull, Spine.

Natural Weapons: Needles.

Hair: Stitches.

Hide: Skin, Plates.

Innocent Harvester.name: Innocent Harvester
Innocent Harvester.text:
A pothecaries Apothecaries create Innocent Harvesters to be loyal, discrete minions that go out and harvest materials for their experiments. These constructs prove far more reliable than unscrupulous thugs and hirelings, who are likely to expose the apothecary to authorities if apprehended or bribed.

The Innocent Harvesters are mindless minions, built to resemble a young street urchin to those who catch a fleeting glimpse of them. Upon closer inspection, they are clearly not human, made from clay, wood, and sometimes metal scrap. A series of valves and gears pump real blood in their chests, infusing the construct with unlife. Many are simply dressed in ragged cloth, worn clothes, or old potato sacks, and fitted with dirty wigs and a painted doll-like face upon a porcelain mask. Some of the more grotesque versions have the surgically removed human faces stretched across their featureless heads.

The more bizarre harvesters are not made to look human but strange stuffed animals or contraptions. These unusual forms are rare, as most Apothecaries seek to create an illusion that the constructs are inconspicuous children roaming the streets.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Medicine gain Advantage on Wisdom (Insight) or Intelligence (Investigation) checks to Study an Innocent Harvester, learning the following based on the result:

(10+) Metal and Wood. You understand the Innocent Harvester's creature type as well as its damage and condition Immunities.

(12+) Clamber and Leap. You are aware of the Innocent Harvester's Leap.

(15+) Simple Construct. You know the Innocent Harvester's mental saving throws.

Combat Tactics

Though small and innocent in appearance, Innocent Harvesters are not defenseless. They are fast and agile, equipped with surgical tools in place of one hand and a syringe in the other. Made to subdue trespassers, or remove body parts from corpses, these unflinching minions will not hesitate to leap atop targets.

However, they are more comfortable hiding and fleeing than fighting. Their job is to collect body parts. If threatened, they leap onto a target and begin using their surgical tools on them.Harvesters attempt to sedate wounded targets and flee.

Harvestable Components (Uncommon)

Animus: Construct.

Fluid: Chemical Solution.

Natural Weapons: Claws.

Hair: Stitches.

Hide: Plates.

Kingkiller Hydra.name: Kingkiller Hydra
Kingkiller Hydra.text:
T he The Kingkiller Hydra is a beast created for a singular purpose. An Apothecary abomination designed by the maddened mind of Dr. Everett Freed, the Reanimator, the most infamous apothecary in the world of Drakkenheim. This beast was created from the slain corpse of a massive hydra with the intention of turning it against those who originally vanquished it. A tool of utter destruction let loose against the foes of the vile apothecary.

The creature has had its parts sewn back together, and in the instance of missing pieces, they have been replaced with the flesh, scales, fangs, and talons of other beasts. Its blood has been replaced with an acidic fluid that pumps through the creature, animating its lifeless corpse and filling it with only thoughts of malice and memories of pain.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Medicine, Arcana, or Survival gain Advantage on Wisdom (Insight) or Intelligence (Investigation) checks to Study the Kingkiller Hydra, learning the following based on the result:

(15+) Lab Construct. You recognize the creature's type, its Resistances, and Immunities.

(20+) Barrage of Bites. You learn of the creature's Hydra Fury Epic Action.

(24+) Head Regrowth. You are aware of the creature's Multiple Heads trait.

Combat Tactics

The Kingkiller Hydra is relentless. It attacks with all its heads against any target in range. If there is distance between it and its foes, it Tramples them before unleashing Bite attacks with its heads, or it Spits Acid at them from afar while closing the distance.

If the hydra takes 75 or more Fire damage in a single round, it attempts to flee.

Harvestable Components (Legendary)

Animus: Construct.

Fluid: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor, Acidic Bile.

Organs: Eyes, Heart, Brain, Guts, Glands.

Bones: Skull, Spine.

Natural Weapons: Claws, Teeth.

Hair: Stitches.

Hide: Scales.

Leeches.name: Leeches
Leeches.text:
L eeches Leeches are a common creature kept in large quantities in apothecaries' laboratories. Aside from their standard practical uses of bloodletting and transfusions, they have also been the subjects of early apothecary experimentation. Different forms of leeches have been designed to better suit apothecaries' needs. Some Alienists have designed leeches that attach directly to the brain stem, allowing the leech to eat the intellect and thoughts of other creatures. Mutagenists have designed leeches that can harness the arcane energies found in mageborn blood.

Leech Variants. Ambitious apothecaries have used leeches in different ways. There are two mutant variations of the Blood Leech.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Arcana or Medicine gain Advantage on Wisdom (Insight) or Intelligence (Investigation) checks to Study a leech, learning the following based on the result:

(10+) Quick Swimmers. You know the leech's Swim speed and senses.

Blood Leech: (15+) Blood Transfer. You know of the Blood Leech's Blood Drain and Blood Infusion.

Mind Leech: (15+) Brain Eater. You are aware of the Mind Leech's Mind Leech's Brain Drain and Thought Infusion.

Spell Leech: (15+) Arcane Ingestion. You recognize the Spell Leech's Spell Drain.

Combat Tactics

Leeches attempt to get close to a target to Bite and Attach to them. They do not retreat, as they are driven by their basic need to feed on the blood of others and nothing else.

Harvestable Components (Uncommon)

Animus: Monstrosity.

Fluid: Monster Blood, Goopy Ooze, Mucus.

Organs: Brain, Guts.

Natural Weapons: Mandibles.

Hide: Skin.

Blood Leech.name: Blood Leech
Blood Leech.text:
A lthough Although the practice of draining a patient's blood to draw out illness and disease is long discredited, many apothecaries understand the value of transfusing blood during surgical procedures. However, storing the blood long term can be a problem. Apothecaries have solved by modifying normal leeches with occult science, transforming the creatures into living blood bags. While these bloodletting techniques are of dubious therapeutic value to patients, they make an effective method for collecting samples from less-than-willing subjects.

Though often benign in nature, these bloated leeches can be turned to violent purpose by an apothecary willing to use the creatures in such a manner. During combat, an apothecary may dispatch the leeches against their foes, then call the creatures back to themselves to heal using their foe's blood.

Mind Leech.name: Mind Leech
Mind Leech.text:
Alienists have long dabbled with the manipulation of the mind. They have little use in their experiments for removing or transfusing blood. However, through occult magic and dangerous experimentation, they have broken ground on the possibilities of extracting thoughts.

The Mind Leech is an Alienist experiment wherein apothecaries have altered the genetics of their laboratory leeches into a Mind Leech. When placed on the back of a patient's neck, the Mind Leech sends tendrils into the spine and brainstem and pulls out the creature's psyche. This process has been used to both learn the patient's secrets and memories, as well as render them malleable to mind control, making perfect minions to Alienists.

Crater Wurm.name: Crater Wurm
Crater Wurm.text:
T hose Those who dared venture into the Crater Basin returned with harrowing tales of the tremendous Crater Wurms. They describe the earth shaking moments before a gargantuan wurm breaches the surface, swallowing creatures in its path. Curiously, the wurms are only seen in the desolate crater. Few understand how such gigantic creatures, let alone multiple wurms, can survive here, or why they do not leave to hunt elsewhere.

In truth, Crater Wurms mainly subsist on inorganic minerals found in the dirt, mud, and rock they burrow through, requiring little organic matter. The wurms gullet functions like a contaminated crucible: minerals, rock, and living matter are broken down and crystallized, with delerium expelled as waste. Crater Wurms spend most of their lives underground, creating miles of twisting tunnels filled with glittering delerium, only surfacing in the Crater Basin to reproduce. Though none have yet seen the event, the wurms massive form splits, releasing young from the carcass.

Perhaps no creature in Drakkenheim is more responsible for the deeply rooted contamination than Crater Wurms. The continued existence of these monsters could see the world transform into a contaminated wasteland. Tunneling below the surface, they have spread contamination deep into the bowels of the earth. Indeed, all the crystals scattered across the surface, the rich veins of delerium near the Scar, and the great deposits around the Crater itself pale in comparison to the mass of delerium left buried far underground by the Crater Wurms.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Nature or Survival gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they Study a Crater Wurm, learning the following based on their result:

(15+) Subterranean Threat. You know it has Tremorsense and that it creates tunnels when digging through rock.

(20+) Earth Shaker. Youre aware of the Crater Wurms Breach and Bite attacks.

(25+) Blunderous Brute. You recognize the Crater Wurms strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.

Combat Tactics

Crater Wurms disregard other creatures, viewing them as only morsels to consume. All are as the dust of the earth to it—simply food. These wurms understand that creatures they devour often try to flee. Their favored tactic is to remain buried until their Tremorsense detects movement. They then surface with its Breach action, making Bite attacks, swallowing nearby Prone creatures. They dive beneath the ground once at least one creature is swallowed, or if reduced to half its Hit Point maximum.

Harvestable Components (Very Rare)

Animus: Monstrosity.

Fluid: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor.

Organs: Heart, Guts.

Natural Weapons: Teeth, Needles.

Hide: Plates.

Spell Leech.name: Spell Leech
Spell Leech.text: It is well understood by apothecaries, particularly Mutagenists, how arcane magical talents are the result of a nascent genetic trait borne in the blood. As such, Mutagenist apothecaries often experiment with blood and tissue samples taken from mageborn, hoping to discover the ways to enhance existing magical talents, or even imbue those without the inborn capacity for magic with spellcasting ability. Thus far, the best results have been either disastrous or temporary. Nevertheless, one result is the Spell Leech.

Living Biohazard.name: Living Biohazard
Living Biohazard.text:
L iving Living Biohazards are the failed experiments of Chemists striving to perfect alchemical concoctions of far greater potency. However, there is still value in their failures. Creating slivers of sentience within chemical compounds is no small feat, and the Living Biohazard, although not perfect, has provided Chemists with a chemical defense system of sorts.

The Living Biohazard is an insatiable ooze that slides around its environment like a spilled liquid looking for creatures to dissolve. The corrosive gelatin can stick to walls and ceilings and drop down on unsuspecting creatures. It is, even in its simple-minded nature, a persistent and deadly hunter.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Medicine or Survival gain Advantage on Wisdom (Insight) or Intelligence (Investigation) checks to Study a Living Biohazard, learning the following based on the result:

(15+) Thick and Acidic. You know of the Living Biohazard's Liquid Form and Hazardous Fumes traits.

Combat Tactics

The Living Biohazard remains completely still until it is close enough to either drop down onto a creature or slide into position surrounding it. Its only goal is to dissolve and consume. It does not flee.

Harvestable Components (Uncommon)

Animus: Ooze.

Fluid: Contaminated Ichor, Goopy Ooze, Acidic Bile.

Organs: Guts.

Plague Carrier.name: Plague Carrier
Plague Carrier.text:
T he The Plague Carriers are the unfortunate test subjects of Pathogenists who have taken to harboring their deadly pathogens within a living vessel for abrupt and grotesque delivery. Plague Carriers are often patients who came to the mad apothecary already sick with one disease or another, and signed off on experimental procedures without reading the fine print.

Pathogenists use these living vessels to incubate and foster new variations of diseases. Apothecaries sometimes use the mortal body as a lab for mixing and matching various diseases at once to see the outcomes they produce. For all the laboratory science a Pathogenist can do, there is no more accurate scientific procedure than a living test subject. Pathogenists often experiment on rats and small creatures first, but when they fail to bring their more complex reagents to proper formation, they move on to humanoid subjects, who in the process are rendered into mindless minions.

The Pathogenist doesn't dispose of their failed experiments. Instead, they often keep them festering, and in their madness, a small but dangerous idea forms. What if a single test subject is not a large enough experiment? What if this test subject could be sent into a populated area and unleashed, spreading the disease? Oftentimes this idea comes at the hands of a pathogenist who

has been shunned from their village or town, who now sees the locals as their enemies, and is willing to use entire populations as a testing ground for their pathogens. The delivery method being a gory and gruesome display of sending a plague carrier in, and having them overflow with the diseases inside, causing a horrific and dangerous pandemic to emerge in their abrupt death.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Arcana or Medicine gain Advantage on Wisdom (Insight) or Intelligence (Investigation) checks to Study a Plague Carrier, learning the following based on the result:

(10+) Multiple Disease Carrier. You recognize the Plague Carrier can carry Fatigue, Coughing Fits, and Shivers.

(15+) Dangerously Infectious. You know of the creature's Bile Spreader action.

Combat Tactics

The Plague Carrier is a vile creature whose sole purpose is to spread its infection. It runs into a crowds and use its Bile Spreader to infect as many targets as possible, resorting to biting any who get too close. It cares little for its own safety and does not retreat.

Harvestable Components (Uncommon)

Animus: Monstrosity.

Fluid: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor, Acidic Bile.

Organs: Eyes, Heart, Brain, Guts.

Bones: Skull, Spine.

Hair: Stitches, Hair.

Hide: Skin.

Reautomata.name: Reautomata
Reautomata.text:
F irst First created by the Reanimator Dr. Everett Freed of Altbruke University, Reautomata were designed as the ultimate shock trooper. These armored warriors feel no pain, fear, or remorse.

Constructs of Metal and Flesh. Despite their outward appearances, Reautomata are constructs, not undead: their organic components operate more like machines than mere flesh. Such is the composition of a Reautomata that they fight on despite grievous injury, unflinching even as they are dismembered. Stopping a Reautomata necessitates mangling its body past the point of physical operation. Reautomata are ultimately brutal and decisive combatants that fight without regard for their personal well-being.

Created in Torment. Reautomata must be skillfully made by a master Reanimator using the finest components. It is essential the work begin on both a living and fully conscious individual. Typically, most apothecaries perform the work without anesthetic, instead opting to sever the vocal cords of their victims so as to not have their screams disturb the grim work involved. Limbs are removed and replaced, and metal is grafted into flesh and welded into the bone of the fully aware subject. Nervous tissue is pulled from the brain and distributed from the body, giving the construct nearly perfect proprioceptive awareness while excising unnecessary or superfluous brain tissues associated with cognitive functions. The process renders the Reautomata fully obedient, but not mindless.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Arcana or Medicine gain Advantage on Wisdom (Insight) or Intelligence (Investigation) checks to Study a Reautomata. Each successful check reveals one of the following pieces of information:

(16+) Dispassionate Metal and Flesh. You are aware of the Reautomata's Relentless Endurance trait, as well as its damage and condition Immunities.

(19+) Limb Weapons. You know of the Reautomata's Arm Blades and Entrapping Rend attacks.

(21+) Focused Killer. You learn the Reautomata's Wisdom, Intelligence, and Charisma saving throws.

Combat Tactics

Reautomata fight with outward ferocity and aggressive attacks which belie the cold, unfeeling calculation at the core of each solider. In battle, Reautomata launch themselves towards their foes in great leaps, impaling their targets upon their rending arm blades. The rending blades flense into flesh and

latch on like hooks, allowing the Reautomata to restrain their targets. They then use their great strength to rend apart their restrained victims.

Reautomata unquestionably obey the orders of their creator and will fight until destroyed without regard for their own bodies. However, even with only general instructions, Reautomata fight intelligently and know how to utilize the environment to their advantage, making use of their climb speeds and jumping ability to prioritize dangerous targets.

Harvestable Components (Rare)

Animus: Construct.

Fluid: Contaminated Ichor.

Organs: Brain.

Bones: Skull, Spine.

Natural Weapons: Blades.

Hair: Stitches.

Hide: Skin, Plates.

Scrap Reautomata.name: Scrap Reautomata
Scrap Reautomata.text:
Creating Reautomata is a time-consuming and delicate process, demanding ideal specimens and high-quality materials. Compromising on either results in a far inferior construct. However, discernment is a luxury under desperate circumstances. Regardless, these so-called Scrap Reautomata make far more effective, resilient, and obedient soldiers than conventional troops, and are ideal for use as cannon fodder.

Scrap Reautomata are animated by crude combustion engines, which are prone to overheating and malfunctions.

Everett Freed first created the Scrap Reautomata from the household soldiers and staff of House von Fritz prior to the Siege of Sodden Castle. Poisoning the water well of the castle itself, the Duke von Fritz led his men to believe they were being “treated” and “healed” by the doctor, who instead used their weakened state to turn them into monsters.

The process for creating Scrap Reautomata relies more heavily on occult necromancy to jump-start the reanimation protocol. Less of the original body is replaced to conserve materials. As a result, Scrap Reautomata are undead, not constructs.

Reautomata Wrecker.name: Reautomata Wrecker
Reautomata Wrecker.text:
Since the death of Dr. Freed, his knowledge and works were nevertheless disseminated, including an unfinished schematics for this advanced Reautomata prototype.

Built as more of a living siege engine than a shock trooper, a Reautomata Wrecker is a furious and destructive machine. Constructed from a collection of parts taken from trolls, ogres, and humans, the wrecker is reinforced with armored plating to carry the tanks and machines that power its frame. At the core of the wrecker is a powerful drive engine which when overclocked can set the construct on a path of wanton fury before it explodes in blaze of alchemical doom.

Ravenous Flora.name: Ravenous Flora
Ravenous Flora.text:
S ome Some apothecaries specialize in the study of plants. These botanist apothecaries often experiment with delerium to affect flora growth cycles. The Ravenous Flora is one unfortunate creation of these efforts. It is a plant that has grown to incredible size, gaining a primitive sentience and a desire to feed. The plant seems singly focused on its hunger, with reports often claiming that the Botanist who created the monstrosity has fallen victim to the creation's insatiable hunger.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Nature or Medicine gain Advantage on Wisdom (Insight) or Intelligence (Investigation) checks to Study a Ravenous Flora, learning the following based on the result:

(10+) Plant-like nature. You understand the Ravenous Flora's Immunities and its Poison Ivy trait.

(15+) Giant Maw with Toxic Pollen. You learn of its Writhing Aura and Swallow.

(20+) Large and Slow. You recognize its movement speed and Dexterity saving throw.

Combat Tactics

The Ravenous Flora attempts to hypnotize its prey with its Hypnotic Pollen. Because it is a slow-moving creature, it uses this to attract victims before attempting to Bite and Swallow its targets. If no targets are in range, it Spits Acid at them and does its best to move to an advantageous position.

Harvestable Components (Rare)

Animus: Plant.

Fluid: Sap, Acidic Bile.

Organs: Flowers.

Bones: Stems.

Natural Weapons: Needles, Spores.

Hair: Leaves.

Dust: Plant Dust.

Ripper.name: Ripper
Ripper.text:
A Ripper is a creation of a truly mad apothecary, though one ostensibly created as a “surgical assistant” for dissection and autopsy. In truth, a Ripper's only purpose is as a butcher, carrying out the grim task of dismembering corpses and collecting severed parts to supply fresh materials to create more abominations. Transforming morgues into abattoirs and surgery rooms into charnel houses, having a Ripper amongst their servants enables an Apothecary to work with startling efficiency.

Due to their horrific appearance and grim purpose, Rippers are seldom encountered outside an Apothecary's laboratory. Given their size and brutal skill, Rippers make ideal guardians.

Parts Collectors. Apothecaries stitch all manner of extra arms, hands, and limbs to their Rippers, which the creature uses to gather severed body parts and hold down subjects.

Fear Engine. The Ripper's tortured mind sympathetically responds when it senses a victim's fear and terror, but its twisted brain responds with adrenaline and bloodlust.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Arcana or Medicine gain Advantage on Wisdom (Insight) or Intelligence (Investigation) checks to Study a Ripper, learning the following based on the result:

(10+) Occult Science Construct. You know of its Insensitive to Pain trait, as well as its damage and condition Immunities.

(15+) Razor-Sharp Weapons. You recognize the Ripper's Whirling Bonesaw attack, and it's Feed on Fear and Dismemberment traits.

(20+) Formidable but Dim-Witted. You learn the Ripper's Constitution, Dexterity, and Intelligence saving throws.

Combat Tactics

The Ripper is an unsubtle and unsophisticated combatant, but it can follow its creators' orders intelligently. Unless directed otherwise, a Ripper usually begins battle by using its Gory Display to terrify its victims. It then ponderously moves towards its chosen target before lowering its Saw Blade down, preferring Frightened targets to benefit from its Feed on Fear trait. During its turn, a Ripper continues attacking with its Saw Blade until it misses. If it reduces a target to 0 Hit Points, it does not stop making attacks until its target dies.

Harvestable Components (Very Rare)

Animus: Construct.

Fluid: Contaminated Ichor, Chemical Solution.

Organs: Eyes, Heart, Brain, Guts.

Bones: Skull, Spine.

Natural Weapons: Blades, Claws.

Hair: Stitches.

Skinwing.name: Skinwing
Skinwing.text:
M any Many apothecaries who delve into the secrets of reanimation and transmogrification are not bold enough to begin with human test subjects. Instead, most opt to begin their cruel experiments upon animals, knowing that these early investigations draw less suspicion and hostility.

Unfortunately, it is for exactly this reason that many apothecaries lose their sense of morality. In time, they come to view even humans with the same cold dispassion as their animal test subjects, seeing the cries of pain and mercy as no different from the barks, squawks, and howls of the animals they so cruelly tortured in their early days.

Study The Foe

Characters proficient in Nature or Survival gain Advantage on Wisdom (Insight) or Intelligence (Investigation) checks to Study a Skinwing, learning the following based on the result:

(15+) Flying Packs. You know the Skinwing's Pack Tactics trait.

(20+) Muddled Mind. You learn the Skinwing's Dexterity, Intelligence, and Charisma ability scores.

Combat Tactics

Skinwings look for opportunities to gang up on a single target, relying on their Pack Tactics to swarm and overpower an enemy.

Harvestable Components (Uncommon)

Animus: Monstrosity.

Fluid: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor.

Organs: Eyes, Heart, Brain, Guts.

Bones: Skull, Spine.

Natural Weapons: Claws, Teeth.

Hair: Fur, Stitches.

Soulbound Host.name: Soulbound Host
Soulbound Host.text:
A Soulbound Host is the physical body of an apothecary who has willingly allowed an extraplanar creature to possess them, trapping the powerful outsider in a mortal form. Powerful yet vulnerable, Soulbound Hosts loathe their creators. They wander the world for the means to reverse the curse of mortality placed upon them and return to their otherworldly domains.

Exorcist and Alienist apothecaries do not primarily study the body, and rarely practice the type of magic and science which leads to mutant horrors and flesh-stitched abominations. They are instead concerned with the supernatural forces of the mind and soul. Many research and contact powerful extraplanar entities, eager to possess mortals as a means of entering the material world. These apothecaries learn how to create Soulbound Hosts as a powerful means to contain and fight back against these dangerous otherworldly foes.

Desperate Gambit. A Soulbound Host is usually created under truly desperate circumstances, such as when a heroic apothecary faces a dangerous otherworldly being such as a demon, fey, spirit, or inscrutable entity from the Space Between Worlds. Not only are these planar invaders pernicious foes, many are effectively immortal—often these creatures simply reform when killed outside their native planes. Thus, an apothecary who lacks the ability to defeat the demon on their own, or who wishes to defeat a powerful outsider in a more permanent fashion, may instead decide upon a heroic act of self-sacrifice by turning themselves into a Soulbound Host.

Preparing the Trap. Using an array of implanted metals, ingested tinctures, mental preparations, and occult incantations, a skilled apothecary may willingly prepare their body for possession. During the process, the apothecary can weave a unique spiritual trap. It then falls to the apothecary to convince the otherworldly creature to possess them, an act that many outsiders are eager to do. Thus, the canny apothecary preys on the ego of the monster itself.

Mortal Curse. When the outsider inhabits the body, the apothecary's soul departs, leaving the extraplanar creature to take their place spiritually. If this mortal form is killed or destroyed, the bound creature does not simply return to their plane of origin. Instead, the spirit departs to the afterworlds like any other mortal soul, losing their accumulated otherworldly power forever. Thus, the Soulbound Host becomes both a prison and a death sentence for the other wielding being tricked into the apothecary's body.

Rogue Hosts. Unfortunately, this act of self-sacrifice is not without its imperfections. The apothecary's body is filled with otherworldly essence, and while the creature's power is greatly diminished, they often remain extremely dangerous—allies of the departed apothecary may still find it challenging to slay the Soulbound Host. Many escape, wandering the world with stolen lives and even assuming the identity of their host while they search for the means to escape their now mortal form. All bound outsiders are painfully aware of their new mortality, frustrated that returning to their planes of origin is

not a simple matter of destroying their flesh-cage or switching their essence into a different host, one which lacks the binding wards placed by the apothecary.

Price of Freedom. Trapped outsiders can win their freedom by calling back the soul of the apothecary who trapped them, and resurrecting them into their body. This is a thing many outsiders are loathe to do out of fiendish ego, since it puts the original soul in a bargaining position. In this way, the apothecary can force the spirit to accept a bargain which requires them to remain in their own worlds for at least the duration of the apothecary's lifetime.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Religion, Medicine, or Survival gain Advantage on Wisdom (Insight) or Intelligence (Investigation) checks to Study a Soulbound Host, learning the following based on the result:

(10+) Possessed Body. You know the Soulbound Host's type and damage Resistances.

(15+) Extraplanar Magic. Depending on the type of spirit, you learn either the Hellfire Chain, Illusory Assault, or Psychic Barrage actions, as well as the Spellcasting trait of the host.

(20+) Cursed Fate. You recognize its desperation caused by its spirit-bound mortality and its Reactions.

Combat Tactics

A Soulbound Host is a careful combatant. Though powerful, the last thing they want is to be killed in their mortal form. If they are seriously injured, they often attempt to bargain, offering power and knowledge to assailants who spare them.

Harvestable Components (Very Rare)

Animus: Fiend, Fey, or Aberrant.

Fluid: Monster Blood.

Organs: Eyes, Heart, Brain, Guts.

Bones: Skull, Spine.

Natural Weapons: Claws.

Hair: Hair.

Hide: Skin.

Dust: Fiendish, Fey, or Aberrant Dust.

Dark Growth.name: Dark Growth
Dark Growth.text:
C Contamination ontamination causes most plants to wither and die, but some thrive on it, absorbing water and delerium from the soil to mutate into deadly flora. In Drakkenheims urban wasteland, suitable plots of fertile soil are scarce outside Queens Park Garden, necessitating a creative adaptation to proliferate. These Dark Growths take root in the bodies of creatures through their infectious, delerium-infused spores.

Emitted from their blooming flowers, these spores drift silently throughout the air until they enter another creatures body through the ears, mouth, or nose. Once inside, these spores can lay dormant for some time, slowly contaminating their host with internal mutation which slowly decay their flesh and bone from within, transforming it into an ideal place for the Dark Growth to germinate. When the creature succumbs to contamination, or dies with the spores within it, the plant awakens. Consuming the internal organs of the dying infected, it suddenly and violently sprouts. Often, this transformation occurs so suddenly that the creature remains walking around, the Dark Growth using the corpse as a mobile shell so it may plant in an ideal location to spread future spores.

One apothecary reports a case where a knight returning from a mission into the Inner City had survived the journey relatively unscathed save for an excursion into the gardens where a puff of what they thought was pollen from strange iridescent flowers got in their eyes. The knight thought little of it, suffering no immediate effects. After returning to Emberwood, the knight complained of stomach cramps, nausea, and headaches, eventually passing out from the pain. The apothecary performed an emergency surgery, cutting the patient open only to have their intestines burst out like a barrage of meaty, thorn-covered brambles that attempted to strangle the apothecary. Their intestines had been completely replaced with plant matter that had fused into their guts.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Survival gain Advantage on Intelligence (Nature) checks to Study a Dark Growth, learning the following based on their result:

(5+) Contaminated and Thriving. You are aware of the Dark Growths Resistances and Immunities.

(10+) Deadly Spores. You recognize the creatures Infection Spores action.

(15+) Kill it with fire! You know the creatures Vulnerability to Fire, and its strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.

Combat Tactics

A Dark Growth is a simple-minded plant. It uses Mimicry to lure passing creatures towards it, often mimicking the sounds of children or people in need. It entangles and infests any target near it, infecting it with its spores. The creature is a stationary plant and does not flee.

Harvestable Components (Rare)

Animus: Plant.

Fluid: Contaminated Ichor, Sap.

Organs: Flowers.

Bones: Stems

Natural Weapons: Spores, Needles.

Hair: Leaves

Dust: Plant Dust.

Stitcher.name: Stitcher
Stitcher.text:
T he The tedious process of suturing and knitting flesh to a capable assistant can prove time consuming and difficult. The Stitcher acts as a lab assistant and an extra set of hands for such tasks. Uniquely outfitted for quickly and efficiently attaching limbs, sewing up wounds, or making surgical incisions, the Stitcher can graft a limb onto a patient in mere seconds.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Arcana or Medicine gain Advantage on Wisdom (Insight) or Intelligence (Investigation) checks to Study a Stitcher, learning the following based on the result:

(10+) Fearless and Enduring. You are aware of the Stitcher's damage and condition Immunities.

(15+) Instantaneous Grafter. You know the creature's Sewing Needle attack.

(20+) Brainless Monster. You learn the Stitcher's Charisma saving throw.

Combat Tactics

The Stitcher has a singular, focused mind, and even when defending itself, uses its sewing and surgical skills to sew up its foes. The Stitcher often identifies what the most advantageous option is for its Sewing Needle, focusing on the mouths of spellcasters, the limbs of melee combatants, and the eyes of ranged combatants. It attempts to attach limbs to victims it has sewn up.

Harvestable Components (Very Rare)

Animus: Construct.

Fluid: Contaminated Ichor.

Bones: Skull, Spine.

Natural Weapons: Claws.

Hair: Stitches, Hair.

Hide: Skin.

Tanker.name: Tanker
Tanker.text:
T he The Tanker is the preferred lab assistant of Chemists and Pathogenists. They are a construct made from a human corpse, built to function as a walking barrel of alchemical reagents. Traditionally meant to supply mixed chemical compounds in large quantities from one vessel to another, the Tanker can also be deadly when threatened as it is equipped with massive hoses that can fire globs of its substances at targets, as well as unleash a gout of toxic fluids. The creature stinks of acrid chemicals and even being near it can be disastrous without proper protective measures.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Arcana or Medicine gain Advantage on Wisdom (Insight) or Intelligence (Investigation) checks to Study a Tanker, learning the following based on the result:

(10+) Fearless and Enduring. You know the Tanker's damage and condition Immunities.

(13+) Deadly Spray. You learn of the Tanker's Chemical Spray attack.

(17+) Brainless Monster. You are aware of the Tanker's Intelligence and Charisma saving throws.

Combat Tactics

The Tanker takes the first opportunity it has to unleash Chemical Spray at a group of targets. After weakening its foes with Chemical Spray, finishes them off with Slams and Chemical Globs.

Harvestable Components (Rare)

Animus: Construct.

Organs: Eyes, Heart, Brain, Glands.

Bones: Skull, Spine.

Hair: Stitches.

Hide: Skin, Plates.

Uncontained Growth.name: Uncontained Growth
Uncontained Growth.text:
N ot Not all Mutagenists formulae succeed. Often, before testing the Transmogrifying Elixir on themselves, they use patients. Sometimes these patients come willingly, looking to repair some element of themselves. They agree to experimental procedures, which the Mutagenist uses to try their newest elixir and to study untested strains.

The Uncontained Growth emerges as one of the more common side effects to transmogrification, where attempts to expand muscular tissue in a controlled way goes awry. The expansion proceeds unchecked, exploding into masses of flesh and appendages. Sadly, these test subjects are a lost cause: the elixir forever alters and expands their form. Some of the most vile Mutagenists keep these Uncontained Growths as minions, protecting their labs and work. As the muscular tissue expands through bouts of agonizing torment for the patient, it causes their mind to break, leaving them in a maddened frenzy of hostility. This rage can be directed at the apothecary's enemies.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Arcana or Medicine gain Advantage on Wisdom (Insight) or Intelligence (Investigation) checks to

Study an Uncontained Growth, learning the following based on the result:

(10+) Resistant Flesh. You recognize the creature's Adaptable Flesh Reaction.

(15+) Persistent Growth. You are aware of the creature's Absorbing Flesh trait.

(19+) Mindless Mass. You learn the creature's Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma saving throws.

Combat Tactics

The Uncontained Growth is a force of raw strength. In a single turn it can grab, crush, and throw a target.

Harvestable Components (Rare)

Animus: Monstrosity.

Fluid: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor.

Organs: Eyes, Heart, Brain, Guts.

Bones: Skull, Spine.

Hide: Skin.

Wretched Patient.name: Wretched Patient
Wretched Patient.text:
M agic Magic is beyond the means of most commonfolk in the continent. Few can afford the services of the Amethyst Academy, and priests of the Sacred Flame and Old Gods alike are selective with their divine magic, offering their boons to devout worshippers or those in dire need only. However, apothecaries are seldom so selective, especially those who operate in remote regions or clandestinely within large cities.

Desperate Vanity. Lesser nobles and vain merchants occasionally seek out apothecaries not for a cure to an ailment, injury, or sickness, but in the hopes of augmenting some quality of themselves they find deficient. These individuals may come to an apothecary looking for a miraculous means to become taller or more comely, reverse aging, or even gain supernatural or magical abilities.

Medical Malpractice. Unfortunately for their patients, unscrupulous apothecaries may be perfectly willing to offer an experimental method or untested procedure in exchange for an affordable price, seeking an opportunity to trial their latest concoction upon a hapless yet willing subject. When these ill-conceived techniques inevitably go awry, the subjects find themselves transformed into a grotesque mockery of themselves.

Promised Cure. The transformation leaves the patient half-mad. Some are manipulated in the hopes of being cured one day, or tricked into believing that they must remain in the care of their “doctor” until they have “recovered” from the procedure. Many lash out in rage, fleeing into the wilderness, back alleys, or hidden away in their homes. Those unable to return to their former lives in fear or shame may remain, however.

Useful Lackeys. Left without the means to restore their former appearance, these wretched patients accept roles as orderlies, guards, and assistants to the apothecary responsible for their tormented contention. Truly psychotic apothecaries may increase their control over their patients through invasive brain surgery, chemical conditioning, and forced indoctrination. These terrible procedures render these unfortunate individuals fiercely loyal to the apothecary, imbuing them with a fanatical drive to protect them even at the cost of their own lives.

The Varied Victims of Many Malpractices

Wretched Patients represent the unfortunate victims of apothecaries' experiments. No matter their area of study, the deranged minds of evil scientists know no bounds with their experimentation on willing subjects in the name of occult science.

Alienist. Often those with mental instability or muddled minds turn to an Alienist. These patients are rendered into mindless and obedient servants through mind control, mental conditioning, and mind-altering procedures. Alienists have been known to go as far as remove portions of their victims' brains or remove their brains entirely while keeping the subject alive.

Chemist. Those looking for tinctures and tonics to ease all manner of ailments have turned to Chemists, often unaware of the danger of their compounds. These patients are often subject to new experimental procedures that leave them burned, or scarred, disfigured by chemical research. In some cases, the chemical procedures can leave the victims hairless, blind, or cause their skin to muddle and scar over completely.

Exorcist. An Exorcists patients seek help with possessions that may or may not be real. These haunted people can find themselves at the hands of mad scientist and spiritualist who will use the willing patient to summon or trap demonic forces. Sometimes these patients are simply what remains after a demonic or spiritual possession, where after the removal, the victim is left numb and catatonic, having lost most of themselves to the entity that inhabited them. More sinister exorcists will perform this procedure on purpose, placing powerful entities into a patient, only to remove it and render the patient hollow and willing to become a subject to the apothecary.

Mutagenist. The failed experiments of a Mutagenist can leave all manner of strange disfigurations and abnormalities upon their patients. Everything from unusual growths, cankers, and tumors, to fully growing extra limbs, eyes, mouths, and other such strange occurrences. These patients become hideous mockeries of their former selves and over time, become reliant on the doctor to keep their growths and mutations in check.

Pathogenist. When sick with disease, or dealing with unknown poisons, subjects will go to a Pathogenist. Those

who take their practices too far often use subjects as vessels for experimentation. Subjects are often riddled with diseases, sores, boils, at times losing their teeth and fingernails to unnatural decay, their skin turning shades of yellow, green, or purple. They appear sickly, carrying a many pathogens, toxins, and diseases.

Reanimator. Reanimators are sought out when a patient has lost a limb, or had severe injury that would leave them scarred or disfigured. The Reanimators who take their practice too far will use the subject as a means of experimentation. Attaching new limbs to them, testing the lengths they can go by adding multiple limbs, or a second head, additional fingers or toes, subjects over time can become a patchwork of various parts that have been removed, reattached, or swapped.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Medicine gain Advantage on Wisdom (Insight) or Intelligence (Investigation) checks to Study a Wretched Patient, learning the following based on the result:

(10+) Broken by Experimentation. You know the creature's Conditioned Obedience trait.

(15+) Fervent Loyalty. You know these creatures protect their creator via their Protective Impulse Reaction.

Combat Tactics

Wretched Patients are simple minions. They defend themselves and reluctantly fight at the command of their creator. If their creator dies, Wretched Patients flee or cower.

Fluid: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor.

Crimson Knight.name: Crimson Knight
Crimson Knight.text:
T he The Crimson Knights are formidable vampire spawn, meticulously trained as elite house soldiers and personal bodyguards for their vampiric masters. These fierce warriors are inextricably bound to serve their lords with unwavering loyalty, showing little interest in advancing beyond their designated roles. Instead, they derive immense satisfaction from the carnage they unleash in honor of their household and liege.

Proud of their exceptional combat skills, the Crimson Knights devote their eternal lives almost exclusively to honing their martial prowess. Their existence is characterized by relentless training and preparation, making them adept in various forms of battle. This rigorous focus on combat not only sharpens their abilities but also fuels their insatiable thirst for the chaos of warfare.

In the heat of battle, the Crimson Knights are at their most formidable. They hunger for the bloodshed that accompanies fierce engagements, and they sustain themselves by feeding on the blood of those they defeat. To fight is to feed for these knights, and their hunger is perpetual, driving them to seek out conflict where they can showcase their deadly skills and quench their relentless thirst.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in History or martial melee weapons gain Advantage on Intelligence (Religion) checks when taking the Study action to examine a Crimson Knight, learning the following based on the result.

(10+) Elite Spawn. You know the Crimson Knight's damage Resistances.

(15+) Unholy Magic. You recognize the Crimson Knight can unleash a variety of powerful smites.

(20+) Weaknesses. You are aware the vampire's regeneration is temporarily halted by Radiant damage,and its Vampire Weaknesses.

Combat Tactics

Crimson Knights form units with other minions and thralls of their vampire masters. Several Crimson Knights may form an elite guard, or one might be attached to lead a contingent of vampire thralls.

In battle, Crimson Knights seek out the most formidable melee combatants to meet head on, disarming them with Crackling Smite. They make use of Unholy Smite to prevent their target from healing, and terrorize them using Wrathful Smite.

A Crimson Knight will give their undead existence to defend their master and hold fast even as they are cut down. If they encounter a foe capable of dealing Radiant damage, they make them the target of their attacks to ensure they can continue to regenerate.

Natural Weapons: Teeth, Claws.

Dark Confessor.name: Dark Confessor
Dark Confessor.text:
W hen When the Court of the Night seeks to infiltrate a community, their first priority is to corrupt its leaders, especially their most bitter rivals in the Faith of the Sacred Flame. Thus, the flamekeepers or local priests are often targeted in particular to be transformed into vampire spawn. When these devout worshipers become vampire spawn, they are known as Dark Confessors. Their divine powers twist and warp into dark, corrupted magic under the influence of vampiric forces. In undeath, they channel that same potent energy, now converted into terrifying vampiric sorcery, which they wield to serve their masters. As Dark Confessors, they lead sinister rites and unholy rituals, gathering more followers to the cause of their vampiric overlords.

With their natural authority and sway over commonfolk, Dark Confessors manipulate communities to fall under the influence of vampire lords. They often foster cult-like followings, leading the people into pledging allegiance to their dark masters. These cults believe that by proving their loyalty, they might escape the curse of undeath and servitude. Entire towns and villages have succumbed to the charismatic influence of a Dark Confessor, their inhabitants abandoning former beliefs and swearing unwavering fealty to their vampire lords, hoping this grim devotion will save them from a far worse fate.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Religion or Survival gain Advantage on Intelligence (Religion) checks when taking the Study action to examine a Dark Confessor, learning the following based on the result.

(5+) Unnatural Resistance. You recognize the Dark Confessor's damage Resistances.

(10+) Deadly Response. You are aware of the Dark Confessor's Bloody Rebuke Reaction.

(15+) Weaknesses. You are aware the vampire's Regeneration is temporarily halted by Radiant damage, and its Vampire Weaknesses.

Combat Tactics

In the first round of combat, the Dark Confessor casts Spirit Guardians. It uses its Claws to attack anyone who comes within its melee reach. The Dark Confessor then proceeds to attack with its Spiritual Maul.

If there are enemies grouped close to one another, the Dark Confessor uses Unholy Light on them.

The Dark Confessor flees if it is below 50 Hit Points or takes steady Radiant damage.

Druid of the Sanguine Rites.name: Druid of the Sanguine Rites
Druid of the Sanguine Rites.text:
T hese These druids are older than even the vampire families. The few that remain are not descendants of any vampiric bloodline; they are the ancient blood druids who performed the rituals that created Vladimir von Drakken. Few of these druids still remain and those who do are reclusive and hidden. Their ancient blood rituals instilled in them a cursed eternal life, and those still roaming the world have transformed into something half alive. Not the same as a vampire, and not shackled by the vampires' weaknesses, these druids are bound to darkness to replenish them and use blood to fuel their rituals and magic. Their powers are a tightly guarded secret that few have witnessed.

Some of these dark druids saw Vladimir as a prophet, a destiny fulfilled. The Druids of the Sanguine Rite saw Vladimir as a vessel for their dark magic, a powerful being that would usher in an age where they could practice their rituals openly and grow their power. Others live eternally in deep regret of transforming Vladimir, feeling that in doing so they cursed themselves to an eternity of hiding in the darkness.

Study The Foe

Characters proficient in Religion or Survival gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when taking the Study action to examine a Druid of the Sanguine Rite, learning the following based on the result.

(10+) Unrelenting Unlife. You recognize the creature's Regeneration trait.

(15+) Bloody Renewal. You learn of the creature's Bloodthorn Whip attack and Plasma Absorption trait

(20+) Unnaturally Aware. You know their highest and lowest ability scores

Combat Tactics

The druid of the blood rites uses dark magic to twist the lifeforce of other creatures. The druid uses its bloodthorn whip to inflict a series of open wounds upon its foes, and then feeds on their lifeforce by pulling it through their wounds using plasma absorption.

When not directly engaged in combat, the druids attempt to charm a group of foes and convince them to partake in their blood rituals, using their life force as sacrifice to empower one of their own.

If the druids are directly confronted with greater numbers, or their health is below half, they attempt to flee.

Hair: Hair

Ghouls.name: Ghouls
Ghouls.text:
T hose Those who fail as vampiric thralls, disobey their masters, or simply outlast their usefulness are transformed into horrible ghouls. Through dark magic and blood rituals, the vampires rob these mortals of their mortality and humanity, issuing them a fate far worse than death. A ghoul is a cursed creature, bound to the will of a vampire and cursed with undead life. These ravenous minions make great foot soldiers in the undead armies of vampires who bide their time until they can rise from their castles with an undead army to conquer the realm of the living. Ghouls are more mindless and chaotic than a thrall and are less useful for the vampire's complex plots. But a vampire hates losing its minions, and so will keep upwards of a hundred ghouls locked in their crypts, ready to unleash upon the living world.

Some ghouls end up with a more coherent mind than others, able to command and organize lesser ghouls. Some have even developed magical capabilities, twisting necromancy to keep their fellow ghouls alive. When a vampire finds a ghoul rising above the others, and showcasing these unique talents, they often become generals and leaders in their undead army.

Study The Foe

Characters proficient in Religion or Survival gain Advantage on Intelligence (Religion) checks when taking the Study action to examine a Ghoul, learning the following based on the result.

(5+) Undead Resistance. You recognize the creature's Immunities.

(10+) Pursuing Hunger. You know the creature's melee attacks and its Bonus Actions.

(15+) Agile Attacker. You are aware of its highest and lowest ability scores.

Combat Tactics

Ghouls are mindless and vicious. They charge towards enemies with an insatiable hunger for human flesh, and rarely flee from a fight. They can be easily distracted by a fresh corpse to eat, and follow the whims of their masters. The hungrier the ghoul is, the less mindful it is, and the more aggressive it becomes.

Some vampires are known to starve their ghouls for months before unleashing them into battle. Although these ravenous ghouls are less coherent, their complete frenzied hunger makes them a much more dangerous threat.

Ghoul priests and Ghoul Lords often accompany larger arrangements of ghouls to help focus them towards their vampire master's enemies. The priests keep them fighting through mortal wounds while Ghoul Lords lead the charge into combat.

Ravenous Ghoul.name: Ravenous Ghoul
Ravenous Ghoul.text:
Ravenous Ghouls make up the brunt of the undead forces of vampires. They are vile undead creatures twisted to the will of their masters, forced to starve for months at a time to put them into a frenzy when they are unleashed upon the vampire's enemies. Their vampire masters care little for their wellbeing, and simply use them as fodder to wear down their enemies.

A spellcaster can use create undead to animate a ravenous ghoul instead of a normal ghoul.

Ghoul Priest.name: Ghoul Priest
Ghoul Priest.text: The ghoul priest is a magically gifted, harnessing necrotic energies to pull ghouls back from the brink of death.

Dark Growth Shambler.name: Dark Growth Shambler
Dark Growth Shambler.text: Sometimes, when the body of one infected with Dark Growths bursts open in the moment of their death, the body does not immediately collapse and decay. Instead, the creature shambles around, its body still intact, but with vines and thorny black branches bursting from its eye sockets, mouth, and flesh, its body now a protective shell for the plant within.

Ghoul Lord.name: Ghoul Lord
Ghoul Lord.text: Some ghouls thirst for combat as much as human flesh and rise above the others as warriors and leaders. These undead creatures are generals of lesser ghouls, leading the charge in vampire armies.

Grim Custodian.name: Grim Custodian
Grim Custodian.text:
T he The Grim Custodian is the right hand to many vampire masters. They have secured themselves a position as an invaluable member of the vampire's inner circle. They do their master's bidding in exchange for access to the finer aspects of vampirism. Grim Custodians work as bookkeepers, keepers of secrets, informants, and caretakers of the many undead who inhabit the castles and manors of vampires.

The Grim Custodian is capable of plucking the strings of death to some degree; the custodians are able to raise corpses up to serve the bidding of its master. It has been said that many vampiric soldiers who fall on the battlefield rise up once more when a Grim Custodian is nearby. Many of the skeleton and zombie minions work under the command of these custodians.

The Grim Custodian also serves the critical purpose of maintaining the illusion of mortal life around their vampire masters. Vampires thrive when the humans surrounding them believe they are nothing more than ordinary monarchs or nobles. The Grim Custodian maintains this guise, keeping any illusions in place and foiling attempts to see through them.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Religion or Survival gain Advantage on Intelligence (Religion) checks when taking the Study action to examine a Grim Custodian, learning the following based on the result.

(5+) Undead Resistance. You know the creature's Resistances.

(10+) Unrelenting Unlife. You recognize the creature's Regeneration trait.

(15+) Arcane Caster. You understand the creature possesses significant spellcasting abilities.

Combat Tactics

The Grim Custodian does everything in their power to avoid combat, liberally using @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.zMAWdyc8UVb37BK4]{Suggestion} and @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.ppWAAEul0QHtm4er]{Detect Thoughts}. When directly confronted and with no one to protect them, they cast @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.1N8dDMMgZ1h1YJ3B]{Invisibility} on themselves and flee. They focus on hiding their undead nature. Grim Custodians can use @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.phbsplNystulsMag]{Arcanist's Magic Aura} and @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.aU62xVUBYkAQWIHv]{Nondetection} to foil divinations which would otherwise detect them, and @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.nslx2nT3p4lNkmdp]{Major Image} and @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.mbFw57uyfLkyiw5k]{Seeming} to further disguise the truth.

Bones: Skull, Spine, Ribs.

Hazeblood Vampire.name: Hazeblood Vampire
Hazeblood Vampire.text:
V ampires Vampires have an innate ability to both gain and purge delerium contamination from themselves by drinking blood. When a vampire drinks the blood of a contaminated creature, they take that contamination into themselves, but when a contaminated vampire drinks the blood of an uncontaminated creature, they can cleanse themselves in turn. However, this only works to a point: once a vampire has gained enough contamination to prompt a Monstrous Transformation, they become a disheveled vampiric Delerium Dreg: a Hazeblood Vampire.

This curious interaction has prompted some vampires to experiment with contaminated magic, perhaps as a shortcut to gaining the power of an ascendant vampire. Countess Constance Kleinkessel has fostered the research of her apothecary Deidrick Mors, hoping his work might yield potential. She has collected countless test subjects for Mors by transforming villagers in Kesselholm into vampire spawn, and then chaining them in coffins below her castle. There, Mors exposes them to delerium or forces them to drink the blood of contaminated creatures. Thus far, the experiments have yet to create a vampire monstrosity that is stronger, faster, and more terrifying than any other, but perhaps Mors is closing in on a breakthrough…

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in History or martial melee weapons gain Advantage on Intelligence (Religion) checks when taking the Study action to examine a Hazeblood Vampire, learning the following based on the result.

(5+) Undead Resistance. You know the creature's Resistances.

(10+) Dangerous Bite. You are aware of the creature's Contaminated Bite attack.

(15+) Delerium Rejuvenation. You recognize the creature's Delerium Healing action.

Combat Tactics

These vampires are riddled with contamination and simply attack any creature they are pointed towards. Their Contaminated Bites can spread contamination as they tear into their foes. They do not have the mind to retreat from a battle.

Night Blade.name: Night Blade
Night Blade.text:
T he The Night Blades serve as elite assassins for their vampire lords. These powerful vampire spawn are tasked with eliminating anyone who threatens to expose the secretive existence of the vampires. When anyone delves too deeply into their affairs, these assassins act swiftly and silently to neutralize interlopers.

Expertly adept at navigating the shadows, Night Blades are not only assassins but also skilled spies for their nocturnal court. They excel at infiltrating enemy strongholds, gathering crucial intelligence, and remaining undetected. Their abilities to scale walls, meld into shadows, and vanish without a trace make them formidable opponents. It is wise for enemies of the vampire lords to converse in brightly lit rooms during daylight, as any discussions held under the cover of darkness are vulnerable to the ears of the Night Blades, who are the eyes and ears of the shadows themselves.

Within the Court of the Night, there exists a specialized faction known as the Night Sisters. The exact number of these vampiric assassins is unknown, but they have orchestrated numerous high-profile assassinations over the centuries. Working closely with the highest echelons of the court, the Night Sisters represent the pinnacle of the court's lethal capabilities and are tasked with eliminating particularly significant targets that the court seeks to dispatch.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Religion or Survival gain Advantage on Intelligence (Religion) checks when taking the Study action to examine a Night Blade, learning the following based on the result:

(5+) Undead Resistance. You know the creature's Resistances.

(10+) Ghostly Blade. You know its Spectral Weapons attack.

(15+) Shadowy Retreat. You learn of the creature's Meld Into Shadow and Spectral Dodge features.

Combat Tactics

The Night Blade sticks to the shadows and darkness, attempting to surprise their foes and gain Advantage as often as possible. They attack their foes using their spectral weapons, using the Mindmuddler option against spellcasters. If the target is still alive by the 2nd round, the Night Blade takes the Disengage action to escape.

The Night Blade flees if it is at a Disadvantage, is surrounded, or is in direct sunlight.

Sanguine Witch.name: Sanguine Witch
Sanguine Witch.text:
Twisted Mages. When a mageborn is bitten by a vampire, the magical energies flowing in their now-tainted blood create a Sanguine Witch. A creature of both vampiric bloodlust and arcane might. These witches serve as right hands to vampire nobility and as generals and lieutenants in vampire armies.They are cunning and manipulative creatures who lure victims with deception and wit.

Arcane Blood. Sanguine Witches are mageborn but their magic energies are stunted and twisted; they can use magic to absorb life essence from their victims and live unnatural lives. The more a Sanguine Witch feeds, the more the vampiric essence mutates with their arcane blood. Sanguine Witches often take on grotesque mutations from this otherworldly mixing. Notably, many Sanguine Witches have acquired blood red glowing eyes and animalistic snouts and fangs.

Mages of the Court. Sanguine Witches stand as the chosen court mages to vampire masters. They perform all the duties a court mage would usually do, but their loyalty to the Court of the Night is unbreaking. Their mastery over undeath, and their ability to warp victims into vampiric thralls makes them a terrifying creature to behold.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Religion or Survival gain Advantage on Intelligence (Religion) checks when taking the Study action to examine a Sanguine Witch, learning the following based on the result:

(5+) Unnatural Resistances. You recognize the creature's damage Resistances and Immunities.

(10+) Siphon Vitality. You learn of the creature's Feast action.

(15+) Arcane Caster. You know the creature possesses formidable spellcasting abilities.

Combat Tactics

The Sanguine Witch uses Darkness to hide themselves and attempt to enthrall subjects with Hold Person before using Feast to feed on them. The witch's goal is to create thralls of their opponents.

If the Sanguine Witch is in direct sunlight, or at less than half their Hit Points, they attempt to flee.

Fluid: Monster Blood.

Bones: Skull, Spine, Ribs.

Hair: Hair.

Hide: Skin.

Skeletons.name: Skeletons
Skeletons.text:
W hen When a vampire is preparing for war, they have no shortage of soldiers. Their crypts are often filled with long-deceased thralls, remains of prisoners, vampire slayers, and anyone who mistakenly wandered into their manor or castle and was never seen again. The vampires use their dark magic to raise these skeletal remains from the crypt and into their legions. Clad in ancient armor and often given bows or spears, these skeletal warriors make excellent minions for a vampire. They do not need to be fed and are easily stored in tombs and crypts when not needed. Some of these skeletons possessed arcane abilities in life and carry that trait through to undeath, leading skeletal armies as mages. They harness what remains of their arcane fortitude to channel elemental fury at their foes.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Religion or Survival gain Advantage on Intelligence (Religion) checks when taking the Study action to examine a skeleton, learning the following based on the result:

(5+) Unnatural Resistances. You recognize the creature's Immunities.

(10+) Deathly Violence. You know the creature's basic attacks and Bonus Actions.

(15+) Unliving Abilities. You learn the creature's highest and lowest ability scores.

Combat Tactics

These skeleton warriors are mindless foot soldiers in the wars of vampires. They march into battle with no care. They feel no pain. They only follow their orders and fight to the death on behalf of their vampiric masters.

Harvestable Components (Common)

Animus: Undead.

Bones: Skull, Spine, Ribs.

Dust: Undead Dust.

Skeleton Soldier.name: Skeleton Soldier
Skeleton Soldier.text: Most corpses on the continent are cremated; vampires must be clever about obtaining minions for their armies. Throughout the lands, there are ancient crypts of heroic warriors and divine soldiers. Sometimes, vampire lords have been known to infiltrate abandoned holy sites and old crypts to steal the dead, raising them as skeletal minions. Furthermore, they often keep prisoners in their own dungeons to feed on, leaving the bodies once they are expended to one day rise again as skeleton soldiers.

Skeleton Archer.name: Skeleton Archer
Skeleton Archer.text: In the armies of the dead, one must have both melee and ranged troops as the backbone to one's forces. Skeletal archers are imbued with elemental magic and given bows that harness the power to chill their enemies with each shot.

Skeleton Mage.name: Skeleton Mage
Skeleton Mage.text: These mages are often former thralls, acolytes, or arcane prisoners to vampire lords. They are twisted in undeath into unholy mages, harnessing elemental magics against their foes and serving an eternal afterlife to the vampires who create them.

Striga.name: Striga
Striga.text:
A Striga is a contaminated undead abomination which results when a true vampire or vampire spawn succumbs to eldritch contamination under the right circumstances, usually involving a backlash of arcane anomalies, an exposure to delerium during the transformation, or consuming the blood of a powerful contaminated creature. Vastly more powerful than a Hazeblood Vampire, a Striga is completely mad.

However, a Striga can reverse its monstrous contamination by drinking the blood of a humanoid creature who has recently been the target of a @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.features.Item.zgfmQrRMpvBoPAnB]{Purge Contamination} spell.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Arcana or Religion gain Advantage on Intelligence (Religion) checks when taking the Study action to examine a Striga, learning the following based on the result:

(10+) Unnatural Resistances. You recognize the creature's damage Resistances and Immunities.

(15+) Terrifying Howl. You learn of the creature's Blood Howl action.

(20+) Defeatable Undeath. You know the creature's lowest ability scores and Vampire Weaknesses.

Combat Tactics

The Striga is a vampire warped by delerium and contamination. It loses its inhibitions and subtlety, becoming a ravenous bloodthirsty monster. The Striga charges into battle and aggressively pursues its foes, clawing and howling as it hunts its prey. The Striga attempts to single out a weak target and tears them to shreds before moving on to the next.

A Striga rarely flees as it is too bloodthirsty to consider its own life.

Harvestable Components (Very Rare)

Animus: Undead.

Fluid: Monster Blood.

Bones: Skull, Spine, Ribs.

Natural Weapons: Teeth, Claws.

Hair: Hair.

Hide: Skin.
