Digipede.name: Digipede
Digipede.text:
A dventurers Adventurers exploring the Inner City learn to heed the sound of scraping nails—a harbinger of the Digipedes approach. Nicknamed “house” centipedes for their prodigious size, Digipedes are nightmarish creatures with a disposition toward violence. Rather than consuming their prey, they leave the bodies of their lifeless victims abandoned in the desolate city streets.

How Digipedes came to be is unknown. Perhaps they originated from ordinary centipedes mutated by pools of contaminated sludge, manifesting humanlike features during their grotesque transformations. Alternatively, they may be the result of an ongoing metamorphosis, their forms continuing to twist and warp, fueled by the relentless magical forces of the Haze. A few attribute their creation to a powerful wizard hiding in the ruins known as the Pale Man, claiming he commands them as spies and assassins. Finally, its possible the beasts are not the product of contamination but a horrific experiment created within the Inscrutable Tower long before Drakkenheim fell.

Nevertheless, a Digipede is solitary, preferring to avoid others of its kind. A few ingenious adventurers have taken advantage of this curious trait, mimicking the creatures rhythmic scraping and generating bursts of static electricity to drive them off, or even guide them toward other threats. This secret is well known to vanguards of the Hooded Lanterns, who use Digipedes as a bizarre form of pest control against other threats haunting the ruins.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Nature gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks to Study a Digipede, learning the following based on their result:

(10+) Charged Form. You recognize the creatures Resistance to Lightning damage and that it has Tremorsense thanks to its large antenna.

(15+) Sharp and Shocking. You are aware of the Digipedes Talons and Eye Beam actions.

(20+) Insectile Predator. You learn the creatures strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.

Combat Tactics

Despite its size, a Digipede will try to hide along rooftops, dark corners, narrow alleys, and any crevice which can accommodate it. It launches its Eye Beam from hiding to hinder its preys escape, then rips into them with its Talons and Bite. The electric shocks from its attacks disrupt the ability of its prey to effectively fight back.

Harvestable Components (Rare)

Animus: Monstrosity.

Fluid: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor, Elemental Fluid.

Organs: Eyes, Heart, Guts.

Natural Weapons: Claws.

Hide: Carapace.

Zealot of Morrigan.name: Zealot of Morrigan
Zealot of Morrigan.text:
A s As it is rumored that Morrigan is responsible for creating the first vampires, there are some amongst the Court of the Night that take to worshiping her in both body and soul. Viewing themselves as the apex predators, all creatures are beneath them. The Zealots of Morrigan pledge themselves to fighting against Morrigan's enemies, not least of which the druids and servants of Arwyn and Kromac. These warriors serve as the vanguard for much of the court's offensive operations, and are often sent in when they want an enemy utterly eviscerated.

The Zealots of Morrigan, as their order is called, give in to the primal nature their vampirism. They see the trappings of civilization and the kingdoms and empires that mankind has built as a blight upon the land, a perversion of nature. They do what they can to bring what settlements they can into complete and utter ruin. Reports of far flung, small villages disappearing overnight are often an indicator of their presence.

As they are vampires, Zealots of Morrigan like to attack and feed at night. There are rumored to be many Zealots of Morrigan dwelling in Netherwind, where the winter nights last several days, and the scarce population is a prime herd for the zealots to feast upon. The Reavers of Netherwind must stay especially vigilant during these times, and fighting them is a true test of their mettle. On occasion, the Zealots of Morrigan get a particular taste for giant's blood, and will coordinate an attack on a giant. This is usually done on Morrigan's holy day, and the blood feeds them for months.

Morrigan has infused these zealots with immense power and vitality. They rarely bother fighting with weapons, viewing their vampiric gifts as more than sufficient. The blood of their foes wraps around them, bandaging their wounds and forming a protective shield to keep them in the fight. The scent of spilt blood drives them into a frenzy, pushing them on into further savagery. There is often very little left of a zealot's quarry, as they get carried away in their bloodlust.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Arcana or Religion gain Advantage on Wisdom (Insight) or Intelligence (Investigation) checks when taking the Study action to examine it, learning the following based on the result:

(10+) Angry Undead. You recognize the creature's Morrigan's Fury bonus action.

(15+) Rejuvenating Violence. You learn of the creature's Blood Shield trait.

(20+) Swift and Strong. You know the creature's highest and lowest ability scores as well as its Vampire Weaknesses.

Combat Tactics

As soon as a Zealot of Morrigan gets the scent of combat, they use their bonus action to enter Morrigan's Fury, amplifying their damage and bolstering them against assault. With their superior speed, they zone in on the easiest meal within range, assailing them with their claws and fangs. The blood spilt from these attacks then serves as a buffer, fueling their Blood Shield. In their fury, the zealots have no sense of survival or self-preservation, as they fight to the death.

Harvestable Components (Rare)

Animus: Undead.

Fluid: Monster Blood.

Bones: Skull, Spine, Ribs.

Natural Weapons: Teeth, Claws.

Hair: Hair.

Hide: Skin.

Dust: Undead Dust.

Vladimir von Drakken.name: Vladimir von Drakken
Vladimir von Drakken.text:
V ladimir Vladimir von Drakken is dead, his broken form buried deep within the crypts beneath an ancient grove in the Brachenwald. Hidden there after he was defeated by his daughter Carmen, his undead body awaits the blasphemous magic needed to reanimate and restore him. Eternal life in undeath was bestowed upon him by the Sanguine Rite which transformed him into an Ascendant Vampire. Vladimir took the druids' words to mean that none could slay him: after the ritual was complete, Vladimir von Drakken could regenerate from any wound or magic.

In truth, he can be struck down by one of his own blood relatives, descendants, or any other who has his “blood” within them. Even in such cases, his undead form is also rejuvenated by their blood. He can be resurrected by performing the Sanguine Rite again upon his remains, a grisly ritual that demands the sacrifice of a powerful sorcerer, a true dragon, and blood descendant of Vladimir von Drakken himself.

Unfortunately for the Court of the Night, the means and materials to perform this ritual again have eluded them for hundreds of years. Not only did Vladimir von Drakken slay the original druids who performed the rite, but the subsequent fall of House von Drakken in the centuries since has made finding a suitable sacrifice challenging. Nevertheless, should that ever come to pass, a threat unlike any other would return to the world.

Roleplaying Traits

  • Personality Trait. Vladimir speaks with vile overconfidence, a sinister smirk, and a demeanor of a creature who believes himself a god, he does not tolerate others treating him as any less than a king of kings.
  • Bond. Vladimir will stop at nothing to conquer the continent and reclaim his throne in Drakkenheim. He made it, and it is his to rule, any other who attempts to sit upon it is an imposter.
  • Ideal. “This realm belongs to the dead, and the dead shall keep it. Any who stand in the way of my reign will join my legions by choice, or by force.”
  • Flaw. Vladimir believes himself entirely indestructible andis blind to the loopholes within the rites that created him.Nevertheless, he is hesitant to trust anyone. He refuses to let anyone get close and assumes everyone is plotting against him.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Arcana or Religion gain Advantage on Intelligence (Religion) checks when taking the Study action to examine Vladimir von Drakken, learning the following based on the result:

(15+) Deadly Foe. You know of the creature's Resistancesand Immunities.

(20+) Renowned Swordsman. You are aware of his Bloodmourne and Bite attacks.

(25+) Nearly Undefeatable. You recognize his Reborn or Ascendent Transformation trait.

Combat Tactics

Vladimir von Drakken is presented here in three forms. As the Ascendent Vampire grows in power he transforms into a new form until he returns to his full strength.

If he is successfully resurrected with the Sanguine Rite, Vladimir von Drakken first begins in his Crypt-Starved form. He remains in this form until he consumes the blood of a living descendant of House von Drakken, which enables him to turn into his Reborn form.

If reduced to 0 Hit Points in his Reborn form, Vladimir von Drakken unleashes his Ascendant form.

In his Crypt-Starved form, Vladimir von Drakken is a craven and desperate combatant. He primarily aims to drink as much blood as possible using his Bite to transform into his Reborn form. He makes use of Shadow Step and Terrifying Glare to reposition himself and hold foes at bay.

Once he regains his Reborn form, Vladimir von Drakken is nearly unstoppable. He wades into melee with Bloodmourne, demonstrating his martial superiority by using his maneuvers. He uses his Claws and Bite as finishing moves and uses Dominate to bend his foes to his will. When surrounded, he uses Wing Blast to reposition.

Assuming his Ascendant form, Vladimir von Drakken becomes an engine of bloodlust and destruction, fueled by primal rage and undead power. In this form, he rips foes apart with melee attacks and flays their spirits whenever his Soul Rend becomes available.

Slaying Vladimir von Drakken

Vladimir cannot be fully destroyed unless he is wholly unmade at the place he was first transformed. Wholly destroying Vladimir von Drakken is difficult. Once he is defeated in combat, with the final blow struck by one who shares his blood, his heart must be cut out, and placed upon the altar within the Standing Stones in in the Brachenwald where he was transformed into a vampire.Under a full moon at midnight, a wooden stake made from a branch from Elenthas the Evertree must be driven through the heart by one of his blood descendants. Then, the heart must be left there until sunrise where it is destroyed by first light. Vladimir von Drakken's minions do not stand idly whilst this happens, and launch a massive assault upon the grove with the desperate aim of retrieving his heart before it is destroyed by the sun.

Crypt-Starved Vladimir von Drakken.name: Crypt-Starved Vladimir von Drakken
Crypt-Starved Vladimir von Drakken.text:
When returned to unlife via the Sanguine Rite, Vladimir von Drakken first manifests in this form. He remains in this form until he has fed on enough individuals of sufficient power, upon which he assumes his Reborn form.

Although he cannot be permanently destroyed in this form, Vladimir von Drakken is greatly weakened in this state and desires nothing more than returning to his full power.

Reborn Vladimir von Drakken.name: Reborn Vladimir von Drakken
Reborn Vladimir von Drakken.text: This is Vladimir von Drakken's normal form, once he has regained his full strength. In this form, he is a cunning and strategic adversary.

Ascendant Vladimir von Drakken.name: Ascendant Vladimir von Drakken
Ascendant Vladimir von Drakken.text: In his Ascendant form, Vladimir von Drakken is truly a monster. Once he ascends to this form, he savagely attacks anyone he sees, including his own underlings.

Storm Troll.name: Storm Troll
Storm Troll.text:
Storm Trolls can be found anywhere storms are common, such as the Rust Edge Mountains, along the coast in the Eastern Vales near Port Brynor, along the Crystal Coast, or down in Terene or the Southern Reach. Storm Trolls thrive in a raging storm, and often hibernate through sunny stretches. They are extremely sensitive to changes in the weather, emerging from their lairs when the winds change. They can sense an oncoming storm a day or two before it comes. Hunters and sailors that spot a Storm Troll know it's time to head back, as a storm is likely only a day away.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Nature or Survival gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks to Study a Storm Troll, learning the following information based on the result:

(5+) From Harsh Environments. You know the troll's Immunities.

(10+) Hard to Kill. You learn of the troll's Regeneration trait.

(15+) Special Weakness. You have insight into the troll's Vulnerabilities.

Combat Tactics

Storm Trolls hunt for food during heavy rainfall or bad storms. Often accompanied by cracks of thunder and flashes of lightning, they begin combat by hurling lightning at their foes before rushing in to maul them with their Claws and Bites.

If a Storm Troll takes Acid damage, it immediately flees and attempts to find a safe place to recuperate.

Animus: Giant.

Fluid: Monster Blood, Elemental Fluid.

Organs: Eyes, Heart, Guts, Flesh.

Bones: Skull, Spine, Ribs.

Natural Weapons: Teeth, Claws.

Hair: Hair.

Hide: Skin.

Dust: Elemental Dust.

Winter Troll.name: Winter Troll
Winter Troll.text:
Winter Trolls occupy the great mountain tops around the continent, but are especially persistent in the Giantfrost Mountains where they share their domain with their bitter rivals of the stone and frost giants. They hunt across the Barren Expanse in packs and have claimed a portion of the ruins of Glitter Peak. Winter Trolls rarely leave snowy environments. They pose a significant threat to settled lands in the dead of winter, when they leave their mountain tops to look for food.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Nature or Survival gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks to Study a Winter Troll, learning the following information based on the result:

(5+) From Harsh Environments. You know the troll's Immunities.

(10+) Hard to Kill. You learn of the troll's Regeneration trait.

(15+) Special Weakness. You have insight into the troll's Vulnerabilities.

Combat Tactics

Winter Trolls hunt for food during heavy snowfall and long winters. Often accompanied by swirling snowstorms and freezing temperatures, they begin combat by unleashing their Freezing Breath before rushing in to maul foes with their Slams and Bites.

If a Winter Troll takes Fire damage, it immediately flees and attempts to find a safe place to recuperate.

Fluid: Monster Blood, Elemental Fluid.

Natural Weapons: Teeth, Claws.

Hair: Hair.

Hide: Skin.

Magma Troll.name: Magma Troll
Magma Troll.text:
Magma Trolls occupy the deep caverns of the earth, the vast Witherbleach desert, or the caldera of volcanoes such as the Dragon's Maw. They prefer places of sweltering heat and lava flows, and rarely leave these locations if they can help it. Naturally, the desire for food sometimes brings them out of hiding to attack mountainside communities or inhabited places near caverns and caves.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Nature or Survival gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks to Study a Magma Troll, learning the following information based on the result:

(5+) From Harsh Environments. You know the troll's Immunities.

(10+) Hard to Kill. You learn of the troll's Regeneration trait.

(15+) Special Weakness. You have insight into the troll's Vulnerabilities.

Combat Tactics

Magma Trolls hunt for food during the hottest days of summer or in places of extreme temperatures. Often accompanied by sweltering heat, they begin combat by unleashing their Sulfurous Belch before rushing in to maul foes with their claws and bites.

If a Magma Troll takes Cold damage, it immediately flees and attempts to find a safe place to recuperate.

Harvestable Components (Rare)

Animus: Giant.

Fluid: Monster Blood, Elemental Fluid.

Organs: Eyes, Heart, Guts, Flesh.

Bones: Skull, Spine, Ribs.

Natural Weapons: Teeth, Claws.

Hide: Plates.

Eldritch Troll.name: Eldritch Troll
Eldritch Troll.text:
W hen When a troll's innate ability to regenerate combines with the devastating mutating properties of delerium, it causes an Eldritch Troll to form. These creatures are near impossible to kill, regenerating from almost any attack thrown at them. They also seem to have some control over their mutations, which they can change at any moment to help them hunt their prey. Eldritch Trolls have been known to grow wings and fly, or grow extra arms to attack or to cover their body in crystalized delerium.

Unlike most other trolls, Eldritch Trolls do not travel in packs or form tight-knit family groups. They are corrupted abominations and lose much of their sentience in the process. They are more likely to be encountered alone, wandering the ruins of Drakkenheim, or the corrupted Thin Places of the continent.

Eldritch Trolls tend to wander the areas they became corrupted in, never straying too far away from the delerium that they crave. Their grotesque transformation gives them a hunger for more contamination, and to contaminate anything else that comes near. When they sense danger, a threat, or even just wandering prey, Eldritch Trolls attack aggressively, and without remorse.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Nature or Survival gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks to Study an Eldritch Troll, learning the following information based on the result:

(5+) From Harsh Environments. You know the troll's Immunities.

(10+) Hard to Kill. You learn of the troll's Regeneration trait.

(15+) Special Weakness. You have insight into the troll's Vulnerabilities.

Combat Tactics

Eldritch Trolls stalk the streets of the Inner City of Drakkenheim attempting to contaminate any creature they come across. They use Corrupting Blast to contaminate their foes, mutating to whatever best suits them in the battle, and then use their Claws and Bite.

If an Eldritch Troll takes Psychic damage, it immediately flees and attempts to find a safe place to recuperate.

Harvestable Components (Rare)

Animus: Giant.

Fluid: Monster Blood, Elemental Fluid, Contaminated Ichor.

Organs: Eyes, Heart, Guts, Flesh.

Bones: Skull, Spine, Ribs.

Natural Weapons: Teeth, Claws.

Hair: Hair.

Hide: Skin.

Dust: Elemental Dust.

Drakkenheim Sewer Gator.name: Drakkenheim Sewer Gator
Drakkenheim Sewer Gator.text:
S ome Some creatures seem less affected by contamination, or perhaps are just lucky to only grow in size and ferocity. Reptiles are speculated to be more resistant to uncontrollable mutations than other creatures. The occasional gator making its way up the Drann River was always a problem, but now, stories of vicious lizards are becoming more bizarre and horrifying.

Rumors speak of a massive gator living in the sewers, with sightings in the Drann River or echoes of its growls heard from sewer grates. None who came close enough to verify its existence have yet survived. Some report half-submerged forms passing through sewer entrances, sometimes mistaking them for large turtles. Others tell of a large beast rumbling through the pipes under their feet. In the taverns of Emberwood, the creature has earned the nickname “the Gray Queen” due to her pale skin and delerium crown. Others have called it by other names: the Devil of the Drann or the Greater Gator. Some have suggested that multiple giant gators live in the dirty waters.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Animal Handling gain Advantage on Intelligence (Nature) checks to study a Drakkenheim Sewer Gator, learning the following based on their result:

(5+) Fearless Aquatic Predator! You learn the Drakkenheim Sewer Gators condition Immunities and Swim speed.

(10+) Watch out for its bite! You are aware of the creatures Crushing Bite and Death Roll actions.

(15+) Get it out of the water! You know of the creatures Contaminated Regeneration trait.

Combat Tactics

The Drakkenheim Sewer Gator is primarily aquatic, haunting the sewer system or the Drann River. These monstrosities lunge from the waters to grab prey, dragging it beneath the surface. Once a target is in its jaws, the gator Death Rolls until its victim stops moving. It is a cunning hunter, knowing how to disappear below murky waters, but it can be provoked to chase its prey. Out of the water it is vulnerable and flees if reduced below half its Hit Points.

Harvestable Components (Very Rare)

Animus: Monstrosity.

Fluid: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor.

Organs: Eyes, Heart, Brain, Guts, Flesh.

Bones: Skull, Ribs, Spine.

Natural Weapons: Teeth.

Hide: Skin.

Troll Hag.name: Troll Hag
Troll Hag.text:
Mothers of Mushrooms

The Troll Hags are the keepers of fungus in the Trogrowth Forest of Caspia, and swamps all around the continent. They tend to mushroom gardens and carry large iron cauldrons filled with strange brews that they use to turn ordinary fungus into Trollings. Their gardens are family, and they protect them with their lives. If you go tromping through mushroom patches in a swamp, you best be ready to face the wrath of these mothers of mushrooms.

Covens and Community

Some Troll Hags are happy to live out their days undisturbed in the deepest reaches of dark forests and smelly swamps. They

infest the forests with mushrooms and mycelia and keep their Trollings as family. Troll Hags have, in rare cases, formed covens of three. When these covens form it is often a problem, as three Troll Hags will overflow their territory with fungal growths, causing entire swamps and forests to decay, spilling hordes of Fungal Trolls into nearby villages and towns.

Roleplaying Traits

The following traits can be used to inspire roleplaying a Troll Hag:

  • Personality Trait: “I care for the fungal growths of the forest as if they were my own dear children. I speak to them, sing to them, and care for them as a mother would.”
  • Bond: “I will protect my mushroom children with my life, for they are the sole reason I am here”
  • Ideal: “All things rot and decay. I am the one who aids the forest in that natural process.”
  • Flaw: “I will not tolerate those who do not respect the forests and swamps. I will seek vengeance on any who harm the fungus.”

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Survival or with a Herbalism Kit gain Advantage on Intelligence (Nature) checks when Studying a Troll Hag.

(15+) Potent Spellcaster. You are aware of her Spellcasting and Spore Step actions, as well as her Regeneration trait.

(20+) Dangerous Equipment. You learn her Fungal Staff and Slimeball attacks and her ability to spawn Fungal Trollings.

(15+) Special Weakness. You have insight into the troll'svulnerabilities, as well as her low Armor Class.

Troll Hag Coven

It is rare for three Troll Hags to converge, but not unheard of. Often when three troll Hags find a secluded swamp to infest with their fungal growths, they work together to harness their powers and utterly change the nature of the heart of the swamp, causing the entire area to fill with their fungal delights.

A coven of Troll Hags often results in a small army of Fungal Trolls emerging and disrupting nearby villages, farms, and anyone unlucky enough to travel near their swamps. The trees and foliage change to fungal growths that confuse and disorient anyone attempting to navigate it.

If three Troll Hags form a coven, their AC becomes 15, and they are Challenge Rating 10

Shared Abilities and Traits

While all three hags are within 30 feet of one another they use the @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.KCrOz30Mxv60YyRu]{Troll Hag (Coven)} statblock.

Combat Tactics

A Troll Hag prefers to keep her distance from her enemies, letting her fungal minions do the up-close work. If the hag finds herself in melee combat, she uses her Fungal Staff and then teleports away using Spore Step to hurl Slimeballs at her enemies.

Harvestable Components (Rare)

Animus: Giant.

Fluid: Monster Blood, Acidic Bile.

Bones: Skull, Spine, Ribs.

Natural Weapons: Spores.

Hair: Hair.

Hide: Skin.

Dust: Elemental Dust.

Humongous Fungus Troll.name: Humongous Fungus Troll
Humongous Fungus Troll.text:
Swampland Protectors. Humongous Fungus Trolls stand as the guardians of their swamps. They do not cater to trespassers of any kind. Loyal to their Troll Hag mothers, they defend their fungal farms and wander the swamps spreading their spores as they go.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Nature or Survival gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks to Study a Humongous Fungus Troll, learning the following information based on the result:

(5+) From Harsh Environments. You know the troll's Spore Slam and Grasping Tendrils Actions.

(10+) Hard to Kill. You learn of the troll's Regeneration trait.

(15+) Special Weakness. You have insight into thetroll's Vulnerabilities.

Combat Tactics

Humongous Fungus Trolls remain motionless and observe trespassers to see if they are a threat. If combat is initiated, the Humongous Fungus Troll uses its Grasping Tendrils to pull victims towards it, then use its Entangling Mycelia to entangle as many creatures as possible within its Rotting Aura.

Harvestable Components (Rare)

Animus: Giant.

Fluid: Monster Blood.

Bones: Skull, Spine, Ribs.

Natural Weapons: Tentacles, Spores.

Dust. Elemental Dust.

Fungal Trolling.name: Fungal Trolling
Fungal Trolling.text:
F ungal Fungal Trollings are grown from the strange concoctions of Troll Hags. A Troll Hag can grow hundreds of these creatures in their gardens within a very short amount of time. However, the trollings are prone to bursting if they get too excited. Only a small few ever grow to adulthood, becoming Humongous Fungus Trolls.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Nature or Survival gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) check to Study a Fungal Trolling, learning the following information based on the result:

(5+) From Harsh Environments. You know the troll's Spore Slam action.

(10+) Explosive Death. You learn of its Death Burst trait.

(15+) Special Weakness. You have insight into the troll's Vulnerabilities.

Combat Tactics

Fungal Trollings emerge from patches of mushrooms and run screaming towards their enemies, lashing out with their tiny tendrils. When hit hard enough, they explode in a puff of spores that can weaken their enemies.

Harvestable Components (Common)

Animus: Giant.

Fluid: Monster Blood.

Bones: Skull, Spine, Ribs.

Natural Weapons: Teeth, Spores.

Hide: Bark.

Dust: Elemental Dust.

Oak Troll.name: Oak Troll
Oak Troll.text:
T he The Oak Trolls wander the woods of the Achtungwald, Trogrowth, and many other forests of the continent. They tend and speak to the forests and trees. When outsiders come through their territory, the trolls defend their trees at all costs.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Nature or Survival gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) check to Study an Oak Troll, learning the following information based on the result:

(5+) From Harsh Environments. You know the troll's Bite and Gnarled Claw actions.

(10+) Hard to Kill. You learn of the troll's Regeneration trait.

(15+) Special Weakness. You have insight into the troll's Vulnerabilities.

Combat Tactics

With their thick shroud of leaves, Oak Trolls are well protected from their enemies. They always look for an opportunity to send their leaves bursting off to Blind their enemies.

Harvestable Components (Rare)

Animus: Giant.

Fluid: Monster Blood, Sap.

Bones: Skull, Spine, Ribs.

Natural Weapons: Teeth, Claws.

Hair: Leaves.

Hide: Bark.

Dust: Elemental Dust.

Agog.name: Agog
Agog.text:
T he The Agog resembles what mortals might comprehend as a tree stump, and when the creature is motionless, it may even be passed by. However, when it springs to life its true form is something wholly bizarre. These creatures waddle along desert landscapes in the Space Between Worlds, or rest in the muck surrounding the screaming heads. They feed on corpses and have a seemingly endless appetite and a need to satiate it.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in History or Nature gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they take the Study action to examine an Agog, learning the following based on the result.

(5+) Climbing Aberration. You know the creature's type, and movement speeds.

(10+) Attack the Fallen. You are aware of the creature's Gobble Bonus Action.

(15+) Dim but Sturdy. You recognize the creature's highest and lowest ability scores.

Combat Tactics

The Agog barrels towards its enemies, flailing its arms towards them and attempting to grab them and toss them to the ground. If it knocks a creature down, it will immediately begin attempting to devour them.

Harvestable Components(Common)

Animus: Aberration.

Fluid: Contaminated Ichor, Sap.

Organs: Guts.

Natural Weapons: Claws, Teeth.

Hide: Bark.

Dust: Aberrant Dust.

Allopine.name: Allopine
Allopine.text:
T he The Allopine is a creature that defies logic, seemingly a shifting and confused array of various animals — its disjointed and bizarre arrangements make them a puzzle to look at. Flying through the Space Between Worlds, the creatures travel in swarms occupying the dark caverns and ruins found throughout the non-places. When making their way into the Mortal World, they will find old barns or caves to hide in.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in History or Nature gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they take the Study action to examine an Allopine, learning the following based on the result.

(5+) Flying Aberration. You know the creature's type, and movement speeds.

(10+) Shifty. You are aware of the creature's Nimble Escape Bonus Action.

(15+) Agile but Meek. They learn the creature's highest and lowest ability scores.

Combat Tactics

Allopines are not warriors, but they are hostile to creatures who enter their territory and will fire Quills at anyone who comes too close. They do not stick around in a fight by themselves, and if they are with a flock, they will prefer to take to the air and fire Quills from afar.

Fluid: Contaminated Ichor.

Organs: Guts.

Bones: Skull, Spine, Ribs.

Natural Weapons: Needles.

Hide: Scales, Webbed Membrane.

Delerium Dragons.name: Delerium Dragons
Delerium Dragons.text:
I nscrutable Inscrutable beings of the Space Between Worlds, Delerium Dragons are order from chaos incarnate. How such creatures came to be is unknown, and few know of their existence. Some propose that they emerged spontaneously, hatching from crystalline eggs with octarine shells.

A Delerium Dragon is not simply contaminated, but a unique type of gemstone dragon with an otherworldly physiology. These dragons are literally made of the crystals: their claws, bones, and scales are refracting delerium shards. Their flesh and organs are incomprehensible organic matter, and their blood is delerium sludge. When unleashings its breath weapon, it exhales a storm of glittering shards that explode, causing madness, mutation, and wild magic to erupt in the area.

Delerium Dragons are amongst the most powerful beings born within the Space Between Worlds. Capable of perceiving dimensions imperceptible to mortals, these dragons often seem flighty or distracted, but this is because they experience layers of reality which humans cannot. They are thus strange intermediaries, able to interact with creatures on a transdimensional level. Indeed, Delerium Dragons are unstuck in time, unrestrained by the linear progression of past, present, and future. Some experience their entire lives simultaneously, whereas others live their lives non-sequentially. Most understand that even their own existences is beyond comprehension, and many contemplate the fundamental nature of existence, chaos, and the cosmos. Many are nihilistic solipsists who believe that nothing actually exists except themselves, and even then many doubt their own existence, believing they are merely half-remembered dreams caught betwixt a fleeting thought. Others instead revel in their chaotic existence, seeking new forms of art and untamed creation. Powerful mages and talented bards have sought their wisdom and knowledge.

Most Delerium Dragons find the Mortal World, and mortals, rather limited and boring. Throughout history, only one emerged in the Mortal World, the mighty Amaranthyst, archmage of the Amethyst Academy—the dragon's true nature known only to the other members of the Academy Directorate.

Delerium Dragons exert their force of will over the Space Between Worlds and make their lairs realms unto themselves. These lairs may open into a Thin Place, the yawning cavern of a normal dragon's lair instead leading to the madness of the Delerium Dragon's home. These dragons fill their lairs with treasures and secrets of mysterious significance and anachronistic origin, hoarding items which may have been valuable in the distant past, or of critical importance to the distant future. Like themselves, some of their greatest possessions may exist in a state mortals can't perceive or which are fundamentally hazardous, such as multidimensional art objects, miniature primordial black holes, degenerate matter taken from a neutron star, or magical vessels containing another universe or pocket dimension.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in History gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they take the Study action to examine a Delerium Dragon, learning the following based on the result.

(15+) Empowered by Eldritch Magic. You understand the dragon's Resistances and senses.

(20+) Octarine Breath. You recognize the effects of the Delerium Dragon's breath weapon, as well as noting its Spellcasting capabilities.

(25+) Few Weaknesses. You learn its highest and lowest saving throws.

Combat Tactics

A Delerium Dragon views combat less as a violent encounter and more as a chance to change foes into a new form. It darts about using flight and teleportation, seldom remaining in the same place for more than a turn. Their movement makes it easy for the dragon to find the perfect place to catch many enemies with its breath weapon. Delerium Dragons love to spread contamination and cause arcane anomalies, and delight causing monstrous transformations with their contaminated attacks.

Delerium Dragons use their Bite, Contaminated Rend, and Tail attacks to tear opponents apart in between uses of their breath weapon. When they are unable to close the distance, they mentally assault their targets with Mindfire.

Delerium. In addition, characters can collect delerium crystals from its body: a wyrmling has [[/r 2d4]] fragments, a young dragon has [[/r 2d8]] shards, and an adult has [[/r 2d6]] crystals. An Ancient Delerium Dragon's body has 1 delerium geode and [[/r 2d6]] crystals.

Delerium Dragon Wyrmling.name: Delerium Dragon Wyrmling
Delerium Dragon Wyrmling.text: Playful and full of wonder, Delerium Dragon Wyrmlings do not stray far from where they hatch, as they still must contend with their multidimensional existence. A wyrmling usually does not yet fully understand their transtemporal senses, and experiences memories of their adulthood and future in dreams and visions.

Young Delerium Dragon.name: Young Delerium Dragon
Young Delerium Dragon.text: Explorers of many worlds and vistas, Young Delerium Dragons venture throughout the Space Between Worlds, ranging far and wide in search of meaning among meaninglessness, form amongst formlessness.

Adult Delerium Dragon.name: Adult Delerium Dragon
Adult Delerium Dragon.text: A fully mature Delerium Dragon establishes its own domain within the Space Between Worlds, finding a place suitable to its temperament. There it seeks to understand itself and the world around it.

Effulgent Cnidarian.name: Effulgent Cnidarian
Effulgent Cnidarian.text:
D rakkenheim Drakkenheim glows at night. The bizarre alien color palette of the cosmic borealis caused by the Haze and the delerium crystals is a sight to behold. Yet, within the eldritch nighttime landscape, one can also spot orbs of strange hypnotic light bobbing and swaying between the tall towers and ruined buildings. Upon closer inspection, these wisp-like motes appear to be a sort of aerial jellyfish, whose semi-translucent skin shifts in kaleidoscopic colors.

These strange jellyfish creatures light up the Inner City of Drakkenheim at night, like bizarre night lights that float through the city. Their nature and what exactly created them remains a mystery. Jellyfish were not a common creature found in the Drann River, and so Academy researchers have speculated that these creatures emerged from rifts between the Mortal World and the Space Between Worlds, or that they are the outcome of arcane energies coalescing into a sentient wisp of magic. They act as if drawn to the glow of delerium that illuminates the city in the twilight of dusk. They gently hum in discordant notes, giving an eerie presence to the ruins at night.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Nature gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks to Study an Effulgent Cnidarian, learning the following based on their result:

(5+) Aberrant Resistance. You recognize the monsters Immunities and Resistances.

(10+) Hypnotic Color Change. You learn of the monsters Hallucinogenic Bioluminescence trait.

(15+) Weak but Aware. You are aware of the monsters Strength and Dexterity ability scores and saving throws.

Combat Tactics

The Effulgent Cnidarians are not predatorial — they only want to bask in the glow of delerium crystals, feeding slowly on the arcane energies they emit. They are, however, protective of their food sources. If creatures venture into an area of heavy delerium crystallization, they are sure to find a few Cnidarians bobbing about. The Cnidarian prefers to use its Hallucinogenic Bioluminescence to dissuade threats from engaging it, instead hoping to cause its enemies to kill one another. The Cnidarians feed on creatures under its hypnosis, absorbing their essence through its tendrils. If attacked, it uses its Reflexive Flash and attempts to move away from its threats, often floating straight up as quickly as it can and out of the reach of danger.

Cnidarians do not stay around to fight. If all targets have avoided its charm, and are actively attacking it, it abandons its food source to seek other safer areas.

Harvestable Components (Rare)

Animus: Aberration.

Fluid: Contaminated Ichor, Goopy Ooze.

Organs: Glands.

Natural Weapons: Tentacles.

Hide: Skin.

Dust: Aberrant Dust.

Ancient Delerium Dragon.name: Ancient Delerium Dragon
Ancient Delerium Dragon.text: Perhaps older than the cosmos itself, Ancient Delerium Dragons possess knowledge and memories of worlds and eons which have past, many more which never were, and countless which cannot be. Their very presence warps the world around them according to their whims.

Far Dweller.name: Far Dweller
Far Dweller.text:
K nown Known as Far Dwellers, these enigmatic beings are among the most persistent and terrifying entities encountered in the Space Between Worlds. They traverse dimensions and Thin Places, abducting victims to perform alien experiments on them. However, their motives and purposes remain utterly obscure, and their objectives beyond human understanding. Nevertheless, Far Dwellers demonstrate uncanny understanding of the psychic forces and wild magic of the Space Between Worlds, and perhaps have an interest in spreading the influence and contamination of that dimension. None possess greater mastery over delerium and contaminated magic than these creatures. They weave their spells to create eldritch machines with unknown purposes, dominate their victims, evade harm, and complete their esoteric research.

It is evident from the limited interactions Far Dwellers have had with mortals that they pose a grave threat and harbor malicious intentions towards humanoids. Far Dwellers perceive humanoids much as a person might view an insect or perhaps a stray animal — sometimes with indifferent disregard, other times with evident disgust or disdain. They rarely communicate with mortals and seem unwilling or disinterested in explaining themselves or their goals. Far Dwellers show scant concern for their captives' desperate pleas for help or cries for mercy as they secure them to stone slabs and invade their minds with countless probing tendrils.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in History or Nature gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they take the Study action to examine a Far Dweller, learning the following based on the result.

(10+) Psychic Fortress. You learn the creature's Resistances and Immunities.

(15+) Mental Control. You are aware of the creature's Pluck the Puppet Strings Bonus Action.

(20+) Otherworldly Intellect. They learn the creature's highest and lowest ability scores.

Combat Tactics

A Far Dweller often disregards creatures it deems lesser than itself until it is outwardly threatened, often outright ignoring nearby mortals like one might ignore a passing insect or rodent. However, when provoked they are intelligent, efficient, and ruthless. Thanks to its great intellect, a Far Dweller rapidly assesses the capabilities of its attackers and responds to methodically dismantle them accordingly.

Far Dwellers begin combat by casting @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.clwv2PWOcT822hlr]{Maze}, @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.6g3WLOZ2u0EbaLAd]{Hypnotic Pattern}, or @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.yqUDoxk4x0NWG5Bz]{Slow} to incapacitate as many foes as possible. On subsequent turns, it uses Contaminate and Mind Scramble to launch a contaminated psychic assault, preferring to target spellcasters and physically weak targets, while choosing physically strong but easily manipulated targets for Pluck the Puppet Strings.

When attacked, a Far Dweller disappears temporarily using Vanish to the Space Between Worlds. Note that this ability functions normally on the Space Between Worlds itself, as the Far Dweller momentarily travels to a different spatial dimension on that plane.

A Far Dweller is always willing to abandon a fight and its projects if it is sufficiently threatened, and will flee to the Space Between Worlds using @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.J6Jpw5XzB5aTeqnz]{Plane Shift} if it is Bloodied.

Natural Weapons: Tentacles.

Hide: Skin.

Far Dweller Abductor.name: Far Dweller Abductor
Far Dweller Abductor.text:
Some folk have told tales of wandering travelers alone at night who saw strange lights in the sky, or through the trees of thick woods, or incomprehensible beings that wandered into their camps through rifts between worlds. The most horrifying are those who speak of the creatures effortlessly entering their homes and taking them somewhere else, only to awake with a hazy memory and no signs that anyone was ever there.

Their motives are completely unknown, but they arrive from the Space Between Worlds to observe, and experiment upon mortals. When one encounters a Far Dweller Abductor, they are left with no memory of ever having experienced the creature in the first place. The abducted are left with strange and bizarre dreams, confused visions, and blurred concepts of what may have occurred. This has led to doubt and discourse over the very existence of these creatures. For those who share stories are often met with disbelief, as witnesses and victim share conflicting tales of their experience.

Study The Foe

Characters proficient in History or Nature gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they take the Study action to examine a Far Dweller Abductor, learning the following based on the result.

(10+) Psychic Fortress. You learn the creature's Resistances and Immunities.

(15+) Confounding Existence. You are aware of the creature's Unfathomable Presence trait.

(20+) Malign Brilliance. They learn the creature's highest and lowest ability scores.

Combat Tactics

The Far Dweller Abductors are not fighters, and simply wish to gather specimens and study them. When Abductors appear, they usually do so when a creature is resting or asleep. They rely on their Unfathomable Presence to confuse and dismantle their target. They use use Mind Warp or Devour Thoughts to weaken the mind of their target before attempting to Abduct them.

The Far Dweller Abductors do not wish to be observed or remembered, and do not want even their dead left behind to be discovered and known to the creatures they are researching. A Far Dweller Abductor will teleport away and use @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.J6Jpw5XzB5aTeqnz]{Plane Shift} if it has lost the upper hand, is outnumbered, or feels in any way threatened. If a Far Dweller Abductor dies, any Far Dwellers still engaged in battle attempt to take their bodies and vanish as quickly as possible, attempting to leave no trace of their presence.

Far Dweller Mastermind.name: Far Dweller Mastermind
Far Dweller Mastermind.text: Especially ancient and terrible, these powerful Far Dwellers have wandered existence for untold eons.

Entropic Watcher.name: Entropic Watcher
Entropic Watcher.text:
M any Many of the creatures inhabiting the Space Between Worlds are aberrant and primordial in nature. The Entropic Watcher is one such incomprehensible creature. To look upon it is like looking at an abstract painting, the forms and shapes of it body painful to observe by the mortal mind. It silently drifts through the Space Between Worlds, drawn to Thin Places where it observes the places beyond, as if analyzing or calculating some unknown concepts as it stares through like a cat at a window. For this reason, Entropic Watchers are one of the more common occurrences in the Mortal World, as they tend to congregate around Thin Places, and often slip through.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in History or Nature gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they take the Study action to examine an Entropic Watcher, learning the following based on the result.

(10+) Guarded Existence. You learn the creature's Resistances and Immunities.

(15+) Imperiling Stare. You recognize the creature's Withering Gaze feature.

(20+) Physically Resilient. You know the creature's highest and lowest ability scores.

Combat Tactics

The Entropic Watcher is a keen hunter who, by its very gaze, can cause a creature to grow weak and leave it open for annihilation. The Entropic Watcher focuses its gaze upon its prey and unleashes its eye beams towards it, knowing that if it can hold its gaze, the creature will succumb to the watcher's blasts much easier. It will use its Force Barrier and Shadow Crash to force its victims into an optimal position for it to strike, and grab them with its tendrils, holding them readily in its Withering Gaze.

If the Entropic Watcher is reduced to less than 50 Hit Points, it attempts to flee.

Fluid: Contaminated Ichor, Goopy Ooze, Mucus.

Fractal Lepidoptera.name: Fractal Lepidoptera
Fractal Lepidoptera.text:
T o To look upon a lepidoptera confounds the mind, as its essence extends into multiple dimensions and the patterns of its form tessellate and refract. Once mesmerized by the spiral of its wings, one is lost in the unformed realms of infinity of the Space Between Worlds. The lepidoptera is simultaneously present in both the known world and the world beyond, bridging the borders between, confounding all on both sides of the divide.

Fractal lepidoptera emerge in Thin Places, or in areas where the northern and southern lights flutter across the sky. These places are a chrysalis to the lepidoptera in which it waits until its pattern infiltrates a realm so it can take flight. Slowly it extends the range of its pattern until all around it exists within the lines of its fractal. And yet it is not truly malevolent. The lepidoptera merely is, living and growing in more dimensions than humans can comprehend. In the dance of its motif and the flutter of a butterfly's wing, mortal lives are set in motion on a path outside of their own will.

The presence of a lepidoptera is recognizable when creatures start behaving repetitively and against their nature. A conspiracy of ravens sings together in syncopated rhythm; streams flow in unnatural direct paths up and down hills; children speak in haikus; hunting animals perpetually circle their prey that has long since died of hunger.

Lair effect

Fractal Lepidoptera transform reality around them, manifesting the following effect:

Quantum Entanglement. Creatures taking a long rest within 1 mile of the lepidoptera must succeed on a [[/save cha dc=17 format=long]] or gain a pattern effect. Creatures can repeat the saving throw at the end of each Long Rest once they are outside the range of Quantum Entanglement. Casting @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.F0GsG0SJzsIOacwV]{Lesser Restoration} or similar spells of higher level on an affected creature can remove the pattern effect.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Nature gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they take the Study action to examine a lepidoptera, learning the following based on the result.

(5+) Mothlike Features. You recognize its Phototaxis trait.

(10+) Chaotic Patterns. You learn the lepidoptera's Quantum Entanglement and Tessellation features.

(15+) Multidimensional. You know of the creature's Multidimensional Presence and IncomprehensibleVision features.

(20+) Creature of Energy. You are aware of its Vulnerabilities and Energy Form trait.

Combat Tactics

The lepidoptera flies through creatures while making Fractal Wing attacks, scattering foes with its Energy Form trait. If at least one enemy is Staggered, it targets them with Tessellation. The lepidoptera uses Criss Cross to protect itself from attacks on the border Ethereal Plane.

Animus: Elemental.

Dust: Elemental Dust.

Interloper.name: Interloper
Interloper.text:
W ithin Within the Space Between Worlds, creatures exist that feed on arcane power, craving magic of all sorts, but particularly power that extraplanar patrons grant to mortals. One such creature identified by the Amethyst Academy has been classified simply as an Interloper.

Drawn to Magic. Interlopers crave magic, especially delighting in extracting the arcane power wielded by warlocks. They latch onto the connection between a warlock and their patron, attempting to follow that connection into the Material plane where they lie in wait for their victim.

Clustered Predators. Interlopers seldom appear alone, preferring to attack in groups of three or more. Occasionally, they have been observed to bicker, fighting each other for the largest share of the spoils.

Spell Snatchers. Interlopers are feared by spellcasters because of their ability to Siphon Spells thrown at them. Once spellcasters recognize an area is infested with these creatures, they often commission Paladins of the Silver Order or grizzled monster hunters to hunt them down.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Arcana gain Advantage on Wisdom (Insight) or Intelligence (Investigation) checks to study an Interloper, revealing the following based on their result:

(10+) Multidimensional Senses. You recognize the creature's Blindsight trait.

(15+) Magical Entity. You are aware of its Siphon Spell ability.

(20+) Agile and Cunning. You know the Interloper's highest and lowest ability scores and saving throws.

Combat Tactics

An Interloper has only one objective, to feast on the spellcaster's magic that attracted it, and then to return to whence it came. It pursues the nearest spellcaster, prioritizing warlocks, assailing them until they are dead, or the caster's magic is spent It Teleports to evade physical attacks. If an Interloper drops below 10 Hit Points, it will @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.J6Jpw5XzB5aTeqnz]{Plane Shift}, retreating into the Space Between Worlds to recover, seeking to return to feast again, likely in greater numbers.

Harvesting Components (Rare)

Fluid: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor.

Organs: Guts, Flesh.

Natural Weapons: Claws.

Hide: Skin.

Dust: Aberrant Dust.

Liminal Herald.name: Liminal Herald
Liminal Herald.text:
L iminal Liminal Heralds are the scouts and messengers of unknown ancient entities that exist in the furthest reaches of the Space Between Worlds. Whatever the purpose is, their galactic information gathering remains a mystery. Liminal Heralds uncover unfathomable truths and whispered echoes of shattered realities as they seek out realms to beckon the coming of their masters.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in History or Nature gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they take the Study action to examine a Liminal Herald, learning the following based on the result.

(10+) Guarded Existence. You learn the creature's Immunities.

(15+) Psychic Retribution. You know of the creature's Reflect Pain Reaction.

(20+) Weak but Perceptive. They learn the creature's highest and lowest ability scores.

Combat Tactics

The Liminal Herald is a contaminated entity from the deepest corners of the Space Between Worlds. It undoes creatures atom by atom with its Eldritch Beams. It targets the intellect of other creatures with its Mind Scramble, especially spellcasters concentrating on spells. The Liminal Herald harnesses the very fabric of magic itself and uses that force against mortals who would attempt to dabble in it. When targeted by an attack, the Liminal Herald bendsspace and time around it using its Reflect Pain feature, causing the creature who attacked it to take on a mental payload of pain felt by the creature. If it is reduced below half its Hit Points, the Liminal Heraldattempts to flee.

Organs: Eyes, Guts, Glands, Flesh.

Lurker on the Threshold.name: Lurker on the Threshold
Lurker on the Threshold.text:
T he The Lurker on the Threshold is a vile and maniacal being, drifting into our realm through Thin Places and screaming in the minds of those it witnesses. It wanders the Space Between Worlds and feeds on the raw arcane energy found in the rifts between realities, and on the shattered atoms of dead realms. It is a creature who exists on the threshold between places and non-places, between time and eternity. It exists as a personification of the roiling unfathomable nothing that is the stitches between the fabric of all things.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in History or Nature gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they take the Study action to examine a Lurker on the Threshold, learning the following based on the result.

(10+) Baleful Resistance. You know the creature's Immunities.

(15+) Arcane Beams. You learn the creature's Cosmic Rays attack action.

(20+) Enduring. You know the creature's highest and lowest ability scores.

Combat Tactics

The Lurker on the Threshold is a creature of pure arcane energy and twisted realities. It fires Cosmic Rays at mortal creatures,warping their minds, showing truths that drive them mad, or undoes their very existence on a cellular level. It grabs creatures with its Tendrils and blasts its beams while holding them in place, undoing the creatures from the inside out, before tossing them aside and moving on to the next.

The Lurker on the Threshold only flees if it is reduced to under half its Hit Points, not because of any sense of fear, but because it finds specific enemies a nuisance.

Hide: Skin.

Eldritch Crawler.name: Eldritch Crawler
Eldritch Crawler.text:
T hese These strange arachnid-like creatures seem to weave together partial realities, parallel dimensions, and alternate timelines like a spider spinning its web. They have features that resemble that of a large spider, but their twisted forms, elongated torsos, fanged maws, and spiny hides give them an otherworldly guise that makes them hard to distinguish as anything from this plane of existence.

Those who have faced one have commented on the broken sense of reality that occurs when attempting to attack an Eldritch Crawler. In response Eldritch Crawlers shift realities, and whether the attack hits or misses, a glimpse through time and space shows all possible outcomes of the attack at once. Even when an Eldritch Crawlers is defeated, it's debatable if they are truly dead, or if it was simply observed in a single timeline in which it was killed—the monster may still exist in every other possible reality. This could mean Eldritch Crawlers transcend human concepts of time and space and can't actually be killed, only removed from one instance of time and space amongst an infinite sea of them.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in History or Nature gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they take the Study action to examine an Eldritch Crawler, learning the following based on the result.

(5+) Uncontainable. You know the creature's Resistances and Immunities.

(10+) Escape Reality. You are aware of the creature's Void Walker Bonus Action.

(15+) Dull and Diffident. You recognize the creature's highest and lowest ability scores.

Combat Tactics

The Eldritch Crawlers weave together fractured timelines, and slip in and out of the Space Between Worlds with ease. They create their own Thin Places and travel through them back and forth as needed. When under attack, Eldritch Crawlers bend and alter the realities they exist in to shift to one where they are more likely to survive. They teleport around the battlefield and vanish into the Space Between Worlds as they need to, using Void Walker and their Fractured Reality Reaction, only to reemerge and attack their prey with Contaminated Venom.

Natural Weapons: Mandibles, Needles.

Hair: Hair.

Animated Delerium Sludge.name: Animated Delerium Sludge
Animated Delerium Sludge.text:
These Contaminated Water Elementals are often found in the cisterns, sewers and other aquatic locations of Drakkenheim.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Nature gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they Study an Animated Delerium Sludge, learning the following based on their result:

(10+) Malleable and Resilient. You learn of the creatures Immunities.

(15+) Contamination by Contact. You are aware of its Contaminated Touch and Engulf actions.

(20+) Easy to Outwit. You know the elementals mental ability scores and saving throws.

Combat Tactics

Animated Delerium Sludge often lies dormant in bodies of water before attempting to Engulf an unsuspecting creature. If reduced to less than 20 Hit Points, it attempts to slip back into the nearby sludge and Hide, hoping to be left alone.

Harvestable Components (Rare)

Animus: Elemental.

Fluid: Contaminated Ichor, Goopy Ooze.

Dust: Elemental Dust.

Phage.name: Phage
Phage.text:
T he The Space Between Worlds is home to alien bottomfeeders known as phages, consuming any magical energy they can find. The barriers between realities become thin near Drakkenheim's Haze-filled areas allowing these creatures to leak through, hungry for mortal magic. They consume spells, storing some of this arcane energy for later ingestion. Sometimes spellcasters can recapture the arcane energy of undigested spells upon the death of a Phage.

On rare occasions, intelligent creatures have tamed Phages, using them as guardians against spellcasting threats. However, they can never be fully controlled and are nearly as likely to consume it's master's spells as any others.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Insight and Investigation gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they examine a Phage, revealing the following based on their result:

(5+) Interdimensional Intruder. You are aware of its Warped Space trait.

(10+) Magic Eater. You understand its Consume Spell Reaction and Bite attack.

(15+) Stored Energy. You learn of the Phage's Spell Vessel trait.

Combat Tactics

Phages are compelled by their hunger for magic. They use their Consume Spell Reaction at the first opportunity, regardless of the spell being cast.

Unfed phages stalk their prey, harassing them with Bites but attacking nonlethally as a dead spellcaster cannot provide them with magical energy. Sated phages often become docile, only using Bite or Spit in defense, disengaging to escape if given the opportunity. When their lives are threatened, Phages digest stored spells to reposition in hopes of getting an even tastier morsel.

Harvesting Components (Uncommon)

Animus: Aberration.

Fluid: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor.

Bones: Baleen.

Organs: Guts, Flesh.

Hide: Skin.

Dust:Aberrant Dust.

Psychophant.name: Psychophant
Psychophant.text:
T he The earliest stories of this realm tell of a great winter when the desperate cried out to anyone who may hear their pleas. These calls echoed in the vastness of the Space Between Worlds, attracting the attention of things from beyond. Psychophants, scavengers drawn to misery, fear, and despair, entered the mortal world through Thin Places and learned to mimic their prey. These adaptive creatures integrate themselves among the vulnerable to feed upon their emotions.

Even now, Civil War veterans of Westemär, huddled in smoky bars recount scouring battlefields for their fallen allies, following distressed cries, only to be set upon by the wounded themselves. In the overwhelmed hospitals of Toddsfeld, contaminated patients insist they are being preyed upon by their nurses, only to have these accusations dismissed as madness. The wretched trenches of war, the blighted lands of natural disasters, the reeking sick beds of convalescent homes, and now, the ruins of Drakkenheim, have all fallen victim to these creature's appetites.

Psychophants are shifters, able to disguise themselves with ease. Some assume the guise of caretakers; such as clerics of the Sacred Flame and Falling Fire, apothecaries and their assistants, and even members of the Hooded Lanterns who watch infirmaries. None are safe from their nefarious infiltration. Psychophants seek positions where they can feed on the vulnerable, ensuring easy access to their victims.

One may quietly stalk a target for weeks, absorbing its mannerisms, and learning its speech, preparing for an opportunity to supplant them. Even when a Psychophant has time to prepare, their ability to deceive is limited. Only able to repeat phrases it has heard spoken by others, their speech is stunted and uncomfortable, their responses terse, or only loosely related to the subject being discussed. While their adopted form is indistinguishable from the original, they lack the skills a target may have possessed.

Pyschophants without the time or impetus to supplant an individual often create an amalgamated identity, combining personal lore overheard from many and pairing it with a stranger's shape. These patchwork creatures are unable to avoid scrutiny for long, frequently moving from town to town. In the ruins of Drakkenheim false pretense lasts only moments. In the ruins, they prey on wounded adventurers posing as an unfortunate survivor of a doomed expedition, begging for help and wailing in despair. Approaching rescuers usually realize too late that the screams coming from this woeful figure are the cries of its most recent victims.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Insight or Investigation gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks to study a Psychophant, revealing the following based on their result:

(5+) Feeding on Despair. You are aware of its Life Siphon ability.

(10+) Resistant Form. You know its Resistances and Immunities.

(15+) Escape with Prey. You learn of the creature's Teleport Bonus Action.

Combat Tactics

A Psychophant feeds on the weak and will avoid a fight with competent adventurers unless the right opportunity presents itself, or its true nature is discovered. In combat it will attempt to subdue aggressors with its Final Scream, then target the bloodiest opponent with its Psychic Grasp. Victim in hand, it will attempt to flee using Teleportation, repeatedly feeding on the target with its Life Siphon until the creature falls unconscious.

Warp Marauder.name: Warp Marauder
Warp Marauder.text:
T he The Warp Marauder is a fearsome predator that lurks within the Space Between Worlds, preying on unsuspecting travelers who stumble into this realm. It is a creature with a body composed of swirling energy and tentacles, able to move freely between dimensions, planes, and realities.

A creature of pure instinct, driven solely by the desire to hunt and feed, these skilled hunters use their ability to navigate between dimensions to stalk prey before launching a surprise

attack, and often preys on creatures that wander along Thin Places near the Space Between Worlds, drawing them into its own dimension where it can feast on their life force.

A Warp Marauder can detect dimensional portals and Thin Places, and will often wait near them for creatures to pass through before pouncing. Its tentacles are incredibly strong, able to crush bones and rend flesh with ease. It can also release blasts of eldritch energy, which can tear through matter and energy alike.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in History or Nature gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they take the Study action to examine a Warp Marauder, learning the following based on the result.

(10+) Mentally Tough. You learn the creature's Resistances and Immunities.

(15+) Reality Distortion. You are aware of the creature's Swirling Color Field trait.

(20+) Strong and Nimble. You know the creature's highest and lowest ability scores.

Combat Tactics

The Warp Marauder has control over the reality around it. It grabs creatures and drags them into extraplanar realities where it feeds on them. The lupine alien isn't afraid to be hit, relying on its ability to alter time and space from an incoming attack, directing an essence of chaotic circumstance back towards the creature.

Warp Marauders flee if they are reduced below half their Hit Points.

Void Pirates.name: Void Pirates
Void Pirates.text:
M any Many humanoids from the Mortal World, and even creatures from the Faerie Otherworlds, the Dreamlands, and beyond have slipped through Thin Places into the Space Between Worlds, and have been unable to return. Many of these unfortunate souls slowly succumb to contamination, eventually disintegrating into contaminated dust that drifts back into the churning ether of the void. However, some survive the prolonged exposure to contamination, and find themselves in an altered state, becoming one with the Space Between Worlds and mutating into a being that resembles their former self, only changed.

Stronger Together

These altered survivors can no longer return to the Mortal World and need the chaotic contaminated environment to survive, but they are also regarded as foreign entities within the Space Between Worlds. Thus, many of the alien creatures inhabiting the twisted landscapes will attack, abduct, or obliterate them on sight.

These survivors have banded together into roving groups of scavengers, pirates, or gangs. They traverse the Void Sea upon scraped-together starships powered by elemental magics. These Void Pirates search and plunder the ancient ruins, caverns, and debris fields looking for anything that will help them survive. They wage war against alien entities and feed on the flesh of their kills, further inducing the never-ending descent into madness and contamination.

When they encounter mortals from another plane, Void Pirates are unpredictable. Sometimes they help lost sailors navigate the sea, hoping the dangerous voyage fails, and a new recruit can join their company. Other times, the pirates are less outwardly kind, kidnapping newcomers and holding them in cells upon their vessels. They use them as a distraction when they come across some horrible entity looking to eat, or as a bargaining chip amongst the other pirates, or even as payment to Far Dwellers for safe passage. A mortal life seems to be of value to many of the strange creatures, so having a few in reserve is often a key to survival.

Ships of the Void Sea

The vessels used by Void Pirates vary from group to group. They range from a small skiff with a sail and winged oars, housing a few pirates, to massive floating castles with elementally fueled propulsion systems housing hundreds.

Some void pirate ships resemble traditional pirate ships, while others appear as floating rafts with makeshift homes, or a series of roped together platforms drifting along. All these ships are bound together in a crude construction made up of junk and debris that has formed randomly in the Space Between Worlds or drifted into the void through Thin Places.

Pirates hunt for better parts, or stronger materials to upgrade their vessels to defend against threats, or to exploit the other gangs of the sea.

Void Pirate ships are often equipped with extra nets, and sometimes ballistae or canons. Some even have more bizarre weaponry befitting the Space Between Worlds

Myriad Forms of Chaos

Void Pirates take on all manner of unusual quirks and physical attributes that represent their prolonged exposure to the shifting chaos of the Space Between Worlds.

(15+) Varied Abilities. They learn the creature's highest and lowest ability scores.

Combat Tactics

Void Pirates often attempt to abduct creatures rather than kill them. They fight without honor, aiming to quickly outnumber and out maneuver opponents. Many target threatening enemies with ship-mounted weapons, or they move in close to use nets and shackles to capture other humanoids. They nearly always take prisoners unless forced to kill a target. If a creature persistently attacks or breaks free, they may decide to slit their throat and use them as bait. They flee if risking defeat. Their lives are more valuable to them than prisoners or treasure.

Harvestable Components

Due to their humanoid origins, these creatures cannot be harvested.

Star Warden.name: Star Warden
Star Warden.text:
T he The Star Wardens are ancient creatures who have traversed the cosmos for centuries. They care little for the multiple realities and their squabbles, nor the relevance of a mortal life. They are eternal beings who exist out of space and time. To them, relativity and dimensions are broken concepts which they can bend to their whims. They exist in multiple dimensions and times at once. They move and age in counterintuitive ways that no mortal can fully comprehend. To a mortal eye, they may appear to phase in and out of existence, or teleport from place to place, at times appearing more ancient, or more youthful. The Star Wardens may not be teleporting at all, but simply experiencing the interaction with a mortal at multiple points in time and space simultaneously. Their existence is wholly outside the standard flow of time or the movement of spatial reasoning. A Star Warden may exist within the past present and future of a mortal being all at the same time.

Their physiology and bizarre existence is utterly baffling to a mortal observer. The few who have witnessed a Star Warden have gone mad by the sheer incomprehensibility of their existence. One such academy mage, Randolf Carter, who practiced entering the Space Between Worlds via Dreamland, said that at several points throughout his life, he has spoken to a Star Warden. From the Star Warden's perspective, their conversation was a singular event, yet for Randolf, it happened in tiny dream-like snippets over the course of 50 years.

The Star Wardens shepherd the cosmos, observing and aiding in the flow of space and time. They view reality as a wavelength of interdimensional strands, and they see to the various timelines and branches of infinite realities. It is impossible to know the full scope of their purpose, but they seem to be protectors of timelines, and ensure no cataclysmic events cause the universe to collapse on itself.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in History or Nature gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they take the Study action to examine a Star Warden, learning the following based on the result.

(10+) Mentally Tough. You know the creature's Immunities.

(15+) Transposition. You recognize the creature's Outside Time and Space Reaction.

(20+) Otherworldly Intellect. You learn the creature's highest and lowest ability scores.

Combat Tactics

Star wardens exist in multiple times and dimensions at once. A creature that tries to fight a star warden is at a loss for where and how the star warden exists before it. Both the Star Warden and the creatures facing it are constantly shifted around the battlefield, unable to grasp their sense of reality. The Star Warden uses its Outside Time and Space Reaction to let two creatures attack one another instead of landing a blow upon itself. It can force the truth of all reality into a creature's mind or have it experience the cold vastness of space. Star Wardens are clever and always flee a losing fight.

Sentient Planetoid.name: Sentient Planetoid
Sentient Planetoid.text:
D rifting Drifting through the void of the Space Between Worlds are planetoids which possess a well of knowledge about the cosmos. They silently float through the void on an endless pursuit of understanding. Their eternal quest for ultimate comprehension of the meaning of all things is an impossible and foolhardy errand, but nonetheless they carry on, observing and learning all they can.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in History or Nature gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they take the Study action to examine a Sentient Planetoid, learning the following based on the result.

(10+) Mental Fortress. You are aware of the creature's Resistances and Immunities.

(15+) Panoptic Arcanist. You learn of the creature's All-Knowing Magic action.

(20+) Unfathomable Strength. You know the creature's highest and lowest ability scores.

Combat Tactics

Sentient Planetoids are not all hostile creatures. Some of them, who have knowledge of mortals deem them a pest or a problem, especially if traversing the Space Between Worlds. Like a mortal who finds a rat in their home, a sentient planetoid will attempt to remove the creature or kill it.

Some planetoids might wish to converse with mortals, wanting to learn information from them about simple concepts of mundane life, or ask questions they think a mortal would know, only to confuse them with esoteric concepts and broad ideas of the universe. This can sometimes frustrate a planetoid who may react by simply wanting to eradicate the creature who bothered it.
