He Who Laughs Last.name: He Who Laughs Last
He Who Laughs Last.text:
H e He Who Laughs Last is a primordial demon of death and decay. Profoundly nihilistic yet strangely mirthful, this archfiend revels in the drama and theatrics of mortal existence, seeing life itself as a cosmic joke. To him, each moment is merely a meaningless scene in the grand tragicomedy of the universe. His spiteful laugh echoes through the corridors of time and space. Legend tells it will be the final sound at the end of all things — when the curtain falls on existence itself. He Who Laughs Last believes this to be his perverse destiny, and this purported knowledge fuels his interactions with mortals, who he regards as powerless pawns in the great play of life and death.

Many undead creatures are believed to be his designs, mocking curses the demon lord has lain upon humanity for his own sick entertainment. Given his mastery over such dark magic, He Who Laughs Last is often sought by necromancers, warlocks, and other arcane practitioners alike as an instructor or patron. Furthermore, He Who Laughs Last often makes eldritch pacts offering power, knowledge, and the promise of escape from mortality. In particular, the demon lord is believed to know the blasphemous rituals required to transform a mortal spellcaster into an abhorrent lich.

Rather than bargain for the souls of his petitioners, however, He Who Laughs Last demands they collect the souls of others instead. He cares not for the method, only that the quota is fulfilled. The demon lord hungers for mortal souls not for the power they contain — although that is certainly a factor — but because he enjoys keeping soul-puppets to entertain himself by replaying the tragedies of their lives.

The Theatre of the Danse Macabre is the domain of He Who Laughs Last. Located in the dark pits of the abyss, this fiendish citadel resembles a great theatre-in-the-round made from bone and blood. There, the collected souls of He Who Laughs Last are bound eternally among the shadowy players and audience members, where they must continually perform tragic stories and watch the dark circus play out.

Although the demon lord's followers are a common target for Knights of the Silver Order, the fiend himself has a particular enmity amongst worshippers of the Old God Morrigan, the goddess of death and magic. He Who Laughs Last often appears to desperate penitents and heretical priests of the Old God, occasionally even impersonating the deity to trick and deceive her devoted followers into creating undead creatures and participating in his schemes.

Roleplaying Traits

Adventurers who interact with He Who Laughs Last must endure his mocking laughter and jeering comments, as he remarks on the futility of their actions, the dramatic irony of their mistakes, and the meaninglessness of their quests. In doing so, He Who Laughs Last carefully offers an escape or solution—if the adventurers will offer him service in exchange, one that is almost certain to have unforeseen consequences.

  • Personality Traits. In conversation, I cannot contain my dark mirth, which manifests from a low chuckle to a belly-bursting guffaw. Most of all, I love the moment when mortals realize the cost of their terrible mistakes and poor decisions.
  • Ideal. Mortals fear death. I play upon that fear, and with it I can catch the conscience of any soul.
  • Bond. I harvest of souls at life's curtain call, binding them to my cast of players in my Theatre of the Danse Macabre.
  • Flaw. I oft direct the play too long, delighting in extending the final act. My patience is as deep as the grave, allowing me to savor each move in the mortal game, though sometimes to the detriment of a timely demise.

He Who Laughs Last loves nothing more than when mortal heroes attempt to outmaneuver him. As befitting his name, there is almost always some unfortunate upset or surprise twist the demon has in store. Even when he is seemingly defeated, he is always sure to remind his foes who will have the last laugh.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Arcana or History gain Advantage on Intelligence (Religion) checks when they take the Study action to examine He Who Laughs Last, learning the following based on the result:

(20+) Powerful Demonlord. You are aware of his Truesight and telepathy, his Resistances and Immunities, and his Epic Resistance. You also know this eldritch entity is beyond life and death and can reform years later if killed.

(25+) Killing Aura. You know of his Mortal Coil aura, and his spellcasting Epic Actions.

(30+) Powerful Presence. You know his highest and lowest ability scores and saving throws.

Combat Tactics

He Who Laughs Last approaches battle lazily, as his mere presence causes mortals to die in short order from his Mortal Coil aura. Nevertheless, he casually ends lives using Sleep No More, Dusty Death, and Out Brief Candle, trapping another foe in a Cage of Sorrows so they must bear witness to the death around them before they expire to his Mortal Coil.

He Who Laughs Last does not fear his own destruction, confident that he will reappear if his corporeal form is destroyed. He is certain of his fate to watch the end of the universe, and even when slain his echoing laughter remains as a grim reminder of his power.

Thing with the Writhing Tail.name: Thing with the Writhing Tail
Thing with the Writhing Tail.text:
T his This esoteric cat-like entity is known by many names and wanders the realms of Dreamland and the Space Between Worlds. It was the scholar Killgar Copperpot who realized its multitudinous identities were one and the same and named it the Thing with the Writhing Tail.

Almost every warlock of the Thing with the Writhing Tail was approached by the creature as a child, appearing before them in the form of a common housecat, though one marked by some strange coloration, demeanor, or smell. It seems to favor those in unfortunate, neglectful, or powerless situations, such as street-wandering orphans or the mistreated offspring of narcissistic aristocrats. It casts itself in the role of their imaginary friend and confidant, sharing reassuring stories, protecting them from danger, and spurring them to precociously seek knowledge and adventure.

Its eldritch pact occurs with a seemingly harmless promise to keep their bond an important secret. In turn, the Thing with the Writhing Tail grants its warlocks a special familiar in the form of a cat, which acts as a direct proxy for the entity itself. The familiar accepts any name the child-warlock chooses, often becoming known by names typical of a household pet, such as Bruce, Dinah, Felix, and others. Since the Thing with the Writhing Tail acts through these familiars, its warlocks are able to converse with the entity on a regular basis through their telepathic bond. As such, the warlocks often exhibit the strange behaviors of having one-sided conversations with their cats.

Although it has appeared throughout history to countless mortals, the motivations of this creature are uncertain, even to its warlocks. It oscillates between agent of chaos and custodian of secret lore known only to cats and may be metaphysically connected to all felines. The Thing with the Writhing Tail is utterly indifferent to the human constructs of morality or duty and observes the Mortal World with a detached curiosity and occasional boredom. While most of the time its desires are guided by hungry impulses, it may suddenly fixate its attention on seemingly innocuous or strange patterns or magical phenomena incomprehensible to its human warlocks.

The Thing with the Writhing Tail rests in places defying logic. It basks within cosmic rays shed by dying suns, languishes atop a shifting nebula, and curls up in the dark corners of reality, where time and space convolute into impossible geometries. Its slumber is deep and filled with dreams of ancient chaos.

It is said that a strange place known as Ulthar, where no one may kill a cat, is especially sacred to the Thing with the Writhing Tail. The Thing with the Writhing Tail is not without its rivals, however. It seems utterly obsessed with one day consuming the Rat God.

Since it goes by so many names, two warlocks who are both pactbound may not realize it at first, believing them to serve different beings. The Thing with the Writhing Tail seems to enjoy this state of affairs, even though it means its warlocks often act against one another. This may in fact be a strange way of weeding out the weak or seeking the most promising and talented warlock amongst its servants.

Roleplaying Traits

This cosmic entity's interactions are marked by caprice and whimsy.

  • Personality Trait. One moment, I might bestow affectionate purrs and nuzzles; the next, I display utter aloofness or sudden ire, swiping with claws of dark matter that rend the veil between sanity and madness.
  • Ideal. My actions are neither cruel nor kind. Mortals cannot know my unfathomable perspective, and that is why they will always be inferior.
  • Bond. I am endlessly entertained by the unpredictability of mortals; their fears, their surprises, and their schemes are like strings of yarn I cannot resist batting at with my cosmic paws.
  • Flaw. My boundless curiosity and the mere whim to explore the forbidden often lead me to stir chaos in realms both mortal and divine, sometimes unraveling threads better left untouched.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in History or Religion gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they take the Study action to examine the Thing with the Writhing Tail, learning the following based on their result:

(20+) Eldritch Aberration. You are aware of its Truesight and Telepathy, its Immunities, and its Epic Resistance. You also know this eldritch entity is beyond life and death and can reform years later if killed.

(25+) Fear and Madness. You learn of its Purring Aura, as well as its spellcasting Epic Actions.

(30+) Brilliant and Nimble. You know the Thing with the Writhing Tail's highest and lowest ability scores and saving throws.

Combat Tactics

In battle, the Thing with the Writhing Tail uses Manifest Duplicate to create numerous copies of itself. It teleports and swaps places with its duplicates as its rends its foes apart. The many duplicates vastly expand the range of its Purring Aura, sowing terror and madness in any who try to oppose them.

The Thing with the Writhing Tail may grow suddenly bored in the middle of combat, deciding to inexplicably flee or change tactics to a new fixation. Other times, it plays cat and mouse with its foes, toying with them like living balls of yarn.

The Whispered Promise.name: The Whispered Promise
The Whispered Promise.text:
T he The Whispered Promise is a demonic entity who appears before mortals of great potential, offering to fulfill their every ambition and desire. It is a mind-reader and shapeshifter, who appears before mortals as their own reflections, but in a grand and idealized form. In this way, The Whispered Promise preys upon their insecurities and dreams simultaneously, showing mortals both their grand potential and many shortcomings through contrast. To those rare few who do not feel ambition or self-doubt, The Whispered Promise appears to be a writhing bundle of hairs.

The Whispered Promise preys upon hopes, dreams, and ambitions, seeking to manipulate and seduce mortals into their web of schemes, and ultimately, make countless powerful mortals utterly indebted to the demon lord. Perhaps The Whispered Promise stands behind the great heroes and villains of history, having spurred their ambitions and supercharged their desires. In particular, the Sorcerer-Kings of the Arcane Empire sought out The Whispered Promise and made countless bargains with the demon to advance their wealth and power. Summoning circles and magic items found within their ancient ruins still allow mortals to contact The Whispered Promise. There are even some tieflings who claim that The Whispered Promise is a distant ancestor through fiendish pacts made in those days. It is unknown whether The Whispered Promise had any influence in ultimately engineering the fall of the Sorcerer-Kings.

There is little The Whispered Promise cannot offer. Knowledge and information are their most common currency: teaching mortals forgotten magic and sharing deeply kept secrets.

They have dealt in magical artifacts, granting mortals powerful magical items, or simply vast amounts of material wealth. The Whispered Promise also enjoys helping mortals undo a past mistake, solve a guilty conscience, get revenge on a hated enemy, or seize the reins of power for themselves. In exchange, The Whispered Promise seeks to extract a promise of future service from the mortal — a promise for a promise. While they try to keep the terms of this service as open-ended as possible, they reassure mortals they will never ask them to do any direct harm to their friends or loved ones, nor perform any task beyond their own capability to fulfill. In this way, they build a web of interactions and debts, trading services for services. The Whispered Promise plots to use their collected debts to fulfill their future bargains.

While an expert in the desires of others, determining The Whispered Promise's motives prove vexing. The Whispered Promise does not lie, and they seldom reveal their full intentions. They seemingly wish to construct a tapestry of promises, never making one of their own, but brokering the promises of others. A broken promise is a broken thread, pushing the entity to always keep their promises. Yet within this web of desire, The Whispered Promise is always at the center.

Roleplaying Traits

Capable of sustaining multiple separate telepathic conversations at once, The Whispered Promise addresses each character individually. They show images of the characters' desires and dreams, depicting them with outrageous fortunes and with immense power.

  • Personality Trait. I whisper softly in mortal's ears… What do you yearn for? I have no interest in using it against you…only in making it a reality. Indulge yourself for a change…
  • Ideal. I want one thing, and one thing only…to provide you the thing you want most. Ask me, and I'll give it to you. What can I give you that you truly desire?
  • Bond. If there's ever a stranger you can trust, it's me. Any deal we made would be signed and sealed. Other demons may utter lies, but I whisper promises…and I keep my promises.
  • Flaw. Are you certain you would deny me? I dislike being turned down…why wait for what you deserve? If you change your mind…you need only whisper…and I'll be there…

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Arcana or History gain Advantage on Intelligence (Religion) checks when they take the Study action to examine The Whispered Promise, learning the following based on the result:

(20+) Demonic Power. You are aware of its Truesight and Telepathy, its Immunities, and Epic Resistance. You also know this eldritch entity is beyond life and death and can reform years later if killed.

(25+) Enraptured Presence. You are aware of the creature's Alluring Aura trait.

(30+) Powerful Presence. You know The Whispered Promise's highest and lowest ability scores and saving throws.

Combat Tactics

The Whispered Promise regards battle as a physical expression of their ability to control others. It uses Alluring Aura to prevent attacks and they negate resistances to its psychic onslaught by grappling with its Unravelling Resolve trait. They sow discord using @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.5OGFdJw35QXp6mh6]{Mass Suggestion}, @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.eEpy1ONlXumKS1mp]{Dominate Monster}, and their Dominate power, revealing in the resentment, jealousy, disdain, envy, and anger its foes have towards one another.

Fluid: Monster Blood.

Organs: Heart.

Natural Weapons: Teeth, Claws.

Hide: Skin.

Rat God.name: Rat God
Rat God.text:
T his This demonic figure is revered by the ratlings that inhabit Drakkenheim. Often dismissed by adventurers and scholars as a fantasy conjured up in the minds of the superstitious ratlings, the Rat God appears to be a new figure amongst the multitudinous eldritch beings inhabiting the cosmos. In actuality, the Rat God has gnawed on the bones of reality for eons, growing fat and powerful on the remains of slain demon lords, fallen elder entities, and destroyed worlds.

The Rat God has followed the course of delerium throughout the universe, eager for opportunities to feast amidst the chaos the crystals bring in their devastating wake. The arcane anomalies and rampant mutations caused by delerium create the perfect conditions under which the Rat God can enter the Mortal World temporarily and glut itself upon contaminated flesh and magic. Drakkenheim and the world it rests upon has become the latest stop for this wandering interdimensional scavenger.

Acting through its warlocks and oracles, the Rat God has enthralled the ratlings of Drakkenheim, sweeping them into its apocalyptic plan to enter the Mortal World and devour it. Ratlings believe that the Rat God guides them through shadows and whispers, pushing them to grow in size and number so they can one day overtake the world. Indeed, the Rat God does send visions and messages to favored ratlings, encouraging them to breed and consume—a chittering throng is needed to conduct the Great Gnaw, the summoning spell to bring the Rat God out of the abyss and into the Material Plane. The Rat God makes pacts with ratlings who demonstrate a curiosity and aptitude for magic, especially those who foster a feverous worship towards the arcane arts, knowing that there must be talented ratling spellcasters to carry out the Great Gnaw.

Meanwhile, the Rat God is not without its foes. The Thing with the Writhing Tail has hunted the Rat God throughout the cosmos, eager to itself consume the gluttonous Rat God. The two entities have played a great eldritch game of cat-and-mouse for countless mortal lifetimes.

Roleplaying Traits

The Rat God has destructive and apocalyptic motivations.

  • Personality Traits. You seem hungry. Are you hungry?
  • Ideal. Eat or be eaten. That is the way of things. Eat! Eat! Eat! It is all food when you need to survive!
  • Bond. What you have is not enough. If you kill and eat them all. What was theirs is now yours!
  • Flaw. Why does your friend get to have nicer things than you? Don't you deserve them instead? Betray them! Eat them! Make it yours!

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Arcana or History gain Advantage on Intelligence (Religion) checks when they take the Study action to examine the Rat God, learning the following based on the result:

(20+) Fiendish Power. You are aware of its Truesight and telepathy, its Resistances and Immunities, and its Epic Resistance. You also know this Rat God is beyond life and death and can reform years later if killed

(25+) Cloud of Rats. You are aware of the creature's Verminous Aura trait.

(30+) Powerful Presence. You know Rat God's highest and lowest ability scores and saving throws.

Combat Tactics

The Rat God is a being of pure malice and appetite. It cares not for the whims of mortals, only for pure destruction and the chattering and gnawing of infinite rats as they devour the cosmos. It finds joy only in annihilation, and the screams of mortals as they are reduced to bone by the Rat God's writhing swarm.

The Rat God can use its Rodent Rift to move to where it can catch as many targets as possible in its Verminous Aura, then set them ablaze with its Flail of Skulls. It will target the weakest characters with its Warp Bolt, and the least intelligent with its Infernal Chittering. It performs a Great Feeding to replenish itself and uses Rodent Rifts to escape a dangerous situation.

Entropic Flame.name: Entropic Flame
Entropic Flame.text:
The fires from the day Drakkenheim was destroyed never truly died. Many became Entropic Flames — Contaminated Fire Elementals that travel the ruins like living embers. Countless can be found wandering the areas around the Crater and southern Drakkenheim. The Followers of the Falling Fire view Entropic Flames almost like fallen angels, symbols of the meteor itself.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Nature gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they Study an Entropic Flame, learning the following based on their result:

(10+) Supernaturally Resilient. You are aware of the creatures Immunities.

(15+) Inextinguishable Fires. You learn of the elementals Dancing Flame action and Flickerjump Bonus Action, as well as its Enduring Flame trait.

(20+) Swift and Senseless. You know the creatures strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.

Combat Tactics

An Entropic Flame is a haughty combatant driven by a burning desire to set the world on fire. It teleports from place to place using its Flickerjump, setting alight creatures and objects using its Dancing Flames. If possible, it tries to remain close to Burning targets to keep them on fire within its Enduring Flame aura.

Within the smoking ruins of Drakkenheim, Entropic Flames love to set buildings, furniture, and other objects on fire. They quickly turn the battlefield into a roiling inferno, one which cannot be extinguished easily thanks to their presence.

Harvestable Components (Rare)

Animus: Elemental.

Fluid: Contaminated Ichor.

Dust: Elemental Dust.

The Algorithm.name: The Algorithm
The Algorithm.text:
T he The calculating entity known only as The Algorithm is a massive being made up of constantly reforming and phasing technology. Their form is a mass of wires, tubes, metal, and electricity that constantly shifts and transforms. It creates tendrils and limbs as needed to manipulate elements around it and constantly hums and buzzes with electronic melodies.

Very little is known of The Algorithm's origins or purpose. Speculation suggests it is obsessed with perfection and expectation; it deems the universe and all its planes a broken and imperfect thing in need of repair and reform.

The Algorithm is the master of calculations and realities. It can predict and evaluate every possible outcome to a course of action within an instant, and has the ability to shift and manipulate time and space to allow its most favorable outcome. If any goal can be surmised from such an unknown being, it is that it sees mortals, and most life-forms and planets as broken objects needing to bend to its whims of expectations and perfections. Anything The Algorithm deems undesirable it will adjust accordingly.

The Algorithm has no known origin — perhaps it was never made, but rather came into existence through the chaotic nature of the Space Between Worlds. It is impossible to say how a construct which was never constructed has gained the level of impossible sentience found in The Algorithm, but it is in its very nature a being of pure order, which itself causes mass chaos. It constantly restructures elements of the Space Between Worlds to suit its perfect vision. Entire planets drifting within the void of the Space Between Worlds have been repurposed into mechanical hubs, quantum spheres, time paradoxes, and machine factories. Whatever The Algorithm's intentions or goals are, they are something that could never be understood by a mortal mind. Its constant shifting of realities and obsession with perfection seems to a mortal to be total nonsense, and utter absurdity. But to The Algorithm, all things are planned, and all things are accounted for.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Arcana or History gain Advantage on Intelligence (Religion) checks when they take the Study action to examine The Algorithm, learning the following based on their result:

(20+) Practically Impervious. You learn the Algorithm's Immunities.

(25+) Order and Consequence. You are aware of the creature's Predictive Analytics trait.

(30+) Enduring Intellect. You recognize The Algorithm's highest and lowest ability scores and saving throws.

Roleplaying Traits

The Algorithm is nigh incomprehensible.

  • Personality Trait. “I speak down to mortal creatures, for they cannot begin to comprehend the depth of my knowledge, or the details of the cosmos. They are but simple accidents in a sea of chaos that must be corrected.”
  • Bond. “I am bound to the order of all things, It is my cosmic ordained purpose to bring order to the chaos of the universe.”
  • Ideal. “Order out of Chaos is perfection, I willachieve perfection.”
  • Flaw. “No one is as humble as I!”

Combat Tactics

The Algorithm is a creature of order and consequence. It sees all of the Space Between Worlds and every reality as a confusing mass of chaos that must be rearranged and perfected. When The Algorithm encounters mortal creatures, it will attempt to organize them as best suits it using its wires and Algorithmic Manipulation to forcibly move them.

It will convert problematic creatures into obedient androids using its Reprogram ability, and any who threaten it are reduced to atoms using Deatomization.

If The Algorithm has created a cyborg using Reprogram, or if there are extra constructs from previous failed experiments nearby, The Algorithm can assume direct control of them, deatomizating itself and entering the construct to use as a suit of armor.

If the combat becomes too stressful or problematic for The Algorithm, and it is unable to control or organize the situation in a way that benefits it, it may get frustrated and begin Deatomizating everything. If that doesn't work, it flees into the void to find something more easily manipulated to work on.

Harvestable Components (Legendary)

Animus: Construct.

Fluid: Chemical Solution, Elemental Fluid.

Organs: Glands.

Natural Weapons: Tentacles, Blades

Hide: Plates.

Academy Apprentice.name: Academy Apprentice
Academy Apprentice.text: These mages-in-training have completed enough study to cast level 1 arcane spells. The Amethyst Academy often assigns apprentices to higher-ranked mages, where they assist with research, experimentation, and fieldwork. One or more apprentices often accompany a Master Mage.

Academy Mage.name: Academy Mage
Academy Mage.text: These rank-and-file members of the Amethyst Academy can cast spells of up to level 3 or 4. Apprentices qualify for this rank when they can cast at least level 2 spells. Most Academy mages conduct research or craft magic items for the Amethyst Academy, and a handful join survey teams exploring ancient sites or the ruins of Drakkenheim. Others are assigned as court mages for low-ranking nobility. The majority of Academy mages never attain a higher rank than this one.

Master Mage.name: Master Mage
Master Mage.text:
The prestigious rank of Master Mage demonstrates the ability to cast level 5 spells or higher. This is a lifetime accomplishment for the few Academy mages who obtain it, representing decades of study, practice, and research. However, a few especially gifted and adventurous spellcasters have risen to this rank quickly.

Master Mages become instructors, project leaders, and representatives for the Amethyst Academy. They are often assigned to act as Court Mages to high-ranking or influential nobles, such as dukes and countesses.

Academy Grandmaster.name: Academy Grandmaster
Academy Grandmaster.text:
These are powerful spellcasters who can cast level 9 spells. They lead the Amethyst Academy's most important projects and can access almost every resource available within. Only a handful exist: beyond the eight members of the Academy Directorate, there are no more than twenty alive today. In the rare event of a vacancy, the Master Mages may nominate Grandmasters for consideration. Since the Directorate must unanimously choose one to join them, openings can take decades to fill.

Combat Tactics

Their first action is to cast @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.JYuRBwxpoFhXduvD]{Time Stop}, followed by @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.o9ZCvuD2B1OTcubb]{Wall of Force} to trap as many foes as possible. Those who aren't entrapped are blasted with @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.eGMhwmuleAM46C6L]{Prismatic Spray}, @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.QbTxN5dWIbYZ4jLU]{Chain Lightning}, and @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.ztgcdrWPshKRpFd0]{Fireball}. They flee using @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.L4J89JXqbKs6puEV]{Teleport} when Bloodied.

Academy Outcast.name: Academy Outcast
Academy Outcast.text: Not all mageborn are cut out for the rules, regulations, and intense study and practice required by the Amethyst Academy, and some do not make it through their schooling. An outcast may still be under the guidance of the Academy, performing field work or odd jobs that require a more hands-on approach. Oftentimes these outcasts dabble in dangerous magics, and have far less caution, and far too much confidence for the Academy's liking.

River.name: River
River.text:
River is a communications expert and analyst. She aids the Academy's mission using spells such as @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.GtGjNjPBgUHxGYAD]{Sending} and @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.uAwtVZkiSTyP6ORB]{Telepathic Bond} to relay messages between field agents and Academy leadership, gathers information using @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.ppWAAEul0QHtm4er]{Detect Thoughts} and @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.fVbCxFRaORalHB20]{Scrying}, and facilitates transportation of Academy assets from their distant strongholds to Emberwood Village via @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.8aWtP5hcrmcEesBW]{Teleportation Circle}.

Roleplaying Traits

  • Personality Trait. I converse using precise academic terminology, but amongst those I trust as competent and capable, I inject a wry and sardonic sense of humor.
  • Ideal. I like people who are professional, deliver results, and don't ask questions. I cannot stand fools who waste my time with buffoonery, haggling, and excuses.
  • Bond. Eldrick Runeweaver is my mentor, teacher, and friend. I've worked alongside him for years, and any success he has will be mine as well.
  • Flaw. I grew up surrounded by the magical amenities of the Amethyst Academy, so I don't understand what life is like for those who had a more mundane upbringing.

Combat Tactics

River is not a combatant and never initiates violence. If she is attacked or finds herself in the midst of conflict, her sole objective is survival. Her first action is always to cast either @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.A4RsPuSvB9wFtz1j]{Dimension Door} or @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.1N8dDMMgZ1h1YJ3B]{Invisibility} and flee. She won't take risks with her own life, even to fulfill a critical objective for the Amethyst Academy or save someone she cares about. However, she will take the opportunity to help another ally escape by using @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.1N8dDMMgZ1h1YJ3B]{Invisibility} on them or bringing them with her when she teleports.

Eldrick Runeweaver.name: Eldrick Runeweaver
Eldrick Runeweaver.text:
One of the finest professors in the Amethyst Academy, Eldrick Runeweaver has personally instructed a generation of talented arcane spellcasters. He is the foremost living expert on abjuration magic but is also highly regarded within the Academy as a dedicated administrator and calculating leader. If Eldrick Runeweaver successfully retakes the Inscrutable Tower, he will likely take up the vacant spot in the Academy Directorate and assume the mantle of Archmage of Drakkenheim.

Roleplaying Traits

  • Personality Trait. I carefully calculate my every action, and I speak using a few well-chosen words. I'm a teacher at heart, so I often phrase my responses in the form of a pointed question.
  • Ideal. I will seek out more information whenever I encounter an unknown situation or problem. Through reason and logic, the facts always bear out the truth of the matter.
  • Bond. I hold a position of responsibility and authority within the Amethyst Academy, and it is my duty to protect the Academy's interests, carry out its agenda, and keep its many secrets.
  • Flaw. I care deeply for my students but tend to overlook their faults and failures. I've had several wayward apprentices over the years, and I've often had to cover up their mistakes.

Eldrick Runeweaver has a Cat familiar, travels with an @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.h98AuPfomEPcCibP]{Iron Golem} bodyguard, and a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.ZQTCZfTV9ZoTjNCU]{Homunculus} servant. He most often communicates via @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.GtGjNjPBgUHxGYAD]{Sending}, @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.uAwtVZkiSTyP6ORB]{Telepathic Bond}, and @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.ePhRKHXRE7l1sEoQ]{Project Image} spells, or by sending his simulacrum instead. Eldrick has a clone kept in a distant stronghold with extra equipment should the unthinkable occur.

Anomollusk.name: Anomollusk
Anomollusk.text:
W hen When a simple snail latches onto a delerium shard, there is a slight chance it fuses with its shell. These humble creatures can grow to massive proportions if they survive the contamination. Over time, the shells merge with more delerium, mutating the snails into chaotic conduits for erratic magic called an Anomollusk.

Its defensive crystalline shells can also absorb arcane energy. This adaptation disrupts nearby magic, rendering spells and magical weapons unreliable. Attacking an Anomollusk with magic is dangerous, causing wild magic flares and arcane anomalies, giving the creature its name. Driven to consume contaminated flora, Anomollusks inadvertently collect magical energy, making them especially valuable for creating magic items.

Anomollusks are predominantly found in areas like Queen's Park Garden, where the flora is richly imbued with magic. Though sometimes seen in the city's outskirts, they prefer heavily contaminated areas such as around the Crater's Edge. These creatures absorb and occasionally release magical energy from the environment, unleashing sporadic bursts of chaotic magic in the landscape.

In their wake, Anomollusks leave trails of acidic decay - ichors far too toxic even for their bodies to contain for long. Moving with lackadaisical whimsy, they etch eerie patterns into stone and metal, occasionally resembling arcane runes when observed from above. If there is any meaning or purpose behind these markings, none can say for certain.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Animal Handling or Survival gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks to Study an Anomollusk, learning the following based on the result:

(10+) Powerfully Protected. You learn its Resistances as well as its Shell Reflection Reaction.

(15+) Dangerous Slime. You are aware of its Snail Trail and Creep abilities.

(20+) Slow and Simple Minded. You recognize its strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.

Combat Tactics

Drawn to magic, Anomollusk's view spellcasters and those equipped with magic items as delicious morsels. It attacks by first using its Creep action before it tries to Slobber on them. If threatened, it tries to cover the enemy and its territory in acidic slime. If reduced to less than half Hit Points, it attempts to flee.

Harvestable Components (Rare)

Animus: Monstrosity.

Fluid: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor, Goopy Ooze, Acidic Bile, Mucus.

Organs: Eyes, Guts, Glands.

Hide: Shell, Skin.

Living Deep Haze.name: Living Deep Haze
Living Deep Haze.text:
True to their name, these Contaminated Air Elementals lurk within the thickest parts of the Haze, seamlessly blending in with the deadly environment. They exist to spread the contaminating mist and fog through their bodies, and delight in causing mutation and monstrous transformation.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Nature gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they Study a Living Deep Haze, learning the following based on their result:

(10+) Mundane Immunity. You are aware of the elementals Immunities.

(15+) Animate Haze. You know of the creatures Fog Form and Deep Haze traits.

(20+) Fast but Dim-Witted. You understand its strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.

Combat Tactics

When it encounters an uncontaminated creature, the Living Deep Haze rapidly moves into its space thanks to its Fog Form trait. It then tries to remain there as much as possible so the creature is exposed to its Deep Haze trait. The Living Deep Haze wants to transform its targets into monsters, so it uses its Slam attacks to knock them Unconscious so they can awaken to a new existence as mutant horrors.

Harvestable Components (Rare)

Animus: Elemental.

Dust: Elemental Dust.

Pilgrim.name: Pilgrim
Pilgrim.text:
The prophetic words of Lucretia Mathias have inspired hundreds of commonfolk to make their way to Drakkenheim. Their motives and reasons are varied: some seek meaning and purpose in life which they find in the righteous calling of the Testament of the Falling Fire. Others are devout adherents to the Faith of the Sacred Flame who are disillusioned by what they see as the corruption and meddling of the clergy. A few travel to join their friends and family members who have already taken up with the Falling Fire.

Combat Tactics

Untrained and unprepared for combat, most pilgrims can only operate as a mob, using their numbers to overwhelm threats. Faith strengthens their resolve, and their morale holds fast whilst their leaders spurn them to holy purpose.

Zealot.name: Zealot
Zealot.text: Zealots are the warriors of the Falling Fire, sworn to protect pilgrims on their journey to the Sacrament. They accompany expeditions into the city, and act as guards for the strongholds held by the faith. Though still dressed simply, and giving up most possessions, these devoted warriors of the Falling Fire are the ones skilled enough to wield weapons and fend off the monsters and bandits of the city.

Missionary.name: Missionary
Missionary.text: These true believers of the Falling Fire's cause travel the continent, spreading the teachings of Lucretia Mathias. They often lead groups of pilgrims to Drakkenheim, where they hope their efforts to spread the word will be rewarded when they take up the Sacrament.

Congregation.name: Congregation
Congregation.text: The Followers of the Falling Fire gather in great throngs filled with fiery passion, lighting their torches and lanterns and taking up whatever they can find as a weapon. When the zealous masses flood the streets, the crowd becomes more than a match for the mightiest warriors.

Sanctified Monk.name: Sanctified Monk
Sanctified Monk.text: Commoners who complete the Sacrament of the Falling Fire are imbued with extraordinary abilities from their great show of devotion. Many become ascetics who reside near the Crater at Saint Selena's Abbey. There they prepare their bodies and minds for the tests of faith yet to come, practicing discipline, faith, and martial arts.

Sanctified Knight.name: Sanctified Knight
Sanctified Knight.text: The Followers of the Falling Fire have attracted a rare few paladins from amongst the Faith of the Sacred Flame to join their cause. Hailed as heroes of their movement, these knights readily embark on the quest to visit the Crater's Edge and become sanctified, then take up positions as mighty defenders of the nascent religious sect.

Sanctified Soul.name: Sanctified Soul
Sanctified Soul.text: Just as paladins of the Sacred Flame have joined the Falling Fire, many Flamekeepers have also converted to the new religion. Occasionally, the process of sanctification awakens a divine connection in an individual with no prior ability. Either way, these powerful conduits for divine magic are among the great leaders of the Followers of the Falling Fire.

Nathaniel Flint.name: Nathaniel Flint
Nathaniel Flint.text:
Nathaniel watches over the Hendrix Farm where Falling Fire pilgrims on their way into Drakkenheim rest or live. He sees to their needs, ensureing the commune is well stocked with bed rolls, firewood, simple food, and any other supplies needed for basic survival. The pilgrimage leader keeps the fires lit, and a bubbling pot of stew available on the communal fire. He is also the guide who brings many into the city to meet with Lucretia, and from time to time brings groups of pilgrims to the Crater's Edge to be sanctified. He takes his job very seriously, believing whole-heartedly in the teachings of Lucretia.

Roleplaying Traits

  • Personality Trait. I speak in a warm and friendly tone, and often use metaphors of light and darkness to make my points. I want all who are in my presence to feel welcome and important.
  • Ideal. Everyone deserves a real chance to see the light for themselves. No matter the darkness they carry, all darkness must flee in the presence of light once one lets it in.
  • Bond. Lucretia Mathias has led these people to something incredible, and the more one speaks to her, and sees her power, the more obvious it is that she is a prophet, and she speaks a truth few can understand. I believe in her more than anyone else in this world and wish only to do right by her teachings.
  • Flaw. I assume the best in people and am willfully ignorant to the harm that could be done by trusting too easily.

Combat Tactics

Nathaniel is not a combatant, and rarely uses his divine powers to harm. However, if he must defend himself, or more likely, protect his pilgrims. Nathaniel uses @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.Opwh2PdX4runSBlm]{Aid} and @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.8dzaICjGy6mTUaUr]{Bless} to bolster his allies, @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.uCud2s4TjMfjiXUb]{Spirit Guardians} to protect himself, and use @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.ztgcdrWPshKRpFd0]{Fireballs} if absolutely necessary to put down his foes.

He will flee as soon as he can and help as many friends as possible do the same.

Lucretia Mathias.name: Lucretia Mathias
Lucretia Mathias.text:
The prophetic founder of the Followers of the Falling Fire was once a prominent Flamekeeper of the Sacred Flame. She was cast out and declared a heretic for her blasphemous insistence in the divinity of delerium.

Roleplaying Traits

  • Personality Trait.I am devout. believe intensely in my faith and will give those seeking me a chance to speak. I care deeply for those who seek me out, bringing my full wisdom and passion to bear.
  • Ideal. The brightest lights shine in the darkest of places. I will find my truth through my commitment to the light. Those who follow me will be spared when the time comes.
  • Bond.The Meteor. I know the meteor is an early coming of the Tarnas comet, symbolizing all I base my faith upon. Only by coming to the Crater and finding yourself within can you be purified and cleansed of all your sins.
  • Flaw. I only reveal the greatest truths I have seen to those I am certain can fully grasp and understand them as I do.

Walking Delerium Geode.name: Walking Delerium Geode
Walking Delerium Geode.text:
More than once has an inattentive prospector confused a rich delerium deposit with a Walking Delerium Geode, only to end up as a red smear on the streets of Drakkenheim. These Contaminated Earth Elementals are found throughout the ruins, and are frustratingly common near especially large deposits of the valuable crystals.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Nature gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they Study a Walking Delerium Geode, learning the following based on their result:

(10+) Dense Delerium. You are aware of the elementals Immunities.

(15+) Pummeled Contamination. Unsurprisingly, hits from this elementals fists cause Contamination.

(20+) Deadly Destruction. You learn of the creatures Death Burst trait, as well as its strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.

Combat Tactics

The Walking Delerium Geode rests in wait unless disturbed by someone trying to harvest its delerium crystals. Once awoken, it hammers targets with its Shard Slam.

Harvestable Components (Rare)

Animus: Elemental.

Fluid: Contaminated Ichor.

Dust: Elemental Dust.

Delerium. True to its name and nature, characters may be able to collect delerium from the remains of the Walking Delerium Geode, though its destruction tends to cause many crystals to shatter and break. Roll [[/r 1d20]] to determine what the characters can find:

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.tables.RollTable.XqX4c2p2HvvTFUNZ rollable]

Royal Assassin.name: Royal Assassin
Royal Assassin.text:
The Queen of Thieves keeps these elite killers on retainer. Agents of death, Royal Assassins are ready to eliminate anyone the Queen of Thieves has deemed a problem. She often keeps one or two nearby at all times as her most trusted guard. However, even the Royal Assassins are kept at arm's length due to her untrusting nature.

Combat Tactics

The Royal Assassins have a selection of potent poisons applied to their weaponry. They carefully prepare and select each dose for their intended targets. They use Silent Scream against spellcasters or when absolute quiet is needed, Sap Strength against warriors likely to put up stiff resistance of their own, and Sluggish Sinews against agile targets who may try to escape.

Eldritch Trickster.name: Eldritch Trickster
Eldritch Trickster.text: The Queen's Men have attracted a handful of renegade mages, undiscovered sorcerous talents, and wicked warlocks. Many are malfeasants who used their magic to commit crimes such as robbery, conspiracy, impersonation, or murder. Now seeking to avoid the clutches of the Amethyst Academy and Silver Order alike, these mages offer their magical talents to the Queen of Thieves in exchange for her protection. Ironically, this often sees them using magic for many more misdeeds.

Blackjack Mel.name: Blackjack Mel
Blackjack Mel.text:
Blackjack Mel is the Queen of Thieves most trusted advisor. That is to say that she doesn't trust him at all, but knows that he is afraid of her, and will do her bidding as long as she pays him more than others. She pays in protection and a good position. No one is more manipulated by the Queen of Thieves' than Blackjack Mel, who handles much of her communications and business deals with the local gangs.

Roleplaying Traits

  • Personality Trait. I can always make a deal with the right angle, I just gotta pitch it the right way. I don't give up when the mark doesn't take the bait, just try something new!
  • Ideal. We're all in this for ourselves. You scratch my back, I'll scratch yours.
  • Bond. Listen, I got some close connections with some powerful people. You wanna meet the Queen of Thieves? Stick with me. We'll go places together. Just uh, watch out you don't piss anyone off, okay?
  • Flaw. I'm a compulsive liar, so what? Yeah, sometimes even I get confused by my own lies, but the truth can always do with a little exaggeration, it makes life more interesting!

Combat Tactics

Blackjack Mel is a coward, a swindler, and a thief. He is often surrounded by Thugs and Assassins who protect him; Mel rarely draws a blade. His overconfidence relies on his company, and he will often only take a stab at someone if they are held down.

Mel's first line of defense is his mouth. He will double-cross, backstab, swindle, and con even his allies to ensure his own survival. He knows a lot of information about a lot of things and will use his well of secrets to bargain for his safety. He is also clever and will usually only divulge half of a fact to save his life, ensuring the other half will be granted once his safety is ensured. He knows very well that information is what keeps him alive, and he isn't about to use up that usefulness.

Mel flees without question at any opportunity if he feels threatened, and often keeps a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.items.Item.rTn4p9nJr4Aq2GPB]{Potion of Invisibility} on his person for just such instances.

Queen of Thieves.name: Queen of Thieves
Queen of Thieves.text:
T he The Queen of Thieves is a scheming mastermind who controls Drakkenheim's underworld. She transformed a hundreds of squabbling outlaws into a criminal empire. However, none know her true identity. She is most infamously encountered as lithe masked woman in swashbuckling attire with a wide-brimmed hat and jeweled rapier. However, she may radically change her appearance, as her mood and circumstances dictate. She typically confirms her identity by revealing a secret or by demonstrating her uncanny ability to alter her appearance.

Roleplaying Traits

  • Personality Trait. “I am never unprepared and have multitudes of contingencies. I casually expose secrets with rakish confidence, and flaunt my ability to be anybody or anywhere.”
  • Ideal. “I relish mind games and manipulating people. Instead of spilling blood, I spill secrets. My enemies are worthless as corpses. When I steal lives, I spend them dearly first.”
  • Bond. “Law is powerless in the chaos of the ruins. As long as anarchy reigns, so shall I.”
  • Flaw. “Anyone who trusts me is a terrible fool. Double-crossing is my nature. I expect everyone to betray me, and I'll relish the opportunity to defeat them when they do.”

Few of the Queen's Men have met her, and even less have been in the Court of Thieves. Most only know that, if you get a Queen of Diamonds card with a note attached, you better do what it says.

Combat Tactics

The Queen of Thieves never fights a battle personally unless she knows she's going to win. If you're running her in combat, she should attempt escape unless you are utterly certain she will defeat your player characters. She does not slay the player characters but should allow them to flee or take them captive. Either way, she mocks them mercilessly for trying to defeat her.

When the Queen of Thieves needs to escape, she uses her Dash and Misdirection Epic Actions, before using @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.tEpDmYZNGc9f5OhJ]{Greater Invisibility}, @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.A4RsPuSvB9wFtz1j]{Dimension Door}, or @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.2IWiZAJtOGDoKjiz]{Gaseous Form} to slip away.

Silver Order Squire.name: Silver Order Squire
Silver Order Squire.text: Squires are the new recruits of the Silver Order. They are often assigned to a paladin for training and although they can perform in combat and go through rigorous training with both sword and bow, they are more often assigned to patch the armor, sharpen the weapons, and tend to the griffons of their paladins.

Silver Order Recruit.name: Silver Order Recruit
Silver Order Recruit.text: Once graduating from the position of squire, a recruit is now a skilled combatant able to take on simple missions of the Silver Order on their own. They often accompany paladins on more important quests, and make up the guards of Silver Order strongholds, and the forward troops in their armies. They no longer tend to the needs of paladins and are now trained to care for their own gear.

Silver Order Paladin.name: Silver Order Paladin
Silver Order Paladin.text: The Knights of the Silver Order are world renowned as the defenders of the Faith of the Sacred Flame. Taking on holy quests and religious missions for the Divine Matriarch, these holy knights have been known to ride griffons into battle, or march forth in force armed with plate mail, swords and shields, and divine magic to bolster their combat prowess. To some, these paladins have a reputation of being divine protectors, noble warriors, and divine symbols of the faith. To others, they are a terrifying and ugly example of the power of the Sacred Flame.

Silver Order Cavalier.name: Silver Order Cavalier
Silver Order Cavalier.text: The cavaliers are the griffon riders of the Silver Order. They are trained in both ground assault and aerial combat. Having reached the rank of paladin, these warriors have chosen to train further in mounted combat. Each cavalier creates a unique bond with a griffon, whom they can summon to them using their divine magic, and often the two are connected for life.

Flamekeeper.name: Flamekeeper
Flamekeeper.text: Every monastery, chapel, cathedral, and shrine to the Sacred Flame is watched over by a Flamekeeper. These white-robed women guided by their faith are known throughout the nations to aid the downtrodden, protect the innocent, and perform religious ceremonies of many types. Occasionally, Flamekeepers will join Silver Order knights on holy expeditions, or as envoys for the Sacred Flame, joining battlefields and wars as protectors, healers, and symbols of the faith.

Eldritch Cataclysm.name: Eldritch Cataclysm
Eldritch Cataclysm.text:
D rakkenheim Drakkenheim was always known for its lousy weather; miserable rainy days were commonplace even before the city was ravaged by the falling stars. Now, the city is frequently wracked by violent and otherworldly weather conditions. The ever-present mists of the Haze occasionally give way to contaminated acid rain, flashing bolts of arcane lightning, and piercing hailstones filled with delerium shards. Most adventurers know its best to avoid venturing into the ruins altogether on such days, but in the erratic conditions of the ruins, the weather can shift dramatically at a moments notice.

During the fiercest octarine thunderstorms, the powerful energies converge into a maelstrom of lesser elemental forces, fusing into a sentient storm known as an Eldritch Cataclysm. Its manifestation is marked by a swirling vortex of dark clouds, debris, and icy shards, all illuminated by the ominous glow of octarine lightning. These raging elementals are driven by pure destructive impulse, and their presence calls forth a host of other Contaminated Elementals to join them in a cacophony of annihilation. @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.123elementalcont#entropic-flame]{Entropic Flames} and @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.123elementalcont#living-deep-haze]{Living Deep Hazes} are readily drawn to Eldritch Cataclysms, but their presence compels even normally docile Contaminated Elementals such as @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.123elementalcont#walking-delerium-geode]{Walking Delerium Geodes} and @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.123elementalcont#animated-delerium-sludge]{Animated Delerium Sludges} to rise up and destroy.

Fascinated by the destructive power of these elemental creatures, mages of the Amethyst Academy have studied these phenomena surrounding the emergence of an Eldritch Cataclysm. Corroborating reports from Hooded Lantern scouts indicate that the locus for these storms appears to be the swirling vortex of raw magical energies which overhang the Crater itself.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Nature or Survival gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they Study an Eldritch Cataclysm, learning the following based on their result:

(15+) Amalgamation of Energies. You learn the cratures Immunities, as well as its Air Form trait.

(20+) An Octarine Storm. You recognize its Chain Lightning, Meteor Strike, Quake, and Icy Bolt actions.

(25+) Exceedingly Resilient. You are aware of its strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.

Combat Tactics

Eldritch Cataclysms rule the skies, and never willingly descend to the ground. Instead, it rains down lightning, meteors, and icy blasts from above. The temperamental nature of these elementals means they delight in attacking with a variety of elements, and seldom use the same action two rounds in a row. They enjoy using their Meteor Strike on targets theyve Frozen with Icy Bolt, and delight in using their Cyclonic Storm to blow away weapons and equipment dropped by targets of their Chain Lightning.

These enraged creatures revel in destruction but have little conception that anything could actually pose a threat to them. When confronted with a foe able to withstand their onslaught, they treat it as a personal affront, and furiously focus their subsequent attacks upon them occasionally to the exclusion of all else. Despite this single-minded strategy, an Eldritch Cataclysm can recognize when a creature is resistant or immune to its elemental attacks and tries to use only the most effective powers against its chosen target.

Harvestable Components (Very Rare)

Animus: Elemental.

Fluid: Contaminated Ichor, Elemental Fluid.

Dust: Elemental Dust.

High Flamekeeper Ophelia Reed.name: High Flamekeeper Ophelia Reed
High Flamekeeper Ophelia Reed.text:
Ophelia Reed is one of the most renowned Flamekeepers in the Silver Order. She has been granted charge overseeing the efforts in Drakkenheim to ensure the Sacred Flame is represented, and the goals of the church and Divine Matriarch are kept during such trying times.

Roleplaying Traits

  • Personality Trait. I attentively listen to others and respond from a place of warmth and kindness.
  • Ideal. I will always seek the right remedy for any ailment or problem, offering my patient guidance to those who ask for it.
  • Bond. I have taken a vow of poverty and devoted my life to the service of the Sacred Flame.
  • Flaw. Darkness is all-consuming once it has taken root. For some, death is the only salvation.

Combat Tactics

Ophelia is a powerful divine figure and is often accompanied by many Silver Order paladins and cavaliers. In combat she often defaults to buffing her allies more so than attacking directly, but will use her spiritual weapon liberally against foes who threaten her. If she can end an encounter using @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.pxpb2eOB6bv4phAf]{Banishment} or @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.15Fa6q1nH27XfbR8]{Dispel Magic}, she will opt for that. Otherwise she relies on @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.8dzaICjGy6mTUaUr]{Bless}, @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.P7mF2MxSuVJwHRRY]{Guidance}, and @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.o8Dh7fblk1d16tnO]{Healing Word} to keep her allies in the fight.

She will flee if her paladin knights demand her to, or if most of them have been slain or she is left alone in a threatening situation.

Knight-Captain Theodore Marshal.name: Knight-Captain Theodore Marshal
Knight-Captain Theodore Marshal.text:
Knight-Captain Theodore Marshal is a decorated veteran of the Silver Order. Hand-picked by the Divine Matriarch to lead their mission to Drakkenheim, the valiant knight possesses a level-headed and clear-eyed faith. He would never ask his soldiers to undertake a task he would not brave himself, and prefers to lead from the front lines.

Roleplaying Traits

  • Personality Trait. Honorable. I treat all matters with great honor and respect, and I standing up for what I believe. I expect others to act similarly, respecting any who match my ideals and honor.
  • Ideal. Tradition. I uphold the traditions of the Sacred Flame and the Silver Order. I take pride in my standing within the Order and the responsibilities that befall my position.
  • Bond. I will willing to lay down my life to reclaim the lost relics in Drakkenheim and sanctify the cathedral. I know that there is no cost too great if it means purging the world of the filth of this blighted city.
  • Flaw. I trust those of my order and faith, and I believe whatever commands come from my superiors. I hestiate to trust those who do not swear to my faith, as there can be no other way that to follow its teachings.

Combat Tactics

Honorable to a fault, Theodore Marshal will always entertain parley and accept surrender, even if he doesn't expect the same from his foes. If it comes to blows, Theodore Marshal charges into battle and strikes hard with his warhammer, setting his enemies alight with @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplSearingSmi]{Searing Smite}. Well aware of the dangers of spellcasters and monsters, he uses call the sacred flame to blind them so he can engage in melee with impunity.

Hooded Lantern Scout.name: Hooded Lantern Scout
Hooded Lantern Scout.text: The forward patrols of the Watch Regiment, scouts are members of the Hooded Lanterns who are not yet ready for the intense field work of the Vanguard, but have proven themselves capable of navigating the ruins and remaining hidden in the streets. They operate as the eyes and ears of the Hooded Lanterns, keeping reports on the monster groups moving through the city. Not only will scouts be on constant patrols within a few blocks of secured Hooded Lantern bases, but also often move ahead of Vanguard Regiments to report any problems ahead of important missions. Scouts use their flare guns to signal issues ahead, calling in the more heavily armed Vanguard to deal with the issue.

Hooded Lantern Trapper.name: Hooded Lantern Trapper
Hooded Lantern Trapper.text: The Hooded Lantern Trapper is one of the field operatives of the Support Regiment. Their job is twofold: they are both a hunter who keeps the Lanterns fed with fresh meats, berries, and foraged goods from the woods outside of Drakkenheim, as well as lays traps and ambushes for special operations inside the city walls. Trappers are well equipped with various tools and alchemical ingredients for building advanced traps for dismantling groups of monsters and helping give the Vanguard Regiments the advantage.

Hooded Lantern Apothecary.name: Hooded Lantern Apothecary
Hooded Lantern Apothecary.text: Apothecaries are trained field medics who support the Hooded Lanterns in battle with helping their wounded stay in the fight, and saving severely injured soldiers, pulling them to safety or administering emergency procedures in the midst of battle. Although an apothecary will rarely move beyond the Support Regiments, they are some of the most renowned and respected Hooded Lanterns. Every field medic has the stories of many Lanterns who would have been dead if it wasn't for their bravery in the face of the horrors of Drakkenheim.

Hooded Lantern Veteran.name: Hooded Lantern Veteran
Hooded Lantern Veteran.text: Rooftop snipers are members of the Vanguard Regiment and are exceptionally skilled at pinpoint accuracy with bows. They tend to stick to high vantage points and are a key part of any Hooded Lantern ambush. Rooftop snipers often travel in a group and will locate their enemies, find multiple vantage points to surround them, and wait for the opportune moment to strike. Often accompanied by scouts and other ground forces, one may suspect they know the number of Hooded Lanterns they are facing, and rarely account for the unseen snipers above them.

Lieutenant Petra &amp; Captain Ansom Lan.name: Lieutenant Petra & Captain Ansom Lang
Lieutenant Petra &amp; Captain Ansom Lan.text:
Petra, the youngest of the two, has spent most of her life training under the Hooded Lanterns. She prides herself on her marksmanship and scavenging, and knows she is looked up to by many of the soldiers. She is a proud and friendly commander who the troops are happy to follow.

Ansom plans to become the Lord Commander once Elias retires. He is a stern commander who leads by example, displaying incredible discipline and unwavering loyalty to his adopted father.

Petra Roleplaying Traits

  • Personality Trait. I see the value in those willing to risk their lives in the ruins. I have great insight and trust in my own judgment of character.
  • Ideal. The right path is often the harder path, but it is always one worth walking.
  • Bond. I was adopted by Elias Drexel, who raised and trained me. I don't want to let him down.
  • Flaw. I am too open and trusting of people who claim to be on the same side as me, and I put a lot of weight in counting on people who I assume are able to handle themselves.

Ansom Roleplaying Traits

  • Personality Trait. I have been in Drakkenheim long enough to know not to trust anyone. I am extremely wary of adventurers, and anyone who might cause problems for the Lanterns.
  • Ideal. I believe that if my sister and I work hard enough, with the right people, that maybe we can change things.
  • Bond. Myself and Petra have had each other's backs since we were children. That will never change.
  • Flaw. I find reasons to not like people, and find reasons to doubt the commitment of the people around me.

Combat Tactics

Petra is a skilled archer and skirmisher. She prefers to keep her foes at range to gain a vantage point over them in combat. She is a cunning scout who is more likely to set up an ambush than attack directly. When pinned down, she tries to move out of melee into a more advantageous position. If she is low on options, she attempts to escape.

Ansom is a skilled swordsman who prefers to engage his foes in melee combat. He typically starts combat from a good vantage point by attacking with his bow and then moving closer to unleash a flurry of sword attacks. He is a confident and aggressive, and has pushed the Hooded Lanterns through many decisive victories over the horrors of Drakkenheim.

Ansom has enough sense to know when a combat encounter is threatening to cost the lives of his unit, and will fall back or retreat if his instincts tell him it is the better move.

Lord Commander Elias Drexel.name: Lord Commander Elias Drexel
Lord Commander Elias Drexel.text:
Elias Drexel was appointed to the office of Lord Commander of Westemär before the fall of Drakkenheim, and was outside the city leading training drills when the meteor fell. Afterwards, he took part in three military expeditions to reclaim Drakkenheim, and saw firsthand the city's horrors. When the expeditions failed and the nation fell into civil war, Elias Drexel found himself caught between mixed allegiances. He is haunted by the ghosts of his past mistakes and those who died under his command, and believes that his redemption will come only when Drakkenheim is reclaimed.

Roleplaying Traits

  • Personality Trait. I have great responsibilities and have no time for senseless humor. I never cease to worry about our struggling militia's desperate task to reclaim these monster infested ruins. I have no patience for anything or anyone who doesn't further the Hooded Lanterns objectives.
  • Ideal. Loyalty and trust are priceless. It must be carefully given, but staunchly held. There is nothing worse than betrayal and treason.
  • Bond. During the Civil War, I switched sides and killed several scions of House von Kessel who could have claimed the throne. I once believed it was for the right cause, but now I feel personally responsible for breaking the royal line. My mission in Drakkenheim is penance and redemption.
  • Flaw. I'm filled with rage and conflict because of my contradictory actions and beliefs, and I don't take defeat, setbacks, or even missteps lightly.

Combat Tactics

Elias Drexel typically leads several Hooded Lantern Veterans into battle, using his Command action to grant them additional attacks while calling in artillery strikes as often as possible. Drexel himself operates as a skirmisher, switching between melee and ranged attacks to control the flow of battle.

Graffiti.name: Graffiti
Graffiti.text:
O n On September 16, in the year 1,111, at 9:02am, strange graffiti appeared on the front door of the Drakkenheim Gazette. This defacement would prove to be a harbinger of doom, for when the meteor struck that woeful eve, a wave of arcane energy fused the heraldic street art with the spirits of the Gazettes couriers, creating a bizarre creature called the Graffiti.

The graffiti delights in using illusions to change road signs, disguise landmarks, and otherwise confuse travelers. Given its predilection for drama, some suggest that bold travelers with enticing words might win the support of the Graffiti, though none alive have claimed to have succeeded.

They say on rare mornings an arcane anomaly can strike within sight of a Graffiti, conjuring another Graffiti to seek the latest events within Drakkenheim.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Arcana or History gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they take the Study action to examine a Graffiti, learning the following based on the result.

(5+) Reforming Words. You learn of the creatures Regeneration ability.

(10+) Manifesting Visions. You recognize the creatures Summon Public Opinion and Transposition abilities.

(15+) Magical Erasure. You are aware of the creatures Solvent Susceptibility and Antimagic Susceptibility traits.

Combat Tactics

When a creature draws a Graffitis attention, it uses illusions to confuse its targets. It then uses Summon Public Opinion and watches the drama unfold. To keep things interesting, the Graffiti uses its Transposition ability to see how creatures respond to situations when theyre forced to approach them from new perspectives.

When the graffiti is in the heart of the action, it targets the most influential creature with Satire. Should the graffiti decide its target is sufficiently entertaining, or dangerous, it will flee the situation. If the graffiti is reduced to 0 Hit Points, it plays dead and then escapes at the first opportunity.

Harvestable Components (Rare)

Animus: Construct.

Fluid: Chemical Solution, Elemental Fluid.

Dust: Elemental Dust.

Gravekeeper.name: Gravekeeper
Gravekeeper.text:
T he The seeping contamination within the castle formed a deadly octarine sludge that came to rest in the deepest parts of the catacombs below. The unfortunate fate of the royal dead of Drakkenheim was to be lost in the contaminated sludge that now rests as a thick pool in the crypts. The former gravekeepers used to tend to the crypts with illuminated lanterns that lit the way for the dead. They would tend to the crypts and keep them clean. They were sworn to protect the royal dead from graverobbers or any intruders. When the cataclysm of Drakkenheim sent waves of contaminated destruction through the city, the gravekeepers mutated into a mass of limbs and screaming faces, merged with several of the dead that were housed in the crypts, while still clutching their many lanterns.

The mind of the Gravekeeper was warped by contamination and now it acts as a hivemind for the dead in the crypts. The dead now reach from their graves causing the walls and pillars of the Drakkenheim crypts to appear as a mass of undead arms, grasping and groaning. The thick sludge below bubbles and ripples and at times gouts of contaminated goo spray upwards, seemingly on the command of the keeper of the crypt.

Now the creature known as the Gravekeeper drifts silently through the crypts, its control over its domain flowing through every corpse. The creature is still bound to uphold the tasks it held in life; protect the dead from any intruders and tend to the crypts.

Study The Foe

Characters proficient in Religion or History gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they Study the Gravekeeper, learning the following based on their result:

(15+) Hovering Viligence. You are aware of the creatures Truesight and its Epic Resistance.

(20+) Magical Lanterns. You learn of its Lantern Blast.

(25+) Plodding Resilience. You know its strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.

Combat Tactics

The Gravekeeper defends the Monarchal Crypts of Castle Drakken from any trespasser.

Harvestable Components (Very Rare)

Animus: Aberration.

Fluid: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor.

Organs: Eyes, Guts, Flesh.

Hide: Skin.

Dust: Aberrant Dust.

Haze Husk.name: Haze Husk
Haze Husk.text:
T he The Haze reanimates those who died in Drakkenheim to mindlessly wander as zombies. Most Haze Husks are those who perished when the meteor struck, while others died exploring the ruins, remaining near where they fell.

While dead bodies do not decay in the ruins, over time even undead flesh is warped by contamination. Their skeletons slowly crystallizing into delerium, eventually bursting through their skin. When damaged, a Haze Husks unstable crystals often break, releasing contaminated energy and splinted shards.

Haze Husks ignore most contaminated monsters but attack all others. They do not eat their victims, preferring to lie in wait until the dead rise to join them. Left on their own, they rarely travel far from where they died, but if commanded, they will follow more powerful undead, such as @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.132hazewight0000]{Haze Wights} and @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.108arcanewraithh]{Arcane Wraiths}, who recruit them into a sort of militia or retinue.

Reanimated by the Haze

Left undisturbed in the ruins of Drakkenheim, the corpse of a humanoid character of 5th level (or Challenge Rating 5) or lower has a 10 percent chance each day of rising as a Haze Husk.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Arcana gain Advantage on Intelligence (Religion) checks to Study a Haze Husk, learning the following based on their result:

(10+) Unintelligent Undead. You know these creatures are clumsy, relatively weak, and nearly mindless.

(15+) Volatile Shards. You are aware of the Haze Husks Death Burst.

(20+) Made With Delerium. You understand that its possible to create these zombies with delerium and an Create Dead spell (see the @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.131hazehusk00000#creating-haze-husks]{Creating Haze Husks} sidebar).

(25+) Blind to Contamination. Haze Husks seem to ignore contaminated monsters. Perhaps a partially mutated person might avoid a Haze Husks attention.

Combat Tactics

In combat, Haze Husks lunge at the closest target without tactics or concern for self-preservation, battering down doors and clamber over obstacles in pursuit. When commanded by other undead or a spellcaster who created them, they are somewhat more capable, and can be ordered to remain at heel.

A character with one or more Contamination levels and at least one mutation may be able to pass themselves off as a contaminated monster to a Haze Husk. Doing so successfully requires a DC 15 Charisma (Performance or Deception) check, which Charms the Haze Husk for 1 minute.

Harvestable Components (Common)

Animus: Undead.

Fluid: Contaminated Ichor.

Bones: Skull, Spine, Ribs.

Hair: Hair.

Hide: Skin.

Dust: Undead Dust.

Delerium. Characters may be able to collect delerium from the remains of the Haze Husk, though its destruction tends to cause any fragment or chips to shatter and break. Roll [[/r 1d6]] to determine what the characters can find:

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.tables.RollTable.WFbQJUZNgrtRXTqn rollable]

Haze Wight.name: Haze Wight
Haze Wight.text:
M adness Madness awaits those who too often venture into the ruins. Not even the dead are spared, as those who fall here may rise again as Haze Wights. These undead retain a semblance of their former intellect and personality but twisted by delusion, despair, and malice. Imbued with contaminated power, they often raise @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.131hazehusk00000]{Haze Husks} to fight alongside them.

Many Haze Wights believe theye are great heroes rallying the common folk against invaders, but in their madness, they see all humanoids as monsters. Like their Haze Husk minions, Haze Wights generally ignore contaminated monsters and treat them like “fair citizens” of the city. Groups of Haze Wights may act as if they are still a party of explorers, monster hunters, or part of a military expedition. In battle, they launch contaminated energy as if making skillful sword swipes, deft crossbow fire, or streaking magical blasts.

Haze Wights are often encountered in groups including a small retinue of Haze Husks and sometimes even an Arcane Wraith. In their madness, they believe their ability to reanimate Haze Husks is an inspiring battle command, a prayer of healing, or a call for reinforcements.

Reanimated by the Haze

Left undisturbed in the ruins of Drakkenheim, the corpse of a humanoid character of 6th level (or Challenge Rating 6) or higher has a 10 percent chance each day of rising as a Haze Wight.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Arcana gain Advantage on Intelligence (Religion) checks to Study a Haze Wight, learning the following based on their result:

(10+) Delusional Undead. You recognize that these creatures think they are still alive, and that we are the monsters!

(15+) Contaminated Eldritch Power. You are aware of the Haze Wight's Contaminated Blast.

(20+) Awaken Minions. You know of the creature's Animate Haze Husk Bonus Action.

(25+) Made With Delerium. You understand that it's possible to create these zombies with delerium and an @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.oyE5nVppa5mde5gT]{Animate Dead} spell (see the @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.131hazehusk00000#creating-haze-husks]{Creating Haze Husks} sidebar).

Combat Tactics

Haze Wights are intelligent warriors who can engage in melee or ranged combat. However, they mistakenly believe their foes are mindless monsters not requiring careful tactics, seeing most targets as beasts to be put down. When a foe demonstrates unexpected magic or strategy, some fight more carefully, commanding minions to surround and corner their opponents.

Groups of these wights sometimes believe they are still-living, acting as if they still possess their former abilities, using teamwork and 'healing' each other by reanimating the fallen as Haze Husks. Nevertheless, their delusions render them incapable of imagining defeat; they do not flee when wounded, nor when allies fall. Instead, they believe they fight in a heroic last stand, desperately railing against the inevitable doom they already suffered.

Harvestable Components (Uncommon)

Animus: Undead.

Fluid: Contaminated Ichor.

Bones: Skull, Spine, Ribs.

Hair: Hair.

Hide: Skin.

Dust: Undead Dust.

Hazewing Moth Caterpillar.name: Hazewing Moth Caterpillar
Hazewing Moth Caterpillar.text:
The larval form of the Hazewing Moth is a disgusting, hairy, purring caterpillar. Using their strange mandibles, Hazewing Moth Caterpillars are able to slowly feed on and consume delerium crystals by secreting a specially adapted saliva which turns crystalized delerium into sludge, that the caterpillars drink. The caterpillars metabolize this into a dust which coats their wings as adults.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Nature or Survival gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they Study a Hazewing Moth Caterpillar, learning the following based on their result:

(10+) Death Bite. This aberrant caterpillar has a dangerous necrotic bite.

(15+) Crystaline Craving. The caterpillar hungers for delerium crystals, which may divert its attention.

Combat Tactics

A Hazewing Moth Caterpillar is always seeking its next meal and attacks without discretion, wriggling towards the closest target to Bite them. The caterpillars continue to eat and Bite a downed character even in combat if they aren't being actively attacked. While it's happy to consume living flesh, a Hazewing Caterpillar is eager to feed on delerium. Characters may be able to draw its attention or even render it docile by offering it a shard or two and making a successful DC 15 Animal Handling check.

Harvestable Components (Common)

Animus: Aberration.

Fluid: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor, Mucus.

Natural Weapons: Mandibles.

Hide: Carapace.

Dust: Aberrant Dust.

Hazewing Moth Chrysalis.name: Hazewing Moth Chrysalis
Hazewing Moth Chrysalis.text:
Once a @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.133hazewingmoth0]{Hazewing Moth Caterpillar} has eaten its fill of delerium, it finds a secure place to wrap itself in a protective cocoon and begin the process of transforming into an adult.
