Filled with digested crystals, these cocoons magnify the presence of the Haze nearby, creating a potent natural defense for the otherwise immobile and vulnerable creatures.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Nature or Survival gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they Study a Hazewing Moth Chrysalis, learning the following based on their result:

(5+) Protective Chrysalis. You understand the creature's Immunities and its Anchored trait.

(10+) Haze Amplifier. You are aware of its Haze Aura trait.

(15+) Adult Emergence. You learn of the creature's Sudden Emergence Reaction.

Combat Tactics

Immobile and incapable of attacking directly, the chrysalis simply holds fast while using Harden. Note that the Haze Auras of multiple chrysalis do not stack.

Harvestable Components (Common)

Animus: Aberration.

Fluid: Contaminated Ichor, Goopy Fluid.

Hide: Carapace.

Dust: Aberrant Dust

Hazewing Moth Adult.name: Hazewing Moth Adult
Hazewing Moth Adult.text:
Adult Hazewing Moths no longer consume delerium crystals. Instead, they seek out mates and psychic forces to sustain themselves. The moths hypnotize their victims and drink their personalities and memories, gaining nourishment from the psychic forces of their prey. The memories and nightmares of the slain appear on the wings and chrysalis of the next generation of moths.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Nature or Survival gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they Study a Hazewing Moth Adult, learning the following based on their result:

(5+) Vulnerable Flier. You know this flying creature has no special Resistances or Immunities.

(10+) Mesmeric Moth. You learn of the creature's Delerium Dust action and Hypnotic Flutter Bonus Action.

(15+) Intellect Eater. You recognize the moth's deadly Proboscis attack, and its strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.

Combat Tactics

Adult Hazewing Moths are protective of the eggs, caterpillars, and cocoons of others of their kind, and use their abilities to defend the clutch. The moths use their Hypnotic Flutter and Delerium Dust to send their targets into a near catatonic state before they flutter down to drink the target's psychic energy using their Proboscis.

Harvestable Components (Rare)

Animus: Aberration.

Fluid: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor.

Organs: Guts.

Natural Weapons: Mandibles, Needles.

Hide: Carapace.

Dust: Aberrant Dust.

Arcane Wraith.name: Arcane Wraith
Arcane Wraith.text:
A n An Arcane Wraith is the disembodied, corrupt, undead spirit of an arcane spellcaster who perished violently in Drakkenheim. Delerium affects people with magical skill in unpredictable ways. In their death throes, those with mageborn blood may transform into vile undead, eternally bound to the Haze while retaining a portion of their arcane power twisted into malevolent, shadowy forms. Arcane Wraiths relentlessly hunger for both magical essence and life force. They are particularly aggressive towards living spellcasters, but readily attack anyone carrying magic items, spell components, or delerium crystals.

These wraiths are most frequently seen near highly magical areas, like the Inscrutable Tower, however, they have been spotted elsewhere in the Inner City, and rarely, outside the city walls. Places like potion shops and a mage's former residence are also common haunts for an Arcane Wraith.

Left alone, these spirits ponderously study arcane phenomena, often drawing paradoxical conclusions. They collect scrolls, and spellbooks while scribbling rambling notes. Occasionally, their mad research may uncover a genuine revelation, but discerning discovery from delusion amidst their tattered scrawlings is difficult. A careful approach may allow one to converse with these undead. However, their speech is a convoluted mixture of half-remembered incantations, loquacious postulations, and incoherent babbling. They quickly grow frustrated when interlocutors fail to grasp the brilliance of their work.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Arcana gain Advantage on Intelligence (Religion) checks to Study an Arcane Wraith, learning the following based on the result:

(5+) Contaminated Undead. You know the Arcane Wraith's Immunities and Resistances.

(10+) Spellcaster's Spirit. You are aware of its Comet Shards and Nightmare Pattern actions.

(15+) Unstable Intellect. You recognize the monster's strongest ability scores and saving throws.

Combat Tactics

Arcane Wraiths take advantage of their Incorporeal Movement, gliding through walls and small openings, before blasting targets with Comet Shards from above. They use Nightmare Pattern to control foes and focus attacks on those unaffected by the illusion. Occasionally, they collaborate with other undead, such as @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.uzeoZGIO0MULOG8a]{Haze Husks} and @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.wH7qy4fPdtUV6yOG]{Haze Wights}, commanding them like apprentices or minions.

Harvestable Components (Rare)

Animus: Undead.

Fluid: Contaminated Ichor, Ectoplasm.

Dust: Undead Dust.

Items: Arcane Wraiths often have [[/r 1d3]] uncommon potions or spell scrolls collected nearby and may occasionally have a spellbook with [[/r 2d6]] wizard spells of 3rd level and lower scribbled inside.

Hypnotic Eldritch Blossom.name: Hypnotic Eldritch Blossom
Hypnotic Eldritch Blossom.text:
Q ueen Queen 's Park Garden was one of the most visited locations in the city prior to the meteor. Although the park existed since the city's founding, it was Helena von Kessel II, the mother of the late Ulrich IV, who ordered its redesign into the brilliance it grew to be. This redesign added tiered gardens, topiary masterpieces, cobblestone walkways, tranquil streams, and quaint waterfalls. The Queen's Park Gardens included an astounding assortment of flowers, many of which were exotic to Westemär. Even the wooded groves bustled with wildlife and an unrivaled selection of trees and bushes. With the contamination of Drakkenheim, the beauty of the gardens have become horrific feasting grounds for carnivorous plants, sentient trees, and strangling vines, and its flowers are now a constant threat to any who enter.

Hypnotic Eldritch Blossoms are one of many plants warped by mutation. They emit a hallucination-inducing pollen and overflow with contaminated nectar. They are often fatally mistaken for eldritch lilies, a magical plant sought for its contamination resistive properties. These flowers mimick lilies to lure prey close enough to be hypnotized. They often grow in hazardous environments such as near delerium encrusted growths, contaminated water, or delerium sludge. Once entranced by the pollen's influence, creatures move closer to be contaminated until transformed into a monsters.

Apothecaries who have studied the strange blossoms suspect they may be part of a network that “speaks” to delerium in a manner we could never understand. The flowers may be seeking to corrupt the living, changing them into more suitable creatures that can further the spread of contamination.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Survival gain Advantage on Intelligence (Nature) checks to Study a Hypnotic Eldritch Blossom, learning the following based on their result:

(5+) Slow Moving Plant. You're aware of the plants movement, Resistances, and Immunities.

(10+) Enchanted Blossoms. You learn of its Hypnotic Pollen action and Spell Reflection Reaction.

(15+) Tough and Unthinking. You recognize the blossom's strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.

Combat Tactics

These plants typically grow in places protected from easy access, such as a pool of contaminated water, and they weaponize their environment against threats. The blossom attempts to contaminate victims with its nectar and uses the surroundings to amplify the danger of contamination. The flower is not agile enough to escape attacks, and relies on its Hypnotic Pollen to keep itself alive. Hypnotized victims view the flower as an impossibly beautiful object and are lured into any nearby hazards.

Harvestable Components (Common)

Animus: Plant.

Fluid: Contaminated Ichor, Sap.

Organs: Flowers.

Bones: Stem.

Natural Weapons: Spores.

Hair: Leaves.

Dust: Plant Dust.

Kronen.name: Kronen
Kronen.text:
D rakkenheim Drakkenheim s citizens were struck with panic and terror the day the city fell. While many tried to flee amidst the chaos, a few sought safety, barricading themselves in whatever shelter they could find. They hid in cellars, closets, outhouses, tunnels, and other seemingly secure places in a desperate attempt to survive. When the flames died down and the Haze took hold, a few chose to wait out the eerie mists. Who can say if they would have fared better had they attempted escape?

Isolated and alone, most tried surviving on contaminated water and subsisting on vermin creeping into their shelters. These fools did not realize the Haze could permeate their hiding places. Worse, the insects and rodents they consumed began to feed on them. Gradually exposed to contamination, the survivors metamorphosed into loathsome, vermin-like monstrosities befitting their wretched dwellings. Most knew that something had changed but they had little sense for how much time has passed.

Many of these unfortunates remain in their hiding places, confined within nightmarish conditions. Indeed, many are trapped within their shelters due to flooded passages, fallen rubble, or collapsing ruins. When discovered within deep cellars and sealed passages, they respond with panicked and confused violence. Explorers seeking to unearth treasure and lost relics within the city quickly learn to carefully inspect dig sites for hollows or buried chambers where a “Kronen” may dwell.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Nature or Survival gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks to Study a Kronen, learning the following based on their result:

(5+) Infected Vermin. You are aware of the creatures Infestation Reaction.

(10+) Speed and Dread. You learn of the creatures Loathsome Presence action and Scuttle Bonus Action.

(15+) Broken Personality. You understand the creatures strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.

Combat Tactics

A Kronen is usually agitated and alarmed when encountered, and its first instinct in combat is to find a new hiding place or flee deeper into its lair. It uses its Loathsome Presence while clawing at any in the way of its escape using Scuttle, reflexively spreading roaches to attackers via its Infestation Reaction.

If it escapes, a Kronen is eventually drawn to return to its old hiding place. Should characters remain there, the Kronen will furiously attack to reclaim its shelter but wont pursue characters who leave it alone in its hideout.

Harvestable Components (Rare)

Animus: Aberration.

Fluid: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor.

Organs: Eyes, Guts, Flesh.

Natural Weapons: Claws.

Hide: Carapace.

Dust: Aberrant Dust.

Last Memory.name: Last Memory
Last Memory.text:
T hese These disembodied undead were formed the moment the meteor struck Drakkenheim. In a flash, those close to the impact were reduced to ash, but eldritch forces unleashed by the explosion trapped the memories of those it obliterated. Captured forever in that moment as silhouettes, a Last Memory is not a ghost or specter. They are not metaphysically connected to a living creature or its spirit—that creature is gone, annihilated body and soul by the eldritch fires which consumed them. Instead, these undead are pain, suffering, and misery given form in a gruesome instant. These spirits cannot be reasoned with nor spoken to, and cannot be aided or soothed. They are incapable of existing outside the singular event of their destruction, desiring only to force that moment into the minds of others, causing them to experience their anguish over and over again.

Even if the mere physicality of a Last Memory is destroyed, its lingering agony causes them to reappear, their endless torment a gravestone marking one lost to the meteor. Last Memories destroyed in the ruins of Drakkenheim return days later, emerging in a sorrowful chorus of screams that echo through the city.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Arcana gain Advantage on Intelligence (Religion) checks to Study a Last Memory, learning the following based on their result:

(5+) Deathless Memory. You know the creature's monster type, Resistances, and Immunities.

(10+) Painful Recall. You are aware of the creature's Anguish action.

(15+) Weak Undead. You learn the creature's ability scores and saving throws.

Combat Tactics

Last Memories can move along the ground or up walls, often hiding as shadows on the ground. They have even followed prey, appearing as a strange movement in ones peripheral vision, or a shifting shadow from an unknown source.

When they reveal themselves, Lost Memories cry out in anguish, causing those nearby to suffer visions of their last moments, inducing emotional trauma to any who succumb to it. They grasp those nearby, terrorizing them with waves of sorrow. Last Memories seem to embody the raw emotions of their death, using those emotions as weapons against the living. They do not flee, for they do not cherish their existence. Their only purpose is to spread the fear and the pain of their own death before fading away, only to reappear days later to relive their agony.

Harvestable Components (Common)

Animus: Undead.

Fluid: Ectoplasm, Contaminated Ichor.

Dust: Undead Dust.

Living City.name: Living City
Living City.text:
S ome Some say that the greatest threat adventurers and faction agents face in Drakkenheim is the city itself. The unstable magic of the Haze makes navigation through the city streets perilous and disorienting. It often feels like the alleys and buildings are changing position around travelers, as if Drakkenheim were slowly weaving a maze around them. Damaged buildings are filled with rubble, prone to collapse, and the perfect places for monsters to hide in ambush. Dangers and hazards abound from the transformed landscape, and tales are told of structures themselves magically transmuted into strange substances, the stone and wood becoming metals, glass, sand, or even partially made from flesh and bone, as if a twisted artist had sculpted the buildings out of macabre materials.

Just as the Haze has awakened unhinged sentience in the elements and guardian constructs of Drakkenheim, bizarre arcane anomalies occasionally cause the furnishings and buildings of the city to awaken. Eyes, mouths, and even tendrils may appear on surfaces within. Those who brave the interior rooms and halls hear whispers in their minds as the building develops its own personality. On rare occasions, however, the internal composition of objects mutates into a metamorphic goo, imbuing the structure with the ability to change its form and composition in nearly limitless ways. When this occurs to a normal object like a table or chest of drawers, the result is a typical mimic.

A Living City emerges when this happens to an entire building. Also called manor mimics or werehouses, these deadly creatures slowly meander through the city, finding empty plots or taking the place of ruined buildings. Once they find a suitable location, they may quite literally set up shop. Due to their nature, a Living City does not create the appearance of a damaged or ruined structure, so adventurers may be naturally wary of oddly intact buildings they encounter while roaming the ruins.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Nature or Survival gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks to Study a Living City, learning the following based on their result:

(15+) Animated Building. You are aware of the Living Citys Structural Form and No Exit traits, as well as its Immunities.

(20+) Escape Routes. You recognize that destroying the creatures walls and doors creates exits, but these are short-lived because of its Shifting Form Epic Action.

(25+) Slow, Smart, and Tough. You learn of the Living Citys strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.

Combat Tactics

A Living City takes the form of an oddly intact residence, workshop, or warehouse using its Structural Form trait, and waits for hapless creatures to wander inside. A Living City may deceive characters into entering it using its telepathy and Haunting Whispers. It suppresses its Digestive Aura and so it can take full advantage of its False Appearance trait.

Typically, a Living City shapes its body to create outer rooms that have walls bordering the edge of the Living Citys space, and inner rooms deep within which do not have walls, ceilings, or floors immediately adjacent to spaces outside the Living City. The Living City will create doors, windows, or even stairs within it so that its prey can easily move from outside, to the outer rooms, and then further inside to the inner rooms. Often, the Living City might place any treasure or valuables it has collected in these inner rooms as bait.

Once a few characters have entered one of its innermost rooms, the Living City attacks and activates its Digestive Aura. When it rolls Initiative, it uses its No Exit trait to close all the doors and windows in its body, trapping characters inside. Then, it attacks them with its Grasping Tendrils, Bite, and Haunting Whispers, while using its Shifting Form Epic Action to slowly change its interior, separating the characters and cutting off their escape routes.

Should the player characters break a hole in one of its walls, the Living City uses its Shifting Form trait to plug the hole. Note that some area-of-effect attacks and spells (such as @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.5SuJewoa1CRWaj1F]{Burning Hands}) can damage or destroy multiple sections of the Living City. However, a Living City can only take damage from one section being destroyed per turn. If characters manage to slip outside the Living City through a breached hole or exit, the Living City may use its Grasping Tendrils to pull them back in. It then tries to quickly seal them inside again with Shifting Form.

Harvestable Components (Very Rare)

Animus: Montrosity.

Fluid: Contaminated Ichor, Goopy Ooze, Acidic Bile.

Organs: Glands.

Loathsome Gag Fly.name: Loathsome Gag Fly
Loathsome Gag Fly.text:
T he The flies grow fat in Drakkenheim. Corpses do not rot, which makes them excellent sources of food for the rats, Garmyr, and bugs of the city. Many bloated corpses are now ripe with large green maggots that feast on the dead contaminated flesh. When these maggots evolve into Loathsome Gag Flies, they buzz around areas of death in the city. Attracted to fresh corpses, or piles of dead bodies, or even following along with a group of @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.131hazehusk00000]{Haze Husks} or @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimHor01.JournalEntryPage.132hazewight0000]{Haze Wights} hoping to munch on bits of their flesh. The city cistern and the old well in Slaughterstone Square is a known hot spot for a large nest of Gag Flies.

The Gag Flies are bloated and overgrown flies whose acidic mucus has now formed a pouch that occupies most of their large thorax. Like all flies, they use this acidic mucus to dissolve possible food and prepare it for eating. Due to their large size, this results in a horrible experience for adventurers wandering past a group of these flies, who all vomit sprays of burning acid onto their prey and buzz down to feed on the burning targets.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Survival gain Advantage on Intelligence (Nature) checks to Study a Loathsome Gag Fly, learning the following based on their result:

(5+) Flying Monstrosity. You know the Gag Flys creature type and speeds.

(10+) Explosive Bile. You learn of the Gag Flys Bloat Burst Reaction.

(15+) Bestial Minded. You recognize the Gag Flys highest and lowest ability scores and saving throws.

Combat Tactics

The Loathsome Gag Fly is a simple-minded creature who wants to feed on flesh and lay larva on the corpses of the dead. It sprays acid on any creature that it sees nearby in an attempt to weaken it. It then lands on them and begins feeding.

Gag Flies usually attack in groups and care very little for the wellbeing of each other. As a matter of fact, when a Gag Fly is killed and explodes in a shower of acid, this usually causes other nearby flies to go into a feeding frenzy on targets sprayed in the gore, as they are drawn to any flesh dissolving in the acids of their mucus.

Harvestable Components (Common)

Animus: Monstrosity.

Fluid: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor, Acidic Bile, Mucus.

Organs: Eyes, Guts, Glands.

Natural Weapons: Mandibles, Needles.

Hide: Carapace.

Lob Frog.name: Lob Frog
Lob Frog.text:
T he The Drann River flows into Drakkenheim from the Kesselwald Forest to the northeast. On some of the especially quiet and warm nights, you could hear the chorus of croaking frogs from within the woods close to the river. These frogs were commonly found there, and large numbers of them would migrate down the Drann River into the northern parts of the city, especially around Kings Gate. Today, the frogs migration continues, but now the contaminated waters of the Drann have caused the amphibians to bloat to horrific size, and also wildly changed their reproductive cycle.

These mutated monsters are now commonplace along the river and make crossing at any point dangerous. Their eggs do not hatch on their own but require a host body to feed on to complete the metamorphosis. For this reason, the frogs weaponize their contaminated eggs, tossing them at passing by adventurers, scouts, and even other contaminated creatures, hence their moniker: “Lob” Frogs.

The Lob Frog produces hundreds of eggs and hedges its bets by throwing them at any creature it finds, hoping that a few of them have the opportunity to gestate into a newborn Lob Frog. Newly formed Lob Frogs always carry a minor element of the host. A Lob Frog formed from a Ratling may have rodent-like ears or whiskers, where one formed from a human may carry the hosts eye color.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Animal Handling gain Advantage on Intelligence (nature) checks to Study a Lob Frog, learning the following based on their result:

(5+) Poisonous Skin. You recognize the Lob Frogs Immunities and Poison Skin trait.

(10+) Hurled Eggs. You are aware of the Lob Frogs Throw Frogspawn action.

(15+) Assured Amphibian. You know the Lob Frogs Strength and Charisma ability scores and saving throws.

Combat Tactics

Lob Frogs are keen to keep their distance from predators and threats, but are constantly on the lookout for hosts for their offspring. They attempt to lob their contaminated eggs at potential threats, hoping to produce more Lob Frogs. If confronted directly, their Poison Skin acts as a defense while they use their Standing Leap to escape unfavorable situations.

If a Lob Frog has at least two or more targets with attached eggs, or if they are reduced below half Hit Points, they leap away to find somewhere safe and wet to hide. They would rather not risk their life, and simply hope to infect as many targets as possible to continue their species.

Harvestable Components (Uncommon)

Animus: Monstrosity.

Fluid: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor, Venom.

Organs: Eyes, Heart, Brain, Guts, Glands, Flesh.

Bones: Skull, Spine, Ribs.

Natural Weapons: Teeth.

Hide: Skin, Webbed Membrane.

Octarine Tree.name: Octarine Tree
Octarine Tree.text:
T The he trees surrounding Drakkenheim for miles in every direction are decrepit and dying things with blackened dead bark, thick knobby roots, and gnarled bare branches. Those traveling the dark roads to Drakkenheim remark how the trees appear like skeletal hands reaching up to the Haze-filled sky. As the trees sway in the wind, even when there is no breeze, the haunting rustling of their dead leaves and creaking boughs sounds like distant whispers.

Yet a few among the foliage carry a hint of life still, soaking up the contaminated rainfall and groundwaters of the toxic Drann River. Their deep roots draw up the delerium in the soil and they are altered in ways that defy understanding. As one approaches the city proper, these trees begin to form strange growths, and crystal fruit in unfathomable colors sprout in abundance upon their twisted branches.

Druids would always say that the trees spoke to them, that the plants and foliage of the land had stories. Now, the forests surrounding the city for miles speak of pain, suffering, anger, and fury. Druids who have come to Drakkenheim have sensed the foreboding of the flora within the city, warning against approaching those strange trees with delerium growths.

These Octarine Trees are terrible to behold, and a tragic sign of the corruption seeping into the earth. They have taken on a life of their own, rising from the soil in a hostile sense of hatred towards the living. They seek to spread their sickness, wailing and hurling contaminated delerium at all who get in their way.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Survival gain Advantage on Intelligence (Nature) checks to Study an Octarine Tree, learning the following based on their check result:

(5+) Resilient Sapling. You learn of the Octarine Trees type, its Resistances, and Immunities.

(10+) Flying Fruit. You are aware of the creatures Delerium Fruit action.

(15+) Combustible Timber. You recognize the creatures vulnerability to fire.

Combat Tactics

The Octarine Tree grows in clusters within Queens Park Garden, or in the forests north of Drakkenheim, but lone trees have been spotted in advantageous positions throughout the city. Whether in market squares or growing on cliff sides

overlooking parts of the city, the trees seem to keep watch over large stretches of road. The Octarine Tree is surprisingly fast when it decides to move but usually opts to root itself in a good position and throw Delerium Fruit at its enemies.

When engaged in melee, an Octarine Tree tangles up creatures in its Crushing Roots and Thwacks them. It will take an opportunity to lumber to a better position and plant itself in the ground to continue hurling fruit if it can.

Harvestable Components (Rare)

Animus: Plant.

Fluid: Contaminated Ichor, Sap.

Organs: Flowers.

Hair: Leaves.

Hide: Bark.

Dust: Plant Dust.

Pyknic Maunder.name: Pyknic Maunder
Pyknic Maunder.text:
E ldritch Eldritch contamination induces chaotic and random mutations that care little for form and function. The changes cause flesh to waste away, exposing raw muscle as skin melts; fingernails, teeth, tongues, and eyes fall out; the lips rot and fester; and the bones turn to jelly. Eventually, the cascading mutations result in total dissolution into a roiling mass of mutated flesh, flailing limbs, and disparate sensory organs known as a Pyknic Maunder.

Transformation into such a wretched creature is typical in cases of sudden, rapid, and overwhelming exposure to contamination. This was a common fate of those just outside the immediate blast of the falling stars who avoided vaporization but were instead exposed to the full brunt of contaminated magic. However, maunders can also be created when people or animals are exposed to intense contamination from Arcane Anomalies, powerful contaminated spells, or are gravely wounded by delerium-infused weaponry. In particular, this may occur when multiple delerium-tipped arrowheads or bolts become imbedded deep into the body. In at least one documented case, a foolish adventurer who tried ingesting a delerium shard quickly mutated into a maunder. Rumors speak of maunders also being created from experimenting with delerium or trying to develop contaminated spells.

Maunders live out a pathetic and confused existence, grasping their way throughout Drakkenheim; they are found everywhere in the city. The creatures attack everything they encounter, including other maunders, absorbing more flesh and matter from their kills. A maunder that grows too large eventually collapses upon itself, and several smaller maunders emerge from the remains to shuffle through the ruins. On rare occasions, these maunders collect and form into a Protean Abomination, a much larger version capable of maintaining its form.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Nature or Survival gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks to Study a Pyknic Maunder, learning the following based on their result:

(5+) Always Upright. You recognize that this undulating mass cant be knocked Prone.

(10+) Mind Numbing. You recognize the creatures Bite and Babble actions.

(15+) Practically Mindless. You are aware of its strongest and weakest saving throws.

Combat Tactics

A maunder has no sense for combat tactics and exists only to eat whatever it can get within the grasp of its many hands. Once it has hold of a creature, it immediately begins to feed using its Bite. A Pyknic Maunder will attack an unconscious or downed character, uncaring about other attackers.

Harvestable Components (Uncommon)

Animus: Aberration.

Fluid: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor.

Organs: Eyes, Heart, Guts, Flesh.

Natural Weapons: Claws, Teeth.

Hide: Skin.

Dust: Aberrant Dust.

Reality Cyst.name: Reality Cyst
Reality Cyst.text:
T he The presence of delerium has caused Drakkenheim to become an epicenter for planar rifts. Commonly known as Thin Places, these tears in reality allow creatures to pass between dimensions and cause the magical qualities which define the linked plane to slowly seep into and change the Mortal World. Outside the ruins of Drakkenheim, most Thin Places are connected to the Faerie Otherworlds or the Shadowlands, but within the city, the Haze is especially prone to create pathways into the Space between Worlds.

This roiling realm of chaotic pandemonium and impossible reality floods the Mortal World with Arcane Anomalies and unfathomable horrors. When rifts to the Space Between Worlds appear in Drakkenheim, it sends a rippling magic outwards from its center, affecting all creatures, plants, and even stone and wood. Thin Places in Drakkenheim are like wounds in reality, and as the wound remains, it begins to fester and infect. Like a disease, the infection begins to cause growths and cancers to form in the area around it. The Reality Cyst is one of these cancerous growths.

Those who have glimpsed a Reality Cyst have seen them vanish from sight a moment later. There are reports of adventurers lost in the ruins for days trying to navigate a city street that become completely alien and unfamiliar, only to be found by another scouting party standing perfectly still in a daze. It seems those who are affected by the Reality Cyst enter a sort of trance. They are unable to perceive the Reality Cyst and instead find themselves in a confused landscape with the very fabric of reality shifting and altering forms. Colors beyond perception bleed from walls, objects appear and disappear at random, nonsensical angles and shapes form and alter before their eyes. People might believe they are moving in one direction and find themselves moving in a completely different direction. Gravity, time, space, logic, and all other concepts are skewed and broken.

For those who have glimpsed through the veil of a Thin Place, and caught that unhinged reality of the Space Be

tween Worlds, the state of order in the bending existence of a Reality Cyst seems strangely familiar. Its wrongness, although completely unfathomable, seems to echo the confused state of the Space Between Worlds. Those who encounter a Reality Cyst and escape Drakkenheims walls have bordered on madness. At best they suffer severe headaches for weeks afterwards. A mind can only handle so much when the reality you interact with pushes up against the rules and concepts of your own comprehension.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Arcana gain Advantage on Intelligence (Nature) checks to Study a Reality Cyst, learning the following based on their result:

(5+) Unmoving Aberration. You learn the Reality Cysts creature type and speed.

(10+) Draining Rejuvenation. You are aware of the creatures Feed Bonus Action.

(15+) Anomalous Influence. You recognize the cysts ability scores and saving throws.

Combat Tactics

The Reality Cyst is less of a hunter than it is a disease. It feeds off the confusion of creatures trapped in its illusions. It mimics the bending realities of the Space Between Worlds and mirrors that into the minds of those who are close to it. After their target enters a trance, it drinks their mental energy and grows.

The Reality Cyst does only one thing: it feeds. It cannot move or defend itself well against attacks. It relies on creatures succumbing to its Unhinged Reality trait and devouring their minds. Once discovered, there is little the cyst can do to survive.

Harvestable Components (Uncommon)

Animus: Aberration.

Fluid: Contaminated Ichor, Mucus.

Organs: Glands.

Hide: Skin.

Dust: Aberrant Dust.

Sewer Thing.name: Sewer Thing
Sewer Thing.text:
N o No one knows how the Sewer Thing came to be. Some speculate its a person who drowned in the sewers before contamination took their form and merged with the raw sewage around them. Others suggest the creature is contamination, turning plants and debris into horrific monsters. Regardless, enough stories have spoken of avoiding the sewers for most to steer clear of those areas.

The Sewer Thing hunts in the sewers of Drakkenheim, absorbing anything that gets in its path. It is an unseen killer using its tendrils to pull victims into the sewage to be absorbed and causes others nearby to retch and vomit. It is depicted as a legend in the scrawlings of aquatic Dregs who call the sewers home. The Dregs and Ratlings speak of the terrible thing that feeds on their people. Ratlings use the Sewer Thing as a cautionary tale for their young, telling them not to travel alone and to run when water churns.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Survival gains Advantage on Intelligence (Nature) checks to Study a Sewer Thing, learning the following based on their result:

(5+) Resilient Plant. You know its creature type, Resistances, and Immunities

(10+) Poisonous Engulfer. You learn of the creatures Poison Absorption and Engulf features.

(15+) Sense of Self. You understand the creatures Wisdom and Charisma ability scores and saving throws.

Combat Tactics

The Sewer Thing waits for the opportune moment to strike. It lets creatures approach, appearing as plant matter over some sewer debris. Once its prey is close, it springs to life, lashing out with its tendrils at any it has surprised, attempting to Engulf

them. This tactic works well if it is in water or sewage, where it can pull victims beneath the surface.

The Sewer Thing starts combat attempting to Engulf surprised targets. Once a creature is Engulfed, the Sewer Thing retreats into the sewer water and flees. It is a hunter, consuming its prey by dissolving them inside of it. Once it has its food, it has no reason to stay and fight.

Harvestable Components (Rare)

Animus: Plant.

Fluid: Contaminated Ichor, Goopy Ooze, Venom, Sap.

Organs: Flowers, Flesh.

Natural Weapons: Tentacles.

Hair: Leaves.

Dust: Plant Dust.

Beetle Knight.name: Beetle Knight
Beetle Knight.text:
B eetle Beetle Knights represent the mutations found within even the smallest creatures in the aftermath of the meteor's strike. Insects that once crawled up from the soil, out of wall cracks, or from between floor boards have been transformed by contact with delerium and exposure to the Haze. Many have grown monstrously, to humanoid size or even larger.

Beetle Knight shells are thick enough to protect them from most attacks. Their name comes from the way their shells have mutated to resemble plate armor, while scything hands and a massive horn look like a pair of blades and an ornate helm. At a glance, these creatures resemble an armored knight ready for battle.

Beetle Knights commonly hide within the ruins and sewers of Drakkenheim, feeding on Deep Dregs and other smaller creatures. Occasionally, at night, or after heavy rains, Beetle Knights emerge in large numbers, to surprise and overwhelm the unprepared.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Animal Handling or Nature gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks to study a Beetle Knight, revealing the following based on the result:

(5+) Alien and Unflinching. You identify itscondition Immunities.

(10+) Watch Out for that Horn! You recognize its Fling Bonus Action, and Pincer Horn action.

(15+) Slow and Unintelligent. You know its strongest and weakest saving throws.

Combat Tactics

The Beetle Knight is surprisingly agile, rarely standing still in battle. They charge during the first round, flinging enemies aside or attempting to grapple. If possible, they back up to charge again but will otherwise defend with their arm blades. They attempt to flee losing battles where their Hit Points fall below half their maximum.

Harvestable Components (Uncommon)

Animus: Monstrosity.

Fluid: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor.

Organs: Eyes, Guts.

Natural Weapons: Blades, Mandibles.

Hide: Carapace.

Shardmaul Manticore.name: Shardmaul Manticore
Shardmaul Manticore.text:
M anticores Manticores were among the most commonly encountered monsters roaming Drakkenheims hinterlands prior to the meteor strike. A few of the creatures would fly south from their nesting grounds in the Giantfrost Mountains to feast on the plentiful livestock and allegedly hapless travelers. Most folk would be able to tell a second-hand story about a neighbor or acquaintance who lost a prized animal to a manticore, or in more grim tales, a family member. Fortunately, their population was kept largely in check by the City Guard. As such, the only individuals regularly slain by manticores were usually would-be monster hunters looking to make a local name for themselves.

Once Drakkenheim fell and contamination caused people to abandon the towns, villages, and farmsteads near the city, the manticores found less easy prey. Growing bolder and more desperate, a handful of the monsters ventured into the city ruins in search of food and new lairs. The manticores were able to readily prey on the contaminated people and monsters inhabiting the city, but in turn, the corrupt flesh caused the manticores to mutate into fearsome Shardmaul Manticores.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Nature or Survival gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks to Study a Shardmaul Manticore, learning the following based on their result:

(10+) Mutated Manticore. Youre aware the creature has no special Resistances or Immunities but is a capable flier.

(15+) Death From Above. You recognize the manticores Stinger and Wing Shards attacks.

(25+) Strong, Fast, and Tough. You learn the manticores strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.

Combat Tactics

The Shardmaul Manticore attacks from above, choosing whichever target looks weakest and the least armored. It descends from above suddenly, making Bite and Claw attacks against the weakest prey it detects. After its first descent, it lifts off again, using Wing Shards to cover its ascent. It then repeats its attack pattern.

A Shardmaul Manticore is bold enough to attack when outnumbered but typically flees if it faces stiff opposition that reduces it to half its Hit Points or fewer.

Harvestable Components (Rare)

Animus: Monstrosity.

Fluid: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor.

Organs: Eyes, Heart, Brain, Guts, Flesh.

Bones: Skull, Spine, Ribs.

Natural Weapons: Teeth, Claws, Needles.

Hair: Fur.

Hide: Skin, Webbed Membrane.

Delerium: The quills on its body are made of delerium and may be harvestable: [[/r 1d6–2]] delerium fragments can be collected from its quills (minimum 0).

Skin Crawler.name: Skin Crawler
Skin Crawler.text:
O ne One of the more horrible forms of undeath reported from the ruins of Drakkenheim are Skin Crawlers. When a person becomes contaminated in a very short time, mutations occur in such quick succession that their body simply cannot withstand the changes. This abrupt mutation causes the persons organs to liquify and they die vomiting a black bile. Even their bones, eyes, brain, and other internal organs dissolve into a thick black contaminated sludge. They retch until they collapse to the ground as nothing but a sack of dead flesh sitting in a puddle of delerium sludge.

The sack of dead flesh does not stay dead. Horribly contaminated, it awakens in a desperate and starved state. It seeks out living creatures for their meat, hoping to fill itself back up with new flesh and take on a more complete form. The Skin Crawlers have been known to consume an entire creature like a python eating its prey, only once the crawler is filled, it assumes the form of the creature it consumed. There are unpleasant and grotesque signs of the Skin Crawlers guise. A creature consumed and transformed by a Skin Crawler will appear to wear their skin like a loose suit. Their eye sockets will droop, their mouth will be too open, their arms and legs will have loose and sagging skin. They appear almost as the person who was consumed, but with their skin hanging off in odd and disproportionate ways.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Medicine gain Advantage on Intelligence (Religion) checks to Study a Skin Crawler, learning the following based on their result:

(5+) Unrestrained Undead. You recognize the Skin Crawlers creature type, Resistances, and Immunities.

(10+) Squeezing Death. You are aware of its Crush and Consume Bonus Action.

(15+) Deathly Aware. You learn of the Skin Crawlers mental ability scores and saving throws.

Combat Tactics

The Skin Crawler is a mindless creature. It is nothing but animated flesh seeking to consume. If it senses a living creature nearby, it crawls towards it with total disregard for its own life. It only wants to bind the living and squeeze them to death while slowly devouring their flesh, consuming it into itself.

A Skin Crawler is too focused to flee and continues to attempt to devour a target until either it or their target is dead.

Harvestable Components (Uncommon)

Animus: Undead.

Fluid: Contaminated Ichor.

Natural Weapons: Claws.

Hair: Hair.

Hide: Skin.

Dust: Undead Dust.

Skretch.name: Skretch
Skretch.text:
S kretches Skretches are mutated scavengers with features reminiscent of various birds, including vultures, pigeons, and crows. These cowardly opportunists feed on corpses and weakened prey while steering clear of more adept aerial predators inhabiting the ruins. Attracted to the sound of conflict, Skretches patiently circle at great heights until the fight ends, then attack any wounded, dying, or survivors caught off guard.

A Skretchs digestive system is a disgusting mess. It is filled with the partially dissolved remains of its last meal, churning into a contaminated slop inside its bloated belly. Skretches shower their meals—whether corpses or still-living targets—with acidic vomit and expelled waste. This noxious mixture dissolves flesh and bones, turning prey into digestible goop that the Skretch then easily consumes.

These beasts maintain a significant distance from the Harpies residing in the highest spires of Drakkenheim since the more proficient hunters are not averse to killing and consuming Skretches. Skretches typically establish their roosts near the city walls or along the cliffsides of Castle Drakken. The magically animated guardians present near the citys fortifications, such as Wall Gargoyles and Tower Dragons, typically overlook the presence of Skretches. These constructs do not consume their vanquished foes, leaving ample spoils for the Skretches to gorge upon. Some of the bolder Skretches perch atop inanimate constructs, waiting patiently for them to animate and dispatch their next victim—thereby securing a fresh meal with and taking full advantage of the cold efficiency of these guardians.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Survival or Nature gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they Study a Skretch, learning the following based on their result:

(5+) Flying Scavenger. You recognize it may be possible to distract it with meat, offal, or strong-smelling food.

(10+) Acidic Vomit. You learn of the Skretchs Expel Waste and Spittle actions.

(15+) Dextrous and Sturdy. You recognize the creatures strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.

Combat Tactics

Skretches keep to high perches and observe potential prey before attacking. A Skretch prefers to attack targets that are visibly injured, weakened, or otherwise vulnerable.

Once it finds a suitable quarry, a Skretch circles their prey overhead pelting them with Spittle while waiting for their Expel Waste to recharge. Since its attacks require the Skretch to be directly overhead its target, they prefer to keep well above their targets to avoid any projectiles or ranged attacks.

A Skretch never enters close combat willingly. If it is engaged up close, it uses the Disengage action to flee. As lazy scavengers, a Skretch doesnt pursue its prey very far or into buildings and flees if reduced to half its Hit Points or fewer.

Harvestable Components (Uncommon)

Animus: Monstrosity.

Fluid: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor, Acidic Bile.

Organs: Eyes, Heart, Guts, Glands.

Bones: Skull, Spine.

Hair: Feathers.

Hide: Skin.

Undulating Polyp.name: Undulating Polyp
Undulating Polyp.text:
T he The Undulating Polyps did not emerge until after Thin Places began appearing throughout the city of Drakkenheim, which has led some to speculate these creatures are born in the Space Between Worlds. However, elements of their bizarre physiology appear somewhat human. They appear at times as a lump of human skin with a massive blister upon them that wriggles like a worm through the ruins, so others have speculated that these polyps are the product of humanoid creatures who are too heavily contaminated by the thin places and emerge from them as nothing more than a mass of undulating flesh.

Still, the essence of the Space Between Worlds is present in the way the polyps exist within space and time: it is entirely nonsensical and confusing and lacking any known laws of such things. Instead, the Undulating Polyps seem to transcend physical space in a manner that makes them quite difficult to pin down. They displace themselves constantly within an area, appearing in multiple places nearly at the same time, or teleporting from one location to another constantly. It is as if they exist in an almost constant state of flux. Their acidic mucus-filled growths allow them to spray acid bile onto anything it deems a threat as it not only teleports itself, but anyone who harms it to a more advantageous position.

These creatures wants and needs are completely unknown. Like much that emerges from Thin Places, or many of the mutated horrors of the city, the mystery of the Undulating Polyp continues to baffle apothecaries and Academy mages. It seems content to wriggle through the city, dissolving creatures it comes across and multiplying through a form of mitosis, splitting itself into more Undulating Polyps as it endlessly grows.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Nature gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks to Study an Undulating Polyp, learning the following based on their result:

(5+) Resistant Aberration. You learn of the Undulating Polyps creature type, Resistances, and Immunities.

(10+) Teleporting Terror. You are aware of the polyps Slip Space action and Confused Realities Reaction.

(15+) Pointed Vulnerability. You recognize the polyps Vulnerability to Piercing damage.

Combat Tactics

Undultating Polyps are quite adept at staying away from predators. They use their various methods of teleportation to avoid dangers and move to a better position. The polyp constantly showers the battlefield in acidic slime as another method of protecting itself.

Undulating Polyps are not combatants and will do their best to escape combat if they feel threatened.

Harvestable Components (Rare)

Animus: Aberration.

Fluid: Contaminated Ichor, Goopy Ooze, Acidic Bile, Mucus.

Natural Weapons: Mandibles.

Hide: Skin.

Dust: Aberrant Dust.

Warp Witch.name: Warp Witch
Warp Witch.text:
T he The Faith of the Sacred Flame says the souls of the departed gently pass from the Mortal World into the Shadowlands, where they wander until they find their final fate. Although their ultimate destination is a mystery, it is well understood that the Shadowlands are a dark reflection of the Material Plane. As such, occasionally wayward spirits slip back into the Mortal World near the places they died, where they typically manifest as incorporeal undead such as ghosts and wraiths.

However, the eldritch energies of the Haze weaken and disrupt the metaphysical fabrics that separate the planes. This wild magic conjures extraplanar energies and creatures into the ruins and has a particularly insidious interaction with the Shadowlands. The forces that draw the souls of the dead into the Material Plane are greatly magnified. Worse, the eldritch contamination corrupts the soul, fragments the mind, and distorts personalities, transforming these spirits into Warp Witches. Grasping for any memory of their former identities, the vengeful spirits of those whose lives were stolen by the Haze haunt the ruins of Drakkenheim. Their hatred and envy for the living manifests in a powerful compulsion to transform others into monsters.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Arcana gain Advantage on Intelligence (Religion) checks to Study a Warp Witch, learning the following based on their result:

(5+) Resistant Undead. You learn of the Warp Witchs Resistances and Immunities.

(10+) Mutative Control. You recongize the creatures Possession action and Mutate Host Bonus Action, but not the means to end the possession.

(15+) Escaping Possession. You are aware that the Warp Witchs Possession can be ended by reducing the possessed body to 0 Hit Points, or by casting Dispel Evil and Good.

Combat Tactics

A Warp Witch begins combat by using its Psychic Scream. The witch then selects a target amongst their foes to possess.

While possessing a host, the Warp Witch will try to use the body to deceive or trick allies of its host into not attacking or harming them, trying to suggest useless, ineffective, and half-mad courses of action to “help” the host “drive out” the spirit, such whistling, dancing, clapping, singing, drawing pictures, and other bizarre commands. Meanwhile, the witch continues to use Mutate Host to contaminate them. The Warp Witch leaves the host after they undergo a Monstrous Transformation, and then moves to repeat the process with another.

Harvestable Components (Uncommon)

Animus: Undead.

Fluid: Ectoplasm.

Hair: Hair.

Dust: Undead Dust.

The World Ender.name: The World Ender
The World Ender.text:
A colossal delerium crystal rests at the center of the Crater. This “Delerium Heart” is a piece of a distant unknown world utterly consumed and destroyed by the Haze. It is the largest source of the contamination spreading out from Drakkenheim. If there is any hope for stopping the slow progression of the Haze, it must begin with the destruction of the Delerium Heart. Characters mighty or foolish enough to accomplish this monumental task alone will not end the contamination of Drakkenheim, but instead unleash a destructive horror unlike anything the earth has ever known: The World Ender.

No two individuals who bear witness to the emergence of The World Ender can describe its arrival in the same terms. One hero perceives it breaking free of the Delerium Heart like a creature hatching from a great egg; another describes it suddenly appearing from the mist in a flash of thunder and lightning; while a third sees a small creature nearby haplessly mutate into a colossal being when exposed to the powerful forces released upon the destruction of the Delerium Heart.

The World Ender is only one possible moniker for this titanic engine of destruction. The Apocalypse, The World Eater, The Harbinger, Death, The Annihilator, The Last Nightmare, The Wrath of Gods, and The Chosen One are all other titles it may wear. It is unclear if the creature is a singular entity, or one of many which have appeared in the death throes of the countless worlds consumed by the Haze.

The World Ender cannot be reasoned with, bargained with, or understood; its origins and purposes remain shrouded in mystery — it simply is. The complexities of human civilization — the sprawling cities, political conflicts, bloody wars, and the rise and fall of monarchs, mages, heroes, and priests — are utterly meaningless before it. Once freed, it tramples cities without awareness or concern, obliterating armies and toppling nations with the same dispassionate ease with which natural forces reshape landscapes. Indeed, The World Enders rampage is more akin to an unfathomable natural disaster, blind to the devastation it wreaks.

Efforts to understand or influence it are as futile as ants trying to comprehend a river that threatens to wash them away. In the face of such power, humanity is left scrambling for survival. Mortals become painfully aware that in the grand scheme of things, our existence might be as transient as raindrops in a storm, unnoticed by the forces that alter our world.

Desperate Speculation

Once unleashed, The World Ender becomes the subject of endless speculation and rumor. Even if the characters manage to defeat it promptly, explanations about its origins and nature abound, though none are conclusive or supported by concrete evidence. Various factions, including the mages of the Amethyst Academy, warriors of the Hooded Lanterns, resolute Flamekeepers, devout Silver Order paladins, worshippers of the Falling Fire, and even the bandits of the Queens Men, all propose their own theories, which are often quickly disproven or contradicted by new information. The reality is that any true understanding of the creatures intentions, purpose, or origins remains elusive, with knowledge about its completely alien motives being particularly scarce. Here are just a few of the tales told about it:

Horror from Beyond the Stars

The mages of the Amethyst Academy have long researched delerium, and discoveries in the Crater enable them to paint a full picture about the origin of the stones. When delerium is left uncontained in massive quantities, it is possible it can slowly grow and seep into the heart of an entire planet, eventually rotting the core. The entire surface becomes a wasteland of octarine crystals as big as buildings, with a Haze-covered sky of eldritch storm clouds that blacks out the sun. Under these conditions, contamination runs rampant and no lifeform on the surface is free from endless mutation. As the planet festers and mutates to the point of destruction, the Haze and delerium cause all manner of abominations to grow and change. Given the hundreds of years it takes for delerium to infect an entire planet, the mutated monstrosities have ample time to grow to massive proportions. This creature is but the first of many which could be created if the Academy is not able to contain and control delerium.

Eventually however, the delerium begins to expand at an increased rate, and some of these creatures end up encased in the eldritch crystals, being forced into a state of hibernation. When the planet is fully contaminated, it explodes sending massive chunks of contaminated rock through the cosmos. Some of these meteors have mutated monstrosities housed within their cores, waiting for a time to break free upon a new contaminated world. We have received the remnants of a distant dead world, and we must contain it before the same thing happens to ours.

Grandmaster Wizard Eldrick Runeweaver postulates that containment of The World Ender is best achieved by sealing it back inside a massive delerium formation: essentially re-creating the Delerium Heart. Such a feat would require a massive flood of contaminated energy and a locus of delerium geodes.

Catastrophic Mutation

The Knights of the Silver Order are resolute that The World Ender confirms the destructive blight that delerium represents. It must be contained and destroyed lest it consume and contaminate the entire earth. This massive monstrosity is but the first of a new generation of titanic horrors which will devour the earth if delerium is not dealt with soon. The Knights

have a blunt theory about how it was created: its just another big mutant caused by the eldritch contamination of delerium. They cite the many documented instances when destroying or damaging a large cluster of delerium caused rifts between the planes or sudden surges of eldritch contamination. If the Delerium Heart is the largest piece of delerium ever encountered, then it stands to reason that shattering it would cause the largest Arcane Anomaly ever known. Its possible that the monster is the result of this catastrophe: it may have been conjured forth from some distant and unknown dimension of destruction, or perhaps a cascading mutation took root within a nearby creature.

Harbinger of Sin

The Followers of the Falling Fire believe a terrible sin has been wrought for destroying the Delerium Heart, and the salvation of this world is now in doubt. This cosmic being was meant to be The Harbinger of the Sacred Flame, but it has been unleashed before its preordained purpose. It is now an infant, mewling and raging at its destiny denied. Any hope we have must now be found in a monumental sacrifice.

Lucretia Mathias believes the only solution is to perform a special variant of the Sanctification of the Falling Fire upon the creature. Instead of using normal delerium crystals, one of the player characters must sacrifice themselves before The World Ender, and the other characters must embed the sanctified delerium crystal bearing the sacrificed heroes soul into The World Enders body. Perhaps then, the righteous soul of the fallen player character will fill the creature and turn it into a divine vessel.

A Grand and Cosmic Scheme

Panic spreads amongst the Queens Men as the scoundrels speculate that this creature came here on purpose. Mad rumors insist that it is a scout from a distant planet of huge lizard-creatures, and that The World Ender “piloted” the meteor into Drakkenheim with an intention to take over the world.

The Queen of Thieves laughs while dismissing such conspiracies, caring little about the origin of the creature. Instead, she sees opportunity. Instead, she sees opportunity and searches for a way to capture or control The World Ender. After all, if its power could be harnessed, if she could learn what the creature wants, tame it and use it against her enemies…well, who would be able to stop her then? She would have an even finer prize pet than Big Linda!

Great Egg

Amongst the Hooded Lanterns, a strange idea emerges that the Delerium Heart was in fact some kind of gigantic egg which bore The World Ender. Lain by some distant cosmic creature, its eggs shoot through the cosmos like meteors, eventually crashing into unknown and unsuspecting worlds. There, the egg incubates for a hundred or more years, changing the landscape around it into suitable conditions for its young. When the egg hatches, an infant version of this cosmic entity emerges, and the planet it finds itself on is its first hungry meal. This being cares not for the creatures inhabiting these planets, it wont even acknowledge them. It simply is following its own cycle of life, and we are unfortunate enough to be here when it awakens.

Lord Commander Elias Drexel is determined to destroy the beast by any means necessary, before it can spread destruction to the rest of Westemär. He looks to the characters and his soldiers to assemble a vast collection of siege weapons and artillery, which can be found in the arsenals of Castle Drakken. While it will take far more than these alone to bring the beast down, the cannons will no doubt be a useful distraction until The World Ender annihilates them.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Nature gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they Study The World Ender, learning the following based on their result:

(20+) Force of Destruction. You recognize The World Enders Resistances, Immunities, and its Immutable Form trait.

(25+) Blast of Energy. You learn of the Enders Charge Eradication Beam and Eradication Beam actions.

(30+) Nearly Unstoppable. You are aware of the The World Enders Rejuvenation trait.

Combat Tactics

The World Ender is a force of utter destruction. It cares little for the creatures or structures around it and merely tramples through them without hesitation or remorse. The World Ender unceasingly proceeds forward, and never halts unless it is somehow prevented from moving. It does not flee or hide and has no conception for surrender or fear. It is a force of nature that levels cities to the ground, leaving a path of utter destruction in its wake.

Few creatures pose an actual threat to The World Ender, and it is content to simply smash them with its Necrotic Claws or devour them with its Bite. Indeed, it may not even attack them directly, making most of its attacks against structures or the environment itself and letting the falling rubble crush any it encounters. When confronted with a large obstacle or building, it stops to unleash its Eradication Beam to clear a path forward with no regard for anything in its way.

However, if The World Ender is actually damaged by an attack or spell, it snaps into action and unleashes its Bellowing Roar in response. It follows up with its Ground Slam and then continue attacking until whatever injured it is slain. If it senses it is under attack by multiple foes (such as an approaching army), it aims its Eradication Beam to destroy them. The World Ender calls down Octarine Lightning Strikes against airborne opponents who target it from above, or against groups of foes on the ground.

Harvestable Components (Legendary)

Animus: Aberration.

Fluid: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor.

Organs: Eyes, Heart, Brain, Guts, Flesh.

Bones: Skull, Spine, Ribs.

Natural Weapons: Claws, Teeth, Tentacles.

Hair: Fur.

Hide: Skin.

Dust: Aberrant Dust.

Delerium Dreg.name: Delerium Dreg
Delerium Dreg.text:
T he The typical Delerium Dreg is a disheveled and piteous creature who wanders the ruins in a quasi-addled state. Most have benign mutations that confer no special traits or unique abilities.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Survival or Nature gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks to Study a Delerium Dreg, learning the following based on their result:

(5+) Humans Transformed. You know these Aberrations are immune to further delerium Contamination but otherwise have no special Resistances.

(10+) Contaminating Claws. You recognize the dangers of the creature's Claw attack.

(15+) Shambling Corruption. You understand the creature's highest and lowest ability scores and saving throws.

Combat Tactics

Delerium Dregs are desperate and confused combatants, incapable of any complex tactics beyond lunging towards their foes to attack by the most direct means. If they see a creature who is not contaminated, they will attack on sight. However, they will band together to form small herds, shuffling through ruins, or wandering the streets together. A wounded Delerium Dreg typically responds with fury and rage, attacking whatever damaged it last without regard to its personal wellbeing. In very rare cases, a wounded Dreg may attempt to flee, especially from a much more formidable combatant.

Harvestable Components (Common)

Animus: Aberration.

Fluid: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor.

Bones: Skull, Spine, Ribs.

Natural Weapons: Claws.

Hair: Hair.

Hide: Skin.

Dust: Aberrant Dust.

Bloated Dreg.name: Bloated Dreg
Bloated Dreg.text:
P eople People who are submerged in contaminated water often become Bloated Dregs. These half-drowned unfortunates are found near bodies of water throughout the city, such as the sewers or near the Drann River. They have absorbed so much contaminated water into themselves that it festers and mixes with their stomach acids, producing a corrosive bile that they hurl towards their foes. Often a Bloated Dreg will only leave the water for a few hours before finding another puddle of sludge or a contaminated pool to rest in.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Survival or Nature gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks to Study a Bloated Dreg, learning the following based on their result:

(5+) Corrupted by Contaminated Water. You know the creature is an Aberration with a Swim speed, and it can breathe underwater.

(10+) Slow and Polluted. You recognize the Bloated Dreg's Acid Spray attack.

(15+) Mockery of Humanity. You are aware of the Bloated Dreg's highest and lowest ability scores and saving throws.

Combat Tactics

The Bloated Dreg shuffles aimlessly through Drakkenheim, stopping to rest in places where contaminated water has built up, or in pools of delerium sludge. It produces large amounts of acidic bile in its guts that it expels when threatened. A Bloated Dreg will retreat to its watery home when threatened, trying to hide amongst the contaminated liquids.

Harvestable Components (Common)

Animus: Aberration.

Fluid: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor, Acidic Bile.

Organs: Eyes, Heart, Brain, Guts, Flesh.

Bones: Skull, Spine, Ribs. Hair:

Hair. Hide: Skin.

Dust: Aberrant Dust.

Chitinous Dreg.name: Chitinous Dreg
Chitinous Dreg.text:
T hese These Dregs have heavy mutations to their bone structure which covers them in a plated exoskeleton. Able to shrug off most attacks, Chitinous Dregs charge into battle, using their jagged forearm bone blades in a frenzy of ferocious strikes upon their prey.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Survival or Nature gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks to Study a Chitinous Dreg, learning the following based on their result:

(5+) Protective Plates. You recognize the Dreg's AC.

(10+) Pinning Blades. You learn of the creature's Bone Blade attack and No Escape trait.

(15+) Sturdy Foe. You are aware of the Chitinous Dreg's highest and lowest ability scores and saving throws.

Combat Tactics

Chitinous Dregs often charge into the front lines of combat. It positions itself between other Dregs and their foes almost as if it was defending its allies. Chitinous Dregs attempt to draw the combat towards itself at all times, using its Bone Blades to keep the focus on it, and its Sentinel Strike Reaction and No Escape trait to ensure creatures facing it cannot get away. The Chitinous Dreg is a warrior and rarely retreats: it is too enraged with a protective bloodlust when thrust into battle to worry about its own wellbeing.

Harvestable Components (Uncommon)

Animus: Aberration.

Fluid: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor.

Organs: Eyes, Heart, Brain, Guts, Flesh.

Bones: Skull, Spine, Ribs.

Natural Weapons: Blades.

Hair: Hair.

Hide: Carapace.

Dust: Aberrant Dust.

Crystalline Dreg.name: Crystalline Dreg
Crystalline Dreg.text:
M uch Much in the manner that some buildings closer to the meteor site had their fundamental elements changed in bizarre ways, such as stone and wood being transformed into flesh or glass, these Dregs have had their flesh warped into hard crystal. They have an innate ability to pull in light and the elements, briefly storing them in their form before expelling them in a manner that uses their body as a focusing lens, increasing the potency of these forces.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Survival or Nature gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks to Study a Crystalline Dreg, learning the following based on their result:

(5+) Light Absorption. You recognize the creaturea has Resistance to Radiant damage.

(10+) Reflecting Attacks. You learn of the Dreg's Refracted Beam attack.

(15+) Prone to Shattering. You understand the creature's Vulnerability to Bludgeoning damage.

Combat Tactics

The Crystalline Dreg is quite literally a glass cannon. It prefers to stay behind other Dregs, blasting its foes with its beam attacks and absorbing any elemental damage to alter its attacks. If an enemy who can deal Bludgeoning damage is present, the Crystalline Dreg will flee from that creature and attempt to kill them from a distance, knowing it is their biggest threat. The Dreg tends to focus on enemies approaching with melee weapons over anyone using elemental damage. If the front line of Dregs that the Crystalline Dreg often uses as shield is gone, or if the Crystalline Dregs are outnumbered and threatened with melee combat, they attempt to flee.

Belfray.name: Belfray
Belfray.text:
O nce Once a common sight, bats in Drakkenheim have swelled in both number and form. Many are now as large as dogs with wingspans stretching almost six feet. Insects no longer satisfy their thirst for blood and they crave the taste of flesh.

Belfrays are nocturnal and seldom encountered during the day. Even within the Haze, they prefer the nightly octarine glow to the strange hazy days.

When night falls, Belfrays gather atop old towers and flutter through the streets. They can be found hanging from old lamp posts and in the rafters of ruined houses, waiting to swoop down upon passing creatures. They are most often found in the citys highest locations such as Castle Drakken, the Clock Tower, the Inscrutable Tower, and a some of the citys larger buildings.

Belfrays mostly feast on Ratlings, but many victims have been surprised by these creatures swarming from the darkness. One should always be wary of damp and dark spaces where a handful of Belfrays could lurk. Disturbing them might be your last mistake.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Nature or Survival gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks to Study a Belfray, learning the following based on their result:

(5+) Accustomed to the Dark. You understand the Belfrays damage Resistances and Immunities.

(10+) Flying Blood-Drinker. You recognize its Flyby and Keen Hearing features, and Enfeebling Bite attack.

(15+) Weak Mind. You know the Belfrays strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.

Combat Tactics

The Belfray attempts to strike with a Sonic Blast from the shadows before engaging. Once a target is weakened, it swoops in with its claws. When damaged, Belfrays Bite, feeding on the blood of their victims to regain strength. It uses movement to stay away from threats, diving to attack before flying to a safe distance. If reduced below half of its maximum Hit Points, it attempts to fly away.

Displacer Dreg.name: Displacer Dreg
Displacer Dreg.text:
D isplacer Displacer Dregs are often the result of contamination leaking from Thin Places within the ruins. These places are shifting gateways between realms that cause those who enter them to traverse alien planes and unknown landscapes. When the contamination leaking from these wounds in reality affects a creature, it can cause them to split into a fragmented form — both existing and not existing, both present and on some distant plane of existence. The Displacer Dreg is, at all times, not fully present. The Dreg uses this broken reality to its benefit when threatened.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Survival or Nature gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks to Study a Displacer Dreg, learning the following based on their result:

(5+) Multiplanar Existence. You know of the Dreg's Displacement trait.

(10+) Teleporting Attack. You learn of the Dreg's Talons attack and Teleport Bonus Action.

(15+) Blurred Form. You recognize the Dreg's highest and lowest ability scores and saving throws.

Combat Tactics

The Displacer Dreg is a difficult creature to pin down. It uses its Talons to fend off attackers while Teleporting itself to safety if it thinks it is in a losing situation or to gain a more advantageous position.

Eldritch Dreg.name: Eldritch Dreg
Eldritch Dreg.text:
E ldritch Eldritch Dregs have a warped and twisted psyche. Contaminated energy collects in their brain, causing it to swell to a massive size while granting the Dreg arcane powers which it can barely comprehend — or control. Through this strange mutation, the Eldritch Dreg has lost most of its muscle tissue. They struggle to hold themselves upright when shuffling on their feet but can Levitate into the air when needed. Spellcasters who succumb to eldritch contamination are particularly likely to become Eldritch Dregs, especially those who have dabbled with contaminated spells.

Characters proficient in Survival or Nature gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks to Study an Eldritch Dreg, learning the following based on their result:

(5+) Haze Bound. You know this Aberration has Truesight.

(10+) Psychic Powers. You are aware of its Hazewarp Hex Bonus Action and Psychic Blast actions.

(15+) Cunning Being. You learn the Eldritch Dreg's highest and lowest ability scores and saving throws.

Combat Tactics

An Eldritch Dreg curses its chosen target with Hazewarp Hex, and then hammers it with its Psychic Blast. It uses Levitate to keep itself out of melee by hovering above the battlefield and it will unleash its Synaptic Shock if its enemies are close to one another. If brought to less than half its Hit Points, it attempts to flee.

Frenzied Dreg.name: Frenzied Dreg
Frenzied Dreg.text:
T he The Frenzied Dreg is a faster, more muscular cousin to its shambling brethren. It hunts the streets of Drakkenheim, actively seeking out prey. It lurks in dark ruins, even occasionally taking to the sewers, or clambering up the sides of buildings. When a group of Frenzied Dregs find other lesser Dregs, they herd them into the streets and use them as a trap, luring adventurers to engage with them and waiting to strike.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Survival or Nature gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) check to Study a Frenzied Dreg, learning the following based on their result:

(5+) Transformed Human. You recognize the creature is an aberration that has a Climb speed thanks to its claws.

(10+) Fast and Dangerous. You learn of the creature's Claws attack and Bounding Leap Bonus Action.

(15+) Dangerous Hunter. You recognize the Frenzied Dreg's highest and lowest ability scores and saving throws.

Combat Tactics

Leaping into the midst of combat, Frenzied Dregs chase down their foes and unleash a flurry of claws. Frenzied Dregs howl in fury as they bound upon their targets. So loud are their screams and screeches that it often attracts other Dregs and monsters to the area. Frenzied Dregs rarely flee; they pursue their enemies through Drakkenheim up to the edges of the Haze.

Gutwretch Dreg.text:
T he The Gutwretch Dreg uses its mutated internal organs as a weapon. It is a violent Delerium Dreg that launches its gut flail towards anyone who tries to get close to it.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Survival or Nature gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) check to Study a Gutwretch Dreg, learning the following based on their result:

(5+) Vigilant Protector. You are aware of the Gutwretch Dregs' Reactive trait.

(10+) Toppling Attacker. You recognize the Dreg's Gut Flail attack.

(15+) Strong and Agile. You learn the Dreg's highest and lowest ability scores and saving throws.

The Gutwretch Dreg keeps its distance from other combatants, watching all creatures who dare approach while swinging its flail over its head. It often protects other Dregs, standing watch over them while they eat or tend to other matters.

The Dreg uses its Reactive trait, as well as its Flailing Guts Reaction to knock creatures out of its way the moment they come near. It will always try to move away from direct combat, preferring to keep its enemies at arm's length so it can continue to pummel them with its Gut Flail.

The Gutwretch Dreg will fight to protect its fellow Dregs and is often the last one to flee from combat.

Lambent Dreg.name: Lambent Dreg
Lambent Dreg.text:
L ambent Lambent Dregs have become so contaminated that they glow like delerium. They are drawn to the contaminated crystals, gathering around them in groups. Studying these strange glowing Dregs, it has become clear that they become more hostile towards already contaminated creatures. Something about contamination motivates them to chase, attacking anyone suffering from mutations or sickness caused by exposure in the ruins.

Characters proficient in Survival or Nature gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) check to Study a Lambent Dreg, learning the following based on their result:

(5+) Drawn to Contamination. You are aware of the Dreg's Arcane Hunger trait.

(10+) Urge to Contaminate. You know of the Lambent Dreg's Octarine Beam and Wave of Contamination attacks.

(15+) Smart and Cunning. You learn of the Lambent Dreg's highest and lowest ability scores and saving throws.

Combat Tactics

Lambent Dregs tends to gather around delerium clusters throughout the city, often appearing in groups in highly contaminated areas. Creatures who have Contamination levels are prime targets for Lambent Dregs. The Dregs chase them down, avoiding non-contaminated targets when possible.

If threatened, Lambent Dregs run into the middle of a group of enemies and expel their Wave of Contamination, attempting to render their foes into a state of contamination, allowing the Dreg to easily engage with them.

Lambent Dregs flee if outnumbered and in a losing situation.

Lurking Dreg.name: Lurking Dreg
Lurking Dreg.text:
I t It is not immediately obvious that a Lurking Dreg is a contaminated monster. Retaining most of their original appearance and personality, Lurking Dregs are often driven by a mad compulsion to deceive friends and loved ones into circumstances or places that will contaminate them in turn. Keen-eyed observers may be able to recognize subtle cues and signs of contamination in these creatures, such as discolored skin tones and a slight octarine glow in the eyes.

Hooded Lantern apothecaries who have examined Lurking Dreg corpses have discovered that the ruse is merely skin-deep: the creatures' innards are entirely contaminated and mutated, with almost all the internal organs rendered into unrecognizable shapes and configurations.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Insight gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) check to Study a Lurking Dreg, learning the following based on their result:

(10+) Something's Off. You suspect this person may have been exposed to eldritch contamination.

(15+) Hiding Something. You are aware of the Lurking Dreg's Cunning Action trait.

(20+) Not A Humanoid. You realize this is a Dreg appearing to be a normal humanoid and recognize the Lurking Dreg's highest and lowest ability scores and saving throws.

Combat Tactics

Some Lurking Dregs hide in the shadows, waiting for an opportune moment to strike. Others pose as human and attempt to converse with prey, hoping to draw them deeper into the ruins. Lurking Dregs have been known to use stories of lost allies, trapped children, and more to lure adventurers into an ambush.

When they attack, Lurking Dregs use their Furious Ambush right away to get as many attacks in as possible. They Disengage if they can and attempt to keep their enemies at bay, possibly having other Dregs tie them up while the Lurking Dreg darts in and out.

If Lurking Dregs find themselves outnumbered at any point, they run into the shadows and Hide, attempting to escape.

Spined Dreg.name: Spined Dreg
