Bojack.name: Bojack
Bojack.text:
M any Many valiant warriors have ridden into Drakkenheim mounted on a loyal steed, not realizing that the rubble and wreckage filling the streets makes the ruins an unsuitable environment for a horse. Often, these poor animals must be abandoned not long after entering the ruins, injured from the unstable terrain. Prime targets for other predators, the horses are often tragically slaughtered. However, when their corpses are left behind, a parasite-like mutation festers within them, causing their skin to erupt with spider-like limbs, pincers, and maws.

Disguising themselves as mere corpses strewn across the dark and misty streets of the ruined city, one can hardly differentiate a Bojack from a dead horse. With their spider limbs they can scurry along walls and ceilings with ease, and barely make a sound. They move with lightning-fast speed, able to scuttle across a city street in mere seconds. This terrifying speed, ease of traversing the terrain, and ability to disguise itself have made them a deadly threat to adventurers in the city.

One of the most horrifying recorded encounters with Bojacks in Drakkenheim came from an early report from Hooded Lantern scouts investigating old stables south of Champions Gate near the city outskirts. They reported finding “piles of dead horses buzzing with large, mutated flies feasting on the meat.” The report goes on to speak of several of the horse corpses suddenly “bursting open” with “insectoid legs and a horrible maw formed from the splayed rib cage of the dead beasts.” The report describes the speed and ferocity displayed in the immediate strike, with nearly an entire squad of eight Hooded Lantern scouts ripped to shreds in only a matter of seconds while the remaining Lanterns fled back out of the city.

One of the surviving Hooded Lanterns, Sten Livingston Sr., was brave enough to volunteer to lead the following expedition into the ruins. On the road into the city a dead and bloated horse corpse lay on the side of the road. Livingston stopped his troops and approached the beast with weapons drawn, kicking the corpse to check if it would spring to life. The corpse remained motionless. It has since become a tradition spread through the Lanterns, and even into new adventuring parties, to kick the horse on the way into Drakkenheim. Many have chalked this up to a sign of good luck, not realizing the harrowing story and the lives lost that caused this strange tradition.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Nature or Survival gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks to Study a Bojack, learn the following based on their result:

(10+) Parasitic Mutation. You recognize the Bojacks Immunities and senses.

(15+) Acidic Ambusher. Youre aware of the creatures Corrosive Mucus and Impaling Limbs attacks.

(20+) Fast and Cunning. You know the Bojacks strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.

Combat Tactics

The Bojack is an ambush skirmisher. It waits for the opportune moment to strike, attempting to surprise as many targets as possible. After it surprises its prey, it attacks with its Impaling Limbs or Corrosive Mucus and uses its Predatory Cunning to move out of melee range.

The Bojack can climb walls and will try and skitter up buildings or behind walls, springing back out to attack before escaping again. If brought below 20 Hit Points, the Bojack attempts to Dash away and Hide.

Harvestable Components (Rare)

Animus: Monstrosity.

Fluid: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor, Acidic Bile, Mucus.

Organs: Heart, Guts, Glands.

Bones: Spine.

Natural Weapons: Blades.

Hair: Fur, Hair.

Hide: Skin.

Minazorond.name: Minazorond
Minazorond.text:
Minazorond perches upon the spires of Castle Drakken, an ornate masterpiece of intricate metalworks of brass and bronze, fitted with glittering scales, diamond eyes, and jewel-encrusted wings. The great dragon was constructed by an eccentric artist from Liberio by the name of Nicoletti. The artist gained renown in Liberio for their incredible metal statues and art exhibits at the Conservatory of Creation. He was the artist responsible for the Statue of Goliath which sits in the central courtyard of the conservatory.

When commissioned by House von Drakken to build a statue befitting Castle Drakken, the artist first declined. Two months later, Nicoletti wrote back to the queen explaining that a great dragon had come to him in a dream. He claimed that the dragon emperor, Minazorond, had spoken to him, and that this mythical dragon of his dreams desired to watch over the city of Drakkenheim. The artist packed his supplies and moved to Drakkenheim to begin construction, which cost a queen's bounty in resources. Nicoletti believed that Minazorond would be the greatest work of his life, but a tragic accident occurred while hoisting the final piece of the statue to its place atop the castle. A pulley snapped, crushing Nicoletti beneath his creation. The great dragon Minazorond would be the last work Nicoletti ever created.

Now Minazorond is a contaminated construct, and swiftly defends the castle from any who dare to set foot within its courtyards or attempt to scale its walls.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in History or any kind of artisan's tools gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they take the Study action to examine Minazorond. They learn the following information based on their check result.

(10+) Resistant Form. You know the creature's Resistances and Immunities.

(15+) Shrug Off Effects. You recognize the creature's Draconic Rebuke ability.

(20+) Tough to Kill. You learn of its Construct Resilience trait.

Combat Tactics

Minazorond is an animated engine of destruction charged with the protection of Castle Drakken. The corrupted protector attacks any who approach the palace itself, opening with a terrifying roar and a barrage of shocking bursts before closing the distance to unleash its breath weapon. Under most circumstances, the dragon is too large to physically enter the palace proper, and is thus restricted to attacking targets in the castle baileys and courtyards.

Harvestable Components (Legendary)

Animus: Dragon.

Natural Weapons: Teeth, Claws.

Dust: Draconic Dust.

Executioner.name: Executioner
Executioner.text:
The Executioner is a hulking clockwork knight that originally carried out public death sentences in the Slaughterstone Square of Drakkenheim. This ancient machine was engineered by the dwarves of Glitter Peak during the height of their brilliance in distant antiquity. It was left buried deep beneath the avalanches which destroyed the magnificent dwarven capital, and subsequently unearthed by an expeditionary team several decades ago. The king commissioned the Amethyst Academy to bring the construct back into good repair; they altered its arcane programming to obey the commands of the monarch of Westemär.

Laws and customs surrounding capital punishment in Drakkenheim have been a controversial matter ever since the tyrannical reign of Albrecht von Drakken, who issued a draconian decree that demanded family members of the convicted be the ones to carry out their execution sentence. After his reign ended, few were ever willing to serve the role of royal headsman, viewing the act of carrying out the killing as yet another act of murder. Although various devices and contraptions were used to create distance between the death and the administer of the punishment, these hesitations and public resistance to capital punishment remained. In the Executioner, the monarchy had the perfect solution to its judicial problem: the impartial construct is no mortal, and therefore none are culpable for carrying out the death sentence. That the machine makes an impressively terrifying show of the deed was certainly not an insignificant factor either.

Unfortunately, the erratic magic of delerium has scrambled the machine's control protocols. Now contaminated by the Haze, the construct is an engine of destruction and terror which can call upon spectral chains and the spirits of its victims to aid its duty. It attacks anyone who enters the square. However, it never wanders outside the bounds of Slaughterstone Square. The large octagonal plaza features the Executioner's platform, and the surrounding buildings have narrow balconies and tall, dour-looking windows overlooking the square. Mountains of corpses are piled in the square—the grim toll of the Executioner's vocation. Nevertheless, scavengers and adventurers still occasionally risk trying to slip past the Executioner to loot the corpses for valuable equipment and magic items. For many, this mistake is their last, and rather than escape with new treasures, they join the pile of the Executioner's trove.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in History or artisan's tools gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they take the Study action to examine the Executioner, learning the following based on the result:

(5+) Unstoppable Machine. You know of the Executioner's Immutable Form, Dimensional Anchor, and Rejuvenation traits, as well as its damage Immunities.

(10+) Strange Abilities. You recognize its Destroyer, Summon Grasping Shadow, and Guillotine Blade actions.

(15+) Powerfully Tough. You are aware of the Executioner's strongest and weakest saving throws.

Combat Tactics

The Executioner is not a foe to be defeated, but rather an obstacle to be avoided or a danger to escape. It is a reminder of the callous and uncontrollable dangers present in Drakkenheim. The Executioner's combat tactics vary based on whether it detects low-level characters trespassing in Slaughterstone Square or high-level characters trying to defeat the machine itself. The Executioner pursues its targets within Slaughterstone Square, but never leaves the plaza.

When the Executioner detects creatures trespassing on Slaughterstone Square, it responds first by using Summon Grasping Shadows, followed up by Death Grip to try to prevent their escape. Meanwhile, it uses Lumber Forward to gain ground. You should embrace clever solutions that characters invent to escape or bypass the Executioner. As long as your players aren't trying to destroy it, the Executioner will only use Guillotine Blade against a Restrained target within its melee range, and does not make ranged attacks nor activate its Necrotic Vents aura.

However, should your players engage the Executioner directly in combat, do not pull any punches. They have made an incredibly foolish mistake by confronting a well-telegraphed deathtrap and should be served their just desserts. It activates its Necrotic Vents, and then relentlessly attacks with its Guillotine Blade. The Executioner throws the massive weapon to hit targets trying to avoid it in melee, or those that try to harm it with ranged weapons or spells. If it encounters any impediment in its way (such as a Wall of Force), it crushes it with Destroyer.

Harvestable Components (Legendary)

Animus: Construct.

Fluid: Elemental Fluid, Contaminated Ichor.

Natural Weapons: Blades.

Hide: Plates.

Dust: Elemental Dust.

Tower Dragon.name: Tower Dragon
Tower Dragon.text:
These dragons perch upon the towers and parapets of the city and Castle Drakken. Once noble protectors of the city, they are now controlled by the will of the Haze.

The tower dragons were all designed in unique forms and no two are the same, although they are made of bronze, many have noted that each dragon is modeled after a different dragon type.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in History or any kind of artisan's tools gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they take the Study action to examine a tower dragon. They learn the following information based on their check result.

(5+) Resistant Form. You know the creature's Resistances and Immunities.

(10+) Ceaseless Pursuit. You learn of the creature's Faultless Tracker trait.

(15+) Simple-Minded Construct. You are aware of the creatures highest and lowest ability scores.

Combat Tactics

Tower Dragons defend strategic locations along the city walls. Most notably, these dragons animate to attack those who try to enter the city via the rivers, or any who attempt to fly above the walls of Castle Drakken. They are also drawn towards any extended engagement with Wall Gargoyles. Combat encounters lasting more than a minute against a gargoyles near the city walls will likely attract a Tower Dragon.

Typically, Tower Dragons attack from above, using their crackling breath weapons to devastate targets. Once animated, a Tower Dragon does not give up pursuit of their target until either it or is quarry is destroyed.

Harvestable Components (Rare)

Animus: Dragon.

Natural Weapons: Teeth, Claws.

Dust: Draconic Dust.

Wall Gargoyle.name: Wall Gargoyle
Wall Gargoyle.text:
These gargoyles defend the walls of Drakkenheim. When the walls were constructed, the gargoyles were placed every 50 feet along the entire perimeter of the walls. Using the combined craftsmanship of the dwarven stonework as well as magic from the Amethyst Academy, the gargoyles were designed as a defensive measure if the city were ever attacked. Any attempt to scale the walls of the city would see the creatures animate and defend the city at all costs. However, the Haze seeping into their magically imbued bodies has caused their arcane programming to falter, and now the creatures attack anyone who attempts to pass the walls of the city. They no longer differentiate friend from foe, and are always set to defend their territory to the death.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in History or any kind of artisan's tools gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they take the Study action to examine a Wall Gargoyle, learning the following based on the result:

(5+) Resistant Form. You know the creature's Immunities.

(10+) Ceaseless Pursuit. You learn of the creature's Faultless Tracker trait.

(15+) Simple-Minded Construct. You are aware of the creatures highest and lowest ability scores.

Combat Tactics

Wall Gargoyles are found only along the city walls. They animate and attack characters who dare attempt any of the following: Climbing more than halfway up the walls or towers, flying within one hundred fifty feet of the city walls horizontally, or over them at any height, or lingering on the walls or towers for more than ten minutes.

The gargoyles attack directly, viciously, and without remorse. If they reduce their quarry to 0 Hit Points, they spend their next turn tearing apart the creature's body before moving on to another target. The gargoyles pursue their quarry into the city to any distance until they or their quarry are destroyed, but give up pursuing characters more than three hundred feet outside the city walls.

Harvestable Components (Uncommon)

Animus: Elemental.

Fluid: Elemental Fluid.

Natural Weapons: Teeth, Claws.

Hide: Plates.

Hazewind Harpy Crone.name: Hazewind Harpy Crone
Hazewind Harpy Crone.text:
Hazewind Harpy Crones are the elders of their communities. Their songs tell of the generations of battles, triumphs, and sorrows of their broods. Harpies see them as oracles and sages, with their songs shared through the ages, but to those who threaten harpies, the crones stand as beacons of power. Their voices fill mortals with dread and foreboding of a coming doom. Few who hear these songs have lived to tell about them.

In Drakkenheim's streets, it's often easy to recognize when one is in harpy territory. Areas of the city left with belfries, towers, and places for harpies to roost often echo with distant melodies—a chorus of heavenly voices, twisted in discordant dissonance. The sound seems sweet, but is laced with uncomfortable notes. Many areas of Drakkenheim are filled with these songs. If you hear them, you know you are in hazewind territory.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Nature or Survival gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they take the Study action to examine a crone, learning the following based on the result:

(5+) Inherently Magical. You know of the creature'sdamage Immunities.

(10+) Dangerous Melodies. You are aware of its Crone Songs action.

(15+) Entrancing but Weak. You know the creature's highest and lowest ability scores.

Combat Tactics

The Hazewind Harpy Crone avoids direct combat. Her songs have a great range, allowing her to perch atop hard-to-reach places, while her songs help her more combat-focused sisters in battle. These songs empower ally attacks, while the Breakneck Hymns increase the falling damage of plummeting enemies. If creatures come too close, she may use her Mesmerizing Melody and move elsewhere.

Harvestable Components (Rare)

Animus: Monstrosity.

Fluid: Monster Blood.

Bones: Skull.

Natural Weapons: Claws.

Hair: Feathers.

Hide: Skin.

Hazewind Harpy Hunter.name: Hazewind Harpy Hunter
Hazewind Harpy Hunter.text:
The typical Hazewind Harpy Hunter is a skilled airborne killer, able to fly at high speeds while aiming their bow with deadly accuracy. They spend their days soaring over the city streets, taking their pick of prey in the streets below. Although they are perfectly happy to survive on ratlings, they are drawn to the weapons, treasure, and trinkets carried by explorers and faction agents, and eagerly attack for an opportunity at a meal with a prize.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Nature or Survival gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they take the Study action to examine a Hazewind Harpy Hunter, learning the following based on the result:

(5+) Agile Flier. You learn of the creature's Aerial Maneuver Bonus Action.

(10+) Dangerous Song. You know the creature's Chorus ability.

(15+) Sturdy and Agile. You recognize the creature's highest and lowest ability scores.

Combat Tactics

Harpies hunt in small flocks, and always attack from the sky or an overhead vantage point using their longbows. They engage in melee only to make the killing blow on a wounded target. When confronted with a foe able to make effective ranged attacks, harpies become much more cautious. Accurate shots from the ground or an exploding airborne Fireball may be enough alone to shake their resolve, causing them to fly off in search of easier prey.

Harvestable Components (Common)

Animus: Monstrosity.

Fluid: Monster Blood.

Bones: Skull.

Natural Weapons: Claws.

Hair: Feathers.

Hide: Skin.

Hazewind Harpy Valkyrie.name: Hazewind Harpy Valkyrie
Hazewind Harpy Valkyrie.text:
Valkyries are the best warriors among the hazewinds. They have faced battles before, survived, and honed their fighting skills. They have practiced their maneuverability, quick strikes, and ability to cover distance. Relying on keeping to the air, pinpointing weak targets, and plucking them off their feet to toss them, valkyries keep to the tops of buildings and towers. Those who cannot fly always face the dire reality of falling to their death.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Nature or Survival gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they take the Study action to examine a Hazewind Harpy Valkyrie, learning the following based on the result:

(5+) Agile Flier. You learn of the creature's Aerial Maneuver Bonus Action.

(10+) Dangerous Talons. You recognize the creature's Pluck trait.

(15+) Strong and Agile. You know the creature's highest and lowest ability scores.

Combat Tactics

The Hazewind Harpy Valkyrie are the chosen warriors of the Crimson Countess, and they are skilled with both their weapons and their talons. They wield barbed javelins and a shield in their hands, and leave their taloned feet open to pluck people off the ground and toss them. They often attempt to lure foes into elevated positions, such as rooftops, cliffs, or balconies, and then pluck them up and toss them to their death.

If they find themselves grounded, or outnumbered they will attempt to escape and fly to the highest location nearby to guard themselves and better defend against attackers.

Harvestable Components (Rare)

Animus: Monstrosity.

Fluid: Monster Blood.

Bones: Skull.

Natural Weapons: Claws.

Hair: Feathers.

Hide: Skin.

Crimson Countess.name: Crimson Countess
Crimson Countess.text:
The Crimson Countess is a powerful queen of harpies. Her red-feathered wings and deep crimson hair set her apart from the many harpy followers she commands. She is clad is black and gold armor and carries with her a spear that crackles with magical energies. Her hands and feet are black talons with sharp claws. The Crimson Countess is a cunning hunter and territorial to the Clock Tower. She has staked her claim over the center of the city, and hunts the various monsters and misguided faction agents who come close.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Nature or Survival gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they take the Study action to examine Crimson Countess, learning the following based on the result:

(5+) Arcane Resistance. You know of the creature's Immunities.

(10+) Dangerous Talons. You recognize the creature's Pluck trait.

(15+) Bold and Nimble. You are aware of the creatures highest and lowest ability scores.

Combat Tactics

The Countess only leaves her clock tower to join in on hunts with her valkyries, but otherwise she prefers the defendable position at the towers highest floor. From here any adventurer who makes it past her soldiers and into her lair can easily be grabbed and thrown off the open balconies, falling to their death.

She is overconfident and will do anything to protect her advantageous position in the city. She only flees if all her minions

are dead and she is below 25 Hit Points. If she flees, she will attempt to gather more soldiers and return to reclaim the clock tower at a later date.

Harvestable Components (Rare)

Animus: Monstrosity.

Fluid: Monster Blood.

Bones: Skull.

Natural Weapons: Claws.

Hair: Feathers.

Hide: Skin.

Alienist.name: Alienist
Alienist.text:
An Alienist seeks to master the mysteries of the mind. Having devoted years to studying the inner workings of the brain to unlock its latent potential, an Alienist is able to bend reality, read thoughts, and manipulate the thoughts of others. They tap into unfathomable realities and shift the world to their will using the psychic energies they call upon from eldritch lore and arcane knowledge.

Alienist Minions. Alienists keep several experiments of their own on hand. They have been known to keep @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.zAN1wRt81LfiLRBi]{Wretched Patients}, their minds melted by the Alienist's inhuman experimentation, turning them into obedient and loyal servants. @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.6vuvKf0uI2czeiGx]{Disembodied Psyches} and @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.xIV1fle7lIJfQqtF]{Cerebrograft} are a few of their higher-end creations, having removed the brain of a creature and given it a unique and bespoke form of sentience, these creatures serve as guards to an Alienist's work, or minions capable of complex thought and aid.

Roleplaying Traits

  • Personality Trait. I can't help but analyze every person who comes before me. I want to know what they think, and why they are the way they are.
  • Bond. I study the mind for scientific advancement. How easily this muscle can be manipulated, altered, and used in unforeseen ways is fascinating research that must be explored.
  • Ideal. I am the only one capable of this level of advanced mental research, someone else would have gotten it wrong!
  • Flaw. My unbound intellect means that I can never be fooled, tricked, or manipulated, and thus I can never be outsmarted, to think I could is laughable.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Medicine or Arcana gain Advantage on Wisdom (Insight) or Intelligence (Investigation) checks to Study an Alienist, learning the following based on the result:

(10+) Mental Master. You are aware of the Alienist's Immunities as well as its Unmatched Intellect trait.

(15+) Mind Control. You know of its Mass Manipulation action.

(20+) Brilliant but Vulnerable. You learn its AC, as well as its strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.

Combat Tactics

An Alienist is a smart combatant who does not wildly use their abilities, nor easily fall victim to manipulation or deception. They begin interactions by attempting to persuade foes to leave them be, resorting to spells such as @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.zMAWdyc8UVb37BK4]{Suggestion} and @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.ppWAAEul0QHtm4er]{Detect Thoughts} to help navigate social encounters. If combat arises, the Alienist unleashes Mass Manipulation to confuse its foes while it Teleports away to make an escape. The Alienist leaves Nerve Gas in its wake to dissuade enemies from pursuit.

The Alienist flees at the first opportunity it has—they are too clever to give in to needless combat. If the Alienist is trapped, it does its best to undo the party, attempting to flee at all costs if it feels it is in a losing situation and below half its Hit Points.

Chemist.name: Chemist
Chemist.text:
Chemists indulge in the science of the alchemical, often harnessing the raw potential of elemental formulae while creating unique compounds and reagents. They have been known to dabble in the science behind the creation of elementals and oozes, and perfecting explosives and acids.

Chemist Minions. Although Chemists often do not dabble in creating creatures, any apothecary can make use of minions. Simple elementals and oozes can be found in a Chemist's lab. @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.rGmIphfEvSNOb08u]{Tankers} work as a good lab assistant for administering large amounts of chemical formulae for the scientist, while @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.EMfL1GhvbuzZnyZw]{Living Biohazard} are often the failed early experiments many Chemists. A @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.hk0bnH8AwMnhHv5M]{Chemystral} is the ultimate pride and joy of many chemists.

Roleplaying Traits

  • Personality Trait. I revel in the chaos and destruction that my concoctions cause, watching the flames and corrosion with maniacal laughter and a crazed gleam in my eyes.
  • Ideal. Creativity is born from chaos; the most groundbreaking discoveries require pushing boundaries, no matter the dangers involved.
  • Bond. I am obsessed with avenging my mentor, who was persecuted by those who feared our knowledge and power.
  • Flaw. My obsession with perfecting destructive formulae often leads me to take careless risks, sabotaging my own work and safety. I've burned down my own workshop more times than I can remember, and I'll do it again.

Study the Foe

Characters proficient in Medicine gain Advantage on Wisdom (Insight) or Intelligence (Investigation) checks to Study a Chemist, learning the following based on the result:

(10+) Resistance from Exposure. You know of the Chemist's damage Resistances and Immunities.

(15+) Masters of Compounds. You learn the Chemist's Critical Condition trait and Explosive Compound action.

(20+) Mental, not Physical, Prowess. You are aware of the Chemist's AC and saving throws.

Combat Tactics

Chemists opt to start things off with a bang, unleashing their Explosive Concoction on the first round, especially against a grouped together party. They use Acid Rain to create a dangerous zone between them and their enemies and default to unleashing their Chemical Spray on enemies stuck in the difficult area. If a creature closes the distance on the Chemist, they use their Caustic Grip. If they find themselves surrounded or outnumbered in close quarters, they attempt to escape.

Save Ends.name: Save Ends
Save Ends.text: Throughout this book, we've used the shorthand “(save ends)” to certain conditions and game effects caused by monsters. This means that the affected creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of their turns, ending the effect on themselves early on a success.
Save Ends.tooltip: This means that the affected creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of their turns, ending the effect on themselves early on a success.

Removing Contamination.name: Removing Contamination
Removing Contamination.text:
Removing Contamination Levels. Only specific magic can remove Contamination levels:

  • The @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.features.Item.zgfmQrRMpvBoPAnB]{Purge Contamination} spell.
  • @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.qcYitWoSMTnKkzM1]{Heal} removes all Contamination levels and mutations in addition to its other effects.
  • Contamination is not a curse, poison, or disease. Spells such as @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.F0GsG0SJzsIOacwV]{Lesser Restoration}, @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.MAxM77CDUu8dgIRQ]{Protection from Poison}, and @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.XZhdgVK3cLoxNCQl]{Remove Curse} do not remove Contamination levels.
  • Being raised from the dead reduces a creature's Contamination level by 1.

When your Contamination level reaches 0, the condition ends, as well as the effects of all mutations.

Skin, hair, fingernails, and toenails lost to mutations regrow normally once Contamination is removed. However, a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.9kGrFXnLiRg3Xnbo]{Regenerate} spell or similar magic is needed to restore any other body parts (such as teeth, limbs, or eyes) lost due to Contamination. Appendages or limbs that develop as a result of mutations wither and fall off when Contamination is removed, and other warped body parts are restored to their original form.

Dying with Contamination.name: Dying with Contamination
Dying with Contamination.text: Dying with Contamination Levels. If you die while you have one or more Contamination levels, your corpse reanimates as a @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.uzeoZGIO0MULOG8a]{Haze Husk} 24 hours later. A creature with six or more class levels or hit dice rises as a @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.wH7qy4fPdtUV6yOG]{Haze Wight} instead.

If you die while you have one or more Contamination levels, your corpse reanimates as a @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.uzeoZGIO0MULOG8a]{Haze Husk} 24 hours later. A creature with six or more class levels or hit dice rises as a @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.wH7qy4fPdtUV6yOG]{Haze Wight} instead.

Monstrous Transformation.name: Monstrous Transformation
Monstrous Transformation.text:
Monstrous Transformation! If you end your turn with six or more Contamination Levels, you permanently transform into a horrific monster controlled by the Game Master.

  • The Game Master chooses the new form, which is most often an Aberration or Monstrosity of some kind such as a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.8pX2JhWUpTNNRBVx]{Gibbering Mouther}, @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.o4CFZu2AnQ5rJAOD]{Delerium Dreg}, or @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.CuSUJc5NnYVVaU0K]{Pyknic Maunder}.
  • Your game statistics are entirely replaced by those of the chosen monster, including the new form's Hit Points and Hit Dice.
  • All Contamination levels are removed, though the GM may grant additional traits to the new form similar to any beneficial mutations gained from Contamination Levels.
  • The Game Master determines what remains of the original creature's personality and memories, if anything. Regardless, the creature falls under the Game Master's control.

Revert Transformation.name: Revert Transformation
Revert Transformation.text:
Reversing the Transformation. A @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.3okM6Gn63zzEULkz]{Wish} spell or similar magic can restore a single transformed creature to its previous form, removing all Contamination and restoring the original creature's personality and memories. This is considered a stressful use of the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.3okM6Gn63zzEULkz]{Wish} spell, and thus there is a 33 percent chance that the caster will be unable to cast wish ever again if they use the spell in this manner.

Note that the means of reversing a monstrous transformation are completely unknown at the outset of the campaign. A Monstrous Transformation is widely regarded as permanent.

Delerium Properties.name: Delerium Properties
Delerium Properties.text:
All delerium samples have the following traits regardless of size:

  • Immune to Necrotic, Poison, and Psychic damage; as well as Bludgeoning, Piercing, and Slashing damage from non-magical weapons.
  • Resistant to Acid, Cold, Fire, and Lightning damage; as well as Slashing and Piercing damage from magical weapons.
  • Vulnerable to Bludgeoning damage from magical weapons.
  • Unless contained within an @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.Eon0jzGzQRNluTPQ]{Antimagic Field}, delerium shatters and crumbles into worthless ash when reduced to 0 Hit Points. However, delerium geodes release a random Arcane Anomaly when destroyed (see @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.tables.RollTable.ho3p6IgN9keG8cPp]{Arcane Anomaly} table).

Delerium Hazards.text: When a humanoid creature touches delerium without protective gear for the first time on their turn, or ends their turn in bodily contact with delerium, they must make a [[/save con 10 format=long]] or take [[/damage 1d6 Necrotic]] damage and gain one level of Contamination.

Delerium Harvesting.name: Delerium Harvesting
Delerium Harvesting.text: Delerium found in Drakkenheim is usually fused into the ground or stone buildings. It is carefully extracted using handheld mining equipment such as shovels, picks, hammers, and chisels. Consult the @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimApp0C.JournalEntryPage.3002delerium0000#delerium-crystals]{Delerium Extraction} to determine how long it takes characters to extract delerium. Lacking proper equipment, extraction takes ten times as long. Massive clusters are impossible to extract without heavy equipment or powerful magic.

Delerium Uses.name: Delerium Uses
Delerium Uses.text:
Delerium has vast arcane potential. Beyond trade, crystals are used for several purposes:

Spell Component. Delerium may be used as an arcane focus or material component for any spell on the sorcerer, warlock, or wizard spell list. When casting a spell which requires a costly material component, a spellcaster may instead use delerium of equivalent or greater value to the required cost.

Magic Items. Delerium is an exceptional material for creating magical items of all kinds. Any existing magic item described in the Basic Rules could be made with delerium. Fragments, shards, crystals, and geodes may be used to make uncommon, rare, very rare, and legendary items respectively. At the GM's discretion, characters who can cast level 5 spells or higher may learn techniques to craft magic items of their own during their downtime.

Stable Delerium. The process for crafting magic items with delerium renders the crystals stable. Unless otherwise specified, characters do not take damage nor risk Contamination when they touch or handle stable delerium. Stable delerium is damaged and destroyed in the same manner as a normal magic item of its kind.

Delerium Dust. Delerium dust is made by grinding the crystals against one another to create a fine powder. This milling process is extraordinarily hazardous unless performed within an @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.Eon0jzGzQRNluTPQ]{Antimagic Field}. Delerium dust can be used in alchemy, as a spell component, a reagent for brewing potions, or mixed into inks used to scribe spell scrolls.

Improvised Weapons & Ammunition. Delerium fragments may be used as ammunition for a sling or fashioned into a makeshift club. Such weapons and ammunition deal an extra 1d6 Necrotic damage, and humanoid creatures struck must make a [[/save con 10 format=long]] or gain one level of Contamination. Delerium used as ammunition in this way is destroyed.

Haze Character Effects.name: Haze Character Effects
Haze Character Effects.text:
Humanoid creatures do not gain any benefits from finishing a Long Rest within the Haze.

In addition, a humanoid creature may only spend up to 12 hours within the Haze, after which it must finish a Long Rest to adequately recover from exposure. Humanoid creatures who remain in the Haze beyond 24 hours before recuperating risk Contamination. For each additional hour spent within the Haze beyond 24 hours, a humanoid creature must make a [[/save con 15 format=long]] or gain one level of Contamination.

Haze Environmental Effects.name: Haze Environmental Effects
Haze Environmental Effects.text:
The Haze magically manifests mist throughout the area. Characters can see normally through the mist up to 150 feet. Vision beyond is &Reference[Lightly Obscured], but vision past 300 feet is Totally Obscured. Any mists dispersed during the day re-form 10 minutes later.

The Haze dampens sunlight. Creatures with Sunlight Vulnerability or similar traits do not suffer these penalties during the day while within the Haze.

The corpses of beasts and humanoid creatures do not rot within the Haze.

Epic Initiative.name: Epic Initiative
Epic Initiative.text:
An Epic Boss always takes its turn on Initiative count 20 (and wins Initiative ties).

On its turn, an Epic Boss can use its movement and interaction as normal. However, an Epic Boss does not take an action or bonus action on its turn unless forced to do so by a spell or other effect. Instead, Epic Bosses take Epic Actions.

Haze Spell Effects.name: Haze Spell Effects
Haze Spell Effects.text:
Any divination or teleportation spell cast outside the Haze targeting a creature or location within the Haze automatically fails. Spell-based telepathic communications or effects such as the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.GtGjNjPBgUHxGYAD]{Sending} spell transmitted from outside the Haze fail to contact a character within it, and vice-versa. Finally, Divination spells fail to reveal useful information about delerium, the Haze, the origins of the meteor, or any events which occurred within the Haze.

When a character attempts any of the above using a spell or other effect, they must make a [[/save int 15 format=long]]. On a failure, they take [[/damage 6d6 psychic average=true]] damage and become &Reference[Incapacitated] with madness until they finish a Long Rest. During this time, the spellcaster speaks only in gibberish. A @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.WzvJ7G3cqvIubsLk]{Greater Restoration} spell ends this effect.

@UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.NXWWWgHtWb7Nv21F]{Tiny Hut} and similar spells or abilities do not provide shelter from the Haze. However, characters may rest within a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.pn4SnsFDvYDiE6rC]{Magnificent Mansion} spell cast within the Haze.

Deep Haze.name: Deep Haze
Deep Haze.text:
Certain areas are so suffused by the Haze that mere exposure is extremely dangerous and potentially fatal. Known as the Deep Haze, these areas have the following additional traits:

  • Deep Haze is instantly recognized by a thick prismatic fog. Characters can see normally through this fog up to 60 feet. Vision beyond is &Reference[Lightly Obscured]], and vision past 120 feet is Totally Obscured. If dispersed during the day, the fog reforms 1 minute later.
  • Characters entering the Deep Haze must make a [[/save con 15 format=long]], and again for each full hour spent within. On a failed saving throw, they suffer [[/damage 3d6 necrotic average=true]] damage and gain one level of Contamination.

Epic Actions.name: Epic Actions
Epic Actions.text:
An Epic Boss takes one Epic Action at the end of each player character's turn. At the game master's discretion, an Epic Boss may take an Epic Action after another non-player character combatant's turn, such as a sidekick or major NPC ally of the player characters.

Therefore, if an Epic Boss were facing five player characters, the boss would take five Epic Actions total during one round of combat, one at the end of each player character's turn. If a player character falls unconscious or dies during the encounter, the Epic Boss continues taking an Epic Action after that character's place in the Initiative order.

Some Epic Actions can only be used once per round, and others may have a recharge condition. In addition, certain Epic Actions must be used as the first or last Epic Action the boss takes that round. For example, a Delerium Dragon may only use its Breath Weapon as the final Epic Action it takes that round.

Epic Actions are not Reactions. Game effects which prevent an Epic Boss from taking Reactions do not work on Epic Actions, nor do game affects which limit a creature to taking only a movement, bonus action, or action on their turn (such as the &reference[dazed apply=false] condition).

Epic Resistance.name: Epic Resistance
Epic Resistance.text:
Epic Bosses possess extraordinary resilience, willpower, and determination which allows them to rapidly recover from spells and effects which would incapacitate or debilitate other creatures. This Epic Resistance action is available to all Epic Bosses as an Epic Action:

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.features.Item.5bEcbjvkdYsbvPAw caption=false]

An Epic Resistance roll is not a d20 Test, that is, it is not an ability check, attack roll, nor saving throw. An Epic Boss can never have Advantage or Disadvantage on an Epic Resistance roll. Furthermore, no bonuses or penalties can ever be applied to an Epic Resistance roll. Finally, no game effect can replace the roll or the result of the roll, nor allow or force the Epic Boss to reroll an Epic Resistance roll.

An Epic Boss can use Epic Resistance to escape conditions and effects before their durations would otherwise expire. For example, if an Epic Boss becomes Stunned by a monk's Stunning Strike feature, it could use its Epic Resistance to end that condition. When Epic Resistance is used on the Exhaustion condition, a successful d20 roll removes 1 level of Exhaustion.

Ever-Present Threat.name: Ever-Present Threat
Ever-Present Threat.text:
Chapter 7:
Trolls

Ever-Present Threat

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.170imgrpresentth inline]

"What has two arms and I hate them? Trolls! They are stupid, violent creatures, and as a Caspian I would know! They come in many different forms, but the smell is pretty consistent. Before your empathy pours in, remember the countless Caspians I personally sent to deal with the trolls, who never returned to their families."

—Pluto Jackson

When the commonfolk think of monsters, trolls are often top of mind. Although slumbering dragons, hulking giants, and the eldritch horrors of Drakkenheim loom large in tales and imaginations alike, seldom do such terrors invade people's everyday lives. Trolls, however, roam far and wide throughout Caspia, Elyria, and Westemär. They are by far one of the most common and well-known monsters plaguing the continent; children hearing of trolls under bridges or as a cautionary tale to venturing into the woods at night. Indeed, those in rural villages, farmsteads, or unwary travelers taking the backroads, may sometimes run afoul of a hungry troll. Many such communities have their own stories about local run-ins with trolls, ranging from the comedic to the tragic and occasionally the terrifying.

Origins in the Faerie Otherworlds

Trolls tell few tales about their own origins, and so it falls to mortal scholars to speculate how they came to this world. Legend says that trolls came from the Faerie Otherworlds long before a great winter fell upon the world. Accounts vary on why and how; some tell of how they were driven from enchanted realms by fey tricksters. Other stories say that trolls are a curse sent by a vengeful Faerie King or Queen for some half-remembered trespass made by mortals millennia ago. Perhaps foolish warlocks accidentally summoned the trolls here in attempts to bargain with their patrons, opening rifts that allowed entities from the Otherworlds to enter the Material Plane. Perhaps the first few trolls simply got very, very lost searching for their next meal, and wandered through a Thin Place only to find that a local farm made for a fortuitous feast. The Faerie Otherworlds are after all the closest “neighbor” dimension to the Mortal World—creatures stumbling through the thin veil that separates these planes is more common than through any other.

Regardless of how they got here, trolls arrived so long ago that there is not a wild place on the continent that isn't home

to some form of troll. Every major city and settlement has their stories of why you shouldn't traverse dark forests, old swamps, or deep caves alone, and the heroic deeds of great heroes who have rescued such wayward travelers from the clutches of these great beasts.

Caspian Legends

In the realm of Caspia, slaying a troll is considered a crucial test of valor and a rite of passage for proving one's worth as a warrior. Troll hunting has evolved into a sport among the Caspians, and many ale houses resound with tales of brave knights confronting fearsome trolls. Distinct varieties of trolls inhabit different parts of the region — the trolls of Trogrowth Forest, the cave dwellers of Caspian Canyon, the Storm Trolls of Bladeshatter Bay, and the Magma Trolls in the deep caverns beneath Dragon's Vault — each with their own legends deeply embedded in Caspian lore.

Caspians take great pride in recounting their battles with these formidable creatures. They decorate their keeps with the skulls of slain trolls, and confronting a troll is widely regarded as a fundamental milestone for those aspiring to be recognized as true Caspian warriors.

Appetites and Bargains

Trolls are creatures defined by their insatiable hunger, often driven by the pursuit of their next meal. This relentless appetite shapes their interactions, behaviors, and societal structures. Securing food is paramount in their daily existence. Despite their fearsome nature and formidable size, trolls typically avoid complex strategies in favor of straightforward approaches to satiating their hunger. This simplicity in motivation, however, does not mean they lack cunning or adaptability when opportunities to feed present themselves without substantial effort. Trolls have a particular craving for fresh meat, wealth, and captives, reveling in the manipulation and terror they can instill in those they encounter, aiming to extract as much as possible before brutally dispatching their victims.

Trolls often rely on their imposing stature, strength, and fearsome reputation to intimidate travelers into relinquishing goods, food, gems, or other valuables in exchange for safe passage. This method allows trolls to amass supplies without the need for hunting. When interacting with humans, trolls make demands they know will be unpalatable, such as threatening to devastate a

farm unless the farmers surrender their prized livestock or even a family member. They have been known to demand adventurers sacrifice an arm and a leg for safe conduct, resorting to violence against those who cannot meet their steep demands.

Trolls are largely solitary creatures, but occasionally form their own secluded communities, creating tight-knit groups that operate as small hunting packs. Strategically, they set up camps or outposts near pathways frequented by wagons or lone travelers, or at narrow passages like gates and bridges where travelers have little choice but to confront them.

Elemental Evolutions

Trolls inherently possess extraordinary regeneration. Their bodies rapidly heal any injury, even regrowing lost limbs and body parts in mere minutes. However, a troll's regeneration is somewhat flawed, prone to leaving behind scar tissue and imperfections which, over time, result in the knobby hide and thick outer skin of most trolls. However, in rare cases, a troll can develop bizarre mutations when they regenerate, such as sprouting additional limbs. Over time, this trait has driven rapid evolutionary developments among trollkin based on their environments. Trolls can adapt to thrive in remote and hazardous settings simply by surviving anything these places can throw at them, even taking on the elemental traits of their surroundings.

In the dense forests, @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimTro07.JournalEntryPage.709oaktroll00000]{Oak Trolls} have evolved as a dominant species, while the overgrown brushlands and marshes are frequent havens for @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimTro07.JournalEntryPage.707humongousfung]{Fungus Trolls}. @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimTro07.JournalEntryPage.705elementaltrol#winter-troll]{Winter Trolls} navigate the lofty peaks and the desolate expanses of Netherwind, while @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimTro07.JournalEntryPage.705elementaltrol#storm-troll]{Storm Trolls} roam along the shores of the Crystal Coast and Bladeshatter Bay. The fiery Drakeclaw Mountains are home to @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimTro07.JournalEntryPage.705elementaltrol#magma-troll]{Magma Trolls}, and the strange city of Drakkenheim has given birth to @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimTro07.JournalEntryPage.705eldritchtroll]{Eldritch Trolls}. Importantly, these diverse types of trolls are not restricted to these areas alone and can be encountered throughout the continent in a variety of settings.

Locations and Lairs.name: Locations and Lairs
Locations and Lairs.text:
Locations and Lairs

Trolls build their burrows or camps in secluded, hard-to-reach areas such as great mountain caves, or deep within treacherous swamps. They often live in small groups and hunt the areas surrounding their homes for wildlife or wandering adventurers.

Traps and Hazards

Trolls know their environments well and often purposely build near natural hazards or outfit the areas surrounding their homes with traps formed of natural elements. They are smart hunters and know how to protect themselves. Use traps and hazards freely when designing troll environments.

Scavenged Goods

Trolls are collectors. They keep anything shiny or that they deem interesting from adventurers they have killed. They often have sacks filled with combinations of mundane trinkets and potential magical items. Almost anything can be found amongst a troll's collection.

Some items commonly found in a troll's bag are below. Choose 2–3 or roll a [[/r 1d12]] twice.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.tables.RollTable.hwxzZ6nkB2EqTcTR rollable]

Natural Networks

Trolls build their homes in natural environments, preferring lairs that have more than one exit, possible secret passages, and multiple ways for them to get the drop on any unwanted intruders. They may not be the smartest creatures around, but they are good at defending their homes, and eating humans who try to trespass in them.

Minions and Pets

Trolls are known for taming creatures to aid them in hunting. Oftentimes these creatures are beasts or monstrosities that they keep as pets. Dire Wolves, Owlbears, Giant Lizards, or more exotic creatures can be companions to a group of hunting trolls.

When it comes to their lairs, oftentimes trolls find habitats with natural wildlife that can act as guards to their own burrows and camps. Finding a cave with a gelatinous cube already residing in it, or a swamp filled with giant crocodiles is perfectly fine for a troll. They try to use these natural predators to deter unwanted guests.

Known Lairs

Trolls typically reside out of the way of humanoid civilizations, knowing very well that humans and trolls do not often get along, they tend to occupy less hospitable locations. Trolls have a rare ability to regenerate, and this regenerative gene has made them quick to evolve and adapt to almost any environment.

Trogrowth Forest

The Trogrowth forest of Caspia is one of the most well-known locations for Caspian sport troll hunting. The woods are filled with all manner of trolls. Many of the typical trolls reside there, but one of the most fearsome troll types to be discovered in the forests are the @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimTro07.JournalEntryPage.707humongousfung]{Fungus Trolls}, whose numbers swell quickly and can easily overwhelm an unprepared Caspian hunt.

Elvenmire Wetlands

Many of the continent's swamps are home to @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimTro07.JournalEntryPage.707humongousfung]{Fungus Trolls} as well. In any place where fungus is common, there is a chance of a @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimTro07.JournalEntryPage.706trollhag00000]{Troll Hag} starting a garden of @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimTro07.JournalEntryPage.708fungaltrollin]{Trollings}. Swamps are seldom inhabited by humans, and so make prime locations for Fungal Troll farms, and burrows of all sorts of trollkin.

Ruins of Drakkenheim

It's well known that many trolls took up at King's Gate and Queen's Park Gardens when Drakkenheim fell. But these trolls are of lesser concern than the ones who got lost in the city itself. Several trolls who fell to contamination still roam the city streets as mindless @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimTro07.JournalEntryPage.705eldritchtroll]{Eldritch Trolls}.

Hagatha's Lair

Between the sister lakes of the Eastern Vales, deep in the murky Shadow Fens, lies a little cottage made of old, moss-covered wood, a quaint cobblestone walkway leads up to its yellow oak door. A stone chimney spouts puffs of black-gray smoke, and a canopy of green leaves cover it from the sun. mushrooms big and small grow upon the wooden exterior, and cover the mossy roof, some as small as a gold piece, others as big as a wagon wheel. The crude wood fence around Hagatha's cabin has an old wooden sign pointing down the swampy road that reads “Snaggletooth Road.” All manner of frogs, flies, gators, and other critters poke their faces out from the algae-covered waters surrounding the winding narrow path.

Hagatha is a @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimTro07.JournalEntryPage.706trollhag00000]{Troll Hag} who delights in growing mushrooms of all shapes and sizes, using her magic to imbue them with sentience to employ them as minions around her cottage. She makes occasional journeys north to the main road and small villages to offer villagers some of her fine brews. She's known for making dangerous propositions to folks in desperate situations, and many have lost children, wealth, or health to her bargains.

Combat Tactics.name: Combat Tactics
Combat Tactics.text:
Combat Tactics

Trolls are aggressive hunters. They defend their territories, and often hunt in packs. It's likely that using trolls in groups of two or three is going to pose a great threat to most parties.

Regenerative Abilities

Trolls have the ability to regenerate. Depending on the type of troll, they have different vulnerabilities that stop their regeneration. Pay attention to what damage types are being used against the trolls. Some parties may be ill-equipped to take on some types of troll if they do not have the right spells, items, or abilities.

Harsh Environments

Trolls often look for an edge in battle by fighting in an environment that favors them and not their foe. Mucky swamps filled with toxic gases, burning volcanoes with falling magma, a treacherous storm with high winds. Keep environmental effects in mind when using trolls and think of the places they inhabit, and how they might use that to their advantage.

Aggressive Persistence

Unless a troll is facing foes who are using the proper damage types against it, they have no reason to let up. A troll who can regenerate is not afraid to die, as it will keep growing back and closing its wounds. They are territorial in nature, so as long as a threat remains in their territory, they defend it and continue their assault. A troll only flees if it receives damage it cannot regenerate and it has a chance to actually die.

Trolls come in many shapes and sizes but they can all do one thing well; die.

Roleplaying Traits.name: Roleplaying Traits
Roleplaying Traits.text:
Roleplaying Traits

Trolls may not be the brightest creatures roaming the wilderness, but they are cunning hunters with rudimentary social structures.

Angry and Hungry

Trolls are straight forward with their goals and demands. They sometimes let humanoids pass if they are offered good food, or something they see as valuable for their collections. If travelers or adventurers try to bargain with them, trolls may ask to eat one of them as payment, unless offered something tastier or more valuable than a delicious adventurer.

Trolls do not enjoy being fooled, ignored, or talked down to, and oftentimes those who try to converse with trolls soon find out the hard way what happens when they don't get their way. Although their requests are often simple, if they are not met, the troll will just as quickly club the lot of them for wasting its time.

Troll Bargains

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.tables.RollTable.7O6tkIWI7EYvCXKc rollable]

Different Trolls, Different Personalities

Not all trolls follow the same ideals or personalities. A troll who is heavily contaminated might be nothing more than a mindless monster, whereas the Fungal Trolls could care more about protecting the natural environments than clubbing and eating adventurers. Pay attention to the types of trolls in your adventure and think about what they might want to help them survive or what causes they may care about.

Adventure Hooks.name: Adventure Hooks
Adventure Hooks.text:
Adventure Hooks

Caspian Troll Hunt

A group of Caspian knights are hiring a hunting crew to go deep into the heart of the Trogrowth Forest in search of a massive @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimTro07.JournalEntryPage.707humongousfung]{Humongous Fungus Troll}.

Grim Harvest

@UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimTro07.JournalEntryPage.708fungaltrollin]{Fungal Trollings} have been seen in larger numbers than usual on the outskirts of the woods. Someone needs to go in and find the hag responsible and destroy her troll farm.

Stormy Weather

A @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimTro07.JournalEntryPage.705elementaltrol#storm-troll]{Storm Troll} is causing all sorts of problems for a small village on the road.

Barren Hunters

A group of @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimTro07.JournalEntryPage.705elementaltrol#winter-troll]{Winter Troll} have made hunting in the Barren Expanse of Netherwind problematic. Someone needs to clean them out.

Elemental Trolls.name: Elemental Trolls
Elemental Trolls.text:
Elemental Trolls

T rolls Trolls have a knack for being able to survive in otherwise inhospitable environments. Many trolls, thanks to their regenerative nature, have evolved quite quickly to suit their environments. They often hunt in groups. forming tight-knit families, and although prone to infighting and rivalry, they tend to stick together for life. Even in the remote places they call home, trolls gather in small groups and survive together.

Elemental Brethren. Trolls who adapt to their hostile environments share some qualities with elementals found in the same regions. Their forms change and adapt to take on the essence of the elemental surroundings they inhabit. Elemental Trolls gain abilities to manipulate or expel elemental powers matching their environments, and even take on qualities of those elements themselves.

Storm Troll

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.171imgmentaltrol inline]

Statblock: @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.8tGpeFd9k38GkPC0]{Storm Troll}

Its gray and white skin is stretched tightly over its muscular form. Its wide-set mouth shows rows of jagged teeth below beady, stormy, blue-black eyes set in the center of its large bald head. Ripples of electrical currents pulse through its body, its veins glowing electric-blue like a network of lightning bolts across its skin.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef01.JournalEntryPage.156biomentaltrol inline]

Just when you think that a torch will be enough, it dawns on you that the troll is made of fire. Guess I'll swing at it.

Winter Troll

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.172imgmentaltrol inline]

Statblock: @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.M1kRs8Yt8eDU3ysF]{Winter Troll}

Its blue and white skin is encrusted with icicles that jut off its flesh at the elbows and knees, and form a mane of ice around its head. Even the creature's teeth look to be made of sharp icicles. Its breath, like a cold winter wind, is tinged with frost and snow.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef01.JournalEntryPage.157biomentaltrol inline]

Magma Troll

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.173imgmentaltrol inline]

Statblock: @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.1tTvTCeSeBXtXpB5]{Magma Troll}

Its flesh is like molten rocks, accented by glowing veins of fire. Its eyes are two burning pools of lava. It lets out a roar that sounds like the grinding rock of an erupting volcano. Its steps leave behind pools of hot liquid magma, which drips from its hands and mouth as well.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef01.JournalEntryPage.158biomentaltrol inline]

Just when you think that a torch will be enough, it dawns on you that the troll is made of fire. Guess I'll swing at it.

Eldritch Troll.name: Eldritch Troll
Eldritch Troll.text:
Eldritch Troll

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.174imgritchtroll inline]

Statblock: @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.jrrdMaSUBkHerOfC]{Eldritch Troll}

The mottled faded purple skin of this massive creature is accented by erupting delerium crystals along its spine, shoulders, and forearms. Its large, frog-like octarine eyes glare at you. Its skin writhes and crawls as new appendages burst forth from it, in a constant state of mutation.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef01.JournalEntryPage.159bioritchtroll inline]

Trolls eat a lot of garbage but the ones that get into delerium remind you how stupid they really are.

Troll Hag.name: Troll Hag
Troll Hag.text:
Troll Hag

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.175imgllhag00000 inline]

Statblock: @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.aW28128on8aD0umc]{Troll Hag}

Massive mounds of rippling, warty flesh, covered in molds and fungal growths protrude from this troll's hunched back. Inky black scraggly hair frames her face and beady red eyes pierce through the darkness. The Troll Hag is covered in tattered burlap and decaying foliage that hide her features. She scurries about on swollen, stumpy limbs, carrying a massive cauldron and ladle as she stirs an acrid concoction.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef01.JournalEntryPage.160biollhag00000 inline]

Humongous Fungus Troll.name: Humongous Fungus Troll
Humongous Fungus Troll.text:
Humongous Fungus Troll

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.176imgongousfung inline]

Statblock: @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.DxRms9It18hCd2Ug]{Humongous Fungus Troll}

Fungus Trolls are most prominently found in the Trogrowth Forest of Caspia but are also known to inhabit prominent wetlands and swamps within the continent. They are one of the most problematic troll groups known in the world. Their ability to produce new trolls en masse is staggering. Not only do the hags who tend to fungal gardens create hundreds of them at a time, but the Fungus Trolls can grow to such massive sizes, that their lumbering presence shakes the very trees of the swamps they inhabit. These massive fungal monstrosities rain down spores that grow into Fungal Trollings. These networks of Fungus Trolls travel together. When you see one Humongous Fungus Troll barreling towards you, be warned that there are likely more following.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef01.JournalEntryPage.161bioongousfung inline]

Spores and sponges standing tall like a tree. One of the many reasons I have a mixed relationship with vegetables.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.177imgongousfung inline]

Fungal Trolling.name: Fungal Trolling
Fungal Trolling.text:
Fungal Trolling

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.178imggaltrollin inline]

Statblock: @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.kMue3OQFZtzXtzni]{Fungal Trolling}

Resembling a large purple and white mushroom, Fungal Trollings throb and ooze with overcharged energy. They appear ready to burst as their grim little expressions whine and wail.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef01.JournalEntryPage.162biogaltrollin inline]

I know how big they can get. So cut em down when they're small. Just hold your breath.

Oak Troll.name: Oak Troll
Oak Troll.text:
Oak Troll

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef03.JournalEntryPage.179imgtroll00000 inline]

Statblock: @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.monsters.Actor.Ao56dfPQdmJJVDzy]{Oak Troll}

What at first appears to be a large pile of autumn leaves rises up and reveals a grotesque carved wooden face and gnarled oaken claws and feet. Its body is cloaked in a thick array of leaves all in hues of oranges, yellows, and reds. As it lurches forward it sounds like the autumn wind blowing through a lush forest, the sounds of its grunts and moans like creaking boughs of ancient trees, and its thumping footsteps like wooden branches hitting the forest floor.

@Embed[Compendium.drakkenheim-monsters.guide.JournalEntry.drakkenheimRef01.JournalEntryPage.163biotroll00000 inline]
